Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Turkey&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Turkey+November+2018+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2018-11-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Turkey&amp;rft.issn=09668632&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
In June Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected as president for a second term in snap presidential and parliamentary elections, in which his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a coalition majority in parliament with the right-wing Nationalist Action Party (MHP).
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Mr Erdogan and the AKP to remain in power throughout the forecast period (2019-23), and possibly beyond.
Following the June elections, an executive presidency has replaced the former parliamentary system of government. The new system provides few checks on the president's powers, raising the risk of discretionary policymaking.
Since the failed coup in July 2016, there has been a marked deterioration in Turkey's relations with its Western allies. We expect a rupture to be avoided, but tensions will remain high and relations could sour quickly.
Turkey's relationship with the US will remain tense. Points of contention include Turkey's pivot towards Iran and Russia (from the US perspective), and the perceived lack of US support after the failed coup (from Turkey's perspective).
Turkey's relationship with the EU will remain transactional. Turkey will not make progress with accession talks and is unlikely to manage to renegotiate the terms of its customs union with the EU.
The government's focus on domestic power struggles, economic growth and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate.
We forecast a slowdown in real GDP growth, from 7.3% in 2017 to about 3.5% per year in 2018-23, reflecting the impact of the August 2018 currency crisis, higher interest rates, global trade tensions and more moderate export growth.
The lira will depreciate in nominal terms against the US dollar during the forecast period, to about TL6.3:US$1 at end-2023, as a result of negative foreign investor sentiment, high inflation and the large current-account deficit.
As a result of the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar (which will boost competitiveness), we forecast that the current-account deficit will shrink in 2019-23, to an annual average of 3.6% of GDP. Turkey will struggle to meet its external financing needs throughout the forecast period.

Turkey's score deteriorates only slightly in 2019-23, but in the global rankings the country falls by ten places, to 59th. The failed coup in 2016 and the government's response have increased the level of uncertainty about the direction of economic policy. Shortcomings include a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Political instability and adverse market conditions will delay further privatisation deals.
2021-23: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in several sectors.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but macroeconomic instability and concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2021-23: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Capital controls are not considered, despite the scale of the currency collapse. Political tensions resulting in tit-for-tat tariffs and US sanctions will disrupt Turkish-US trade and relations.
2021-23: Negotiations with the EU to update the customs union are likely to be protracted, given poor Turkish-EU relations.
Taxes
2019-20: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Tax rises introduced in 2018 to curb the widening of the budget deficit reduce company profits.
2021-23: Income tax base becomes broader as exemptions and exceptions are reduced.
Financing
2019-20: Asset quality likely to deteriorate on the back of financial market turmoil in 2018. Central Bank of Turkey to lower rates gradually as inflation moderates in 2019. Risk of the US imposing fines or sanctions on some Turkish banks.
2021-23: Lending growth to pick up again as banking system regains strength. Continued reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2019-20: Relatively high labour costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment.
2021-23: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2019-20: First phase of third airport in Istanbul becomes operational. Slower progress made on other projects.
2021-23: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks might persist.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Spending on research and development remains moderate, at about 1% of GDP, holding back efforts to move the economy up the value-added ladder.
2021-23: Turkey's young population spurs further rapid digital transformation of the banking sector.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then, Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West. The country became a member of the Council of Europe (in 1949) and NATO (in 1952), and signed an association agreement with the then European Community (in 1963). A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but a coup attempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey currently has a presidential system of government, with parliament elected for a five-year term. To win seats, parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Since the failed coup, power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president and AKP leader, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who was re-elected as president for a second term in June 2018. Following his re-election, a presidential system of government was introduced and the post of prime minister was abolished.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability and stabilising the lira following the August 2018 currency crisis are Turkey's biggest policy challenges. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and tightening global liquidity conditions require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy tight to attract adequate capital inflows and slow down the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar. The Kurdish issue, which has blocked economic development in the south east, is one of Turkey's most pressing policy challenges, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015, and there has been a resurgence in violence. Politicisation of the judiciary since the coup attempt has undermined its independence. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The corporation tax rate has been raised in 2018, from 20% to 22%. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Reducing tax evasion was one of the elements of previous IMF programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2017 goods exports came to US$166bn and imports to US$225bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$59bn and a current-account deficit of US$47.5bn (or 5.6% of GDP). The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
In June Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected for a second term in the first round of a snap presidential election. On the same day his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a parliamentary coalition majority with its right-wing ally, the Nationalist Action Party (MHP). The election process appeared mostly free, but largely unfair. Opposition candidates received little or no media coverage; the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP) candidate, Selahattin Demirtas, had to campaign from prison; and the government restrained freedom of speech and freedom of association. Mr Erdogan secured a majority of the vote after a high turnout. Results published by opposition observers were very similar to those announced by the government.
Mr Erdogan's re-election concludes Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. This move was initiated with a constitutional referendum in April 2017, which the government narrowly won. The new system grants the president wide-ranging executive powers-including the selection of most of the officials in the judiciary-and will greatly weaken parliament. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the AKP and Mr Erdogan, who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in July 2016, to remain in power until 2023-and possibly beyond this.
Mr Erdogan will continue to restrict political dissent and stifle the opposition. Despite allowing the state of emergency to expire on July 18th, parliament passed a security law on July 25th that imposes stringent barriers on freedoms. These are similar to those of the state of emergency, which was introduced after the attempted coup, in a bid to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies. These include the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric who is accused by the Turkish government of masterminding the coup plot.
Security risk remains high, as Turkey appears vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and Islamic State (IS). Neither the government nor the PKK is interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, which increased the risk that violence will return to 1990s levels. Turkey's military operations in Syria seek to block the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds affiliated with the PKK, but risk fuelling the conflict with the PKK in south-east Turkey. The formation of a governing coalition between the AKP and the MHP will hinder attempts to resolve the Kurdish issue, as the MHP is likely to push for hawkish policies aimed at constraining and delegitimising the HDP. The MHP will advocate the repatriation of Syrian refugees and adopt a tough stance on all issues related to national security, in line with Mr Erdogan's ultra-nationalist and conservative views.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
On June 24th parliamentary and presidential elections were held, earlier than the originally scheduled date of late 2019. Mr Erdogan was re-elected as president in the first round, securing 52.6% of the vote after a turnout of 86.2%. In the parliamentary election the AKP lost its absolute majority (although it secured a coalition majority alongside its partner, the MHP), as the HDP managed to poll more than the 10% threshold needed to enter parliament. The AKP received 42.6% of the vote, the MHP 11.1%, the Republican People's Party (CHP) 22.6%, the HDP 11.7% and the Good Party (IP) 10%.
Local elections are planned in March 2019. The shift of focus to the local polls in the aftermath of the June elections is a sign that Turkey will remain in the mood for an election until next year. The AKP and the MHP look unlikely to co-operate in the local elections after disagreements regarding the selection process for mayoral candidates in large cities.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Domestic political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign policy sphere. Although not our core forecast, there is a risk of a rupture in the country's ties with its traditional Western allies. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration in relations, including a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the failed coup; US military backing for PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurdish groups; Turkey's forging of closer relations with China, Russia and Iran; and US sanctions on Turkish government officials owing to Turkey's detention of a US pastor on terrorist charges (sanctions have been lifted in November after the pastor was released in October). The government's authoritarian tendencies and confrontational approach (partly motivated by Mr Erdogan's need to appeal to nationalists) have also damaged relations with Turkey's Western allies.
Turkey's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic and transactional, rather than strategic. However, we expect Turkey and its Western allies to avoid a breakdown in relations. Turkey and the EU have a common interest in handling refugee inflows from Syria and Iraq; the fact that Mr Erdogan visited Germany in late September lends credence to this view. However, EU-Turkey relations would deteriorate quickly if the EU suspends Turkey's moribund accession negotiations, or if Turkey closes the Incirlik air base to US forces or withdraws from NATO (not our core forecast).
Turkey's involvement in the conflict in Syria will continue to influence the direction of its foreign policy. Relations between Turkey and Russia have improved in the past two years, but the level of trust is still low. In September Turkey and Russia announced an agreement to create-and jointly patrol-a demilitarised zone in Idlib, the last rebel-held governorate in northern Syria. However, this does not alter our view that they are co-operating in Syria while pursuing contrasting goals (Russia backs the government led by Bashar al-Assad, the Syrian president, and Turkey provides support to rebels). As a result, we expect relations to continue to be transactional. The risk of new tensions will remain high.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
The government's past focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business, and investment, climate. Nonetheless, Turkey's economy has shown resilience during previous bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing largely to its solid public finances, its well-capitalised, effectively regulated banking sector, and its dynamic and diversified private business sector.
In the aftermath of the failed coup in July 2016 a highly accommodative policy stance has exacerbated fiscal as well as external imbalances. This, together with heightened political uncertainty, the tightening of global liquidity conditions and tensions with the US, led to a currency crisis in August 2018. The heavily pro-growth approach to economic policymaking that Mr Erdogan has espoused enthusiastically over the past decade will remain a predominant feature over our forecast period (2019-23), at the expense of inflation control and fiscal discipline. This approach will continue to have an important effect on, for example, monetary policy, macroprudential regulation, public-private capital investments and social spending. Shortcomings such as cronyism and corruption, skills mismatches (a key factor behind the high unemployment rate) and tax evasion are unlikely to be addressed in 2019-23, as propping up economic growth-partly to avoid social unrest-will remain the priority.
In the case of a severe economic or banking crisis (not our core forecast), Turkey's options will remain limited, as Gulf Co-operation Council (GCC) countries appear unwilling to offer financial support, partly because Turkey is forging closer ties with Iran, a country with which Saudi Arabia is at odds. Meanwhile, an IMF programme would include what the government would regard as an unacceptable conditionality and would run counter to Mr Erdogan's nationalist, anti-Western rhetoric. Finally, there is little prospect of EU financial assistance, not least because there would be no consensus on this issue among EU member states. Only China, therefore, appears able at present to offer a financial lifeline to Turkey. Such assistance could come as part of China's Belt and Road Initiative, which seeks to boost transport infrastructure between Asia and Europe in order to foster trade and connectivity in the coming decades.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
The public finances have traditionally been one of the Turkish economy's most reassuring aspects. Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios reflect the positive impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past. Despite a series of tax rises this year and official promises of budgetary tightening, higher government spending on defence, security, infrastructure, public employment and social benefits will cause the deficit to widen in 2018, to 1.9% of GDP, from 1.5% in 2017. We subsequently expect a cautious approach to on-balance-sheet fiscal policy, which, alongside a recovering economy, will lead the deficit gradually to contract in the second half of our forecast period, to 1.5% of GDP in 2023.
We expect the central government debt/GDP ratio to have remained broadly stable, at 28% of GDP at end-2018 (from 28.3% at end-2017), despite economic turmoil following the August currency crisis and various government handouts to parts of the population ahead of the June election. The ratio will decline slightly, to 25.3% by the end of 2023 as macroeconomic conditions normalise and the budget deficit shrinks.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
On September 13th the Central Bank of Turkey's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) raised its main policy rate, the one-week repo (repurchase agreement) lending rate, to 24%, from 17.75% previously. The MPC's decision represents a response to the lira's sharp depreciation against the US dollar in August, as well as to the record rise in annual consumer price inflation. The average cost of central bank funding is likely to be above the main policy rate, however. The bank retains the option of providing some of its funding for the banking system at its overnight lending rates, which are 1.5-3% higher than the one-week repo rate.
We expect the central bank to keep monetary policy tight in the remainder of 2018. In 2019-20 the central bank will gradually lower its policy rate in response to declining inflationary pressures and a normalisation of financial market conditions. In 2021-23 we believe that it will miss its inflation target of 5%. This reflects the government's continued pro-growth stance; it will put pressure on the bank to keep nominal rates below what would credibly be required to lower inflation to the 5% target.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Real GDP growth accelerated sharply in 2017, to 7.3% (from 3.3% in 2016), supported by government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit, improved export competitiveness and a pick-up in global demand. However, the surge in economic growth has exacerbated internal and external imbalances. These imbalances-coupled with heightened policy unpredictability, foreign investors' concerns regarding the independence of the central bank, reliance on short-term capital inflows, a rising interest-rate environment in advanced economies, and a diplomatic spat with the US-have contributed to the lira losing about 40% of its value against the US dollar in January-August, before recovering in September-November. The depreciation of the lira, which gathered pace in August, has caused consumer price inflation to accelerate from already high rates, and has increased input costs for corporations and raised the debt-servicing costs of foreign-currency-denominated liabilities. Higher domestic interest rates and rising risk premiums further dent the economic outlook.
High-frequency indicators for September (latest available data) suggest that the economy is decelerating sharply in the wake of the currency crisis. After mild growth in the second quarter (5.7% year on year, down from 7.3% in full-year 2017), we expect the economy to contract on a quarterly basis in the third and fourth quarters of 2018, and in January-March 2019. There are substantial downside risks to this forecast; this growth profile does not reflect the possible impact of a severe banking crisis (not our core scenario), although we expect non-performing loans to rise and credit availability to be impaired in the coming quarters.
We believe that full-year growth will decelerate to 3.1% in 2018 and that GDP will grow only slightly in 2019, by 1%, mainly owing to base effects. In 2020 we expect full-year growth to rebound to 4.9% as the economy recovers and spare capacity is depleted. In 2021-23 economic growth will average 4%, broadly in line with the economy's forecast potential growth rate.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Even before the lira's collapse against the US dollar in August, inflation was already stubbornly high and well above the central bank's official 5% medium-term target; it averaged 11.1% in 2017. This year, however, the currency's depreciation and rising global commodity prices have driven inflation higher, to 25.2% year on year in October. This will push inflation to an average of 16.8% this year (from 11.1% in 2017).
In 2019 inflation will remain elevated in the first half of the year and then moderate gradually on the back of a broadly stable lira (against the US dollar), an only limited increase in global oil prices and the emergence of spare capacity in the economy. On average, we forecast inflation of 16.6% in 2019, only marginally below the 2018 rate.
The moderating trend in inflation will continue in 2020, with an average inflation rate of 9.1%, as global oil prices decline, owing to a slowdown in the US economy, and the exchange rate depreciates only slightly (in nominal terms) against the US dollar. In the final years of our forecast period we expect inflation to stabilise at an average of 7.2%-still above the central bank's medium-term target of 5%. Economic growth in these years will be close to the economy's potential growth rate (limiting upward inflationary pressures). However, an expected pick-up in global oil prices and a depreciation of the lira will maintain upward pressure on prices in 2021-23.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
In 2017 the lira depreciated by an average of almost 18% against the US dollar. In 2018 we estimate a further average depreciation, of about 25% (in nominal terms) in the full year. The lira depreciated significantly in January-August, with the exchange rate briefly reaching TL7.2:US$1 on August 13th. After a substantial recovery from September to mid-November, we expect the lira to remain broadly stable against the US dollar in the remainder of the year. This expectation is underpinned by our view that the decrease in tensions between the US and Turkey, the sharp reduction in the current-account deficit owing to the depreciation of the lira and the tight monetary policy stance will contribute to a broad stabilisation of the exchange rate in the near term.
In 2019 we forecast that the lira will continue to depreciate on average against the US dollar, albeit at a much more moderate pace than in 2018. A normalising economic and financial domestic situation will support the exchange rate. However, there will be an increase in global risk aversion as the effects of the US-China bilateral trade war are fully felt, the cooling of the global economy will cause expectations of a recession in some advanced economies to build and central banks in advanced economies will tighten their monetary policy stances. As a result, we expect an average exchange rate of TL5.7:US$1 in 2019. Risks around our exchange-rate forecast for 2019 are tilted to the upside.
In 2020 we expect the exchange rate to remain broadly stable as the economy starts to grow more markedly after an expected slump in 2018-19. Thereafter in 2021-23 we expect a gradual depreciation of the lira against the US dollar in nominal terms, to TL6.3:US$1 by the end of 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The current-account deficit as a share of GDP will narrow in 2018, to 4.6%, from 5.6% in 2017, as the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar will depress imports and heighten competitiveness. In 2019-23 we expect a smaller average annual current-account deficit, of 3.6%. Significant gains in competitiveness from past lira depreciation, which moderated inflation, and the emergence of spare capacity will result in a boost to exports and imports compression over the medium term.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
Global data
OECD growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP growth and components: Turkstat
Population: UN Population database and Economist Intelligence Unit interpolation
Consumer prices: IMF, IFS; Turkstat
Industrial production: derived from OECD, Main Economic Indicators
Exchange rates and interest rates: IMF, IFS
External trade and balance of payments: IMF, IFS; Central Bank of Turkey; Turkstat
Central government financial balance: IMF, IFS; Turkish Treasury
Foreign direct investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report; Central Bank of Turkey
Abbreviations
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
Turkstat: Turkish Statistical Institute
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development

Country Forecast Venezuela November 2018 Updater

Abstract: In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly. [...]we expect extremely limited real investment inflows, the vast majority going into the oil sector, which will restrict economic recovery and fuel continued unrest. Owing to the need to maintain political stability, we do not expect the closure of the various handout programmes in operation, nor the complete removal of utility subsidies or the reformation of inefficient state-owned firms. [...]we expect public expenditure to be hard to reduce; we expect the deficit to be substantial throughout the 2019-23 period. The exact nature and implementation of such moves are hard to foresee, but our baseline forecast includes the continuation of some currency controls for the duration of the forecast period. Since the start of the year the government has devalued the official exchange rate by over 99% but exchange controls remain.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Economic collapse and the erosion of the patronage scheme supporting the president, Nicolás Maduro, have put the ruling regime's internal cohesion in jeopardy. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a traumatic rift that will end in regime pragmatists allowing opposition participation in a "mixed admin-istration" as a way to remain in power from 2019 onwards. There is a risk that the existing regime will retain cohesion and cling to power beyond 2019 if it finds financing to meet its debt obligations and boost dwindling oil production.
We estimate that inflation exceeded 2,500% at the end of 2017 and will reach 715,130% by end-2018. GDP will continue to contract in 2018-20. High inflation has led to a collapse in private consumption, and difficult operating conditions have hurt investment. Following a change in policy under a new government, we expect economic growth to resume in 2021.
The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. From 2019 a new government will stabilise the economy, but the wholesale rethink of the institutional framework needed to restore investment and confidence is unlikely.
Worsening shortages of consumer goods and hyperinflation will hit private consumption, and an increasingly difficult operating environment will accentuate a fall in fixed investment. The recession that began in 2014 will continue to deepen despite a partial recovery in oil prices as oil output slumps, and the economy will not return to growth until 2021-assuming that a new government takes power and implements reforms. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, reinforcing our forecasts of only a weak recovery.
US dollar measurements of Venezuela's market size provide an overly positive picture of the economy, given the marked overvaluation of the fixed exchange rate. In reality, recession and extremely high inflation (driven by shortages of foreign exchange and basic goods) will continue to restrict purchasing power. After 2020, under a new government, we expect purchasing power and the business environment to improve.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Venezuela is in 82nd position globally in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings for 2019-23, making the country the least attractive invest-ment location in our ranking. This reflects the highly heterodox macroeconomic policies of an authoritarian government, a lack of legal security and weak institutions.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Start of roll-back of interventionist measures like price controls, but political-instability concerns slow liberalisation. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition.
2021-23: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Regulation by new government protecting property rights introduced in an attempt at attracting investment.
2021-23: Despite efforts, actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2019-20: Currency controls are made less opaque but restrictions on the private sector's access to foreign currency remain in place.
2021-23: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2019-20: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2020-22: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2019-20: Inflation remains high and concerns about economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2021-23: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2019-20: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. The current freeze on redundancies is fazed-out
2021-23: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Underinvestment in the water and electricity grid ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2021-23: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued water and electricity rationing.
Technological readiness
2019-20: E-government services remain almost non-existent and deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment.
2021-23: Limited regulator capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has plummeted as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices has plunged the country into a massive economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded republican institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is how to stabilise an economy mired in a years-long economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. At the same time, mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign-exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Using IMF data, The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$21.1bn in 2017 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages. We estimate the current-account surplus at 2% of GDP that year.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
Despite an extremely severe economic crisis, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) and the president, Nicolás Maduro, retain their hold on power. Regardless, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects worsening economic conditions to result in a chaotic political transition, to a government with nominal opposition participation-a "mixed administration"-at some point in the forecast period. Currently, we assume this will happen during 2019. But the process will be highly uncertain and may feature several false starts. We expect the forecast period to be characterised by political instability.
The opposition, owing to internal infighting and years of government harassment, is in disarray and incapable of channelling the populace's dissatisfaction. This notwithstanding, the PSUV is dependent on the military for support. The country is run by civic-military alliance and a network of businessmen with military or political connections. This network is sustained by opportunities for corruption made possible by foreign-exchange controls, subsidised imports, clientelism, control of wasteful state-owned companies and the government's tacit approval of transnational organised crime (as evidenced by numerous press reports, and sanctions and indictments related to drug-trafficking on regime leaders abroad). Regime factions are primarily explained by personal and patronage ties, resulting in different civic-military factions coexisting within the regime. Outside of potential outright criminal income, the resources maintaining this patronage system comes from the export revenue generated by PDVSA, the state-owned oil company.
Mismanagement and underinvestment at PDVSA has led to declining output and exports, destabilising the regime. Purges in the military and re-organisations in civilian government are common as factions jostle for power. In late October Mr Maduro appointed General Manuel Figuera to head SEBIN, the national intelligence agency. He replaced General Gustavo González López, who was a close ally of Diosdado Cabello, head of the Constituent Assembly (ANC, the country's de facto legislature) and Mr Maduro's main internal rival. With resources dwindling, control of the coercive apparatus is key to maintaining regime cohesion. Mr Maduro has thus seemingly increased his capacity to wrangle the regime's competing factions.
However, our baseline view is that the government's proven inability to increase output in PDVSA or secure sufficient financing makes the status-quo unsustainable. This process may be hastened if exports are disrupted by external forces, such as US government sanctions on the oil trade (the US is PDVSA's largest cash-paying market and a key source of production inputs) or asset seizures stemming from unpaid debts. With oil output nearing 1m barrels/day (b/d), down from 2.5m b/d when Mr Maduro took office, we currently expect an internal fracture in 2019 but, regardless of the timing, what happens next is hard to predict.
Given that the regime's raison d'etre is the enrichment of its members, stabilisation of PDVSA and the economy would take priority under a new government. We expect regime pragmatists to seek assistance from Western governments and multilateral organisations. To gain international legitimacy and secure the financing, these pragmatists would allow nominal opposition participation in a "mixed administration". Given past behaviour, there should be plenty of opposition figures willing to participate. Even with regime pragmatists, this administration would face pockets of resistance in places like the judiciary, the ANC and the radicalised supporters of the PSUV known as colectivos. As such, political stability through the forecast period will be limited.
Three key assumptions underpin our baseline view. A crucial assumption is that, given economic conditions, Mr Maduro cannot sustain regime cohesion indefinitely. The change at SEBIN introduces risks to this assumption. A second assumption is that Russia and China-erstwhile financiers-will not provide substantial funding to the current administration (or to a PSUV-only successor administration). We base this view on the regime's inability to repay already expired loans and limited aid since 2015. Venezuela's oil wealth, however, remains a draw-especially if sold off at low prices by a bankrupt regime. A significant third assumption is that the need to restore macroeconomic stability and steady resource flows through the patronage system has become so urgent as to allow pragmatists to accept Western-demanded democratic and macroeconomic reforms. The former would likely involve judicial retribution on a number of current regime leaders, while the latter would eliminate the economy's distortions, closing avenues for corruption and enrichment.
As such, there are strong risks to our baseline view and there is a strong possibility of alternate scenarios. These range from: a PSUV-only administration securing enough Chinese financing; a permanently impoverished nation under an outright military government (or one with civilian figureheads); or-as an outside possibility-prolonged chaos if regime cohesion fails but no faction gains clear control of the state apparatus across the country.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
We do not expect free and fair elections in the short term. Municipal elections are scheduled for December 9th. Most of the opposition has been proscribed and only some parties are participating (which has led to further infighting). In this context, a PSUV sweep is all but guaranteed. Based on our political assumptions, an electoral timetable may be announced, as international financing will almost certainly come with demands for democratic reforms.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Most regional governments have denounced the Venezuelan government, as has the EU. The US has put individual sanctions on most regime leaders, including potential successors to Mr Maduro. This limits the field of negotiating partners in the event of an internal fracture of the regime, but sanctions are reversible. US country-level sanctions block Venezuela from refinancing its debts. Military intervention and sanctions banning the oil trade not part of our baseline assumption, but the hawkish US foreign policy team increases risks.
Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the financing- tens of billions of dollars a year-to stabilise the economy and PDVSA. The regime openly courts China, but seemingly with apparent little success. A change in the current Chinese stance represents a major risk to our forecast.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Monetisation of large public deficits, coupled with mismanagement of the state-dominated oil industry, has led to hyperinflation and shortages of foreign currency, basic goods and industrial inputs. The government remains tech-nically unable and politically unwilling to undertake the deep and wide-ranging policy and institutional changes needed. Its latest economic plan, launched in late August, was self-defeating and the government has not complied with a cornerstone promise: to abolish the monetisation of public deficits. As such, monetary imbalances will persist and foreign exchange will continue to be rationed. Economic policy will remain interventionist in the short term, deepening the economic crisis that underpins our baseline forecast of political change. Furthermore, outside of promising a hard-to-implement reduction in fuel subsidies, the plan had little focus on PDVSA's falling output; production at PDVSA remains crucial factor in supporting the economy amid a collapse in the non-oil sector.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect that more orthodox economic policies will be implemented under a new government. However, the pace and depth of the adjustment will be constrained by uncertainty over the stability of any new regime, and whether this takes precedence over the likely demands for reform from multilateral and bilateral lenders. Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and multilaterals (totalling US$19bn in 2019-22) and the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. This in itself will be a huge task for any administration. At the same time, PDVSA will need wholesale reform to open itself to the foreign finance needed to increase output, a process that will require considerable political capital.
Pockets of resistance are likely to exist. Internal stability within the PSUV is a major risk to our forecast, as the success of a mixed administration would depend on PSUV pragmatists fending off more radical party members. These members would oppose international assistance, foreign investment and policy reforms on both ideological and personal grounds (as many regime insiders profit from the state's indirect and direct control of the economy).
Outside of these areas, we do not expect much success in rolling back the PSUV's strong interventionist bent in the economy. As a result, we expect extremely limited real investment inflows, the vast majority going into the oil sector, which will restrict economic recovery and fuel continued unrest.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
Authorities have not published complete official data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We estimate that the fiscal deficit is well into double figures as a percentage of GDP. The government relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency. High inflation and the overvalued official exchange rate make debt/GDP ratios misleading indicators of fiscal stability. Considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) understates the true size of total public liabilities.
Most sovereign and state-owned bonds (including PDVSA's) are in arrears. Bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy changes or a change in leadership. The exceptions to arrears are debts that threaten PDVSA's foreign assets, which facilitate the company's capacity to export oil and import production inputs. PDVSA is complying with a settlement to ConocoPhillips (US), which has consequently halted its attempts at seizing PDVSA's assets in the Caribbean. PDVSA is to pay US$1.5bn over the next 54 months. Similarly, in late October PDVSA made a US$949m payment on a bond that carries 50.1% of Citgo, its US subsidiary, as collateral. Citgo, however, is under threat from Crystallex (Canada), which is already attempting to seize it in lieu of payment of a legal award. (Venezuela has so far stalled via appeals.)
Citgo itself is highly indebted and PDVSA pledged 49.9% as collateral to Rosneft (Russia) as collateral for a US$1.5bn loan in 2016. Citgo's fate could be resolved by a prolonged judicial process. We believe that, if forced to choose, the government would prioritise its Caribbean assets over Citgo, as the former are key for PDVSA's capacity to export, while import-export trade with Citgo could be re-routed to other US companies. However, it is unclear when the government may have to choose. Venezuela has demonstrated its preference for retaining offshore assets, but PDVSA's strained financial situation means that the risk of default and seizure will remain high in the short term. Stalling tactics (including partial compliance with payments) will continue.
Under our baseline forecast, we expect a restructuring with external creditors in 2020. Owing to the need to maintain political stability, we do not expect the closure of the various handout programmes in operation, nor the complete removal of utility subsidies or the reformation of inefficient state-owned firms. Therefore, we expect public expenditure to be hard to reduce; we expect the deficit to be substantial throughout the 2019-23 period.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank) to print money. Money supply (M2) continues to grow rapidly, expanding by 43% month on month at end-October. We expect a new administration to place a much greater emphasis on tackling hyper-inflation, and expect a substantial monetary adjustment in the context of a macroeconomic stabilisation plan. The introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) in such a context is highly likely.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 15% in 2018, we expect further contractions in 2019-20. A forecast recovery in 2021-23 rests on the assumption of a political transition that, supported by IMF assistance, produces a credible macroeconomic programme with improved management of oil wealth. However, reform will be limited in scope by a weak government, and we expect only a partial rebound in real GDP, following a decline of around 50% in 2013-20.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2018, reflecting the effect on real wages of hyperinflation, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will also contract, reflecting difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange. Our forecast for a recovery in investment later in the forecast period assumes a political transition and a pick-up in oil investment.
We expect oil output to bottom out at 1m b/d in mid-2019, kept from going lower owing to PDVSA's joint-venture partners. Under our baseline forecast of openness to foreign investment under a new government from 2019, production will start to recover in the second half of 2020, but will remain well below 2m b/d, the average output in 2017, even at the end of our forecast period.
Export volumes will only start to recover in 2020, as an increase in domestic demand, which has been artificially constrained, will initially absorb the increase in oil output. For the same reason, import demand will rise sharply in 2019.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Decimated domestic supply, severe limits on imports and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official data have not been published since 2015, but the opposition-led National Assembly estimated that monthly inflation was 233% (488,865% year on year) in September. In the context of a macroeconomic stabilisation plan in 2019, we expect much tighter monetary policy and lower inflation.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
Under our current baseline forecast, the introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) amid deep imbalances and as a means to try to tackle hyperinflation is possible in 2019. The exact nature and implementation of such moves are hard to foresee, but our baseline forecast includes the continuation of some currency controls for the duration of the forecast period.
Since the start of the year the government has devalued the official exchange rate by over 99% but exchange controls remain. The official rate is determined by an auction process, but the government-which monopolises the country's exports-does not supply the system with foreign-exchange, making the system unsustainable and access to foreign exchange practically impossible. In early November the black-market exchange rate was around BsS240:US$1; the official rate stood at BsS65:US$1.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
After an estimated current-account surplus of US$14.2bn in 2018, we expect the current account to remain in surplus for most of the forecast period. These figures are buoyed by non-payment of interest on bonded debt ("savings" in excess of US$5bn in 2018 alone). Our export data, which are based on IMF data, may overstate receipts, as some exports are actually payments in-kind for loans, the repayment of which may not be included in their totality under forecast interest repayments (we have excluded repayments to Chinese lenders to maintain consistency with the World Bank's data on which our debt forecasts are based).
By 2020, with a new government in power, we expect that-following debt renegotiation-external financing will be restored. Although we expect exports to grow as oil production increases, we also expect a surge in imports, as Venezuela's own productive base has been decimated and imports have been compressed to artificially low levels. In addition, the government will be complying with its debt obligations, meaning that the restructured debt will actually result in increased outflows in interest payments. These factors will erode the current-account surplus from 4.8% of GDP in 2020 to a deficit of 1.6% by 2023.
We currently expect that the new administration will secure sufficient finance to stabilise the balance-of-payments dynamics. However, there are considerable risks to this rosy outlook. In addition to assuming a pragmatic mixed administration capable of retaining power, it hinges on substantial finance from the IMF, the quick implementation of a successful macroeconomic stabilisation package, the fast resolution of a debt renegotiation process in 2019-20, substantial inflows of financial and real investment into the economy in 2020-23, and a fast recovery in oil output after years of underinvestment and mismanagement.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
BCV: Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The government-comprising Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza, the party of the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras) and the small, right-wing Independent Greeks (AE)-has a two-seat majority in the 300-seat parliament. Mr Tsipras will aim to complete his parliamentary term, ending in October 2019.
The government is vulnerable to further defections, and there is a significant risk of an early election. The centre-right New Democracy (ND) is likely to win the most seats in such an election and to form a government, but it would probably have to secure the support of at least one other party to muster a parliamentary majority.
Greece will remain subject to strict policy conditionality over the medium term and until its debt to its international creditors is substantially reduced. Protests over labour market reforms, pension cuts, privatisation, and tax and social security increases are likely to continue as the government strives to meet ambitious annual primary surplus budget targets of 3.5% of GDP until 2022 and 2.2% from 2023, as agreed with Greece's creditors.
Mr Tsipras's promises to lower tax, reverse spending cuts and abandon the pension reform agreed before Greece exited the bail-out programme in August could cause tensions with the country's international creditors and investors.
Greece faces its biggest macroeconomic challenge, now that it has exited the bail-out programme and no longer has access to official borrowing at preferential interest rates. However, Greece does not face short-term financing difficulties, as it will have sufficient funds to cover its debt repayments for almost two years after exiting the bail-out programme. A Greek exit from the euro zone represents a risk over the long term.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that real GDP growth will pick up from 1.3% in 2017 to a moderate 2% per year on average in 2018-23. Public debt is forecast to continue to exceed 170% of GDP in 2023. Meeting large primary surplus targets and restoring competitiveness will prove difficult.
We estimate that annual average inflation will ease, from 1.1% in 2017 to 0.8% in 2018, before rising to an annual average of 1.4% in the forecast period (2019-23), reflecting higher oil prices and a pick-up in domestic demand. These factors will result in widening, but still moderate, current-account deficits in 2018-23.

Greece's score recovers modestly in our forecast period, from a low base. The main areas of improvement are expected in the macroeconomic environment and as a result of efforts to improve policy towards foreign investment, private enterprise and competition, and the labour market.
Country forecast overview: Greece's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The country's privatisation agency, under new management, gains momentum. Deals start to make progress.
2021-23: Efforts to valorise public property through concession management and long-leasehold development agreements.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: The Investment Incentives Law of 2016 offers more tax relief and fewer subsidies, and focuses predominantly on small firms. Plans to cut down on bureaucracy make little progress.
2021-23: "Fast-track" legislation could become more important if the economy normalises. It will cover "strategic" investments in energy, tourism, transport, communications and health.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Capital controls introduced in June 2015 are eased gradually. Capital buffer of about EUR24bn sufficient to cover almost two years of the government's financing needs
2021-23: There is a significant risk of Greece leaving the euro zone in the long term if growth continues to disappoint. Grexit would probably result in the reintroduction of exchange controls and, possibly, restrictions on trade.
Taxes
2019-20: Extensive efforts to widen the tax base. Government pledges to pursue aggressive tax collection, but implementation is difficult. Indirect taxes increase. Mandatory introduction of electronic point of sale terminals helps.
2021-23: Limited progress in cutting corporate income tax or value-added tax (VAT). Measures to tackle tax evasion stepped up. Independence of tax authority remains in doubt.
Financing
2019-20: Liquidity tight. Uncertainty constrains lending capacity. Steps to reduce non-performing loans (NPLs) painfully slow, but foreign interest picks up. A moratorium on foreclosures is lifted for the majority of debtors.
2021-23: Lending hampered by need to increase provisions for still high NPLs. More Greek bank foreign subsidiaries are sold off.
The labour market
2019-20: Labour market reforms now mostly passed, but implementation is problematic. Unemployment remains high.
2021-23: EU funded job-creation schemes, particularly for youth, raise employment, but create few productive jobs.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Energy infrastructure comes to the fore as Trans-Adriatic Pipeline (TAP) nears completion. Privatisations pick up pace.
2021-23: Despite technical assistance from the EU, problems with absorption of funds persist.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Greece rolls out high-speed internet, at a slow pace. The private sector adopts electronic payments by law.
2021-23: Significant financial and technical assistance from the EU, but Greece remains a laggard.

Background: After 400 years of Ottoman rule Greece emerged as a sovereign state in 1830. A devastating civil war followed the retreat of German occupying forces in 1944. A military junta ruled the country from 1967 to 1974, but since then a democracy has been in place. In 1981 Greece joined the European Economic Community, now the EU. It became a member of the economic and monetary union (EMU) in 2001, but its public finances became unsustainable, resulting in a sovereign debt crisis in 2009-10. Greece's public debt has put its continued membership of EMU in question.
Political structure: Greece is a parliamentary republic, with deputies elected for four-year terms. The prime minister and the government hold executive powers. The president is elected by the 300-member parliament for a five-year term. The government requires the support of parliament to hold office. Since the 2010 crisis the traditional party system has broken down. Voters have blamed the parties that ruled Greece after the return of democracy in the mid-1970s-New Democracy (ND) and the Panhellenic Socialist Movement (Pasok)-for causing the crisis, which led to the imposition of painful austerity by the country's external creditors. The result has been political fragmentation and the rise of populist parties such as the left-wing Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), which came to power in 2015, and far-right parties such as the neo-fascist Golden Dawn (XA).
Policy issues: The ND-Pasok government of 2012-14, like its two predecessors, imposed draconian austerity packages. It also enacted fiscal and some structural economic reforms to meet the conditions of two EU-IMF bail-out packages totalling EUR240bn. Implementation proved difficult and ultimately brought down the government. After a seven-month confrontation with Greece's creditors, the Syriza-led government negotiated a new three-year European Stability Mechanism (ESM) programme in August 2015. In 2012 Greece restructured its public debt, reducing the value of private-sector creditors' holdings by EUR107bn. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any further debt write-down. Now that Greece has exited the programme, it is subject to an "enhanced supervision" monitoring regime by its euro zone creditors.
Taxation: The tax rate on corporate profits is 29% and on distributed dividends is 10%. The top marginal personal income tax rate is 45% for income of more than EUR40,000. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at rates of 24%, 13% and 6%.
Foreign trade: In 2017 goods exports (fob) were worth EUR27.9bn (US$31.5bn) and imports (fob) amounted to EUR46.3bn. The current account registered a deficit of EUR1.4bn, equivalent to 0.8% of GDP.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
The coalition government-comprising Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza, the party of the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras) and the small, right-wing nationalist Independent Greeks (AE)-has survived since September 2015, despite having only a slim majority in the 300-seat parliament. Following the defection of two members of the AE, in protest at the agreement reached with Macedonia on the 27-year Macedonia name dispute in June, the government's majority has been reduced to just two seats. Mr Tsipras will aim to see through his parliamentary term, which ends in October 2019, but there is a significant risk of a pre-term election.
Tensions within the government coalition persist on a range of issues, including the continued implementation of austerity measures and the Macedonia name issue. The AE, which has seven seats, has said that it will oppose the name change agreement reached between Macedonia and Greece in June if it is brought before the Greek parliament. In a consultative referendum held on September 30th Macedonians voted overwhelmingly in favour of changing their country's official name to Severna Makedonija (North Macedonia), but turnout was well below the 50% threshold for the result to be considered valid. The outcome has cast uncertainty over implementation of the agreement, taking some pressure off the Greek government. However, the Syriza-led coalition government remains fragile, as illustrated by the resignation on October 17th of the foreign minister, Nikos Kotzias, one of the main architects of the agreement.
On August 20th, after eight years of austerity and unpopular reforms under three economic adjustment programmes, Greece exited the third bail-out programme signed by the Syriza-led government in 2015. However, having failed to obtain significant debt relief to ease future austerity, Mr Tsipras has lost much popular support and will struggle to revive his party's political fortunes before the next election. He hopes that economic growth will gain momentum over the coming year and allow him to implement promises to lower taxes and increase spending. He also hopes that Greece's international creditors will approve his government's proposal to cancel agreed pension cuts in 2019 on the grounds that they will not be needed in order to achieve the country's fiscal targets (a 3.5% primary surplus). The Economist Intelligence Unit remains sceptical that real GDP growth will rise much higher than 2% during the 2019-23 forecast period, and expects that rolling back on reforms agreed with Greece's international creditors could trigger tensions in the country's financial market.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Syriza trails in opinion polls behind the centre-right New Democracy (ND), led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis; the gap has been more than 10 percentage points for some time. ND's lead may narrow during the election campaign, as Mr Tsipras is a formidable campaigner and there is little overt enthusiasm for Mr Mitsotakis or his party. However, given widespread popular disaffection with the government, the election-due by October 2019-is ND's to lose. If, as we expect, ND wins the largest share of the vote, it would benefit from the 50-seat bonus rule for the winning party. Even so, it would probably have to secure the support of at least one other party to muster a parliamentary majority.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
In mid-June 2018 Greece and Macedonia (the official name of which is the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia; the constitutional name is the Republic of Macedonia) reached an agreement to change Macedonia's constitutional name to Northern Macedonia to end Greece's opposition to that country's accession to NATO. However, there is strong public opposition to the agreement in both countries, and Greece's coalition government is divided on the issue. The low turnout at the referendum in Macedonia on September 30th has complicated implementation. For this, the proposed changes need to be incorporated into Macedonia's constitution with a two-thirds majority in the country's parliament by end-January 2019 and ratified in the Greek parliament next year.
Tensions between Greece and Turkey have risen recently. The risk of military hostility is high, particularly in the Aegean Sea, but both sides will seek to avoid clashes. Points of contention-such as historical territorial disputes in the Aegean Sea and the Greek courts' rejection of Turkey's extradition request for Turkish soldiers who fled to Greece on the night of the July 2016 failed coup in Turkey-have fuelled distrust. Turkey's release in mid-August of two Greek soldiers arrested for alleged espionage in March 2018 while on patrol in the border area of Evros has eased tensions, which were threatening to boil over.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Despite exiting the third economic adjustment programmes in August 2018 without a precautionary credit line, the government will be subject to huge policy constraints during the next five years and beyond. General government debt is huge, officially projected to reach EUR335bn by end-2018, or almost 185% of GDP, according to our GDP estimates. It is also now almost entirely owed to official creditors (the EU and the IMF), so another debt write-down, as happened in 2012, is unlikely.
At the June 21st meeting of the Eurogroup, Greece's official creditors agreed to close the final review of the third bail-out programme, paving the way for a disbursement of EUR15bn, which was released on August 6th. Of this, EUR3.3bn was earmarked to repay more expensive IMF debt, and the balance to create a buffer for Greece to use while it builds up market access. The total buffer, estimated at EUR24.1bn, should be sufficient to cover almost two years of the country's financing needs. This is more onerous than a precautionary credit line would have been, as Greece will be accruing interest on money that it does not currently need. However, intense political pressure not to invite further policy conditionality led the government to choose the more expensive option.
The Eurogroup meeting agreed to further debt relief for Greece, which was granted a ten-year grace period and a ten-year maturity extension on EUR96bn of its loans (provided by the European Financial Stability Facility). It will also get a reduction in the interest rates (for loans of EUR130.9bn) and a return of profits from the securities market programme and from the Agreement on Net Financial Assets, which comprise the official sector holders of Greek debt-the European Central Bank (ECB) and national central banks of euro area countries. The value of the return is estimated to be about EUR5bn.
Greece, in response, has committed to long-term fiscal prudence. It must achieve annual primary budget surpluses of 3.5% of GDP in 2018-22 and 2.2% thereafter, until 2060. It will also be subject to an "enhanced surveillance" regime, which is a more exacting system of post-programme monitoring than those applied to other former bail-out countries. The debt-relief measures will be subject to quarterly reviews of the state of the economy and of the government's adherence to its commitments. As these reviews will be published, transgression by Greece would adversely affect market access.
After a three-year absence Greece has returned to the financial markets three times since July 2017. However, after its exit from the bail-out programme in August, it will do so without the backstop of an official credit line. Recent emerging-market turbulence and investor risk aversion highlight the difficulties that Greece could face in the future on the international capital markets. Greece should have sufficient funds to meet its financing needs in the short term, through to early 2020. However, in the medium and long term the political and, arguably, the economic price of meeting high annual primary surplus targets may become unbearable. During the past two years Greece has exceeded its annual primary surplus targets, but at the expense of economic growth, which has been disappointing. Meeting such targets will remain a constraint on growth, alongside other negative factors, such as poor demographics and a weak business environment. Grexit is not a short-term risk; however, given that Greece is highly unlikely to improve competitiveness inside the euro zone or grow its way out of its huge debt burden, it will represent risk in the long term.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
In 2017 the budget surplus was equivalent to 0.8% of GDP and the primary surplus (budget balance minus interest payments) exceeded the bail-out programme target of 1.75%, coming in at 4%. We estimate a minimal budget deficit in 2018, of 0.2% of GDP, and expect Greece to fall just short of its annual primary surplus target of 3.5% of GDP this year and in 2019-22. Although the primary surplus target will decline to 2.2% of GDP in 2023, it will still be difficult to achieve, owing to the fact that debt repayments become much more onerous from that year on. We forecast that the deficit will widen gradually during this period, reflecting constraints on revenue collection, a relaxation of spending restraint and only modest economic growth.
The restructuring of government debt owed to the private sector cut the debt/GDP ratio to 159.4% at end-2012, from 171.9% in 2011. However, large primary surpluses in 2016-17 were insufficient to arrest the growth of gross consolidated government debt, which rose to EUR317.4bn, or 179.1% of GDP, in 2017. We expect that, without a debt write-down and assuming moderate nominal medium-term GDP growth rates, the public debt/GDP ratio will remain above 170% in 2018-23.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The ECB is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a quantitative easing (QE) programme that is running at EUR30bn per month in January-September 2018. It will run at EUR15bn per month in October-December before coming to an end. Economic activity in the euro zone has softened this year, but the ECB's view of the outlook remains fairly positive. Rising commodity prices and evidence of building domestic price pressure in some parts of the euro zone should mean that sufficient inflationary pressures will begin to emerge on the policy horizon in 2019-20. In response, we expect the ECB to take steps towards normalising its policy stance, with an increase of 25 basis points in the main refinancing rate to 0.25% in early 2020, followed by five more rises that will lift the rate to 2% by end-2023. An increase in the deposit rate, which currently stands at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019, easing the pressure on banks' lending margins and supporting profitability.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Compared with 2007 levels, real GDP has shrunk by more than a quarter, government consumption by almost a quarter, household consumption by a fifth and gross fixed investment by almost two-thirds. The recovery, which began at the start of 2017, is fragile and vulnerable to domestic and external developments. We forecast that real GDP growth will pick up from 1.3% in 2017 to an average of 2% per year in 2018-23. The risks to our forecast are balanced. Upside risks include a continued strong tourism performance, if capacity constraints are addressed. Downside risks include the frailty of the banking sector and political instability.
Seasonally and calendar-day-adjusted real GDP growth slowed from 0.9% quarter on quarter in January-March (2.5% year on year) to 0.2% (1.8% year on year) in April-June, despite steady expansion of domestic consumption and a strong export of services (largely driven by tourism). We estimate that real GDP growth will reach 2% in 2018. This remains a disappointing rate of expansion in the context of the slump of the past decade. We expect a combination of more and higher taxes, higher social security payments, debt repayments and spending cuts to put pressure on household disposable income. Although we expect a modest acceleration in household spending in 2018-23, this will be from a low base and will be constrained by large primary surplus targets of 3.5% of GDP per year up to 2022 and 2.2% in 2023, continued high unemployment and insipid lending growth.
Quarterly gross fixed investment has been volatile in recent years, but recorded strong full-year growth in 2016-17, albeit from a low base. However, reflecting base effects and a loss of momentum, investment contracted by 7.9% year on year in the first half of 2018. We expect a pick-up in the second half of the year to reduce the contraction to 1% in 2018 as whole, followed by average annual of growth of 5.2% in 2019-23, leaving fixed investment still about 50% below its 2007 peak. Underinvestment during the crisis, and the depletion of Greece's capital stock, as well as uncertainty about the country's euro zone membership, are likely to restrict growth potential in the medium term.
Greece's external trade will be constrained by its relatively uncompetitive goods exports. Over the medium term we expect tourism to continue to support services export growth, contributing to annual average growth of exports of goods and services of 4.8% in 2019-23.
Greece will face its biggest macroeconomic challenge now that it no longer has access to official external financing at preferential rates. How the economy performs over the next five years (and beyond) will determine whether the country will remain in the euro zone. We believe that there is a significant risk that Greece will exit the euro zone in the long term, given the difficulties that it will face in attaining rapid growth while meeting large primary surplus targets, and in restoring competitiveness without a currency devaluation. Grexit would lead to a sovereign default and severe recession in the first few years, but the economy would then recover, assuming a responsible fiscal policy guided by the necessity to achieve a primary surplus.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
After averaging 1.1% in 2017, driven by higher global energy prices, Greece's annual consumer price inflation rate (seasonally adjusted, EU harmonised) dipped sharply at the start of 2018, before accelerating moderately since May. The economy has returned to growth, but significant slack remains in the labour market, and domestic demand is subdued. Despite rising global commodity prices and increased tourism, we estimate that annual inflation will average 0.8% in 2018 (it averaged 0.6% in the first nine months of the year). We forecast a pick-up to inflation of 1.4% per year on average in 2019-23 as the pace of growth quickens.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
In 2017 the euro rallied as the region's economic recovery strengthened and expectations of QE tapering increased, and as political risk waned in Europe but rose in the US. The exchange rate peaked at almost US$1.25:EUR1 at the beginning of February 2018, but had weakened to US$1.16:EUR1 by late May in response to the formation of a populist, Eurosceptic government in Italy, and remained close to that level in June-July before weakening to US$1.13:EUR1 in mid-August. The euro has since recovered to US$1.16-1.17:EUR1 in September-October, but will remain under pressure from political risk in Italy and monetary tightening in the US. We expect it to begin firming against the dollar from 2019, on the assumption that the region's recovery will continue while growth momentum in the US slows. We forecast an average of US$1.19:EUR1 in 2018-19 and US$1.21:EUR1 in 2020-21. The euro will also receive structural support from a large current-account surplus, and we expect it to appreciate to an average ofUS$1.24:EUR1 in 2022-23.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
Greece's current-account deficit has narrowed since the start of the crisis. This mainly reflects the compression of imports due to contracting domestic demand, but is also partly the result of improved competitiveness in the tourism sector. The current-account deficit narrowed to 0.8% of GDP in 2017, from 1.1% of GDP in 2016, according to the Bank of Greece (the central bank). We expect widening deficits in 2018-23 as import prices rise and import volumes pick up in line with higher domestic demand, but these will be much smaller than the average annual deficit of 7.2% of GDP since Greece joined the euro zone in 2001.
