Note. WCF (World commodity forecasts) is an index of 22 hard and soft commodities. FFB (Food, feedstuffs and beverages) is a price index of 13 soft commodities. The beverages sector has a weight of 20% in the FFB index, grains 46.4%, oilseeds 28.6% and sugar 4.9%. The FFB index has a weight of 55.6% in the WCF index.
Agricultural prices will show a faster than expected recovery in 2018
The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that its food, feedstuffs and beverages (FFB) price index rose by 2.8% in 2018, halting a seven-year decline. Nonetheless, this is a downward revision (from 4.4% previously), primarily owing to weaker prices for beverages such as coffee and cocoa, as well as sugar. The bilateral trade war between the US and China has disrupted existing trade patterns and caused the prices of some products that are subject to tariffs, including soybeans and soymeal, to diverge in various markets. A number of other markets, including grains such as rice and maize, are also beginning to tighten slightly, which will support sustained price growth through to 2020. Nonetheless, supplies in most markets remain comfortable by historical standards; several crops registered record harvests in 2016/17, including wheat and soybeans, and large carryover stocks will limit the potential for price growth in 2018. Downside risks related to a potentially disruptive El Niño event will persist, but we do not forecast an agricultural price shock. FFB prices are forecast to remain flat in 2019 as the effects of the US-China bilateral trade war start to impact markets. However, by 2020 we expect producers and consumers to have adapted to shifting supply chains, supporting 4.1% growth in the FFB index, owing to strong price growth in beverages, sugar and grains. Overall, we expect rising populations and incomes to continue to support modest growth in demand (and therefore prices) in the FFB sector in the medium and long term.
FFB prices will rise again in 2020, and risks to the forecast remain mixed
Nonetheless, the road ahead will be bumpy. Agricultural markets have been well supplied for several consecutive seasons, providing ample stocks to draw on. We expect global GDP growth to remain relatively firm, at an average of 2.6% per year in 2019-20. However, uncertainty surrounding tightening monetary policy in major developed markets, including the US, the risk of a disorderly economic slowdown in China (which is not our core forecast) and the impact of increasingly protectionist trade policies espoused by the US president, Donald Trump, continue to pose risks to our forecast. In addition, exchange-rate trends may help to keep a lid on global commodity prices. Since April the US dollar has rallied strongly against other major currencies, and we expect the dollar (in which most raw materials are traded) to continue to remain fairly strong against most emerging-market currencies in 2018-19-especially as the sharp depreciation of the Turkish lira and the Argentinian peso in recent weeks sparks concerns over potential contagion in other emerging markets. This will weigh on import demand in many emerging markets and encourage exporters to increase output, further contributing to global supplies.
Grain prices registered strong gains in 2018
We estimate that grain prices will rise by 14.1% in 2018. Maize prices rose by about 10% on average in February in response to worries about drought and rapidly shrinking production prospects in Argentina. However, as other crops come to the market and carryover supplies from the bumper 2016/17 crop remain available, we estimate full-year maize price growth to average 9.4% in 2018. For wheat, adverse weather conditions are affecting yields across the world, changing the supply outlook significantly. As global demand growth remains strong, we expect the market to register a deficit in 2017/18. Overall, we estimate wheat prices to surge ahead by around 17% year on year in 2018 (from 18% previously) and by a further 2% in 2019 (from 3% previously).
Oilseed prices will fall in 2019-20
Oilseed prices are estimated to fall by 2% in 2018 after a similar decline in 2017, largely owing to the bumper soybean crop in major producers such as the US and Brazil. Despite strong global demand, this has driven global soybean stockpiles higher. We expect soybean prices to decline by an average of 1.7% per year in 2019-20. China's imposition in July of a 25% tariff on soybean imports from the US has created the potential for greater price volatility; for now, however, we expect China to source imports from other suppliers, avoiding a sharp increase in prices. Sunflowerseed oil prices are likely to weaken in 2019, reflecting comfortable supplies. Palm oil prices are forecast to follow a similar trend as global output surges and changing consumer habits result in lower demand growth-particularly in developed economies, where health concerns have caused consumers to opt for alternative products.
A forecast recovery in coffee prices in 2019 will lift the beverages sub-index
We estimate that the beverages sub-index, which includes coffee, cocoa and tea, will fall again in 2018, for the sixth consecutive year. We expect cocoa prices to rise by 13.4% in 2018, before declining by around 7% in 2019; however, this will do little to erase the massive drop in 2017 of nearly 30%, which was caused by soaring global production and fairly weak demand growth. Global coffee prices (arabica) are forecast to fall by 13% in 2018 on the back of higher than expected production from Central America as well as the comparative strength of the US dollar, which will encourage exporters to sell their stocks. In 2019 we expect prices of higher-value arabica coffee beans to rebound by 6.4%, as several consecutive years of market deficits begin to erode global supplies.
Sugar prices will recover in 2019
Sugar prices are estimated to decline by around 27% in 2018, following a decline of 11.6% in 2017. This reflects crop-friendly weather conditions in key producer markets, which are fuelling expectations of a larger global sugar surplus than we had previously anticipated. Policy moves to restrict import dependence in key consumers (notably China, India and the EU) have weakened market sentiment further. This decline will continue in 2019, but we expect supplies to begin to tighten in 2020 as higher ethanol prices encourage farmers to divert more cane to ethanol (rather than to its rival, sugar). This should support growth in global sugar prices of nearly 10% year on year in 2020.

Cocoa
Demand
After decelerating from 2.4% in the 2016/17 season (October-September) to an estimated 1.5% in 2017/18, global cocoa consumption growth is forecast to slow further during 2018/19-2019/20. Although cocoa consumption in the world's largest consumers-mainly developed economies, as well as some large markets in the developing world-is forecast to remain positive, consumption growth will remain weak in many of these countries, at less than 1%. By contrast, cocoa consumption growth will prove stronger in other, smaller cocoa consumers, but these markets will not be sufficiently large to drive stronger overall growth in global cocoa consumption. By region, Asia accounts for much of the increase in global demand, although rising demand in the Americas and Europe will also contribute. The Economist Intelligence Unit is forecasting global cocoa consumption growth to average 1.3% per year in 2018/19 and 2019/20. High per-capita consumption levels in major developed markets will prevent faster demand growth. Another factor precluding more rapid growth in global cocoa demand includes retail prices, which may rise in response to the increase in global cocoa prices in recent months, potentially pushing some consumers towards non-chocolate confectionery. Meanwhile, the size of many chocolate bars has shrunk-partly in response to consumer concerns about obesity but also to protect profits against a background of rising cocoa prices in previous years-which will also hamper consumption growth.
Balancing demand between cocoa powder and butter will be challenging
Asian countries will see slightly faster growth in cocoa demand than the global average, as these markets are far less saturated and GDP growth will remain higher than in developed economies. Stronger demand in Asia will have implications for global demand for cocoa butter (used in richer products, such as chocolate confectionery) and cocoa powder (used to add chocolate flavour to products such as biscuits, cakes and drinks). The demand balance between cocoa powder and butter is both delicate and cyclical. We expect demand for cocoa butter to remain strong in the short term, but it will not outstrip demand for powder indefinitely. Given that Asia accounted for 27% of the world's imports of cocoa powder in 2016/17, compared with just 11% of global imports of cocoa butter, firmer consumption growth in that market is likely to lift demand for powder.
Consumption growth will remain fairly low in more saturated markets
We forecast modest but positive growth in demand for cocoa in developed markets in 2018/19-2019/20. Health concerns, market saturation and changing retail habits will constrain demand (the rise of internet grocery shopping is eroding spur-of-the-moment in-store chocolate purchases). However, rising demand for dark chocolate-which has a higher cocoa content than milk chocolate and is perceived to be healthier-will support overall consumption. Consumers in the US (the largest cocoa-consuming country, which accounts for 18% of global demand) and in European countries, which collectively account for 46% of global demand, are showing an increasing preference for premium chocolate with a higher cocoa content, but with less frequent purchases. However, somewhat weaker underlying economic conditions will contribute to a gradual deceleration in cocoa consumption in many of these markets over the course of2018/19-2019/20.
Cocoa consumption growth will remain firm in Asia
China and India have huge potential for further expansion in cocoa demand, given currently low per-head consumption levels of just 35 g in India and 62 g in China in 2016/17, compared with 2-6 kg in developed markets. However, demand growth will be constrained by high retail prices. Chinese demand will continue to rise firmly, at a rate of around 5.1% per year in 2018/19-2019/20 on the back of a relatively firm GDP growth forecast. In India, we expect demand growth to pick up from an estimated 2.1% in 2017/18 to an annual average of 3.1% per year during the forecast period.

a October-September; domestic grindings and net imports.
Supply
After falling by an estimated 3.5% in 2017/18, prospects for global cocoa production are weak for the 2018/19-2019/20 forecast period, reflecting a projected drop in production in Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana, respectively the world's largest and second-largest cocoa producers. Although output in both countries will remain high by historical standards, lower farm-gate prices and weaker confidence among growers will drag down cocoa output. Notwithstanding a rise in prices in 2018, the previous long-running period of weak prices is likely to have dissuaded farmers from investing in fertiliser and pesticides, raising the incidence of crop disease and contributing to the broader decline in global cocoa production. Rising production in other Asian and Latin America producers will fail to offset the decline in cocoa output among several of the largest African producers.
Structural and geographical factors will hamper long-term supply
Longer-term structural problems will also constrain supply. Not only have farm-gate prices in several large producing countries begun to fall in line with lower market prices for cocoa, but farmers are also getting a much smaller share of the final retail price than in previous decades owing to higher costs further down the supply chain. In West Africa, for example, many farmers remain below the poverty line, and as a result few young people are choosing to work in the cocoa sector. Governments are trying to lift farmers' incomes to attract new workers, but it is uncertain how effective this will be in the long term.
Geographical considerations will also hamper the diversification of production. Cocoa can only be grown in certain regions (three-quarters of world production comes from regions that are located within eight degrees of the equator) under warm and humid conditions. Cocoa production is therefore likely to remain concentrated among a small group of countries, limiting the scope for strong and sustained output growth. Periodically, there is speculation that climate change will hamper production in these countries to such an extent that cocoa production will plummet. However, we believe that some countries have significant potential to expand production, mainly in Latin America, where high-quality cocoa is produced. The expansion of grinding facilities in producing countries may also encourage new investment to lift output.
Côte d'Ivoire's production is set to drop in 2018/19 and 2019/20
In Côte d'Ivoire, we estimate that cocoa output fell by 3.5% in 2017/18, partly as a result of dry weather, which affected the mid-year-crop. We are forecasting production to fall again in 2018/19, by 5.1%, reflecting a relatively unsupportive domestic policy backdrop. Not only has the state-run cocoa authority, the Conseil du Café-Cacao (CCC), issued fewer export licences, but plans to accelerate the replacement of old crops infected by swollen shoot virus (which cuts yields) with new crops over the course of the next three years will hamper production. In addition, the CCC has kept farm-gate prices on hold, which has discouraged the use of fertiliser and pesticides, with the incidence of crop disease rising as a result. Even if farm-gate prices were raised-which is unlikely now that global cocoa prices are falling-it is doubtful whether this would come soon enough to impact output trends for the 2018/19 harvest. A stabilisation fund is supposed to protect farmers' revenue from price volatility, but the amounts have been insufficient, and given the lack of transparency over the financial reserves held by the CCC, neither farmers nor exporters are confident that losses arising from low global prices in 2016/17 will be recouped. Given that we do not expect a significant improvement in any of these factors in the short term, we expect cocoa production to slip again in 2019/20, although by a milder 1.4%.
Ghanaian production is set to decline in both 2018/19 and 2019/20
Similar production trends are evident in Ghana. Adverse weather and a difficult policy backdrop hampered production in 2017/18, with cocoa output declining by an estimated 12.4%. We are forecasting a continued, albeit gentler, contraction in 2018/19 and 2019/20. The cocoa authority, Cocobod, is encountering financial problems that are likely to affect the amount paid to farmers, which will in turn depress output. Cocobod was forced to seek a bridging loan from the Bank of Ghana (the central bank) last year, and following the recent depletion of its stabilisation fund and indications that it may take on more debt this year, Cocobod has announced that it is considering amending the way in which farmers are paid. This is likely to involve the removal of a scheme that pays subsidies to farmers (guaranteeing a minimum income level). The authorities are instead considering a scheme in which farmers are paid 70% of the cocoa export price, which would expose incomes to considerable market volatility. Given anxiety among farmers about the government's intention to prioritise other crops over cocoa, the ongoing encroachment by gold miners, the government's decision to stop providing free fertiliser and the fact that around one-fifth of trees are affected by swollen shoot disease, production is forecast to fall by 2.9% in 2018/19 and by 3% in 2019/20.
In the longer term, the New Patriotic Party government plans to rehabilitate cocoa farms, cutting down trees that are over 30 years old and replanting them while providing financial compensation to farmers until the trees start yielding fruit (generally 3-5 years). The authorities aim ultimately to raise production significantly, with Cocobod recently indicating that it is targeting output of 1m tonnes within the next five years (an apparent downgrade from previous statements citing a target of 1.5m tonnes within four years), driven by better soil management, pest and disease control and improved irrigation. These plans are positive, since Ghana has a large share of unproductive trees (estimated at 40% by Cocobod) and consequently a low average yield per hectare (at 400 kg/ha, compared with 600 kg/ha in Côte d'Ivoire and 1 tonne/ha in Indonesia). However, it will be difficult to secure the necessary funding. We think it is unlikely that these ambitious plans will come to fruition, since the weak macroeconomic backdrop is likely to hamper public investment and external creditors are unlikely to fund the project.
Cameroon's and Nigeria's production targets will prove overambitious
Cameroon's cocoa production is estimated to have moderated in 2017/18 by 8.5% as political unrest in the south-west of the country, which produces around half of the country's output, dragged down national production, with rising numbers of farmers fleeing their plantations in the wake of violent clashes between separatists and the security forces. Although we are forecasting a slight recovery in cocoa output, by 1.8% on average per year in 2018/19 and 2019/20, production levels will remain weak. Cuts in farm-gate prices will be a disincentive to farmers, meaning that the government will remain significantly off track from its 2020 production target of 600,000 tonnes-a level that even the national Cocoa Development Corporation has described as "unrealistic and unattainable". Plans to increase the harvested area by 100,000 ha each year are highly unlikely to materialise in the context of the recent political instability.
Cocoa production in Nigeria has recovered in recent years after a slump in 2014-16, rising by an estimated 4.1% in 2017/18 to 255,000 tonnes (still below the government target of 300,000-320,000 tonnes). The authorities are seeking investment to raise cocoa production with the aim of diversifying and expanding sources of foreign-exchange earnings beyond the mainstay of oil, with the Ministry of Agriculture recently stating that it believes Nigeria can boost cocoa production above the levels recorded in Côte d'Ivoire. However, we remain pessimistic about production prospects and are forecasting a contraction of 1.6% on average per year in 2018/19-2019/20. Government initiatives meant to support farmers-including efforts to introduce high-yielding cocoa and to increase the distribution of free seedlings-have not been successful. In addition, investment has been slow to materialise, and reports of the dieback fungal disease in the south-west of the country-affecting trees that account for 10% of national output-will hamper production in the near term. Structural problems such as weak infrastructure, corruption, poor and expensive access to financing along with weak implementation remain unaddressed and will prevent a significant increase in output.
Production will continue to recover in Indonesia
Indonesia is one of the few major cocoa producers that are likely to see output rising firmly during the forecast period. Stable weather conditions in 2017/18 are likely to have lifted cocoa output by an estimated 7.4%. We forecast continued growth of 5.1% during the forecast period, but at 320,000 tonnes in 2019/20 output levels will remain weak by historical standards. The authorities have ambitious plans to triple cocoa output by 2020, from 325,000 tonnes in 2014/15, but these targets are highly unlikely to materialise. Indonesian firms will probably rely increasingly on imported processed cocoa from nearby Malaysia to meet domestic demand.
Strong potential for growth in Latin America
Structurally, there is scope for both of Latin America's two largest cocoa producers, Brazil and Ecuador, to lift output as manufacturers look to develop production centres outside West Africa. The region's reputation for producing high-quality cocoa will help in this respect, given rising global demand for premium chocolate. Although some of this investment will be slow to materialise, we still expect annual average output growth of 3.5% in Ecuador and 4.9% in Brazil during 2018/19-2019/20.

Stocks and prices
We expect the surplus in the global cocoa market to narrow sharply, from an estimated 382,000 tonnes in 2017/18 to 132,000 tonnes in 2019/20. Although production is forecast to fall steadily, the fact that it will do so from such a high base (output was exceptionally strong in 2016/17) means that we continue to forecast a market surplus, despite signs of continued (albeit weaker) demand growth. Stocks are forecast to reach close to 2.5m tonnes at the end of the 2019/20 season. Although this is high by historical standards, the relatively gloomy production outlook is likely to bolster prices towards the end of the forecast period.

Market surplus will put downward pressure on prices in 2019
Cocoa prices traded at comparatively low levels between February 2017 and February 2018, mainly in the range of US$1,950/tonne and US$2,050/tonne. However, prices rose sharply in March-May, to US$2,600-2,700/tonne, on the back of gloomy prospects for production in Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana. Better weather conditions subsequently led to a reduction in prices to an average of around US$2,170/tonne in August.
In spite of our estimates for a gradual moderation in prices over the remainder of 2018, we expect average quarterly prices to remain above US$2,200/tonne. Our full-year average price forecast, at US$2,304/tonne, implies a 13.6% year on year increase. Despite falling production in 2019, weaker demand and a persistent market surplus will suppress prices, which are forecast to average US$2,145/tonne, marking a decline of 6.9% year on year. Although the same factors will remain in play in 2020, with declining production and weaker demand growth, investor concerns about the impact of several years of falling output will place some support under prices, which we expect will pick up to around US$2,300/tonne by the last quarter of 2020.

Coffee
Demand
Global coffee consumption has been accelerating moderately in recent years, to an estimated 3.5% in the 2017/18 crop year (October-September), largely boosted by rising consumption in coffee-importing countries-mainly developed economies-which account for two-thirds of global demand. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects growth in global coffee demand to decelerate to 2.6% in 2018/19 and 1.9% in 2019/20, mainly reflecting less supportive underlying economic conditions. Continued monetary policy tightening in some of the large coffee consumers will affect overall domestic demand, although with the policy stance remaining fairly loose and most economies decelerating rather than entering into a recession, coffee consumption will rise more steadily. In coffee-exporting countries, many of which are emerging markets, consumption growth will be lower, averaging 2.2% per year in 2018/19-2019/20. Tepid demand growth in Brazil, which currently accounts for around 40% of exporting countries' consumption owing to the sheer size of its domestic market, is the main factor contributing to weak overall growth in coffee consumption among coffee exporters. Consumption growth will be strongest in Asia-notably China, whose economy will continue to grow firmly. However, per-capita coffee consumption levels are low in China, so even as domestic demand rises quickly, this will contribute only modestly to global growth (China will account for only 3% of the total global rise in coffee production in 2017/18-2018/19).
Coffee habits are shifting around the world
Consumption trends will change in both the home and out-of-home sectors. In the latter, the expansion of coffee-shop chains will continue, providing a boost to demand, particularly in North America (with 46% of coffee in the US now consumed out of the home) and Europe (which saw the number of coffee shops rise by 6.4% in 2017), but store formats will evolve. Increasing demand for "on the go" beverages will result in larger numbers of smaller shops, including within petrol stations and supermarkets, as well as the spread of coffee delivery services by large chains. In some markets-including the US and China-large coffee chains are increasingly moving towards prepayment through smartphone apps, allowing customers to pick up their purchases without having to queue. These technological developments are likely to help the out-of-home sector to defend its market share at a time when a large number of consumers have single-serve coffee-capsule machines at home. This will be accompanied by the heavy marketing of other coffee beverages, including iced coffee and cold brew. Although accounting for only a small share of the out-of-home segment, sales of these products are likely to grow rapidly.
Single-serve coffee will help to drive growth in developed markets
Demand for coffee at home that rivals the quality of beverages found in cafes will result in a shift away from the consumption of instant coffee. On a global level, coffee-pod sales are approaching the total combined value of instant and ground coffee, although the higher cost of pods means that in volume terms the instant- and ground-coffee market remains larger. Despite the sharp slowdown in sales of machines and capsules after initial firm growth, the coffee-pod market will continue to provide important support for overall demand of arabica coffee (most pods contain predominantly arabica beans).
Coffee consumption growth in North America will continue to rise
We expect US coffee consumption to continue to grow at a more moderate pace than in recent years. From an estimated 4.8% in 2017/18, coffee consumption growth is forecast to decelerate to 4.1% in 2018/19 and 1.8% in 2019/20, reflecting a gradual slowing of underlying consumer demand growth. That said, coffee consumption is not expected to fall, with the US National Coffee Association estimating that the percentage of people drinking coffee is continuing to rise (up from 57% in early 2016 to 62% in early 2017, according to the latest data). Daily consumption is rising, and consumers are increasingly attracted to a variety of products; for example, US consumption of cold coffee products has risen by 75% over 2015-17. Moreover, the number of coffee shops is increasing at a rate of around 3.6% per year, while the share of 13-18-year-olds drinking coffee has gone up from 23% in 2014 to 37% in early 2017. Demand growth among 18-24-year-olds is also rising strongly, which bodes well for medium- to long-term coffee consumption trends.
Similar dynamics are evident in Canada, with the share of 18-24-year-olds drinking coffee jumping from 48% in 2015 to 58% in 2016 (up from just 32% in 2009). Younger consumers, in particular, are showing a much stronger preference for speciality coffees and for drinking coffee in out-of-home locations. We expect Canada's demand growth, which has been fairly steady at around 2.5% in recent years, to slow moderately to an average of 2% per year in 2018/19-2019/20.
Coffee consumption in Brazil will moderate
Brazil is the world's second-largest coffee consumer, but consumption levels per head are still modest (at around one-third of those in most European countries), so there is scope for a significant increase in demand. As Brazil emerges from a sharp economic recession that caused coffee consumption to remain fairly flat in 2014-16, coffee consumption is showing signs of strengthening and is estimated to rise by 3.6% in 2017/18. This is likely to moderate but remain fairly firm at around 2.3% per year in 2018/19 and 2019/20, although the local coffee processing association, the Brazilian Coffee Industry Association (ABIC), is projecting firmer coffee consumption growth in 2018 as the economy recovers. However, household consumption will remain constrained by high unemployment and rising fuel prices, which will all act as a drag on disposable income.
Continued coffee consumption growth is forecast in Japan and South Korea
Japan is the largest coffee market in Asia, with coffee boasting around the same share of the beverages market as tea. After rising by an estimated 0.9% in 2017/18, we expect coffee consumption to growth to rise by an average of 1.2% per year in 2018/19-2019/20. This growth will be driven by coffee sales in convenience stores, given that the number of coffee shops is falling. Meanwhile, in South Korea the coffee market has expanded rapidly in recent years, with imports more than trebling in the past decade and the number of coffee shops increasing even faster. We expect the pace of growth to slow but remain firm by global standards, at an annual average of 2.6% per year over the forecast period.
China consumption and production data
Until recently we have not included China in our list of top coffee consumers and producers, instead including it in our list of "others". This reflects the fact that the International Coffee Organisation (ICO) does not report China's coffee consumption and production, complicating direct data comparisons with other consuming and producing countries. Widespread acknowledgment of China emerging as a major player in the coffee market has prompted us to amend our tables to include figures for China. However, a lack of historical data series means that these figures should be regarded as estimates.
Consumption
We have based the historical series of our coffee consumption data on a paper written by the ICO, in which it estimates consumption based on production, export and import figures. It provides data to 2013/14, with annual consumption calculated from domestic production plus net exports. From 2013/14 onwards we have estimated coffee consumption based on growth in private consumption to provide a rough guide to the size of the Chinese coffee market. According to these calculations, China is the sixth-largest coffee consumer among coffee-exporting countries, but at 2.4m bags in 2016/17 its market is significantly smaller than those of many coffee-importing countries. By comparison, Chinese coffee consumption remains lower than consumption in the UK, despite huge disparities in population size.
Production
We have used data from the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO), which are current until 2016/17. This series indicates that coffee production rose sharply between 2008/09 and 2013/14, more than trebling, but output has since stabilised at around 1.9m bags. This makes China the world's tenth-largest coffee producer.

Demand in China and India will continue to grow
Coffee demand in China and India, which have similar levels of consumption, will continue to grow, aided by still-firm economic growth in both countries, which will lift disposable incomes. Although GDP growth is likely to be stronger in India, we expect coffee consumption growth in China to be firmer. This reflects the fact that the middle class has expanded much more rapidly in China than in India, where disposable income levels for the most part remain extremely low. The emergence of a coffee-shop culture in urban centres is a key factor contributing to the rise in coffee consumption in China, aided by a rapid expansion of international coffee chains. Starbucks now runs 3,200 outlets in 139 Chinese cities, up from 2,300 in October 2017. Of these, around 600 are in Shanghai alone-Starbucks' largest presence in a single city. A new store which opened in the city last December, the Shanghai Reserve Roastery, is the company's highest-earning branch worldwide. Despite signs of weaker sales growth in China amid greater competition from fast-growing start-ups offering coffee delivery, the company is still planning to have 6,000 stores open by the end of 2022. With the out-of-home sector expanding slightly less rapidly in India, coffee consumption will grow more slowly. We therefore forecast average growth of 2.1% per year in 2018/19-2019/20, compared with an estimated 2.2% growth in 2017/18.
South-east Asia also has relatively low levels of coffee consumption per head, but demand is increasing rapidly in some countries, mainly in coffee-producing economies such as Indonesia and Vietnam. Rising incomes are encouraging companies such as Starbucks to expand in Indonesia and the Philippines, where consumption is increasing. Costa Coffee is expanding in Thailand, Singapore and Cambodia and opened its first store in Vietnam last October.
Asian markets will drive demand for robusta beans
Given taste preferences for soluble and instant coffee-which generally use the robusta variety-in faster-growing Asian markets, demand will be stronger for robusta beans than for the more expensive arabica blends. Improved quality of robusta will also play a part here, with such beans slowly losing their reputation for inferior taste. In addition, improvements in processing technology mean that it is possible to use a larger proportion of robusta in coffee blends while maintaining quality.
Supply
The biennial crop season in Brazil, the world's largest producer, will continue to have a significant impact on overall global coffee output trends. Global output fell by 0.3% in the 2017/18 crop year, which mainly reflected a drop in output in Brazil as the crop year switched to a lower-producing (off-season) year. However, we expect global coffee production to rebound by a firm 6.5% in 2018/19. A recovery in Brazil's production as the crop switches back to a higher-producing year will account for over 80% of the global increase in coffee output. Rising production in several other Latin American coffee producers as well as Asian growers will have a marginal but positive impact on coffee output. We are forecasting a 1.8% drop in global coffee production in 2019/20, with Brazil switching to another off-season year. We are currently forecasting only mild production increases elsewhere, which will fail to compensate for the decline in Brazil. This is based on the assumption that recent low coffee prices will hamper output in the medium term as cutbacks on pesticide and fertiliser usage affect production levels.
Coffee production is Brazil is estimated to reach record levels in 2018/19
In Brazil, notwithstanding the shift from an on-season crop in 2018/19 to an off-season crop in 2019/20, production in both years is forecast to be high by historical standards. Although some arabica-producing areas reported dryness earlier in 2018-delaying harvest progress-recent weather conditions have been much better, which will bolster prospects for 2018/19. Local observers have stated that there is potential for a bumper crop, with some even suggesting that output of up to 65m bags is possible, which would be a record high by some margin (to date, the highest production was recorded in 2012/13, at 55.4m bags). We believe that this figure is out of reach and are forecasting coffee production of 59.5m bags for the 2018/19 season. This is above the forecast of 58m bags from Conab, Brazil's food statistics agency, and the 57.1m bags projected by the government statistics agency, but below the forecast of 60.2m bags from the US Department of Agriculture (USDA). The strong result is likely to reflect a firm recovery in both arabica and robusta production (which are expected to account for three-quarters and one-quarter of total output respectively). Our expectation that coffee production will fall to a still-strong 54m bags in 2019/20 is based on the belief that the continued weakness of the local currency will continue to provide an incentive to growers.
Coffee production in Vietnam is set to stabilise at historically high levels
In Vietnam, supportive weather conditions led to a sharp 15.5% increase in the 2017/18 crop, with coffee production coming in at 29.5m bags. We expect a slight decline in coffee production in 2018/19 and 2019/20, although at around 29m bags output levels will remain high compared with recent years. These forecasts are more optimistic than the authorities' projections for medium-term coffee production, which tend to be fairly low. However, recent weather conditions have been relatively supportive, while government efforts to replant 140,000 ha of coffee, targeting 25,000 ha a year, as well as a rising arabica crop will support still-firm output, particularly given that yields from new bushes are typically higher. Firm demand for robusta in the domestic market and other Asian countries will also encourage growers. We expect coffee output to decline by 0.8% per year in 2018/19-2019/20.
Output growth is Mexico and Central America will flatten
Coffee production also stood at historically high levels in Mexico and Central America in 2017/18, growing by 7.6% to close to 21m bags (surpassing the 20m-mark for the first time on record). After several outbreaks of disease in recent years greater use of fungicides and fertiliser boosted coffee production, with weather conditions also proving supportive. We expect coffee production in the sub-region to stabilise at around current levels in 2018/19 and 2019/20. We expect some countries to register slightly weaker production levels, in particular the sub-region's largest producer, Honduras, where output will moderate after an exceptionally strong 2017/18. Guatemala will also register a decline owing to the effects of a volcanic eruption in the south-west of the country in June, which is believed to have wiped out 1% of the country's coffee plantations. However, this will be offset by moderate rises in coffee production elsewhere in the sub-region, including Mexico and Nicaragua, which will benefit from ongoing programmes to rejuvenate ageing coffee plantations.
Colombian production is set to recover after a weather-induced fall in 2017/18
After five years of rising coffee production in Colombia output fell by 4.3% in 2017/18 to 14m bags as cloudy weather conditions affected flowering on coffee bushes early in the season, which was followed by very wet weather. However, the sector's fundamentals are strong, including a comparatively high percentage of rust-resistant bushes, and as such we do not expect the decline to persist. Recent additional planting in existing plantations has focused on improving yields, which at 18 bags/ha in 2016 were much lower than in other large growers (27 bags/ha in Brazil and 35 bags/ha in Vietnam). As a result we expect production to recover in 2018/19 and 2019/20, with output growing by 5% and 2% respectively. Towards the end of the forecast period the 2016 peace agreement between the government and the then FARC rebels will allow coffee cultivation to expand in previously isolated areas of the country (although we view the government's statements that output could reach 20m bags by 2020 as overly optimistic).
Coffee production is likely to recover but remain fairly weak in Indonesia
Indonesia's ambitious expansion plans for the coffee sector, which include more than doubling production within five years to make the country the world's second-largest producer after Brazil, have been completely derailed. The El Niño weather phenomenon brought excessively dry weather to the main coffee-growing areas, affecting the harvests in both 2016/17 and 2017/18. Even assuming a 5.5% increase in 2018/19 and a 2.6% rise in 2019/20, at just 11.8m bags output will remain low by historical standards. Low average yields-at only around one-fifth of the levels recorded in Vietnam-reflect high levels of structural inefficiency in the sector, which we do not expect to be tackled during the forecast period.

Production prospects in Africa, which accounts for around 11% of total global coffee output, are relatively bright. Many of the continent's coffee producers have very low levels of output; together, Ethiopia and Uganda account for 70% of African coffee output. Production rose firmly in both countries in 2017/18, mainly on the back of better weather conditions. We expect output to continue to rise in 2018/19 and 2019/20, reflecting an extensive reseeding programme in recent years, an expansion of the coffee-growing area and domestic efforts to streamline the organisation of the sector.
Stocks and prices
After falling marginally in 2017/18, we expect global coffee stocks to rise in 2018/19 on the back of a sharp rise in production, coupled with continued sales of stocks by exporting countries, with producers taking advantage of weak local currencies against the US dollar to boost locally denominated profits. However, with coffee production falling and consumption continuing to rise (albeit more mildly) in 2019/20, the market balance is expected to tip into deficit. By end-2019/20 we expect global stocks to have fallen to 30.3m bags, which will support a partial recovery in prices.

Coffee prices are increasingly reactive to changes in the strength of the US dollar
Arabica prices have fallen more or less steadily since the beginning of 2017, standing at an average of US$1.25/lb in August 2018 (compared with close to US$1.70/lb in January 2017). Futures prices are trading even lower, with arabica for December delivery falling below the US$1/lb mark in early September (a 12-year low). Given that the global market is estimated to have registered a slight deficit in 2017/18, the fall in prices-to levels not seen since 2013-is curious. We believe that coffee prices are increasingly driven by investment trends, with swings in sentiment often caused by a spate of positive or negative news on the supply side. Coffee prices are also becoming increasingly reactive to changes in the strength of the US dollar, with dollar depreciation tending to lead to higher coffee prices. In recent months speculation about bumper production levels in Brazil in 2018/19 has pushed prices lower. The fact that several large exporting countries are continuing to sell spare stock to take advantage of weak local currencies is also suppressing prices, because this has been accompanied by a rise in coffee stocks in importing countries, which in turn may contain demand in the future.
Aside from positive signs from Brazilian producers, continued high levels of coffee output from other main producers are likely to keep prices suppressed in the near term. We expect prices to fall further in the fourth quarter of 2018, with an estimated average price of US$1.31/lb for the full year representing a 12.9% year on year decline for arabica. Given that the next off-season in Brazil (2019/20) is likely to hit market confidence during the 2019 calendar year, we forecast a recovery in prices to an average of US$1.39/lb in 2019, before a continued rise to US$1.56/lb in 2020 as the global market balance slips into deficit.
Prices for cheaper robusta will also decline during much of 2018 as bean supply picks up. We expect prices to average 85 US cents/lb in 2018-a 15.7% year-on-year decline-before rising to 90 US cents/lb in 2019 and US$1.03/lb in 2020.

Maize
Demand
World demand for maize has increased at an astonishing pace during the past two decades, rising from just 600m tonnes at the turn of the millennium to a projected 1.09bn tonnes in 2018/19, up by 2.9% compared with the previous year. Provisional demand projections for 2019/20 are for further, albeit more modest growth of 1.7%, to 1.1bn tonnes. Apart from 2012/13, when US crops were badly affected by drought, consumption has increased each season, with growth averaging 3.1% per year over 2012/13-2016/17. While stocks mostly tightened through to 2006/07, the spike in demand has lately been more than offset by an even steeper rise in production, resulting in a build-up of supplies. Maize is primarily used as a feed ingredient, which accounts for around 55% of total usage.
Amid broad-based gains in world meat production, especially of poultry and pork, demand for high-starch, high-energy feed maize continues to trend higher almost everywhere, with growth averaging around 2% per year. Booming demand for biofuels, and to a lesser extent other sugars and starches, has boosted the use for industrial processing at an even faster rate. Led by gains in the US and China, world industrial use has surged from around 75m tonnes 20 years ago to a projected 305m tonnes in the 2018/19 marketing year. Helped by a series of large crops in Sub-Saharan Africa, food maize demand has also seen relatively firm growth in recent seasons and is forecast to reach 123m tonnes in 2018/19.
World feed demand will rise by 3% in 2018/19
Growth in global demand for meat and other animal proteins shows no sign of slowing, with consumption gains driven by population growth, greater purchasing power and changes in diets and tastes. Maize is an extremely useful ingredient in animal feed, which can contribute to rapid livestock weight gain. We expect 3% annual growth in the use of maize for livestock feed in 2018/19, broadly in line with the previous year, with overall demand touching a new record of 621m tonnes. The EU and China are likely to account for much of the increase, with notable gains also expected in Russia, Brazil, Iran, Saudi Arabia and Vietnam.
The EU is a huge consumer of maize for livestock feed, with use seen averaging 57m tonnes/year (t/y) in recent seasons. Compound feed manufacturers across the bloc consume near-equal amounts of maize, barley and wheat in most years, with price and availability determining how much of each is used in a particular year. The 2018/19 season will in large part be shaped by the drought that has occurred across much of northern Europe. As a result, wheat availabilities are much tighter than normal, while pastures are bare in many countries, raising the need for additional feed grain supplies. Based on current price spreads, maize is best-placed to meet the shortfall. Feed consumption is seen climbing to a new record high of 62.5m tonnes, up by 7% from 2017/18. With question-marks over the size of local maize crops, the additional supplies will come from a 25% rise in imports, seen climbing to 21.5m tonnes in 2017/18 (July-June). At that level, the EU would by some distance be the world's biggest importer of maize, surpassing the imports of second-placed Mexico by some 5m tonnes. The majority of this is likely to be sourced from Ukraine and Brazil, although additional purchases from Serbia and Canada are possible. Following the mid-June implementation of a 25% tariff on US maize imports by the EU, supplies from that country are not expected to be competitive.
African swine fever could affect demand for feed in China
African swine fever, a highly contagious viral disease for which there is no vaccine, has recently been detected for the first time in China and is now spreading rapidly. The virus is transmitted by ticks or direct contact between animals, as well as by contaminated animal feed or meat products, where it can survive for months. The virus is not harmful to humans but is often lethal for domestic pigs and wild boars. Infections have also been reported this year in parts of the EU, as well as in Russia and Ukraine. However, with half of the world's pig population located in China, this latest outbreak is by far the most alarming. The local authorities have moved quickly to contain the infection, culling thousands of pigs, banning the transport of live animals and closing markets in affected areas. At this early stage of the outbreak the potential impact on animal feed demand remains unclear. In the short term, any sharp reductions in slaughter rates might actually strengthen spot feed demand, while in the longer term much will depend on the severity of the outbreak and how many animals are affected. At an emergency regional meeting called by the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) in early September, officials cautioned that the infection would likely spread to other parts of Asia.
World industrial demand set to rise again in 2018/19
Industrial processors are projected to use 305m tonnes of maize in 2018/19, up by 3% year on year to another record high. Robust global GDP growth continues to drive demand for maize-based industrial goods, including starch, while use for ethanol fuel is also increasing in the US and Brazil. There is potential for a steep rise in maize-based biofuel production in China, where the authorities have announced plans for an ambitious nationwide ethanol blending programme, similar to the one that led to the recent boom in the US.

A partial breakthrough in NAFTA negotiations
US maize farmers and exporters were relieved by the announcement in late August of a preliminary trade agreement between the US and Mexico. Negotiators concluded a deal to change parts of the North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA), while at the same time maintaining duty-free access for agricultural products. NAFTA negotiations with Canada are ongoing and will remain crucial for the completion of the renegotiation process.
Supply
Global maize production has increased by an average of 3% per year over the past two decades, rising from less than 600m tonnes in 1999/2000 to more than 1bn tonnes since 2016/17. During this period production has declined on just five occasions, typically as a result of spells of difficult cropping weather. In general, production has been driven steadily upward by increases in both areas and yields. Amid strengthening demand for animal feed and industrial products, high market prices have encouraged additional plantings almost everywhere. New seed varieties, fertiliser and better farming practices have also been used with great effect to push up average yields, which are now approaching 6 tonnes/ha, compared with 4.4 tonnes/ha in the late 1990s.
The 2018/19 the world supply outlook for maize currently appears fairly comfortable, especially when compared with wheat, production of which is expected to decline by around 6% year on year. An expected shift in feed demand away from wheat to maize places extra importance on the outcome of this year's maize harvest in the US-the world's largest producer and exporter. Yields currently appear encouraging, implying that the US should be able to meet any predicted uptick in demand. South America remains a major area of uncertainty, as 2018/19 crops are not yet in the ground. Based on increases in September for the US and Ukraine, our 2018/19 global crop estimate is raised by 6m tonnes to 1,056m tonnes, potentially the second-largest crop on record. The outlook for 2019/20 remains highly provisional at this stage. However, assuming a rise in US sowings and potentially bigger crops in South America, global output could tick higher, to around 1,062m tonnes, marking a rise of 0.5% year on year.
US output is seen unchanged in 2018/19
July and August are the critical months for US crops such as maize and soybeans. Summer weather this year has been broadly favourable across large swathes of the US Corn Belt, with mostly seasonable temperatures interspersed with regular rainfall, especially in Illinois and Iowa, the two core producing states. Crops have developed rapidly in many areas, while crop tours conducted over the past month or so have mostly confirmed excellent yield potential. Indeed, the survey-based analysis from the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) suggests that record yields-possibly as high as 11.2 tonnes/ha-should be in prospect. In conjunction with advanced farming techniques and ever more sophisticated technology, the latest hybrid seeds have performed extremely well in recent years. With excellent productivity seen offsetting this season's drop in area, 2018/19 production is forecast to be almost unchanged compared with the year before, at 370.5m tonnes.
Smaller area and lower yields are expected in Brazil
While the global focus has already shifted to the 2018/19 crop outlook, Brazil's 2017/18 season is still far from over. With harvesting still not finished, our total production estimate is held unchanged at 82m tonnes, down by 16.2% from the previous year. Following a spike in internal transport costs and a drop in the value of the Brazilian Real, the cost of farm inputs, including fertiliser, has risen sharply in recent months, boosting production costs in the run-up to planting of the 2018/19 maize and soybean crops. Continued disagreements about internal trucking costs have also slowed physical deliveries of fertiliser from the southern ports to the main producing areas. Very strong competition for soybeans is again expected to impact planting of the full-season (first) crop, predominantly grown in traditional producing areas in the south of the country. However, assuming producers expand soybean plantings in central and western parts, there could be large areas of farmland primed for sowing the second (safrinha) maize crop after the oilseeds are collected in the early part of 2018. Assuming an overall rise and area and normal yield levels, the 2018/19 is forecast to rise by 14.6% year on year, before growth moderates to 3.2% in the 2019/20 season.
Emergency taxes on primary exports will be imposed in Argentina
Soon after assuming office in December 2015 the Argentinean president, Mauricio Macri, moved quickly to abolish export taxes on wheat and maize and introduce a series of gradual cuts for soybeans and products. The move was welcomed by farmers and contributed to a renewed willingness to incorporate maize and wheat back into crop rotations, which had been increasingly dominated by soybeans. However, with the government seeking additional income streams as part of efforts to improve the fiscal situation ahead of a new funding deal with the IMF, and with traders deemed to have benefited from a massive slump in the value of the peso in recent months, the president has opted to introduce emergency taxes on commodity exports. Effective until the end of December 2020, maize exports will be subject to a levy of 4 pesos per US dollar exported, currently equivalent to a tax of 10.5%. The announcement coincided with the start of the 2018/19 sowing season. With interest rates also climbing sharply in recent weeks, potentially raising financing costs for input-intensive maize crops, there are now considerable doubts about maize/soybean cropping mixes for the season ahead. For now we maintain our expectation of a modest increase in area, which could support production of around 41.5m tonnes, a rise of almost 30%. However, with so much uncertainty, this figure could be subject to revision in the months ahead.
A larger than average harvest is predicted in Ukraine
After earlier dryness, the weather in July and August across much of Ukraine was much more favourable for 2018/19 maize crops, boosting yields. Harvesting has now started in all regions, with very good results reported so far. Forecast production is raised by 1.5m tonnes from previously, to 29m tonnes, up by one-fifth from the season before and potentially enough for exports of 23m tonnes, possibly the highest on record. Overseas demand is expected to be very strong in the year ahead, especially from buyers in the EU and China.
Sowings in Russia dropped by 12% year on year
Our 2018/19 production forecast for Russia, where maize has become an increasingly important export crop in recent years, is unchanged at 12.6m tonnes, with the risks skewed very much to the downside. Farmers had been expected to sow even more maize this season, but difficult weather conditions have prompted many to turn instead to oilseeds, planting additional acreage to sunflowerseed, rapeseed and soybeans. Hot weather in key growing regions could also affect yield potential.

Stocks and prices
With the authorities in China keen to reduce burdensome stockpiles, overall supplies have tightened, and global stocks are projected to decline in both 2018/19 and 2019/20. We expect global stocks to ease back to 269m tonnes by end-2018/19, 3% below the previous five-year average. As China remains only a small player on the world stage, importing less than 4m tonnes in a typical year and exporting only limited amounts to North Korea, it is helpful to exclude notional estimates of Chinese inventories (no official data are published) in an analysis of world stocks. Because of some weather problems and overall strong export demand, cumulative inventories in the major suppliers (Argentina, Brazil, Ukraine and US) are forecast to tighten to 56.3m tonnes at end-2018/19, which would imply a decrease of 10% year on year, potentially the lowest level since 2015/16. While forecasts remain highly notional, a similar trend is projected in 2019/20. Led by further drawdowns in China, world stocks could shrink to around 221m tonnes, including 52.4m tonnes in the top exporters.
Using year-end stockpiles as a gauge for measuring market supplies is the most widely used tool for evaluating the size of surpluses or deficits in a particular year. Leaving aside difficulties with definition and whether stocks can actually be accurately judged at any one particular point in the season, the differences in marketing years between the biggest producers mean that any efforts to assess cumulative stocks are subject to even more uncertainties. For example, with South American stocks typically at their lowest in February and those in the US at their lowest in August, any analysis of combined stocks is inherently flawed, since inventories are never as low (or as high) as suggested by just adding together stocks in individual countries.
China's stock estimates are highly provisional
In mid-July China's State Council announced a country-wide inspection of the quantity and quality of national and local grain reserves, to be conducted over 15 months. The checks will focus on the volume, quality and location of state stocks, and final results are due to be submitted to the State Council by the end of October 2019. According to local press reports, similar inspections were carried out in 2001 and 2009, but the results were not made publicly available. It is therefore unlikely that the outcome of the next survey will be publicly released, although the results are likely to play a major role in determining future policy decisions. We expect stocks to be drawn down in 2018-19 as the government seeks to boost domestic consumption, particularly in the biofuels industry. However, given that these stocks are primarily held as a domestic food security measure, this is unlikely to influence global prices.
US ending stocks are expected to drop back to 44.2m tonnes by the end of 2018/19, down by 14% from the year before and potentially a three-year low. Given reduced competition from Brazil, large supplies continue to be sent for export, with ending stocks down by around 14m tonnes from the 30-year highs seen at the end of 2017/18. While supplies are tightening, it should be stressed that the absolute level of stocks remains fairly comfortable and only marginally lower than the average.

Average prices are above year-ago levels
The volatility in global maize markets continued in August. After initially gaining on a continued improvement in the US export demand profile and spillover from a rally in wheat, prices turned lower in the second half of the month, dropping by a net 6% from our previous forecast. The recent declines were mainly tied to expectations of a bumper US crop, with a number of scouting tours mostly confirming anecdotal reports of excellent yield potential. As at September 7th average prices were around 9% up on year-earlier levels. Despite much smaller 2017/18 crops in Brazil and Argentina, prices in South America were only a few dollars higher than equivalent US values as new crop supplies began to replenish the exportable pipeline. Traders were also keen to maintain competitiveness with exports out of the US.
In light of a tighter world supply outlook we continue to expect prices to bounce higher from current levels, especially if, as expected, the US-China trade war has little impact on US maize exports. However, given the likelihood of another very large US crop, our price forecast profile has been pared back. US prices (fob Gulf) are now seen as averaging US$176/tonne in 2018, compared with an average of US$195/ tonne in the five-year period ending 2017. Price growth is likely to moderate over the forecast period, with growth of 4.6% per year on average during 2019-20.

Palm oil
Demand
There have been mixed trends in palm oil consumption in the 2017/18 season. Imports into two of the major consumers, India and China, have failed to live up to expectations, while imports into the other major importer, the EU, have been sluggish. Growth in consumption has relied more on the producers of palm oil, notably Indonesia but also Malaysia, both of which recorded double-digit growth rates. Overall, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects palm oil consumption in 2017/18 to rise by 4.5% year on year. While this is above recent averages, it is disappointing in the context of production levels. The energy sector offers the best prospects for improved growth, and we expect above-average consumption growth in the next two years.
India will remain the largest market for palm oil
In India, palm oil demand was below expectation throughout 2017/18. Although this is in part accounted for by the imposition of higher import duties, there is concern that it represents a more fundamental shift in demand away from palm oil to other vegetable oils. We have again revised down our consumption estimate for 2017/18. It now seems likely that consumption will fail to match the 2016/17 total of 9.4m tonnes. The import of palm oil via Bangladesh and other countries via a free-trade agreement has the potential to undermine the new import tariff levels. This, coupled with increasing price competitiveness at international level, should mean that Indian palm oil consumption will grow again in 2018/19. Our current forecast is for consumption of 9.7m tonnes, representing an above-average growth rate of 4.3%. However, given the experience of 2017/18, this forecast may yet turn out to be too optimistic.
Indonesia's biodiesel sector will post solid growth in 2018-19
Indonesian biodiesel production is running ahead of expectations, reflecting the increased competiveness of palm oil as a feedstock following a build-up of local stocks. Improving biodiesel exports, notably to China and the EU, and greater offtake in the domestic market have both contributed to this recent growth. Our estimate of 2017/18 palm oil consumption in Indonesia is raised again. Consumption of 10.4m tonnes is 13% higher than in 2016/17 and makes Indonesia easily the largest consumer of palm oil. There is plenty of spare production capacity in Indonesia, and the authorities plan to increase the domestic incorporation further. From September 2018 all diesel engines are required to run on B20 biodiesel. As a result, we expect consumption to rise by a further 4.5% in 2018/19. Indonesia is also trying to secure palm-based biodiesel facilities overseas by linking its purchase of Boeing and Airbus aeroplanes with the establishment of biodiesel production facilities using palm oil in the US and the EU, which we expect to contribute to further demand growth in 2019/20.
China's palm oil demand is hindered by soybean competition
In China, palm oil continues to face strong competition from soybean oil, but falling palm oil prices and a modest recovery in the instant noodles sector have improved the outlook. We continue to estimate that consumption has risen by 6.4% year on year in 2017/18. While this has ended four consecutive years of decline, this growth level has failed to live up to early-season optimism. The bilateral trade war between the US and China presents an upside risk to palm oil demand; however, there are few indications to date of any increase in Chinese imports of palm oil as a result of this. At the moment we are forecasting modest growth of only 2.4% in 2018/19. While it had been hoped that the domestic biodiesel industry would import significant quantities of palm oil to process, it now seems that imports of biodiesel are the more likely route to meet China's bio-energy requirements.
Energy demand in the EU will rise, boosting usage
In the EU palm oil has become a more attractive feedstock for energy production. This is encouraging growth in palm oil imports and consumption, despite increased competition from imported biodiesel. This growth is expected to continue into the 2018/19-2019/20 seasons. While the long-term future of palm oil in the EU is clouded by legislative issues, we now expect slightly higher demand growth throughout the forecast period, reflecting growing energy use and stable consumption in the food sector.
Biodiesel consumption in Malaysia is set to rise
Malaysian palm oil demand growth has been limited by delays in implementing biodiesel incorporation mandates. The implementation of the B10 mandate has been persistently delayed-the most recent government announcements indicate implementation in the second half of 2019. On the plus side, Malaysian exports of biodiesel have been comparatively buoyant, and domestic demand for B7 biodiesel is also reported to be improving. We have increased our estimate of consumption in 2017/18 to 3.2m tonnes, 16.2% above 2016/17 levels. Our forecasts for palm oil consumption in 2018/19 and 2019/20 show good growth, reflecting the improving outlook for biodiesel exports, and to a lesser extent the planned implementation of the B10 incorporation mandate.
Consumption prospects in other countries are broadly positive
The geographical markets for palm oil are diverse, with the top five consumers accounting for less than 55% of global consumption. There have been sharp increases in exports to a number of these destinations, including Pakistan, Iran, the Philippines and various other Asian and African destinations. The largest of these "other" consumers, Pakistan, is likely to show sustained growth, given that attempts to encourage local oilseeds production have been mostly unsuccessful. With palm oil prices continuing to fall, there is sustained interest in palm oil from these other consumers.

Supply
The main changes to our output projections from our previous report reflect the the fact that the levels of production in Malaysia continue to disappoint. As a result, we now expect global palm oil production in 2017/18 to be just under 70m tonnes, more than 0.4 tonnes lower than our previous estimate. This reduced total still represents above-average annual growth of 5.7%. A recovery in Malaysian production and continuing growth in Indonesian output should result in 2018/19 palm oil production of more than 72m tonnes-a slowdown in overall growth of 3.1%. This chiefly reflects the slow expansion in the mature area and virtually no yield growth owing to tree stress and potentially lower input use.
Yield cycle may offset favourable growing conditions
Indonesian production of palm oil is now rising seasonally, but we expect output in 2017/18 to remain at 38.3m tonnes, unchanged from our previous forecast. While this growth rate is below recent levels, it is building on particularly rapid growth of 16.4% in 2016/17. We continue to expect good yields over the next 6-9 months, although there are early signs that the rate of growth in yields is slowing. Indeed, slow yield growth has been a persistent feature of Indonesian production: output growth has been more a reflection of increases in harvested area. Despite the slowdown in plantings, the mature area for next season will be higher, albeit by just 3.4%. A modest yield increase would result in palm oil production of just under 40m tonnes, representing below-average output growth. The 40m-tonne barrier is unlikely to be breached until 2019/20.
Malaysian output continues to disappoint
Malaysia's palm oil production continues to disappoint. While output has resumed its normal seasonal increase, recent output levels are almost 20% below those recorded over the same period in 2016/17. This would appear to be the result of some workers taking extended leave and a higher than expected replanting rate, as well as a downturn in the biological yield cycle. We have again revised down our estimate for 2017/18 production to just below 20m tonnes. Some local estimates put the total even lower. Despite the downgrade output will still be some 5.8% higher than in 2016/17. The 2018/19 season should see an increase in average yields, although any improvements will inhibited by an ageing tree population. We have adopted a relatively cautious production forecast of 20.4m tonnes in 2018/19, only 2% higher than in 2017/18.

Thailand output exceeds expectations
There has been a recent slowdown in yield growth in both Thailand and Colombia. The increase in yields in Thailand during 2017/18 has been especially strong, reflecting good weather and favourable oil extraction rates. While our estimate for 2017/18 is little changed, we expect a reduction in output in 2018/19 as tree stress and the probable use of lower inputs reduce yields. In Colombia, we have reduced both our estimate of output in 2017/18 and our production forecast for 2018/19. There remains potential for further land for palm oil cultivation without any deforestation issues. Recent yields have been well above year-earlier levels but should revert to more normal levels in 2018/19 and 2019/20. Some other smaller palm oil-producing countries, such as Honduras, will also see solid output growth in 2017/18.
Stocks and prices
Palm oil stocks in both Indonesia and Malaysia have continued to rise. By contrast, stock levels in importing countries are at normal or slightly below normal levels. Overall, 2017/18 continues to show a market surplus, albeit a smaller one than previously forecast. At the end of the season stocks will be the equivalent of 65 days of consumption. This is below the level recorded in 2014/15 but still above normal levels. The 2018/19 season looks set to show another (albeit smaller) market surplus, while early projections suggest that the 2019/20 season may be more or less in balance.

Rising stock levels will push prices down further
As predicted, physical palm oil prices continued to weaken in August. Indeed, the decrease was larger than expected, with prices standing at less than US$600/tonne, a level that we had not expected to see until mid-2019. Futures prices traded within a narrow range during the month, suggesting that market participants believe that the market has reached bottom or is close to it. However, we continue to expect global palm oil prices to drift lower during the rest of 2018 and into 2019. These predictions are based on our expectation of only moderate consumption levels during 2018/19. On current projections, prices should tend to stabilise and even increase as the 2019/20 season approaches. Further downgrades to Malaysian production forecasts or a pick-up in demand are the factors most likely to lead to a more bullish outlook.

Rapeseed oil
Demand
Despite higher estimates of rapeseed oil consumption in the EU, China and India, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global rapeseed oil consumption to fall in 2017/18 for the third consecutive season. At just over 25m tonnes, 2017/18 consumption is at its lowest level since 2012/13. Rapeseed oil is suffering from increasing price competition from sunflowerseed oil, which has not been offset by higher mineral oil prices. Recent increases in rapeseed oil prices, following downgrades to future production prospects, are likely to constrain consumption growth in 2018/19 further. We have reduced our projections of 2018/19 consumption in almost all the major consumers and are forecasting an overall total of 25.3m tonnes, just 0.5% above 2017/18 levels. Further downward revisions may be necessary.
EU consumption is threatened by biodiesel imports
For most of the 2017/18 season the use of rapeseed oil in the EU's biodiesel sector has faced strong competition from recycled cooking oil and from imported biodiesel. Nevertheless, there has recently been an upturn in demand for rapeseed oil from the biodiesel sector, which has prompted us to increase our estimate of 2017/18 consumption to just over 10m tonnes. However, the reduction in likely local availability will cut short any consumption gains during 2018/19. We expect consumption to fall to 9.9m tonnes and to remain fairly flat in 2019/20. This forecast implies significant imports of either rapeseed for local crushing or rapeseed oil, which will depend on the final outcome of the Canadian and Australian crops.
Chinese consumption is limited by supply constraints
In China, local rapeseed oil availability is limited, despite recent improvements in local crushing of imported rapeseed, and this has been acting as a constraint on consumption. Rapeseed oil imports into China have continued to rise, justifying a further increase in our 2017/18 estimate of consumption to 4.8m tonnes. Despite the increase, this total still represents the lowest consumption level in the last ten years. Higher local estimates of rapeseed production in 2018/19 should help to boost consumption. However, competition for imported rapeseed for local crushing as well as for imported rapeseed oil is likely to be intense. At this stage we project 2018/19 rapeseed oil consumption at just over 5.2m tonnes; given the competition for available supplies, this total may turn out to be too optimistic.
India's consumption will rebound in 2017/18
In India, 2017/18 rapeseed oil consumption has been encouraged by improved local availability and strong GDP growth. Rapeseed oil is the preferred oil in north and central India, which typically absorbs local production along with a small, but increasing, volume of imports. However, import volumes are being inhibited by high import duties. With local rapeseed oil production expected to contract, we anticipate that 2018/19 consumption will also be lower, with consumption falling back to 2.6m tonnes, some 5% less than in 2017/18 but still above the previous five-year average.
Only modest demand growth is likely in the US market
In the US, rapeseed oil has been losing out to cheaper soybean oil over recent months. This pattern has continued, and our assessment of rapeseed oil consumption in the US is further reduced. This position is likely to recur in 2018/19, inhibiting any substantial recovery in rapeseed oil use.
Several smaller consumers which switched away from rapeseed oil in 2016/17 have recently returned to the market. However, growth in rapeseed oil consumption among this "other" consumers category during 2017/18 has been constrained by more competitive sunflowerseed oil.
