Supply
A late surge in rapeseed crushings in the EU, Canada and India has resulted in an increase in our estimate of global rapeseed oil production in 2017/18. Our estimate of 2017/18 output now stands at 25.6m tonnes, almost 2% higher than in the 2016/17 season. However, prospects for global rapeseed production in 2018/19 have been adversely affected by dry conditions in the EU, Canada and Australia. The major impact to date has been in the EU and Canada, with a substantial downgrading of crop estimates. Even allowing for a significant reduction in rapeseed stocks, rapeseed oil output in 2018/19 is likely to be below 2017/18 levels, at just above 25m tonnes.
Weaker demand is weighing on EU rapeseed oil production
Recent levels of EU rapeseed oil production have exceeded earlier expectations. For the 2017/18 season as a whole we now expect production to reach 10.1m tonnes, less than 1% lower than in 2016/17. However, the 2018/19 crop has been badly affected by the hot and dry summer. Estimates of the size of the harvest continue to fall, with the latest European Commission forecast putting the total at only 19.2m tonnes. This would be the smallest crop since 2008/09. Even allowing for high carry-in stocks and higher rapeseed imports, 2018/19 rapeseed oil production will be affected by the low seed production level. For the moment we have retained our forecast of EU rapeseed oil output of 9.5m tonnes in 2018/19. However, this is contingent on a significant increase in rapeseed imports, which may be at risk if the more pessimistic forecasts of Canadian and Australian seed production are realised.
China will rely on imports for oil production
Chinese rapeseed oil production is becoming increasingly dependent on imported seed supplies. Our estimate of 2017/18 rapeseed oil production remains unchanged at 3.7m tonnes, only 1.7% higher than 2016/17. The uncertainty surrounding the impact of tariffs on imports of US soybeans has not yet impacted rapeseed import levels. Despite dry conditions in many areas, the rapeseed crop appears to have reached the earlier forecast of 5.3m tonnes. We continue to expect rapeseed oil production to expand in 2018/19, the second consecutive year of growth. Early indications of increased volumes of rapeseed imports, along with the bigger domestic crop, have encouraged us to raise our 2018/19 rapeseed oil production forecast to 3.9m tonnes. Demand for rapeseed meal is reported to be increasing, helping to increase rapeseed crush margins in China.
Canada's 2017/18 harvest will rise
2017/18 Canadian canola oil production continues to exceed expectations, encouraged by strong exports of canola oil. An upward revision to our estimate means that 2017/18 canola oil output could reach almost 4.2m tonnes. For 2018/19 Statistics Canada's most recent estimate puts canola production at only 19.2m tonnes. This is well below most trade estimates, although a reduction had been expected as a result of the hot and dry conditions in many areas through August. Trade assessments suggest a crop just above 20m tonnes, which is consistent with the most recent harvest reports. Canadian canola oil production is typically more dependent on market developments than on the availability of seed for crushing. Yet the smaller crop estimates suggest that competition for available canola seed for crushing will be intense. We have therefore reduced our canola oil production forecast in to 4.3m tonnes in 2018/19, although we expect a rebound to 4.6m tonnes in 2019/20.
India's production is set to grow owing to higher rapeseed imports
In India, 2017/18 rapeseed oil production has exceeded previous expectations. We now estimate that output reached a new record of more than 2.5m tonnes. For 2018/19 the area under rapeseed is expected to show a small increase, in part reflecting the government's actions to boost production (measures include higher vegetable import tariffs and increased minimum support prices). At this early stage it is thought that yields will not match the 2017/18 high levels, but given good planting conditions they are likely to remain above average; this would result in a harvest only slightly smaller than 2017/18. For the moment we have retained our forecast of 2018/19 rapeseed oil production of 2.4m tonnes.
Australian production could be constrained by dry conditions
There are increasing concerns over the 2018/19 Australian canola crop. Estimates now put the likely output at 3.1m tonnes, 15% lower than 2017/18. The estimate of 2018/19 Ukraine rapeseed production is raised and now stands at 2.7m tonnes. Rapeseed is reportedly the most profitable of the oilseed crops in Ukraine, and further expansion of the area planted to rapeseed is expected.

Stocks and prices
We estimate global rapeseed oil stocks to have risen in 2017/18 on the back of a market surplus. However, the surplus is estimated to be lower than previously thought, given revisions to our supply and consumption estimates in this report. When measured as a share of consumption, oil stocks will remain well below the average in recent years. Rapeseed stocks will also be below normal levels at end-2017/18. The production downgrade for 2018/19 means that the season will now see a market deficit, with rapeseed oil stocks ending the season at very low levels. Rapeseed stocks are also expected to be below normal at the end of 2018/19, reaching levels (measured in terms of days of consumption) not seen since 2012/13.

Concern over production leads to firmer prices
The impending tightness of the rapeseed oil market is being reflected in increasing prices. Physical prices of rapeseed oil continued to rise in August and are now trading at a high premium relative to other major vegetable oils. Futures prices for rapeseed have also been firmer, although they tended to ease in the latter part of August. The downgrading of crop estimates has reinforced the bullish outlook for rapeseed oil prices, and we continue to expect prices to rise steadily for the foreseeable future. Although gains will be constrained by the prices of other oils, rapeseed oil prices are expected to exceed US$900/tonne by the third quarter of 2019.

Rice
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that global rice consumption will rise by 1.4% in 2018/19, to a record of just over 500m tonnes. As is usual, Asian markets, which account for an estimated 90% of world use, will drive the predicted expansion, notably via increased demand in India. Smaller increases are likely elsewhere in East and South Asia, as well as in Latin America and Africa. Prospects for the following season remain tentative, especially since we are referring to an international trade year that will not commence until January 1st 2020. Nevertheless, global demand is expected to continue on an upward trajectory in 2019/20, again rising by 1.4%, to reach 507m tonnes.
Rice feed use may edge up on increased uptake in China
The use of rice in animal feed mixes could actually edge up in both years, largely owing to events in China, by far the biggest consumer. With the government keen to avoid the potential for a further build-up of inventories, it is looking to scale back production and possibly imports. In addition, both domestic and export markets offer another way of reducing inventories. While food use per head could edge lower, it is likely that consumption in feed sectors could grow further as the government encourages the disposal of inventories through feed channels.
Japan has utilised stocks of imported rice in feed mixes, but data suggest that demand for domestic rice feed may have peaked. Overall, the non-food usage of rice globally (including by the industrial sector) will continue to account for only a small proportion of overall demand.
Trade should remain robust in 2019-20
Africa and Asia account for more than two-thirds of all rice imports, primarily white and parboiled grades sourced from Thailand, India, Pakistan and Vietnam. In Sub-Saharan Africa, in particular, a significant share of demand-mainly for high-quality white and parboiled supplies-is met through imports. Following record global rice purchases in 2017, of 45.4m tonnes, many Asian buyers are likely to be well stocked. Furthermore, strong demand for Thai rice from African buyers in 2017 was largely linked to availabilities of attractively priced rice from the government's stockpile. In light of strong demand from Indonesia, Bangladesh and the Philippines in the first half of the year, we expected global trade to increase by around 4%, to some 47m tonnes in 2018, with similar volumes likely in 2019. In 2020 we expect demand from key buyers in Asia and Africa to push up trade to a high of almost 48m tonnes-more than 50% above the level seen a decade earlier. Nevertheless, it is worth noting that trade would still acount for less than 10% of total production or consumption-an exceptionally low share when compared to wheat (the other major food grain) or soybeans.
China's imports are likely to fall over the forecast period
China is by far the world's largest consumer of rice, accounting for almost 30% of global demand. Although locally produced rice makes up the bulk of national consumption, China is also the world's largest importer. Domestic early-season long-grain milled rice still commands hefty premiums over supplies from other major origins in Asia, owing to the easy availability of rice from major suppliers outside China. We expect China's purchases to peak at 5m tonnes in 2018 before declining slightly in the following two years. Although it remains unclear how lower state support will impact rice imports, for now we think that imports are likely to fall in future years as the government seeks to reduce inventories. Nonetheless, volumes are likely to remain substantial, given that local prices are above international values. Although we expect rice imports to fall to 4.1m tonnes by 2020, China would still be the world's biggest importer.
Bangladesh's imports set to fall in 2019-20 as local supplies improve
Bangladesh is one of the leading rice markets within Asia, with annual demand reaching at least 35m tonnes. The three domestic crops cut each year are the boro (seeded in December-January and harvested in April-May), aus (planted in March-April and cut in June-July); and aman (sown in July-August and normally threshed in November-December). Although the bulk of the country's rice needs is met by domestic crops, significant quantities are sometimes procured from the world market, especially in times of shortages. Purchases in 2018 are expected to reach 2m tonnes-more than three times the 2017 level-before falling again in 2019 and 2020 as domestic supply improves.
The Philippines is expected to remain a key buyer
In the Philippines, stocks held by the National Food Authority, the grain procurement agency, have dwindled to their lowest level in about a decade. In contrast, inventories held by private households and commercial warehouses remain comfortable. Underscoring thin state reserves, imports are estimated to have risen further in 2018, to reach 1.6m tonnes, and are expected to average close to 1.5m tonnes annually in coming years as the country looks to ensure adequate domestic supplies.
Solid growth in Saudi consumption of cereals
In Saudi Arabia, consumption of cereals, including rice, has posted strong growth over the past two decades. As the preferred ingredient for inclusion in feed rations, barley accounts for more than half of aggregate domestic demand, while growth in the use of other commodities, including wheat and maize in the food and feed sector, respectively, has been particularly notable.
Rice is a staple food, with kabsah, a traditional dish, being consumed widely. In addition, significant volumes are eaten by foreign workers, chiefly from South Asia. However, demand for white rice among middle- and high-income families has fallen, reflecting a shift towards an increased uptake of protein as well as fruits and vegetables. Overall, therefore, growth in rice consumption has been relatively modest. Consumption is forecast at around 1.3m tonnes in both 2018/19 and 2019/20, little changed on the previous year, and only marginally higher than the 1.1m tonnes seen a decade ago.
Saudi Arabia's local market is one of the largest in the Middle East
Nevertheless, the domestic rice market in Saudi Arabia remains one the largest in the Middle East-comparable in size to Iraq and second only to Iran. As climate conditions do not allow for domestic rice cultivation, local market needs are met entirely through imports, which are typically of a very high quality and consist mainly of fragrant-especially basmati-varieties. The origins of the nation's international rice purchases have changed little over the years, with South Asian exporters the most important suppliers. Purchases from India and Pakistan are predominantly of basmati varieties, with relatively smaller quantities of high-quality white and parboiled types secured from a range of origins, including Thailand, Vietnam, the US, China and Australia.

Supply
We expect global rice production to inch up by 0.3% in 2018/19, to a record 494m tonnes. Achieving this will depend on harvest outcomes in Asia's main producers, primarily India, where the monsoon season began on June 1st. Given that only a small expansion of planted area is likely, an increase in global output will depend on improved yields. All of our scenarios assume continued state support for farmers in Asia, as recently announced in India, although seeding in China is likely to fall as the authorities seek to reduce production-and possibly imports-to draw down excess inventories. In 2019/20 marginal acreage expansion and trend yields should boost production by 1.1%, to a new record of 499m tonnes.
India's kharif crop harvest remains central to global output prospects
In any year global prospects are to a large degree shaped by India's main summer-sown (kharif) crop, which is crucial in terms of domestic supplies and the surplus available for export. Most recent government data show that sowings were completed on 37m ha by the end of August, slightly ahead of both the previous year and the five-year average. After progressing slowly, the pace of seeding has improved, which is probably linked to a pick-up in the intensity of the monsoon in some growing regions compared with earlier in the season. By September 9th cumulative full-season rainfall (since June 1st) was estimated to be 7% below the long-term average.
The government has raised kharif support prices
Earlier in the season the government announced that it had lifted minimum support prices for all 2018/19 kharif crops, including a 13% rise for common-grade paddy (rice) to Rs1,750 (US$24) per tonne. Assuming that rains are in line with normal levels in the main rice-growing areas, total production in 2018/19, which also includes the relatively tiny winter-seeded (rabi) crop, is forecast at a record 113m tonnes, up from 111m tonnes in the preceding season. Output may reach 116m tonnes in the following year, given continued farmer support and a good monsoon.
India will remain the largest global exporter
India has been the world's largest exporter of rice since 2011. Volumes have been shaped by demand for high-value basmati varieties from buyers in Europe and the Middle East, as well as shipments of low-quality white and parboiled rice primarily to markets in Africa and Asia. We estimate that India's full-year rice exports rose to 12.2m tonnes in 2018, up from 11.7m tonnes in the previous season. Exports are currently running below the levels necessary for such a rise, but we expect their pace to accelerate in the remainder of the season, given that prices have fallen at most major origins and that African buyers are likely to return to the world market. In the following two years the outlook for exports will ultimately be linked to kharif crop outcomes. Nevertheless, assuming that availabilities remain ample, India will retain its status as the world's largest exporter, with deliveries to global markets reaching nearly 13m tonnes by the end of our forecast period.
Drought conditions in Pakistan harm rice production prospects
The rice crop outlook in Pakistan is uncertain owing to water shortages in the main producing areas, following persistent below-average rainfall since the end of 2017. Water availability in the main reservoirs is estimated to be more than 50% below average, constraining planting operations.
A reduced crop will tighten exportable supplies
Rice sowings usually commence in the later stages of May and early June in southern areas of the country, while cultivation in northern areas usually takes place in late July. However, in the current season fieldwork was as much as 45 days behind schedule. Some growers will therefore seed much less than anticipated, and yield potential could be significantly down. While the situation may have improved owing to increased monsoon rains we now expect output in 2018/19 to fall by 2.8% year on year, to 6.8m tonnes (from 7m tonnes previously). This will have a knock-on impact on export volumes, given that around half of the crop is typically exported. We project that a crop of 6.8m tonnes would support exports of 3.8m tonnes in 2019, down from 4.1m tonnes in the preceding season. In the following year shipments are likely to edge up again as better crops are harvested.
The Chinese government is keen to reduce inventory levels
Following a fall of 4m tonnes (year on year) in 2018/19, rice production in China is likely to drop further in 2019/20, to an eight-year low of 140.5m tonnes because of acreage reductions. The Chinese government aims to reduce rice acreage by around 2% in 2018/19 by scaling back low-quality rice production. Ultimately, this is meant to address the significant structural imbalance between domestic supply and demand. In late April the Communist Party leadership of Hunan Province stated that it aimed to reduce plantings by 200,000 ha in the province during the current year, shifting land to high-value specialty rice crops. This development is significant, since state policy had previously been geared towards stabilising or increasing paddy (rice) output. Acreage has changed little over the years, so a fall of 2% would represent the first significant decline since 2003/04. Furthermore, the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) outlined lower minimum purchasing prices in early 2018 across all types of rice, with falls of between 8% and 11% noted. This is important, because it represents the second consecutive annual cut in farmer support and suggests that the government is aware that supply and demand must be rebalanced owing to burdensome inventories.
The government has also announced a reform of its minimum price support scheme for rice. This year's programme sets stricter conditions for activating minimum price procurement-which can only take place when the market price has remained below the minimum set price for three consecutive days. The scheme must be suspended once the market price exceeds the minimum support price for another three days. This latest policy shift illustrates further the administration's eagerness to reshape the rice sector by introducing market-based conditions under which rice will be procured from farmers. As with efforts to reduce the production of low-quality indica rice, this underlines the government's awareness that domestic stock levels are unsustainably high.
Exports offer a convenient way for China to reduce stocks
Procurement of early indica rice runs from August 1st-September 30th, while middle and late indica rice procurement runs from October 10th until January 31st. Japonica rice procurement commences on November 1st and must close by the end of February. China's exports of rice have traditionally been nominal and shaped by sales of japonica varieties, including to Japan and South Korea, for example. However, there was a big shift in 2017, with shipments rising sharply, largely owing to sales of indica rice to African nations. These included particularly substantial deliveries to Côte d'Ivoire, Liberia, Mozambique, Senegal and Sierra Leone. Prospects for exports are somewhat uncertain at this stage. Nevertheless, the export market offers a viable way of reducing state reserves during the next two years. We anticipate shipments to African nations to remain significant as total exports range between 1m tonnes and 2m tonnes.
Thailand's main crop prospects boosted by good rainfall
Prospects for rice production in Thailand in 2018/19 were boosted by above-average precipitation in the first half of 2018, and the government meteorological office expects rainfall to remain above average thoughout the crop's main reproductive stage to end-October. Due to expanded acreage amid high farm-gate prices for fragrant paddy and with yields expected to be better than in the previous season, total rice output in 2018/19 is predicted to expand by 1m tonnes (5%) to 21.5m tonnes. This includes an assumption of increased secondary (off-season) plantings.
Thailand's exports will remain below those of India
Thailand's exports of all varieties of rice totalled 11.5m tonnes in 2017-easily its highest total and up from 9.9m tonnes the year before. The strong increase was mainly attributable to a large expansion of shipments to markets in Africa, with a portion almost certainly consisting of older intervention reserves from the government's long-held stockpile. Since the government is reported to have sold off food-quality stocks from past harvests last year, exporters will have no access to significant quantities of attractively priced inventories that can be sold to buyers in Africa and other regions. We expect export volumes to fall to 10.5m tonnes in 2018, down from 11.5m tonnes in 2017, largely owing to lower volumes going to African countries and China. Although sales could trend up slightly in 2019-20, they will remain well behind India's volumes.
Elsewhere in Asia, Vietnam's exports have progressed solidly during 2018, with data from the General Statistics Office placing the January-August tally at 4.4m tonnes, a rise of 8% year on year. However, in the absence of a significant increase in cultivation and production, shipments are likely to remain below 7m tonnes over the remainder of the forecast period.
The US crop is expected to rebound strongly
Conditions for the next US outturn remain broadly positive, with recent weekly crop progress reports issued by the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) estimating that 75% of paddy fields were in good or excellent condition as of September 2nd-a significant improvement on levels in late July and in the year-earlier period. In addition, harvesting was about one-third finished, also ahead of the previous year. Based on long-grain area gains, total acreage in the US is expected to expand by 20% year on year, and assuming on-trend yields, production in 2018/19 should rebound to reach 6.8m tonnes. Given that a larger crop should ensure that availabilities are much improved, exports in 2019 are likely to expand to 3.6m tonnes, up from 3.2m tonnes in the previous season. In the following year much depends on prevailing prices ahead of planting; we tentatively expect an average-sized crop and exports of around 3.7m tonnes.
Rice production puts pressure on Egyptian water supplies
Egypt has traditionally been a relatively small but important rice-producing country. Although the bulk of its crop is channelled to the local market, it has also been a modest exporter of medium-grain varieties to global markets, competing with nations such as the US and Australia. The government has for a number of years been using restrictions on exports to ensure availabilities for local consumption. It is now seeking to reduce the cultivation of water-intensive crops, including rice. According to reports, 1,400 litres of water are used in the production of 1 kg of rice, with agriculture accounting for an estimated 80% of Egypt's total water resources. The Ministry of Water Resources and Irrigation has announced a reduction of more than 30% year on year in the approved rice area in 2018/19, to 304,080 ha. According to local reports, this is because farmers have grown more rice than the government's allotted total during the previous year. In addition, growers have faced financial penalties for exceeding the official area target.

Large-scale imports could feature in the longer term
Given that rice cultivation in Egypt is attractive for farmers, it seems possible that growers could again boost plantings above the allotted target. Nevertheless, we still anticipate a fall in output in 2018/19 of about 1m tonnes, to 3.3m tonnes, the lowest in eight seasons. Although local demand has been falling in recent years as the population increasingly turns to alternative, cheaper forms of carbohydrates, such as pasta, imports of rice are likely to rise to 300,000 tonnes, but this is still small in terms of the overall supply-and-demand balance sheet. However, the Egyptian prime minister, Sherif Ismail, has announced that the country would import rice so as to increase stocks and control the market. While no timeframe was provided, the statement could be significant, potentially signalling a switch to large-scale imports as production continues to fall. Some traders and analysts have suggested that purchases from the world market could end up totalling as much as 1m tonnes/year. Exports are expected to remain officially banned in 2018-19. However, modest amounts-around 50,000 tonnes per year-are expected to find their way on to international market, as has been the case in recent years during times of restrictions.
Stocks and prices
World end-season inventories in 2018/19 are likely to tighten, reflecting lower inventories held by the world's leading exporters, primarily India and Thailand. In China, too, the government is encouraging farmers to scale back production of low-quality rice and diversify into high-value varieties as a means of preventing further excessive growth of inventories. Accordingly, we anticipate some reduction in stocks there in 2018/19 after many years of accumulation.
Caution is generally advised when analysing stocks data, reflecting the fact that the bulk of year-end figures provided is arrived at via residual calculation, as most countries do not collect or provide meaningful figures. Furthermore, inventories in China on a milled weight tonnage-equivalent could total as much as 70m-80m tonnes. However, since no official data are published, it is likely that the actual level of stocks could be vastly different from consensus estimates. As we have previously noted, the exclusion of Chinese stocks therefore produces a more realistic figure for what is available on the world market, mostly located in the five major exporters, and specifically in India.

Asian markets for white and parboiled grades of rice generally showed differing trends in August and early September. In Thailand and Vietnam offers for the main grades for export were mostly judged to be steady or slightly firmer, although international demand remained steady at most origins. In Vietnam, where the underlying pace of sales has been fairly robust during 2018, slower buying in recent weeks exerted a bearish influence on the market. Nevertheless, rumours of future tenders by some Asian importers helped to push up prices slightly. In Thailand, quotations for 100% B were unchanged over the month, at US$394/tonne fob Bangkok, while the 5% broken grade in Vietnam increased by US$8, to US$394/tonne fob Ho Chi Minh.
In India, by contrast, markets for white rice have weakened over the past four weeks, with the 5% grade dropping by 3% month on month, to US$392/tonne fob, tcomparable with other origins. Supply and demand fundamentals were little changed, although the approach of the nation's main crop will have had a minor impact. It seems that the fall was more to do with currency movements as the Indian rupee lost value against the US dollar. Elsewhere in South Asia there were heightened worries about drought conditions in Pakistan, with planting of the monsoon crop as much as two months behind schedule in some parts of Sindh province, fuelling concerns that production could be much smaller than in the previous season.
Recent price declines have depressed the 2018-19 outlook
Mainly reflecting strength during the early part of the year, especially in the second quarter, the average 2018 price of 100% B in Thailand is estimated at US$404/tonne fob Bangkok, a 3.7% year-on-year increase. Over the remainder of the forecast period through to the third quarter of 2020 export quotations at all leading origins could strengthen, which would be consistent with expectations of tighter global stocks, including in major suppliers to the world market. To some extent, however, the potential for higher prices may be limited by the fact that much of the fall in inventories could be due to a policy-driven adjustment in China.

Soybeans
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global soybean consumption to have increased for the ninth consecutive year in 2017/18, to a record 337m tonnes, with growth of 3.9% well below the four year average of 5.3%. In 2018/19 we anticipate further growth in consumption of around 4.5%, to 352m tonnes. Projections for 2019/20 are extremely tentative, and much will depend on whether the current US-China bilateral trade war can be resolved. Factoring in potentially below-par expansion in China, world consumption is tentatively seen at 358m tonnes, up by 1.7% year on year in 2019/20.
The principal driver of the near-uninterrupted expansion of demand over the past decade has been rising use in Asia, mostly China, underpinned by the increasing uptake in that country's vast feed sector. While the poultry, livestock and dairy sectors have made the greatest contribution, the aquaculture sector has become an increasingly important source of growth, with soybean meal the feed ingredient of choice owing to its abundance and high protein content. Soybean consumption in other regions is relatively small but has also risen steadily in recent years, with notable increases in the Middle East and Africa.
Overall consumption growth in China is likely to moderate in 2018-19 compared with recent years, assuming that rising trade barriers cause China to reduce its purchases from the world market slightly. Nevertheless, consistent with our expectations of larger shipments by the US to other markets, growth in demand in other regions, including the EU, will compensate. Furthermore, a recovery in Argentina's production would boost supplies for local processing as consumption there rebounds.
We forecast that global trade in soybeans in 2018/19 (September/October basis) will reach 154m tonnes. While China's purchases may actually fall, this will be more than offset by bigger imports by other buyers. Chinese purchases of US soybeans have floundered since April as bilateral trade tensions have escalated. The impact on Chinese processors has been limited, since this period coincided with the southern hemisphere export programme. Nevertheless, even before April China's imports of US supplies were much smaller than in the previous season owing to big purchases from Brazil between October 2017 and January 2018. More recently Chinese demand has reportedly slowed owing to heavy stocks and an erosion of processing margins.
The 2018/19 trade year is characterised by a great deal of uncertainty regarding China's needs owing to the implementation of a 25% tariff on soybean imports from the US, which came into effect on July 6th. Nonetheless, the US-China trade war is unlikely to dent soybean demand significantly as China will probably source more from other origins, primarily Brazil. Additionally, industry and trade sources suggest that purchases of other feed ingredients, such as rapeseed/canola, sunflowerseed and possibly even soybean meal, could compensate for any shortfall. Nevertheless, supplies at South American origins are likely to be tighter than normal from October 2018 onwards until new crops are threshed in early 2019. As a result, it is possible that even with the import tariffs in place, Chinese buyers will be required to source as much as 15m tonnes from the US in 2018/19-although this is well below its purchases of around 30m tonnes per year in recent years. China's total imports are forecast to fall by 1.5% in 2018/19-the first fall in eight years-and are expected to remain at this level in 2019/20.
China's massive pork industry accounts for around one-third of global consumption of soybean meal, a major feed ingredient for pigs. The recent outbreak of African swine fever in a number of Chinese provinces is therefore of huge importance for the soybean market and could have substantial implications for future demand. The authorities have moved swiftly to control the outbreak, culling thousands of animals and introducing bans on live animal transportation and markets in affected areas. However, new cases were being reported on an almost daily basis in early September. The effects on local feed demand are difficult to assess at this early stage, however. For now, our forecasts for soybean demand in China are unchanged: despite lower imports in 2018/19 we expect higher domestic output and some destocking to support overall demand growth of 5% year on year in 2019/20. However, we will keep an eye on these events and adjust our forecast accordingly.
Ample domestic supplies will support demand in the US
US soybean consumption in 2017/18 is estimated to reach an all-time high of nearly 59m tonnes, growing by 5.7% year on year, after a large crop boosted supplies for processing. In addition to local feed sector needs, strong international demand for soymeal-owing to reduced supplies from drought-hit Argentina-has boosted local crushing. We expect another large crop in 2018/19 to support further consumption growth of 1.5% year on year, before declining by 0.5% in 2019/20.
In South America the outlook for consumption is weak, largely reflecting trends in Argentina, where we expect consumption to contract by 5.4% in 2017/18-the first contraction in five seasons-after a heavily reduced crop tightened availabilities for processing. While ample domestic stocks and a reduction in export volumes have helped to ease the impact on domestic availability, some growers may hold on to inventories as export taxes are gradually reduced. In 2018/19 and 2019/20, assuming a recovery in soybean production and with firm demand for soybean product exports, domestic processing and total consumption should rebound by 5.3% per year on average.

Imports are central to EU requirements
The EU has achieved successive record crops in recent seasons. Nevertheless, at less than 3m tonnes domestic outturns represent only a tiny share of overall consumption. The remainder is typically met by imports of soybeans and soybean meal, typically accounting for up to 35m tonnes. In 2017/18 soybean imports are expected to rise by 3.9% after the previous season's fall. In recent months EU import demand has strengthened as buyers have taken advantage of the heavy fall in US market prices. With a poor rapeseed/canola crop on the horizon, another season of increased imports is expected in 2018/19-2019/20, with consumption forecast to grow by 3.1% per year on average.
Supply
Boosted by larger plantings in the US and Brazil as well as increases in relatively smaller players such as Canada, eastern Europe, China and the EU, global sowings are estimated to have risen by 4% year on year in 2017/18 to their highest ever level. However, with yields being compromised by adverse weather in some countries-most notably Argentina, where crops were first ravaged by drought and then impacted by heavy rains and flooding during harvesting-global production is estimated to have contracted by 3.8% year on year, to 335m tonnes. Nonetheless, this is still about 30m tonnes higher than the average of the previous five seasons. The outlook for 2018/19 is tentative, but with a further expansion of seeded area likely-led by growth in South America-output could recover to 365m tonnes, a year-on-year increase of 8.9%. Our very early projections for 2019/20 suggest that US plantings could decline, with farmers perhaps switching to maize and spring wheat. Even if South American crops are larger, world production might therefore dip to 358m tonnes, down by 2.1% year on year.
US yields are expected to be very good in 2018/19
US farmers have enjoyed generally favourable cropping conditions over the spring and summer. With plantings completed on time, the weather in June and July was warm and wet in many areas, setting the scene for successful pod filling in August, the key month for determining soybean yields. The mostly favourable weather has continued in recent weeks, and the first objective yield survey assessment from the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) suggests that average yields will be only slightly down on the 2016/17 record. According to the agency, expectations for pod weight (and yields) will benefit from this season's extended period of crop development. Incorporating this uprated yield figure, we have raised our production forecast by 6.8m tonnes to an unprecedented 124.8m tonnes, up by 4.4% on the previous season.
US farmers will be compensated for ongoing trade disputes
On September 4th the USDA formally launched a US$12bn aid package aimed at assisting local farmers hit by current international trade disputes. The flagship Market Facilitation Programme will provide payments to eligible producers of soybeans, wheat, maize, sorghum, cotton, dairy and pigs. Payments will be made on 50% of actual 2018/19 production volumes, with soybean growers eligible for a payment of US$1.65/bushel, up to a maximum of US$125,000 per farm. Additionally, a Trade Promotion Programme will assist in developing new export markets, while a Food Purchase and Distribution Programme will purchase surpluses of certain affected commodities for distribution through nutrition assistance programmes. While the payments were well received in certain quarters, most farm groups have reiterated their desire for a resolution to the trade disputes with major US trade partners and called for a more permanent solution.
Brazil is on course to smash its existing record for exports
After progressing slowly in the first quarter of its 2018/19 local marketing year (starting February 1st), Brazil's exports have surged owing to robust demand from Asia, with volumes hitting respective monthly records in May, June and July. This was achieved despite major logistical challenges and disruption to transport flows caused by industrial action by hauliers and brought cumulative exports in 2017/18 (October-July) to more than 63m tonnes, the biggest amount ever dispatched in that period. This suggests that the full-year total will exceed 70m tonnes, despite a slowdown in spot demand from Chinese importers. Although the outlook for 2018/19 remains uncertain, we have factored in further growth in Brazil's exports to a record 75m tonnes as the US-China trade war continues, allowing Brazil to capture a larger share of China's import needs.
Brazil's 2018/19 growing season is subject to much uncertainty
Brazil's economic and political landscape is challenging for farmers, with exchange-rate uncertainty, higher freight costs, US-China trade relations and Brazil's 2018 presidential election contributing to heightened market uncertainty. The Brazilian Real has fluctuated significantly against the US dollar in the first half of 2018 and is down by around one-third compared with the same point last year. On the one hand, a weaker Real could encourage expanded acreage through higher domestic prices, as has been the case in previous years. Highlighting this point, although export quotations (from Paranagua ports) have risen modestly, the increase in local values has been much more significant, at around 30%. While area gains may come from a shift of some area from full-season corn to soybeans in southern regions, it may also be due to the seeding of soybeans on new lands. On the other hand, however, the weaker Real will inflate production costs, including imported inputs such as fertilisers.
Just weeks before the start of Brazil's new crop planting season in September, a decision by a federal judge to ban the use of products containing the agrochemical glyphosate caused alarm across the agricultural sector. Glyphosate is used extensively across the country, with many soybean farmers now practising no-till production, whereby plants are seeded directly into existing crop residue, with weeds controlled by chemicals rather than through ploughing the seedbed. The decision drew widespread criticism, including from the agriculture minister, who expressed doubts that farmers would even comply with such a ruling. Following an appeal by the Attorney General, the decision was overturned in early September, clearing the way for the use of glyphosate in the 2018/19 season.
However, problems with inland transport costs remain broadly unresolved. With local supplies mainly transported by lorry from producing areas to ports, recent legislation instituting minimum freight rates has had a big impact on the agricultural sector, squeezing profit margins. The costs of transporting fertiliser and other key farm inputs in the other direction, from ports to farms, has also increased in recent months. Brazil's Supreme Court has held a series of public hearings over the new minimum freight rates, introduced to appease independent lorry drivers, who launched a damaging nationwide strike in May. However, a decision on the law's constitutionality is not expected to be made until November.
Soybean area is set to increase even further in Brazil
Despite background uncertainty about freight costs, worries about the rising costs of production and volatility in foreign-exchange markets, the allure of high prices and potentially huge demand from China are expected to encourage a twelfth successive increase in soybean area in 2018/19. The earliest planting will start around the middle of September, continuing until the end of December, with harvesting starting normally just after the turn of the year. With forecasts unchanged from last time, we continue to predict a 4% increase in acreage, a new record. Assuming that productivity is broadly in line with trend, output is projected to grow by 1.3% per year in 2018/19-19/20 to a new high of 121m tonnes by the end of the forecast period.
Adverse weather conditions hamper fieldwork in Argentina
In Argentina's 2017/18 season yield potential was damaged irrecoverably by hot and dry weather, followed by heavy rains across key growing regions that led to delays to harvesting, crop losses and an erosion of quality. At 35m tonnes, production is estimated to have contracted by nearly 40% year on year. This has significantly reduced Argentina's presence in the export markets for soybeans and soybean meal, despite unusually heavy purchases of soybeans from the US and Paraguay for local processing. Soybean exports in 2017/18 are expected to total only 3m tonnes, the smallest volume in many years and less than half the amount shipped in 2016/17.
Faced with another financial crisis and the need to appease the IMF ahead of a new loan agreement, the authorities in Argentina have once again turned to grain and oilseed exporters as a source of much-needed revenue. With agricultural exporters deemed to have benefited from the massive drop in the value of the peso in recent months, the president has reneged on previous pledges to gradually reduce taxes on soybeans and their products. Under a series of changes, effective from September 3rd until the end of 2020, the soybean export tax has been raised to 28.5% (from 25.5% previously), with levies on soybean oil and meal raised to 25.8% (from 23%). The taxes had previously been scheduled to be reduced by 0.5% per month until the end of 2019. The announcement came just a few weeks before the start of the 2018/19 planting season, due to get under way in central parts in October.
Local prices are currently very supportive, and despite the changes in the tax regime it appears likely that soybeans may be a less risky proposition than maize for many growers. Financing costs for soybeans are comparatively lower, and with the prime interest rate now at 60%, farmers may be more incentivised to plant soybeans, especially given the potential for increased buying from China. With our numbers subject to revision but unchanged from the previous report, area is forecast to increase by about 2% in 2018/19. Should yields revert to normal, production is forecast to rebound sharply, to around 54m tonnes in 2018/19, up by more than 50% from the very poor results of the preceding season.
Uruguay is a relatively small player among South America's soybean producers. In the 2017/18 season production is estimated to have contracted significantly, to less than 2m tonnes (from 3.3m tonnes in the previous season), owing to the impact of harsh climatic conditions. As in Argentina, growers grappled with hot and dry weather in early 2018, and since this is the time when crops are setting pods, this resulted in area losses and a heavy reduction in yield potential. In some cases there were reports of average productivity being as low as 0.5 tonnes/ha. Subsequently growers had to contend with excessive rains. As a result the government has declared a national agricultural emergency and activated a fund to assist the worst-affected producers.
Most of Uruguay's supplies are exported to China
Since domestic consumption of soybeans in Uruguay is marginal, the bulk of the country's crop is exported, with China by far the largest market. Other destinations include Europe and Argentina, as well as North Africa and the US. Prospects for 2018/19 are uncertain at this early stage, as the seeding campaign is months away. However, based on average productivity and an area of 1.2m ha, output may recover to 3m tonnes.
Paraguay is a small but important exporter
Paraguay is a modest but important exporter of soybeans to a range of world markets. Output has sometimes varied sharply from one season to the next but has generally trended up over the past decade. Despite increasing local consumption, this has resulted in bigger surpluses for export. Furthermore, the expansion of domestic soybean use as a result of increased processing reflects growing international demand for soybean products.
Exports will decline in 2019/20
In 2017/18 farmers in Paraguay planted 500,000 ha of zafrina soybeans, following on from 3.5m ha of the much more important primary (zafra) crop. However, with yields from the zafrina crop potentially below expectations, production in 2017/18 fell slightly year on year, to 9.9m tonnes. The EU is the main market for Paraguay, accounting for 30-40% of all shipments, while sales to the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), mainly Russia, have risen strongly in response to rising local demand in the region. Elsewhere, markets in Latin America are also important. Based on the current pace of exports, mainly to Argentina, we now expect 2017/18 exports to reach a record high of 6.6m tonnes, up from 5.3m tonnes in the previous season. In the following year and in 2019/20 a tentative recovery in production is expected, but shipments may dip as Argentina's import demand falls back to normal levels.

Production in China is rising but lags behind demand
China is by far the world's largest importer but only a minor producer of soybeans. However, potential has been capped over the years by limited yield gains compared with those of the world's big players as well as the attraction of alternative crops such as wheat, maize and rice. Nonetheless, the government is keen to boost production of oilseeds, particularly soybeans, at the expense of corn in north-eastern areas as part of a supply-side adjustment programme. To this end, Jilin and Heiliongjiang provinces issued orders in early 2018 to increase soybean planting with the promise of public financial support. Based on an area increase of about 14% year on year, production in China in 2018/19 is projected to reach a ten-year high of 15.5m tonnes, expanding by 8.4% before flattening in 2019/20. Nevertheless, this still meets only a small portion of overall domestic need, the bulk of which is served by imports channelled to the country's vast feed sector.
Stocks and prices
Following the previous season's exceptionally strong gains, global ending stocks are estimated to have remained fairly flat in 2017/18, at about 120m tonnes-the largest on record and equivalent to a stocks/use ratio of 36%. In 2018/19 the global soybean market is expected to tip back into surplus, led by increases in Argentina-assuming a much improved crop-and the US. Amid huge US supplies and more limited opportunities for export, US stocks are forecast to reach record levels, with the world total placed at 133m tonnes (6.5m tonnes higher than in our previous forecast). We expect only a fractional drawdown at the end of the 2019/20 marketing year.

Export quotations were subject to contrasting trends in the past month. Average prices dropped by a net 5% in the period since our last report, with weakness noted in the US, Brazil and in Argentina. Earlier gains in US prices were mostly undone in August, as previous worries about yield prospects were soothed by a period of much better weather and news of good results from local crop tours. With traders beginning to factor in potentially record-high production, fob quotations at Gulf ports began to weaken, dropping by a net 10% to around US$316/tonnes. Export prices in Brazil (Paranagua) were a touch lower, but maintained a US$60 premium over US quotations. With Argentina's exportable surplus having been dramatically reduced by the smallest outturn in about a decade, quotations there were largely nominal.
We expect the average third-quarter 2018 US Gulf export price to be significantly lower than in the previous quarter and the same period last year as a result of the US-China trade war. In 2018 overall we now expect prices to average US$365/tonne, down by 3.1% year on year and a multi-year low. Amid a rebound in global production expected in 2018/19, international prices will remain under pressure, with Gulf quotations expected to fall by a further 5.2% year on year in 2019.

Sugar
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that global annual sugar consumption will expand at a fairly modest rate of 1.2% per year in 2018/19-2019/20 (years ending September 30th). Increasing global consumption will continue to be underpinned by population growth and rising incomes in emerging markets, where urbanising populations are adopting the food and drink habits of developed countries. Sugar plays a key role in this dietary shift as a sweetener in food and beverages and a binding and preserving agent in processed foods.
However, heightened awareness of the health implications of excess sugar in diets will put a brake on consumption growth, amid consumer calls for the food processing industry to reduce sugar and, in an increasing number of markets, the introduction of "sin taxes" on sugary products. These taxes have the potential to suppress sugar demand, although their impact will vary according to the level of taxation, the rigour of implementation and the elasticity of consumer demand. In addition, the growing supply of cheaper, starch-based alternative sweeteners in both Asia (where Chinese production is expanding rapidly) and Europe (where the market was liberalised in September 2017) will limit demand for sugar in the food and drinks industry. Meanwhile, the impact of low global sugar prices on demand will be muted by long-standing domestic pricing policies, which will limit the extent to which lower prices pass through to consumers.
China will remain a key consumer, but growth is set to moderate
Demand in China is forecast to expand more rapidly than the global average, but the pace of demand growth will begin to moderate (to 2.2% in 2018/19 and 2.1% in 2019/20) as the market matures. We expect private consumption in China to soften over the coming years, owing largely to issues in the property markets, but this pressure on real disposable income is likely to strengthen demand for cheaper food and drink products, many of which rely on sugar as a preservative. This will spur demand for industrial sugar. However, consumption growth will also be held back by the growing supply of starch-based sweeteners and rising concerns among wealthier consumers about the health implications of excess sugar in diets.
Import demand will be constrained by higher domestic output and the government's protectionist policy agenda. Amid pressure from domestic producers to support the local industry, the government reduced import permits in mid-2017 to 1m tonnes/year (t/y), roughly half the previous level, and raised duties on some out-of-quota sugar imports from 50% to 95% in May 2017. Initially these tariffs applied only to imports from the largest global producers, but the rules were amended in August to apply 90% duty to all out-of-quota imports. Sugar imports have fallen to multi-year lows, and even assuming China grants some tariff exemptions (as seems likely), weak import demand is likely to prevail through 2019-20. However, China will be unable to scale up domestic production anytime soon to a level that could fully satisfy its domestic demand and preserve its strategically high levels of stocks. It will therefore continue to make purchases overseas, and with prices higher in China than the global norm, it will remain an attractive export destination.
Urbanisation and income growth will drive Indian consumption
Demand in India is forecast to reach 26m tonnes in 2019/20, driven by fairly rapid urbanisation and steady income growth. The subdued price environment will also support demand, with local prices sinking since mid-2017 as the high domestic output hit the market. Amid pressure from producers to support prices the government has hiked import duties, imposed stockholding limits on mills and approved plans to create a buffer stock of some 3m tonnes. These measures, coupled with a recovery of demand among bulk consumers during the festive season, lifted domestic prices in the third quarter of 2018. Even so, large domestic stockpiles will place a firm lid on prices in 2018/19-2019/20, signalling that weak prices will continue to support demand.
Demand growth elsewhere in Asia is threatened by starch-based rivals
Beyond China and India, the outlook for sugar consumption in Asia is mixed. Demand growth in the more developed countries (such as Malaysia and South Korea) is expected to slow, but rising income in populous developing countries (such as Indonesia, the Philippines and Vietnam) will offset this. However, even in these developing countries demand will be tempered somewhat by concerns over the health impact of excessive sugar in diets. Policy measures to ensure that sugar consumption remains within recommended health guidelines will soften demand growth, with sugar taxes now in place in Thailand and the Philippines. Several other Asian countries are considering similar moves, and the prospect of a tax hike will limit investment in sugar-reliant food- and drink-manufacturing industries. Sugar demand will be further dampened by a gradual shift in the food and drink industry towards cheaper, starch-based sweeteners as China (Asia's largest producer of such sweeteners) seeks export markets. In light of these pressures, we expect demand growth in Asia (excluding China and India) to moderate to an average of 1.7% in 2018/19-2019/20, down from average growth of 2.5% over the previous five years.
Health warnings may eventually dent developed-world demand
The liberalisation of the EU's sugar regime in September 2017-when production quotas, guaranteed farm-gate prices and export caps were abolished-has limited the need for imports and brought European sugar prices (which have historically traded at a premium) closer to the global norm. Although lower prices should support demand, the production of isoglucose (a starch-based alternative to sugar) was also liberalised in 2017, and this is likely to gradually steal market share in the sweetener industry. Indeed, Europe's largest beet producer, Germany's Südzucker, has announced plans to start making a sweetener with a lower sugar content.
Health concerns are spurring this shift away from sugar. In many EU countries average consumption levels of sugar are already far higher than recommended by the World Health Organisation (WHO). In an effort to tackle this, in April the UK introduced a tax on sugary drinks, and the French government intends to hike its so-called soda tax in 2018. The WHO scrapped its non-binding recommendation to impose a sugar tax in May, calling instead on governments to improve labelling and regulate the marketing of sugary products. Regardless of policy interventions, we expect consumer pressure to make manufacturers wary of using excess sugar in their products, which will reduce demand growth in the medium term. We therefore expect sugar demand to remain broadly flat in 2018/19-2019/20, despite low prices and population growth.
Changing consumer tastes will boost demand growth in Africa
African consumption will continue to increase on the back of population growth, rising incomes and urbanisation. Several countries (including Nigeria, the region's largest importer, as well as Kenya and Ghana) are pursuing long-term investment plans in the sugar sector in the hope of becoming self-sufficient. However, inefficient domestic supply chains will impede the development of Africa's sugar industries, and most will be unable to compete with the cheap imports from an oversupplied global market. Aggregate import demand from Sub-Saharan Africa will therefore remain well above 5m t/y in 2017/18-2018/19. A sugar tax came into effect in South Africa in April 2018, but amid pressure from food and drink manufacturers it has been set at just 10%, and we doubt that it will have a significant impact on overall sugar demand.
Policy changes will shift global sugar trade dynamics
The overhaul in 2017 by the EU of its sugar policy will drive its emergence as a net exporter, although the impact of this on the global market will be delayed somewhat by a weak European harvest in 2017/18. Nevertheless, exporters in the EU will focus in 2018/19-2019/20 on capturing market share in European countries with a sugar deficit, which will crowd non-EU producers out of the European market. The smaller producers, particularly in Africa and the Caribbean, which supply the EU under preferential trade deals, will be hit hardest by this shift. Some smaller producers have increased their market share in China since the May 2017 tariff regime was introduced, but they are unlikely to retain this market under the new rules. Brazil, which was hardest hit by China's tougher import rules, has opened a consultation with the WTO to examine these rules, but any possible intervention by the international body is a long way off. However, several producers (notably India) are, hoping to negotiate tariff exemptions with China, which could shift the pattern of near-term trade flows. Elsewhere, trade patterns will be influenced by the liberalisation of sugar sales under the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) free-trade agreement, which will probably cause less efficient producers (such as Vietnam) to rely more heavily on imports from elsewhere in the region (probably Thailand). Intra-regional trade in North America is likely to increase following a trade deal agreed by the US and Mexico in mid-2017.

Supply
After rapid global production growth of some 11.8% in 2017/18 we expect output to moderate slightly in 2018/19-2019/20, to 181.7m tonnes. This dip is driven by lower output from Brazil, where producers can respond to the low global sugar price environment by diverting cane to ethanol production. However, global supply will remain high by historical standards, with output in India, Thailand and Europe still hovering around all-time highs. This will keep the global market in surplus and sustain pressure on prices. Most of the world's sugar producers will therefore struggle to break even. Cane will be diverted to other industrial uses, notably ethanol production, where possible, but financial pressures will put some mills out of business over the coming years.
This correction will, however, be slow to take effect. Sugar is a multi-year crop, and the industry is characterised the long contracts. Taken together, this will delay the responsiveness of farmers to low cane demand. Moreover, increased cane acreage and greater access to high-yielding inputs will deliver another strong harvest in 2018/19-2019/20 in most markets. Government intervention (notably in India) will also keep unprofitable sugars mills in operation.
Trade deals and policy measures will shift the direction of global trade flows, but trade volumes will ultimately be defined by production levels in countries (notably India) that swing between being importers and exporters. The bulk of India's output is consumed domestically, but a strong harvest will lead to higher exports; much of this will probably go to emerging markets with costly local production. We therefore expect trade flows to average 59.9m tonnes in 2018/19-2019/20, above the 58.6m-tonne average over the previous five years. There is, however, a downside risk of further protectionism in the sugar industry as governments attempt to shield their local manufacturers from cheap imports, and this could act as a major weight on trade flows.
Output in Brazil will be determined by price dynamics
We expect sugar production in Brazil to decline to an average of 33.9m tonnes in 2018/19-2019/20. This is largely due to the diversion of cane to ethanol production, which is more profitable than sugar production in the current price environment. Indeed, since the local 2018/19 season began in April, Brazil has crushed more cane than in the previous year, but sugar production is down and ethanol production is on course for all-time highs.
However, ethanol production cannot absorb all of the country's cane supply, and domestic prices of the biofuel are already tumbling as demand fails to keep pace with surging supply. There is a risk that ethanol prices will drop below sugar prices, particularly if the newly elected government caps fuel prices, which would prompt producers to switch back to sugar and sell more supplies into the saturated global market. However, this is not our central forecast, as we expect oil prices to remain relatively high (thereby boosting demand for ethanol in Brazil) and the depreciation of the Real to be fairly modest (thereby failing to provide a significant incentive for dollar-denominated sugar exports). Moreover, even if the ethanol/sugar price dynamic does change, sugar output will be limited by low investment in aging cane fields. The profitability of soy crops in Brazil is also prompting farmers in the sugarcane belt to switch crops wherever possible, and although long-term contracts and multi-year crops will delay this crop rotation, a resurgence in Brazilian production seems unlikely.
A strong post-drought crop revival is expected in India
After a record-high output in 2017/18 we expect output in India to remain high in 2018/19-2019/20 at an average of 33.9m tonnes/year, as cane supply remains plentiful and efforts to build other cane-dependant industries (notably ethanol production) are slow to take off. However, producers are unable to break even in the current price environment, and millers' arrears to farmers are estimated to have reached some US$3.5bn. The government has provided a bail-out package to millers, but this covers just 40% of existing arrears. Some casualties (particularly among the most debt-ridden mills) are likely, and the government will remain under political pressure from both millers and farmers to intervene.
Policies designed to restore balance in the local industry include removing export duties, setting a price floor for domestic sugar prices, subsidising a portion of millers' contracts with farmers and subsiding loans to increase ethanol production capacity. These measures are yet to have much impact on the level of oversupply or prices, however. The government is attempting to find new export markets, but low global prices mean that producers will still struggle to break even. The government is also considering indirect export subsidies via cane growers, but any such moves will face resistance from Brazil and Australia via the WTO. With the government in effect subsidising an oversupplied and unprofitable domestic market, it will eventually have to allow some producers to fail. Political expediency and a general election in 2019 (in which the government will be seeking the support of farmers) make it unlikely this will happen anytime soon, though.
Brisk EU production growth following sectoral liberalisation
Production in Europe is forecast to average 19.7 tonnes/year in 2018/19 and 2019/20. This follows a record-high year of production in 2017/18 of 21m tonnes as producers sought to take advantage of the lifting the EU's 50-year-old sugar quota system at the start of the season. Under the new regime producers (led by France and Germany) extended their crush seasons, thereby making better use of existing capacity, and increased the acreage under plantation. These factors will support production over the coming years. However, output in 2018/19 will be hit by the heavy rains, which delayed springtime planting, and the hot summer months in key producing countries, which will reduce sugar yields. However, the impact of recent weather patterns is somewhat uncertain, given the varying crop conditions in Europe.
More fundamentally, European producers are struggling to break even in the current price environment, with Südzucker reporting a 49% drop in profits in the first quarter of 2018. Weak global prices, coupled with the fact that the liberalisation of the sugar industry has removed the premium at which European sugar was previously traded, will place a firm brake on investment in the sugar industry over the coming years.
In Russia, production will continue to benefit from the significant investments that have been made in modernising sugar factories in recent years. After favourable growing conditions in 2017/18 led to record-high production, though, both cane acreage and yields are expected to be lower in 2018/19-2019/20. Production will continue to exceed domestic consumption, but soft demand in Central Asia (Russia's main market) will lessen its export potential.
Output in Thailand is recovering but pressures are mounting
Thai sugar production is surging as both crop acreage and yields exceed the long-run averages. After reaching a record-high of 13.8m tonnes in 2017/18, we expect output to edge up further in 2018/19-2019/20, driven by more planting. Output growth will, however, be somewhat constrained by the increased diversion of cane to ethanol production. This diversion reflects limited export opportunities in an oversupplied global market and mounting price pressures in the local sugar industry. The local industry was formally liberalised in early 2018, after Brazil successfully argued that Thailand was violating WTO rules on free competition. Quotas for sugar production will therefore be phased out, and the domestic price-fixing system will be revoked, but mills are still obliged to reimburse farmers if the final sale price drops below a pre-agreed level. This protects farmers from global volatility, but with global prices at their current lows, mills are struggling to turn a profit. This will lead to some consolidation in the industry. Moreover, weather-related risks are rising as farming moves towards more drought-prone interior regions.
China's output will rise but will still fall short of government targets
After falling sharply in 2013/14-2016/17 owing to adverse weather conditions and the impact of rapidly rising costs of labour, land and farm machinery, China's sugar output has begun to recover. We expect this trend to continue, with output rising to 10.7m tonnes in 2019/20 on the back of normal weather conditions and some government support. However, producers will face price pressures. Production costs have increased, driven by higher prices for fertiliser and pesticides, and prices have come under pressure from a rebound in local output and global oversupply. The government has been quick to intervene to protect local producers by hiking import duties, and this should provide some support to prices in 2018/19-2019/20. Even so, prices will remain too low to spur much investment in the sector. In addition, the sector is dominated by smallholder farmers, labour costs are high, and sugarcane areas do not lend themselves to mechanisation. We therefore expect that China will fall far short of achieving the 10% annual supply growth that would be needed for the state to meet its medium-term production goals.

Stocks and prices
Global sugar stocks increased to an estimated 101m at end-2017/18 on the back of a large market surplus. We expect this surplus to decline, from 13.6m tonnes in 2017/18 to 3.5m tonnes in 2019/20 as modest consumption growth is matched by a slight drop in output. Even so, these dynamics will not be significant enough to bring the market back into balance, and successive years of global surpluses will lift stocks. We therefore expect global stocks to reach 112.9m tonnes in 2019/20, equivalent to over 63% of consumption.

A prolonged global surplus will sustain the pressure on prices
Significant oversupply in the sugar industry is piling pressure on prices. Global sugar prices fell to an average of 16 US cents/lb in 2017, down by 11.3% year on year and more than 30% lower than the 2016 peak of 23 US cents/lb. Prices have remained under pressure through the course of 2018, dropping to a multi-year low of 10.75 US cents/lb in August. Uncertainty over the impact of recent weather conditions on the European crop has provided some support to prices in the first half of September, but the modest price rebound is unlikely to be sustained. Indeed, traders are still positioning for further losses, with total short positions within 3% of the all-time record that was reached in May.
Brazil is the only producer able to act as a shock absorber, given millers' ability to divert significant cane supply to ethanol production when prices drop. However, owing to Brazil's falling market share this is insufficient to raise prices, and the link between ethanol/sugar price parity has become less significant globally as a floor on sugar prices. As a result, prices are forecast to remain under considerable pressure in the coming months. Far-reaching policy interventions by Asian governments are also likely to keep unprofitable producers in the market and delay a market correction. Hence, we have revised down our forecast to a yearly average of 11.8 US$ cent/lb in 2018 and pushed back the point at which prices will begin to recover.
We expect prices to drift slowly higher from mid-2019. This will be driven in part by the sugar-trading market pricing in more risk, particularly as regions highly exposed to weather shocks gain prominence in global supply. More fundamentally, the market will gradually tighten over the medium term as costlier producers are forced out of the market. With traders taking their price cues from markets some two years ahead, this will provide some support to prices.

Sunflowerseed oil
Demand
Global sunflowerseed oil consumption growth was always likely to slow in 2017/18, following record year-on-year growth of 15% in 2016/17. Nonetheless, consumption continues to outperform The Economist Intelligence Unit's expectations. Although the increases to our consumption estimates for 2017/18 are small, a 3.4% increase on 2016/17 is a good performance. With sunflowerseed oil becoming more competitive again, this momentum is now more likely to be maintained into the 2018/19 season, and we expect consumption to expand by a further 3.4% to reach 19.5m tonnes. The 20m-tonne barrier is likely to be breached in 2019/20.
Improving price competitiveness will boost EU usage
The price discount of sunflowerseed oil to other oils continues at historically high levels. Consumption in the EU remains buoyant, with a further increase in our 2017/18 consumption estimate to 4.8m tonnes (previously 4.7m tonnes). In 2018/19, however, consumption may be constrained by local availability, although rising global production estimates mean that imports could fill any gap. At this stage we expect only a modest 1.6% increase in consumption to just under 5m tonnes. Trends in soybean oil prices, following US-China trade tariff changes, are likely to have a strong influence on sunflowerseed consumption levels.
Russian consumption set to rise in 2018/19 with higher local output
A strong export market for Russian sunflowerseed oil has had a limiting impact on consumption by bolstering domestic prices. Our estimate of 2017/18 consumption is virtually unchanged, at 2.4m tonnes. We expect consumption growth to resume in 2018/19, supported by higher domestic production and continued GDP growth. However, changes to trans-fat regulations may discourage the use of sunflowerseed oil in the margarine sector. We currently expect 2018/19 consumption to approach 2.5m tonnes, representing growth of more than 3%.
Transshipment into India increases
India's previously robust pace of sunflowerseed imports began to slow in early 2018, reflecting the imposition of higher import tariffs. However, import levels have since risen again. In part this is attributable to a loophole in India's import tariff arrangements, which allow duty-free imports via countries such as Bangladesh and Sri Lanka. Transshipment of oils through these locations is reported to be rising. Our estimate of 2017/18 consumption is increased to 2.5m tonnes. The impact of the higher tariff rates on 2018/19 consumption will depend on the extent to which the transshipment trade continues to develop. At present, we maintain our forecast for relatively modest growth of 2%.
Consumption growth to moderate in "other" countries in 2017/18
Many countries, including Turkey, Iran, Iraq and Egypt as well as several other smaller states, increased their purchases of sunflowerseed oil to take advantage of competitive prices. Their imports have now slowed, and total consumption of these "other" countries in 2017/18 is likely to remain at very similar levels to 2016/17. With sunflowerseed oil production expected to increase, consumption in these other countries is expected to resume its upward trend in 2018/19 and 2019/20. There are also reports of Chinese buyers showing increasing interest in sunflowerseed oil.

Supply
Although global sunflowerseed oil production in 2017/18 is expected to fall short of the record 2016/17 output, it will still remain an above-average performance. Our estimates of production in individual countries show small increases in all the major producers with the exception of Argentina. With northern hemisphere harvesting now well under way, 2018/19 sunflowerseed production looks set to establish a new record. Output growth continues in Russia and Ukraine, and the EU crop is also large by recent standards. There is a need to rebuild sunflowerseed stock levels, but sunflowerseed oil production should still comfortably exceed 19m tonnes in 2018/19.
Crush rates improve slightly
Following a mid-season slowdown, crushing activity in Ukraine continues to run marginally above expectations following an improved export outlook for sunflowerseed oil. We have again increased our estimate of 2017/18 sunflowerseed production. Output will remain below last season's total but will still be the second-highest total ever achieved, reflecting the high base of comparison in 2016/17. The sunflowerseed area for 2018/19 is 3% larger than in 2017/18, despite earlier concerns that falling profit margins would act as a disincentive to farmers. Harvesting has now started, although only a small area has been cut so far. At this early stage field reports suggest that yields have been above earlier expectations and above 2017/18 levels. We have raised our crop forecast to 10% above the 2017/18 outturn. This should ensure sufficient raw material to boost sunflowerseed oil output to 6.2m tonnes, more than 9% higher than in 2017/8 but still below 2016/17 levels.
Russia's 2018-19 crop could be constrained by dry conditions
In Russia, crush rates continue to be consistent with our estimate of just above 4.5m tonnes of sunflowerseed oil production in 2017/18. With harvesting just getting under way, most projections put the crop in the 11.5m-12m tonne range; the previous high was 11.6m tonnes in 2016/17. At this stage we have retained our forecast of 2018/19 sunflowerseed oil output of just over 4.7m tonnes. This would represent relatively modest growth of 3.4% but would still constitute a new record high, exceeding the 2016/17 level.
The outlook for the 2017/18 EU sunflowerseed crop remains firm
The record 2017/18 sunflowerseed crop and high carry-in stocks have supported substantial growth in EU sunflowerseed oil production. Production is estimated at 3.7m tonnes in 2017/18-easily a new record and more than 12% above the 2016/17 output. While sowings for 2018/19 are virtually unchanged, weather conditions have largely been favourable in the important growing regions in south-east and south-central Europe. Crop estimates are tending to rise, with some assessments putting the outturn above 10m tonnes, which would be a new record. We expect EU sunflowerseed oil production in 2018/19 to be only marginally lower than in 2017/18. If the higher crop estimates are realised, sunflowerseed oil production could also set a new record.
Prospects for Argentina's crop remain positive
Recent data suggests that 2017/18 Argentinean sunflowerseed production will not meet our earlier expectations. Our new forecast of the likely outturn is now 1.3m tonnes (as against 1.4m tonnes previously). We continue to expect the planted area to expand in 2018/19, especially given reported difficulties in planting other crops. However, recent weather has not been favourable for crop development, with conditions too dry in many important growing regions. The critical yield-determining period has not yet been reached, but we have made a small reduction in our harvest forecast. On this basis we expect 2018/19 sunflowerseed oil production to reach 1.5m tonnes (almost 12% higher than the previous season), provided export markets can be found.
