Stocks and prices
Although global sunflowerseed stocks at end-2017/18 will be plentiful, they will be lower than at the end of the 2016/17 season, when they were at very low levels. This means that 2017/18 sunflowerseed oil output will rely very heavily on the sunflowerseed harvest. Current projections suggest that the 2018/19 season will be sufficiently strong to support an increase in seed stocks, and consequently rising sunflowerseed oil consumption. Sunflowerseed oil stocks will fall during 2018/19 but should end the season at levels above recent averages.

Upward pressure on prices is likely to be felt from mid-2019 onward
Sunflowerseed oil was the weakest of the major vegetable oils during August, with prices falling by almost US$40/tonne. Sunflowerseed oil continues to trade at significant discounts to both rapeseed oil and soybean oil. With comfortable production and stock levels, we expect that prices will tend to be easier over the 2018/19 season as a whole. While price falls will be limited by the prices of rapeseed and soybean oils, overall sunflowerseed prices are expected to remain below US$750/tonne for much of the season. Early projections suggest that 2019/20 might see below-normal stocks of sunflowerseed oil, and prices could start to edge up towards the end of 2019 and beyond.

Tea
Demand
Global tea consumption is growing steadily, driven mainly by China, which accounts for nearly 40% of world tea consumption and is drinking ever-greater quantities of green tea. However, demand is growing in other major consuming regions as well, including India, which has offset weaker growth in demand in Europe. Despite press coverage of strengthening consumer demand for high-end luxury tea as well as iced tea, this accounts for only a tiny share of the market, with lower-cost varieties continuing to dominate. As such, demand for tea will remain less exposed to economic cycles than other commodities, meaning that tea demand will remain driven principally by demographics. This explains why The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecast for tea consumption growth, of 4.6% a year on average in 2019-20, is relatively high and in line with the long-term historical average. It also explains why our demand-side forecasts tend to remain relatively stable, since consumption of tea is driven by structural factors to a much greater degree than other beverages.
Global demand for black tea will continue to rise, driven in particular by its increasing popularity in China, but the pace of growth will be outstripped by that for green tea, fruit tea, herbal tea, rooibos (from South Africa), purple tea (mainly from Kenya) and high-end organic tea, reflecting their greater reported health benefits and heavy marketing. Iced tea and other ready-to-drink tea beverages account for a small share of the market but have seen rapid growth in sales-notably in the US, but also in traditional markets such as China.
Tea demand will benefit from changing consumer habits
The main tea-consuming countries are also the largest producers, with a rising share of output retained for domestic consumption, partly reflecting domestic marketing campaigns by various tea boards to promote tea-drinking. The premise behind these efforts is that higher domestic consumption will incentivise producers to lift output in order to raise exports. In producing countries tea will also benefit from changing consumption habits related to rising incomes, but in most places it will continue to remain a consumer staple. Combined with favourable demographics, consumption growth in producing countries is therefore likely to rise further. The fact that a smaller share of tea than coffee is consumed in the out-of-home sector-owing partly to customer perceptions that tea in cafés offers less value for money-will shield tea consumption from adverse economic developments, which tend to have less of an impact on at-home consumption.
Both India and China will continue to see robust demand growth in 2019-20
Tea consumption will continue to be dominated by Asian consumers, particularly China and India, which together accounted for an estimated 59% of global demand in 2018, up from 48% in 2010. In China, where growth in tea consumption has averaged over 10% per year in the past decade, we expect tea demand to continue to rise firmly, albeit by a more moderate average of 6.9% per year in 2019-20. Despite this strong growth projection risks to our forecast are primarily to the upside; average consumption per head stands at just over 1 kg/year, ranking China 14th in the world. This leaves room for growth, particularly as only around 35% of the population drinks tea.
Given that tea is regarded as a traditional drink, it will suffer from mounting competition from coffee and soft-drinks retailers, owing to a growing preference for these beverages among younger Chinese consumers. Moreover, younger segments of the population are also showing a preference for black tea over green tea (black tea consumption has risen by an average of 26% per year since 2008, while green tea consumption has risen more gradually), which should bolster demand for black tea, albeit from a low base. Although ready-to-drink products are gaining market share, particularly in cities, the importance attached to the quality of tea means that sales of loose-leaf tea will continue to dominate the local market.
UN data also show a sharp increase in India's tea consumption, to 1.05m tonnes in 2016, accounting for 19% of global tea demand. We estimate that consumption rose by a further 5% in 2017, before accelerating to 6% in 2018. In 2019-20 we expect strong economic growth to be accompanied by higher household spending, firm consumer confidence and supportive demographics, driving annual average growth in tea consumption of 6.4% in 2019-20. Structurally, the Indian market has significant potential-aside from its sheer size, average consumption per head is lower than in China, at just 740 g per year, which bodes well for longer-term demand growth. Currently the out-of-home sector accounts for just under 50% of tea consumption, compared with 85% of the coffee market. The expansion of tea bars across many cities aims to lift this share and fuel overall tea consumption growth.
Structural constraints will hamper tea consumption growth in many markets
Demand in some large consuming countries will be hampered in 2019-20 by market saturation and weakening demographics. Despite a firmer economic performance the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) forecasts overall stagnation until 2027 in European markets (which together account for 4% of global consumption) as well as in Russia, which accounts for 2.5% of global consumption and is the world's largest tea importer. Turkey, which accounts for around 4% of global consumption, has a particularly saturated market, with the highest consumption of tea per head in the world by some margin. The EU also registers some of the world's highest per-capita levels, particularly in the UK and Ireland. Although our forecasts anticipate further growth in demand, reflecting population growth and in many markets ongoing (if weaker) growth in private consumption, the pace will be fairly mild. In 2019-20 we forecast average annual demand growth of 1.2% in the EU and just 0.1% in Turkey, reflecting underlying economic difficulties in the latter. Russian demand growth will be stronger, at an average of 2.7% per year in 2019-20, but this is flattered by a weak base of comparison following a sharp decline in consumption in recent years.
There is plenty of room for market growth in the US
The US is a small market for tea, accounting for an estimated 2.4% of global consumption in 2018, and per-capita consumption is relatively low. However, with most of the larger tea markets dominated by loose-leaf tea, the US remains one of the most important single markets for instant tea and iced tea, with the latter accounting for 85% of the country's total tea consumption. It also remains one of the world's largest tea importers. We expect demand to increase by 3% in 2019, before weaker underlying economic conditions in 2020 prompt a deceleration to 0.9% that year. In the medium term we expect relatively firm demand for tea, with a continued shift away from carbonated drinks towards other beverages.

Supply
Although tea production has recovered in 2018 in both Kenya and China, following a poor outturn in 2017, production has dropped in India. We estimate that this will cause global tea production growth to moderate to 2.7%. We expect global production growth to accelerate in 2019-20, to around 3% per year. Nonetheless, this remains below the long-running average of 4.5% growth per year in 2006-16, with several structural factors preventing faster production growth during the forecast period. In inflation-adjusted terms, farmers' profits are lower than in past decades owing to the higher cost of inputs, which will weigh on investment. In some cases, falling real earnings mean that smallholders' incomes place them within international and national measures of poverty. Investment will also be hampered by overall market perceptions that prospects for longer-term global consumption growth are weaker than those for some other, more fashionable beverages such as coffee, despite the fact that global tea consumption growth will remain fairly strong. In addition, many local currencies will remain weak against the US dollar in 2019-20, which will hamper operating conditions for farmers.
Much of the forecast growth in 2019-20 will come from a rise in green tea output, where growth has outpaced black tea by a significant margin in recent years. Green tea now accounts for one-third of total global tea production, compared with less than one-quarter a decade ago. This mainly reflects rising production in China, where loose-leaf green tea accounts for 68% of domestic production, and in Vietnam, where it now represents 55% of tea output, up from 43% a decade ago. We expect these trends to continue in 2019-20.
Structural efforts in China to bolster tea production
China's tea production rose by an estimated 3.5% in 2017 after heavy rains hit several of the large tea-producing provinces in southern China mid-year, including Hunan, Jiangxi and Zhejiang. The rains were followed by extremely hot weather in some areas (including parts of Zhejiang), which is likely to have hampered production. On the back of more supportive weather conditions, we estimate that tea production growth recovered to 5% in 2018. However, we are forecasting a deceleration in 2019-20, reflecting broader government efforts to improve the enforcement of environmental regulations, with local authorities destroying illegally planted tea bushes. Although we do not believe that these efforts will escalate to a level that would lead to a decline in tea production, it will take the edge of what had previously been extremely strong levels of tea production growth, at an average of 9.1% per year in 2004-16. Despite the tighter enforcement of environmental regulations, the government will still seek to foster increased agricultural productivity. A focus on eliminating rural poverty is likely to be accompanied by continued efforts to improve farmers' access to credit from the Agricultural Development Bank of China, the Agricultural Bank of China and rural credit co-operatives.
Official efforts to promote innovation, increase the use of technology and lift quality standards will also help to spur production, and better availability and quality should boost exports (only about 15% of tea production was exported in 2016). Germany and the US are China's main tea export markets; although trade relations with the US have deteriorated in recent months, tea has not been included in the list of items attracting US import tariffs. We believe that there is potential for gains in productivity, which would also increase long-term tea output growth, since China's average yield per hectare is low by global standards (at 801 kg/ha in 2014-16, compared with 2,153 kg/ha in India and 2,088 kg/ha in Kenya).
India's tea production will grow slowly in 2019-20
After rising by 0.9% in 2017, tea production in India has been disappointing in 2018. Output fell by 5.1% in the first seven months of the year, according to the Tea Board, reflecting dry conditions in Assam (India's largest tea-growing state) as well as in Bengal and parts of southern India. We estimate a 4% drop in tea production in the full calendar year. In 2019-20 we forecast that output will recover gradually, rising by an average of 2.9% per year. Efforts to channel funding to tea growers and to introduce an insurance scheme for smallholders (who account for 50% of production) to protect against falls in market prices and weather-related crop disruption will provide support, but several structural factors will hold back firmer growth in production. There has been little progress on reforms to boost foreign direct investment (FDI) in several sectors, including agriculture. Furthermore, India's tea bushes are old: nearly 40% of existing bushes are over 50 years old, compared with Kenya, where fewer than 30% are over 40 years old, and Vietnam, where the entire tea plantation is less than 20 years old. Replanting has progressed slowly, and rising input costs have eroded profits; labour now accounts for 50% of production costs (a figure that has grown by 12% in the past three years). As a result, India will struggle to raise output as significantly as other major producers in the long term. With several tea manufacturers reporting losses in India (the world's largest firm, McLeod Russel, made losses in India compared with profits in Uganda, Vietnam and Rwanda), it is unclear how much FDI the sector will attract.
High costs will prevent a significant recovery in Sri Lanka's 2018-19 output
Tea production in Sri Lanka bounced back strongly after landslides and severe flooding in May 2017, with full-year production actually rising by 4.1%, despite alarmist warnings of a collapse in output following the heavy rains. In 2018 favourable weather early in the year has been followed by more adverse conditions in recent months, with tea production stagnating in January-July compared with the year-earlier period. We have downgraded our full-year estimate and now expect an increase of just 1%, compared with 4.2% previously. The government's decision to lift a ban on the use of glyphosate weed killer (used by all major tea producers) in tea plantations will provide some support in the near term, since there had been speculation that some key export markets (notably Japan) would cut imports from Sri Lanka on the basis that farmers had resorted to using a replacement chemical, MCPA, which is more stringently regulated in Japan.
However, there are several structural hurdles that will restrict the pace of growth in the medium term. Despite some replanting as a result of a 20% increase in subsidies to small tea farmers, the replanting rate is not high enough to lead to a significant and sustained increase in output. Local reports also show that fertiliser use has been low, and the risk of industrial unrest persists. Sharp wage rises and low mechanisation mean that production costs in Sri Lanka are some of the highest among the world's main tea producers. Reflecting these factors, we forecast a weaker rate of tea production growth, of 1.6% in 2019-20.
Continued production growth in Kenya is likely in 2019-20
After poor weather conditions in the first three quarters of 2017 led to a full-year decline in production of over 7.4%, tea production is showing solid signs of recovery so far in 2018, with output in January-June rising by 14% year on year. As such, we estimate a record output of 500,000 tonnes this year. In 2019-20 we expect only modest production growth, averaging 2.5% per year, as periodic industrial action over pay disputes, combined with a change in the tea levy on farmers-which is now based on the value rather than the volume of sales-undermines profitability and prevents faster growth. The government has pledged to support small farmers and reduce the tax burden, but conflicting interests and a lack of funds will also hinder progress.
Investment will have an impact beyond our forecast period
Many countries have been investing to stimulate tea production, including large producers such as India (which is raising subsidies for plantation rejuvenation), Kenya (where processing plants are being expanded and production is being diversified to non-black varieties) and China (which is concentrating on raising black tea output for export), and even a minor producer, Ethiopia (where Saudi investment is seeking to expand tea production). Other smaller producers, such as Tanzania, Uganda, Rwanda and Bangladesh, have also seen renewed investment. However, we assume that some of these investment plans will be scaled back or suspended altogether, while others will progress only slowly, reflecting overambitious investment plans, bureaucratic hurdles and broader concerns about long-term global oversupply. In addition, it takes 3-5 years for a tea bush to become commercially productive, so the impact of recent price falls on output will be evident only after the forecast period.

Stocks and prices
With consumption growth expected to outstrip production growth in 2019-20, the market balance is expected to fall from an estimated surplus of 13,000 tonnes in 2018 to a deficit of 172,000 tonnes in 2020. Given that there is no global measure of total tea stocks, it is impossible to gauge the degree to which these movements will affect actual physical stock levels. Stock movements have only a limited effect on prices, not least because much of the increase in consumption and production is the result of consumption and output (mainly of green tea) in China. Although some of the annual production data are broken down into green and black tea, the consumption data are not, which prevents a calculation of the market balance in relation to black tea.
Only a fraction of the increase in production will be exported, and even this will not be in any of the three markets (Colombo, Kolkata and Mombasa) where our average tea price is measured. Prices in these markets respond to demand and supply dynamics in Sri Lanka, India and Kenya, respectively (essentially black tea). Often prices diverge between these three markets on the back of local developments that have an impact on supply and demand in the respective auction or to reflect the quality of tea offered at each auction. For example, prices at the Colombo and Mombasa auctions have fallen so far in 2018 as production in Sri Lanka and Kenya have risen, while prices at the Kolkata auction have fallen as Indian output has declined.

Although some of the auction houses are becoming digitised, we do not believe that the tea market will attract sufficient interest from investors to make price dynamics vulnerable to broader global macroeconomic changes. There is currently no futures market, although the latest meeting of the FAO Intergovernmental Group (IGG) on Tea, which took place in May, discussed the feasibility of introducing one in an effort to address price volatility and differentials between individual tea auctions. However, given that the IGG meets fairly sporadically (usually once a year), we do not expect the introduction of a futures market within the forecast period. Prices will therefore remain volatile and largely led by local supply-and-demand factors.
Prices will retreat in 2019 before recovering slightly in 2020
Average tea prices fell from US$3.17/kg in the fourth quarter of 2017 to US$2.96/kg in the second quarter of 2018, with prices stabilising around that level since then. We expect prices to rebound modestly in the third quarter; however, this will be not be sufficent to prevent a drop in average prices over the full year, as we expect prices to weaken again the fourth quarter. We forecast that average prices will fall further in 2019, to an annual average of US$2.81/kg, before picking up to US$2.90/kg in 2020 as demand remains relatively firm, outpacing production growth.

Wheat
Demand
Global wheat consumption has nearly tripled since the 1960s, to more than 730m tonnes in recent years. However, gains in demand, mainly for food and milling purposes, have failed to keep pace with increases in production, resulting in a five-year period of stock accumulation between 2013/14 and 2017/18 (local marketing years). Although stronger demand for wheat has mainly been driven by a rising global population, it should also be noted that wheat demand growth has generally outpaced population growth. Wheat's popularity in diets has been sustained, as has its use as an animal feed ingredient. A small proportion is also used for brewing and the manufacture of starch and ethanol. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global wheat consumption to increase only fractionally in 2018/19, by 0.5% year on year to 738m tonnes, as gains in consumption for food only partially compensate for an expected drop in use for animal feed. Initial projections for 2019/20 remain highly tentative at this stage. Assuming larger crops and renewed growth in the use of wheat as an animal feed, total consumption is projected to rise by 1.9%, to 752m tonnes.
Rising food use is being driven by emerging and developing markets
Annual growth in global wheat consumption for food use has remained relatively consistent over the past decade. Urbanisation, together with shifts in diets and incomes, has also resulted in greater consumption of wheat-based convenience foods, such as noodles and Western-style bakery products, which are best produced using high-quality wheat and flour. With much of the growth in demand stemming from countries outside the main wheat-producing belts, rising demand for milling wheat and flour has been accompanied by an increase in imports in most years. We expect the global use of wheat for food to rise by 1.3% in 2018/19. Growth will be driven mostly by India, Indonesia and Sub-Saharan Africa.
World livestock feed use is expected to drop in 2018/19
Wheat is the world's second-most important grain for use in animal feed, with annual consumption roughly equal to the feed use of barley, sorghum, oats and rye combined. Wheat usage is typically equivalent to one-quarter of the amount of maize that goes into animal feed each year. Given shrinking supplies and continued strong competition from maize-especially in the EU and US-we expect feed use of wheat to drop below recent peaks to a five-year low of 133m tonnes. Demand will depend on relative pricing and overall levels of quality. Following huge crop losses across northern Europe, feed-wheat supplies are expected to be much tighter in 2018/19, and demand will potentially need to be rationed. Feed-wheat use in the EU, which accounts for around 40% of the world total, is currently predicted to drop by around 6m tonnes in 2018/19 to around 48m tonnes as users switch to more competitively priced alternatives, mainly imported maize. Strong export demand for barley may limit how much of that grain is fed domestically in the coming season. However, given this season's very short pasture and grazing availabilities, prospects for the EU feed-grain market outlook are still quite uncertain, and much will depend on how price relationships develop over the coming months. Feed-wheat use in South Korea, Thailand and Vietnam could also decline. However, feed use of wheat in China is expected to rise as more sub-standard domestic supplies are diverted into feed mills in the main southern meat-consuming hubs.
A large harvest is expected to contain Morocco's import needs
Wheat is a staple food in Morocco, where per-capita consumption has long been among the highest in the world, estimated at 216 kg annually in recent years. As domestic production is highly dependent on seasonal rainfall, there are occasionally huge swings in output from one year to the next. This was particularly evident just a few seasons ago, when a record crop of 8.1m tonnes in 2015/16 was followed by an outturn of just 2.7m tonnes in 2016/17. With annual domestic needs close to 9.5m tonnes, Morocco is a major buyer on the global market, importing an average of 4.3m tonnes per year, mainly from the EU, the Black Sea region and Canada. After an unusually dry start to the 2018/19 winter wheat planting season, which prevented some farmers from sowing the intended area, abundant rains in recent months have greatly revived crop prospects, and production should be on track to match last season's 7.1m tonnes, including 4.8m tonnes of soft milling wheat and 2.3m tonnes of durum. As part of efforts to contain third-country arrivals, the Ministry of Agriculture announced in early May 2018 that import duties on common wheat would be hiked to 135% (from 35%) until the end of October 2018.
China has imposed 25% tariffs on US-origin wheat imports
Following the souring of the US-China trade relationship in recent months, a number of US agricultural products, including wheat, are now subject to an additional 25% duty on imports into China. With purchases mainly linked to quality shortfalls in its own huge domestic crop and capped by a restrictive licensing system, China is usually not an overly large importer of wheat. Annual imports have recently averaged 4.1m tonnes per year, with the US typically maintaining a 32% share. Buying interest has almost completely dried up in recent months, mainly reflecting price considerations, but with some importers also reportedly wary of the risk of additional checks or holdups when sourcing US wheat. Instead, local buyers have so far looked to secure additional supplies from Russia and Kazakhstan. We expect Chinese demand to recover in 2018/19-2019/20 by 2.1%, after an estimated decline of 1.3% in 2017/18.

Supply
World wheat production has reached unprecedented levels in recent seasons, with output climbing to successive highs in each of the past five years. Part of this upswing is linked to a small overall rise in plantings, with harvested area trending marginally higher, but much of this has been tied to better average yields, seen close to 3.5 tonnes/ha in 2017/18, compared with 2.8 tonnes/ha a decade ago. Despite concerns about years of underinvestment in wheat-seed technology, productivity gains have been achieved almost everywhere as farmers employ ever more advanced agronomic practices. However, following extended periods of adverse weather across many key producers and exporters, world output in 2018/19 is projected at 715m tonnes, down 5.7% from 2017/18 and potentially the smallest crop since 2010/11. Despite an earlier build-up of stocks, the sheer scale of the drop in production, combined with a solid demand base, has quickly shrunk exportable availabilities. Prices have begun to rise, especially in Europe, with US supplies gradually turning more competitive. Assuming more normal weather conditions, world production is expected to rebound by 4.9% in 2019/20, with output pegged at 750m tonnes.
A drop in 2018/19 plantings and yields will cause EU production to decline
Cumulative production in the EU is forecast to slump by 10.7% in 2018/19, the smallest total in in six seasons. This reflects downgrades in expected yields in northern Europe, the Baltics and Scandinavia. The winter wheat harvest in Germany, typically the bloc's second-largest grower, was finished much earlier than normal. Due to a damaging drought, average yields are down by one-quarter compared with the five-year average, with production seen dropping to only around 18.5m tonnes, compared with 24.2m tonnes in 2017/18. Similarly bad conditions have been reported in Poland, normally the EU's third-largest wheat exporter. Amid exceptionally hot weather in recent months, even sharper declines in yields are expected in Denmark, Sweden and Finland. Harvesting in France, by some distance the EU's largest grower and exporter, was finished by early August. While production is expected to fall slightly short of the average, cropping weather was generally more favourable than in more northern states, and output is expected to fall by only around 8%, to some 36m tonnes. The production shortfall is expected to limit exportable supplies in the 2018/19 marketing year severely, with exports potentially seen falling to just 21m tonnes, down 6% from last season and perhaps the lowest level since 2011/12.We expect the situation to improve in 2019/20, when overall EU output is forecast to grow by 9.6%, still around 3m tonnes less than the 2017/18 level.
Russia's output will decline by almost 20% in 2018/19
The outlook for Russia has also deteriorated. While the 2018/19 crop is still on course to be similar to the recent average, it will fall well short of the previous year's record. The harvest is now expanding into Siberia. Spring wheat yields in that region are typically low, and while some operators have reported positive results, so far crops were planted very late in some areas. This implies that here is a risk of greater than normal levels of abandonment, especially if winter conditions arrive early. Based on latest harvest updates, it appears that recent cuts to our production forecasts might have been overly harsh, with total output now seen at close to 68m tonnes (66m tonnes previously), broadly similar to the recent average but down sharply from last year's enormous crop of 84.9m tonnes. This will mark a contraction of almost 20% in 2018/19, before output rebounds by 5.9% in 2019/20. Winter grains sowing for harvest in 2019 has started in parts of southern Russia, where soil moisture deficiencies have been reported.
Speculation about possible export controls has gained traction in recent weeks, amid meetings between the Ministry of Agriculture and the National Association of Exporters of Agricultural Products (NAESP). While there remains some disagreement about exactly what was discussed at these meetings-with some observers pointing out some subtle differences between Russian and English-language statements-it is clear that authorities are monitoring the situation closely. Local feed manufacturers are said to be particularly concerned about tightening local supplies and rising prices. There have been some indications that grain exports could be capped at 30m tonnes, including 25m tonnes of wheat; based on the current very strong pace of shipments, this level could potentially be reached as soon as January 2019. This year's early harvest has quickly replenished exportable pipelines, and with a much weaker rouble inflating exporter returns, 2018/19 (July-June marketing year) shipments have started very rapidly. The threat of export controls has also spurred additional sales as exporters look to maximise shipments ahead of possible restrictions later in 2018.
Average yields in Ukraine are likely to drop
Ukraine's Ministry of Agriculture announced in August that it had reached an agreement with exporters to ship 16m tonnes of wheat in 2018/19 (July/June), including up to 8m tonnes of milling varieties. These Memorandums of Understanding are signed each season and are used as an informal mechanism of ensuring adequate domestic supplies. In some press reports and across social media the deal was instead reported as a formal limit on exports. With markets already nervous about shrinking exportable wheat availabilities, prices quickly spiked higher before dropping again on official confirmation that exports were not being restricted. The 2018/19 winter harvest is now complete and is forecast at around 25.4m tonnes; this is almost 6% down compared with 2017/18 levels, with an increase in acreage more than offset by a drop in average yields. Final quality evaluations are still ongoing, but it seems likely that a smaller percentage of this year's crop will meet milling specifications.
Chinese output to drop in 2018/19
As part of ongoing agricultural market reforms and with a view to capping centrally held stockpiles, China's government recently outlined some further adjustments of its minimum support price programme for 2018/19. After lowering the support price late last year, the authorities announced that purchases of standard (3rd class) wheat between June 1st and September 30th will only be made once the government has confirmed that the average market price has fallen below the minimum price for three successive days. While tinkering with foodgrain price support measures remains a sensitive policy area, the current system has resulted in a sharp build-up of moderate-gluten wheat supplies and the need for costly stockpiling. More radical changes in policy can therefore be expected in the years ahead.
Based on latest production data by province, we expect Chinese output to decline by 5.6% in 2018/19-a five-year low of 122.5m tonnes. Excessive rains have badly affected yields and quality in parts of Henan, Anhui and Jiangsu provinces, where final results were even worse than previously anticipated. Local officials have reportedly been instructed to support affected farmers by procuring sub-standard wheat under the minimum support price programme. It is unclear how much wheat will be procured and exactly what it will be used for, but it is expected to be diverted into feed channels as long as mycotoxin specifications are met.
Spring wheat yields relatively disappointing in parts of Canada
With drier than normal weather affecting crops across the Canadian Prairies, the latest official survey-based production data included sharper than expected downgrades in yields for spring wheat and durum. Despite increases in area planted in Saskatchewan, Alberta and Manitoba, average yields are expected to decline in all three provinces. Harvesting is making good progress overall, with operations already finished in Manitoba, where yields and quality are said to be higher than previously expected. Overall, however, we have reduced our production forecast for 2018/19 to 30m tonnes (from 31m tonnes previously), unchanged from 2017/18 levels. We expect conditions to improve, and the output to grow by 4% in 2019/20.

Argentina imposes an export tax on primary exports
Faced with deepening financial market woes, which include a massive depreciation in the value of the peso, soaring interest rates and rampant inflation, the Argentinean president recently unveiled new revenue-raising measures aimed at an accelerated loan agreement with the IMF. As part of this, the president has announced a reversal of his flagship commodity tax-cutting policies, applying a floating tax of 4 pesos per US dollar on primary exports, including agricultural products such as wheat, maize and soybeans. The policy, which is effective from September 4th until the end of 2020, is based on current calculations and basically places a 10.5% export tax on wheat. With the levy only recently announced, there is still uncertainty about whether previously declared export sales will be subject to the new arrangements. In the short term, farmers may hold back from selling dollar-denominated agricultural products by means of a hedge against currency movements, especially if foreign-exchange-market volatility continues. However, the announcement will have no bearing on 2018/19 wheat production, as plantings are already complete.
After an extremely favourable start to the cropping year, with soil moisture adequate almost everywhere, conditions have turned progressively drier. Rains have been particularly scarce in parts of Cordoba province and in the north of the country. However, local sources continue to report better conditions in core central producing areas. Because of expected strong returns, plantings increased by around 7% year on year. Farmers are also reported to have maximised fertiliser use, which should be supportive of yields. Forecast production is maintained at a record 20m tonnes, marking an increase of 8.1% in 2018/19. This trend will continue in 2019/20, and production is forecast to increase by an additional 5% in that year.
Stocks and prices
Following five consecutive increases, the world wheat carryover is forecast to contract by 8.6% by the end of 2018/19 to around 246m tonnes, still the second-highest ever and some 9% higher than the previous five-year average. Stockpiles in China are expected to grow even larger, seen rising by as much as 5% to 132m tonnes, equivalent to more than half of the global total. Since stocks there will only ever be used to satisfy local demand, many observers have argued that China should be excluded from global stock calculations. The US Department of Agriculture (USDA) recently announced that its supply-and-demand outlook would at some point in the future include such estimates. Other organisations suggest that it is perhaps more useful to measure stocks in the eight largest exporters as a proxy for global supply. Cumulative stocks in these countries are expected to tighten by 23.4m tonnes to 58.1m tonnes, a 29% year-on-year decline. Exporter stocks are forecast to reach their tightest level in five seasons. A smaller exportable surplus and the need to ration demand away from feed channels are expected to provide a floor to prices going forward, especially in the event of further crop downgrades. Based on early projections for 2019/20 supply and demand, wheat ending stocks could decline again by the end of the following season by an additional 1%. However, exporter inventories are projected to be larger by 11% in that year.

An earlier slump in prices has been undone
World wheat markets have become more volatile in recent months. As the focus turned on increasingly tight wheat supply-and-demand fundamentals, average milling wheat prices rallied by around 15% between late June and mid-August. Despite expectations of much tighter availabilities in the season ahead, around half of these gains have since been reversed. This most recent downturn was linked to speculation that the gains had been overdone, especially given that no restrictions had yet been imposed on Russian exports. While prices have corrected somewhat, we would still argue that risks are on the upside. We expect that price direction in the coming months will largely be shaped by the final results from northern hemisphere harvests, and perhaps more particularly the exact size of Russia's 2018/19 surplus. Average prices are expected to strengthen in 2018, but assuming Russian shipments remain high in the coming years, world prices are expected to show only limited upside potential over the remainder of the forecast period.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Economic collapse and the erosion of the patronage scheme supporting the president, Nicolás Maduro, has put the ruling regime's internal cohesion in jeopardy. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a traumatic rift that will end in regime pragmatists allowing opposition participation in a "mixed administration" as a way to remain in power from 2019 onwards. There is a risk that the existing regime will retain cohesion and cling to power beyond 2019 if it finds financing to meet its debt obligations and boost dwindling oil production.
We estimate that inflation exceeded 2,500% at the end of 2017 and will reach 715,130% by end-2018. GDP will continue to contract in 2018-20. High inflation has led to a collapse in private consumption, and difficult operating conditions have hurt investment. Following a change in policy under a new government, we expect economic growth to resume in 2021.
The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. From 2019 a new government will stabilise the economy, but the wholesale rethink of the institutional framework needed to restore investment and confidence is unlikely.
Worsening shortages of consumer goods and hyperinflation will hit private consumption, and an increasingly difficult operating environment will accentuate a fall in fixed investment. The recession that began in 2014 will continue to deepen despite a partial recovery in oil prices as oil output slumps, and the economy will not return to growth until 2021-assuming that a new government takes power and implements reforms. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, reinforcing our forecasts of only a weak recovery.
US dollar measurements of Venezuela's market size provide an overly positive picture of the economy, given the marked overvaluation of the fixed exchange rate. In reality, recession and extremely high inflation (driven by shortages of foreign exchange and basic goods) will continue to restrict purchasing power. After 2020, under a new government, we expect purchasing power and the business environment to improve.

Venezuela is in 82nd position globally in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings for 2019-23, making the country the least attractive investment location in our ranking. This reflects the highly heterodox macroeconomic policies of an authoritarian government, a lack of legal security and weak institutions.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Start of roll-back of interventionist measures like price controls, but political-instability concerns slow liberalisation. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition.
2021-23: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Regulation by new government protecting property rights introduced in an attempt at attracting investment.
2021-23: Despite efforts, actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2019-20: Currency controls are made less opaque but restrictions on the private sector's access to foreign currency remain in place.
2021-23: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2019-20: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2020-22: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2019-20: Inflation remains high and concerns about economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2021-23: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2019-20: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. The current freeze on redundancies is fazed-out
2021-23: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Underinvestment in the water and electricity grid ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2021-23: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued water and electricity rationing.
Technological readiness
2019-20: E-government services remain almost non-existent and deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment.
2021-23: Limited regulator capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has plummeted as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices has plunged the country into a massive economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded republican institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is how to stabilise an economy mired in a years-long economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. At the same time, mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign-exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Using IMF data, The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$21.1bn in 2017 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages. We estimate the current-account surplus at 2% of GDP that year.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
Despite a decimated economy and spiralling hyperinflation, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) and the president, Nicolás Maduro, retain their hold on power. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects worsening economic conditions to result in a chaotic political transition, most likely ushering in a government with nominal opposition participation-a "mixed administration"-at some point in the forecast period. Our forecasts are based on the assumption that this will happen during 2019. But the process will be highly uncertain and may feature several false starts. We expect the forecast period to be characterised by political instability.
The opposition, due to its own penchant for infighting and years of government harassment, is in disarray and incapable of channelling the anger generated by the country's economic crisis. Even so, the PSUV is dependent on the military for support. The country is run by civic-military alliance and a network of businessmen with military or political connections. This network is sustained by opportunities for corruption made possible by foreign-exchange controls, subsidised imports, clientelism and control of wasteful public-sector companies. Within this arrangement, factions are primarily explained by personal and patronage ties, resulting in different civic-military factions coexisting within the regime. The ultimate source of resources flowing through this patronage system is the export revenue generated by PDVSA, the state-owned oil company.
Jeopardising the civic-military alliance is PDVSA's declining output due to mismanagement and underinvestment. Resultant strains have been highlighted by periodic purges in the military and re-organisations in civilian posts within the regime. Given the government's proven incompetence and lack of financing, we expect declining oil output to jeopardise the patronage system supporting Mr Maduro. This process may be hastened if exports are disrupted by external forces, such as US government sanctions on the oil trade (the US is PDVSA's largest cash-paying market and a key source of production inputs) or asset seizures stemming from unpaid debts.
Regardless of the timing, what will happen following any internal fracture is hard to predict. The transition could be violent, chaotic and potentially lengthy. The PSUV's internal stability is a concern, as the end of the current set-up is likely to unleash jostling for position between the PSUV's varied civic-military factions.
It is possible that the regime may reconfigure itself as an outright military government or with a PSUV civilian figurehead fronting a military-heavy administration. However, given that the regime's raison d'etre is the enrichment of its members, stabilisation of PDVSA and the economy would be likely to take priority under a new government. Thus-assuming, crucially, that assistance from Russia and China would be insufficient-we expect regime pragmatists to seek Western assistance-specifically from multilaterals and governments. As these financiers will demand democratic reforms, we believe that the most likely outcome of the political transition is a "mixed administration", in which pragmatically minded regime leaders allow opposition participation to gain international legitimacy. Given past behaviour, there should be no shortage of opposition figures willing to participate.
The main risk to this mixed administration baseline view is that regime pragmatists will be unable to secure consensus within the regime. Democratic reforms (and consequent judicial accountability for current regime leaders) that Western lenders would insist on may not be acceptable to some PSUV figures. Similarly, foreign financing would underpin a macroeconomic programme that-by eliminating the economy's distortions-would close avenues for corruption and upset regime insiders. Other hurdles of uncertain size will remain. These include the judiciary, the de facto legislature that is the Constituent Assembly (ANC), and the radicalised supporters of the PSUV known as colectivos. In this context, there are strong risks to our baseline assumption of political transition, and a strong possibility of alternate scenarios including a more permanently impoverished nation.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
We do not expect free and fair elections in the short term. Municipal elections are scheduled for December 9th. Most of the opposition has been proscribed and only some parties are participating (which has led to further infighting). In this context, a PSUV sweep is all but guaranteed. Based on our political assumptions, an electoral timetable may be announced, as international financing will almost certainly come with demands for democratic reforms.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Most regional governments have denounced the Venezuelan government, as has the EU. The US has put individual sanctions on most regime leaders, including Mr Maduro, his closest allies, and three of the regime's strongmen: Vladimir Padrino López, Diosdado Cabello and Tareck El Aissami. Although this limits the field of negotiating partners in the event of an internal fracture of the regime, the US has stated that sanctions may be reversed if the subjects "take concrete...actions to restore democratic order". The US has also instituted country-level sanctions that, among other effects, block Venezuela from refinancing its debts. Sanctions banning the oil trade are not part of our baseline assumption, but the hawkish US foreign policy team increases risks to this assumption. Despite recent public rhetoric, we do not currently foresee military intervention.
A priority for the Maduro administration is the maintenance of good relations with Russia and China, with a view to securing the necessary financing to stabilise the economy and PDVSA. Both have provided financing in the past but, despite recent announcements, they seem unwilling to provide the several billions of dollars required. A change in the current Chinese stance represents a major risk to our forecast.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Monetisation of large public deficits, coupled with mismanagement of the state-dominated oil industry, has led to hyperinflation and shortages of foreign currency, basic goods and industrial inputs. The government has reacted to the deepening of the crisis in recent months, but it remains unable and unwilling to undertake the deep and wide-ranging policy and institutional changes needed. Furthermore, patchy implementation has once again demonstrated the government's unwillingness-or incapacity-to enact real change. An economic plan launched in late August included the removal of five zeroes from the currency, a massive devaluation and another large increase in the minimum wage. The government also promised to abolish the monetisation of public deficits, but available money supply data show that it has not done so. As such, monetary imbalances will persist and foreign exchange will continue to be rationed. Economic policy will remain interventionist in the short term, deepening the economic crisis that underpins our baseline forecast of political change. Furthermore, outside of promising a hard to implement reduction in fuel subsidies, the plan had little focus on PDVSA's falling output; production at PDVSA remains crucial factor in supporting the economy amid a collapse in the non-oil sector.
With no capacity to finance investment, the government announced in September that it had secured US$5bn in funding from China to boost oil output, but details are hazy. It is unclear how much has been disbursed and how much control the Chinese will exert over how the funds are spent. Regardless, the US$5bn seems insufficient to stem the decline in oil output and, if the increased production is earmarked to pay back Chinese loans, it will do little to promote macroeconomic stability.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect that more orthodox economic policies will be implemented under a new government. However, the pace of adjustment, and the policy mix itself, will be complicated by uncertainty over the stability of any new regime, and whether this takes precedence over the likely demands for reform from multilateral and bilateral lenders. Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and multilaterals (totalling US$19bn in 2019-22) and the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. This in itself will be a huge task for any administration. At the same time, PDVSA will need wholesale reform to open itself to the foreign finance needed to increase output, a process that will require considerable political capital.
Pockets of resistance are likely to exist. Internal stability within the PSUV is a major risk to our forecast, as the success of a mixed administration would depend on PSUV pragmatists fending off more radical party members. These members would oppose international assistance, foreign investment and policy reforms on both ideological and personal grounds (as many regime insiders profit from the state's indirect and direct control of the economy).
Outside of these areas, we do not expect much success in rolling back the PSUV's strong interventionist bent in the economy. As a result, we expect extremely limited real investment inflows, the vast majority going into the oil sector, which will restrict economic recovery and fuel continued unrest.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
Authorities have not published complete official data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We estimate that the fiscal deficit is well into double figures as a percentage of GDP. The government relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency.
High inflation and the overvalued official exchange rate make debt/GDP ratios misleading indicators of fiscal stability. Considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) understates the true size of total public liabilities. Most sovereign and state-owned bonds (including PDVSA's) are in arrears. Bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy changes or a change in leadership. An exception regarding default is a single bond issued by PDVSA, which has 50.1% of Citgo as collateral. A payment of US$949m will come due on October 27th and it is unclear if the government will be able to meet it. Crystallex (Canada) is already attempting to seize Citgo to collect a legal award and ConocoPhillips (US) has halted its attempts at seizing PDVSA's assets in the Caribbean pending payments of a settlement, the first instalment of which is reportedly scheduled for mid-November. We believe that, if forced to choose, the government would prioritise its Caribbean assets over Citgo, as the former are key for PDVSA's capacity to export while sales to Citgo could be re-routed to other US companies. However, it is unclear when the government may have to choose. In the short term, the regime may not meet the ConocoPhillips settlement, and try to further delay payment.
Under our baseline forecast, we expect a restructuring with external creditors in 2020. Owing to the need to maintain political stability, we do not expect the closure of the various handout programmes in operation, nor the complete removal of utility subsidies or the reformation of inefficient state-owned firms. Therefore, we expect public expenditure to be hard to reduce; we expect the deficit to be substantial throughout the 2019-23 period.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank) to print money. Despite the regime's assurances to the contrary, money supply continues to grow rapidly, expanding by 378% month on month at end-September. We expect a new administration to place a much greater emphasis on tackling hyperinflation, and expect a substantial monetary adjustment in the context of a macroeconomic stabilisation plan. The introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) in such a context is possible.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 15% in 2018, we expect further contractions in 2019-20. A forecast recovery in 2021-23 rests on the assumption of a political transition that, supported by IMF assistance, produces a credible macroeconomic programme with improved management of oil wealth. However, reform will be limited in scope by a weak government, and we expect only a partial rebound in real GDP, following a decline of around 50% in 2013-20.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2018, reflecting the effect on real wages of hyperinflation, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will also contract, reflecting difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange. Our forecast for a recovery in investment later in the forecast period assumes a political transition and a pick-up in oil investment.
We expect oil output to bottom out at 1m barrels/day (b/d) in mid-2019, kept from going lower owing to PDVSA's joint-venture partners. Under our baseline forecast of openness to foreign investment under a new government from 2019, production will start to recover in the second half of 2020, but will remain well below 2m b/d, the average output in 2017, even at the end of our forecast period.
Export volumes will only start to recover in 2020, as an increase in domestic demand, which has been artificially constrained, will initially absorb the increase in oil output. For the same reason, import demand will rise sharply in 2019.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Decimated domestic supply, severe limits on imports and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official data have not been published since 2015, but the opposition-led National Assembly estimated that monthly inflation was 233% (488,865% year on year) in September. In the context of a macroeconomic stabilisation plan in 2019, we expect much tighter monetary policy and lower inflation.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
Under our current baseline forecast, the introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) amid deep imbalances and as a means to try to tackle hyperinflation is possible in 2019. The exact nature and implementation of such moves are hard to foresee, but our baseline forecast includes the continuation of some currency controls for the duration of the forecast period.
Since the start of the year the government has devalued the official exchange rate by over 99%. At the same time the government announced the "free convertibility" of foreign exchange, but in practice the exchange controls remain. The official rate is determined by an auction system, but the government-which monopolises the country's exports-does not supply the system with foreign-exchange, making the system unsustainable and access to foreign exchange practically impossible. In early October the black-market exchange rate was around BsS110:US$1; the official rate stood at BsS63:US$1.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
After an estimated current-account surplus of US$14.2bn in 2018, we expect the current account to remain in surplus for most of the forecast period. These figures are buoyed by non-payment of interest on bonded debt ("savings" in excess of US$5bn in 2018 alone). Our export data, which are based on IMF data, may overstate receipts, as some exports are actually payments in-kind for loans the repayment of which may not be included in their totality under forecast interest repayments (we have excluded repayments to Chinese lenders to maintain consistency with the World Bank's data on which our debt forecasts are based).
By 2020, with a new government in power, we expect that-following debt renegotiation-external financing will be restored. Although we expect exports to grow as oil production increases, we also expect a surge in imports, as Venezuela's own productive base has been decimated and imports have been compressed to artificially low levels. In addition, the government will be complying with its debt obligations, meaning that the restructured debt will actually result in increased outflows in interest payments. These factors will erode the current-account surplus from 4.9% of GDP in 2020 to a deficit of 1.6% by 2023.
We currently expect that the new administration will secure sufficient finance to stabilise the balance-of-payments dynamics. However, there are considerable risks to this rosy outlook. In addition to assuming a pragmatic mixed administration capable of retaining power, it hinges on substantial finance from the IMF, the quick implementation of a successful macroeconomic stabilisation package, the fast resolution of a debt renegotiation process in 2019-20, substantial inflows of financial and real investment into the economy in 2020-23, and a fast recovery in oil output after years of underinvestment and mismanagement.

The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
BCV: Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank)

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
In June Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected as president for a second term in snap presidential and parliamentary elections, in which his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a coalition majority in parliament with the right-wing Nationalist Action Party (MHP).
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Mr Erdogan and the AKP to remain in power throughout the forecast period (2019-23), and possibly beyond.
Following the June elections, an executive presidency has replaced the former parliamentary system of government. The new system provides few checks on the president's powers, raising the risk of discretionary policymaking.
Since the failed coup in July 2016, there has been a marked deterioration in Turkey's relations with its Western allies. We expect a rupture to be avoided, but tensions will remain high and relations could sour quickly.
Turkey's relationship with the US will deteriorate in 2019-23, owing to bilateral tensions that so far appear hard to resolve. The possible US imposition of sanctions on Turkish banks for evading US Iran-related sanctions is a risk.
Turkey's relationship with the EU will remain transactional. Turkey will not make progress with accession talks and is unlikely to manage to renegotiate the terms of its customs union with the EU.
The government's focus on domestic power struggles, economic growth and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate.
We forecast a slowdown in real GDP growth from 7.3% in 2017 to about 3.5% per year in 2018-23, reflecting the impact of the August 2018 currency crisis, higher interest rates, global trade tensions, and more moderate export growth.
The lira will depreciate in nominal terms against the US dollar during the forecast period, to TL6.2:US$1 at end-2023, as a result of negative foreign investor sentiment, high inflation and the large current-account deficit.
As a result of the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar (which will boost competitiveness and depress imports), we forecast that the current-account deficit will shrink in 2019-23, to an annual average of 3.4% of GDP. Turkey will struggle to meet its external financing needs throughout the forecast period.

Turkey's score deteriorates only slightly in 2019-23, but in the global rankings the country falls by ten places, to 59th. The failed coup in 2016 and the government's response have increased the level of uncertainty about the direction of economic policy. Shortcomings include a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Political instability and adverse market conditions will delay further privatisation deals.
2021-23: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in several sectors.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but macroeconomic instability and concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2021-23: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Capital controls are not considered, despite the scale of the currency collapse. Political tensions resulting in tit-for-tat tariffs and US sanctions will disrupt Turkish-US trade and relations.
2021-23: Negotiations with the EU to update the customs union are likely to be protracted, given poor Turkish-EU relations.
Taxes
2019-20: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Tax rises introduced in 2018 to curb the widening of the budget deficit reduce company profits.
2021-23: Income tax base becomes broader as exemptions and exceptions are reduced.
Financing
2019-20: Asset quality likely to deteriorate on the back of financial market turmoil in 2018. Central Bank of Turkey to lower rates gradually as inflation moderates in 2019. Risk of the US imposing fines or sanctions on some Turkish banks.
2021-23: Lending growth to pick up again as banking system regains strength. Continued reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2019-20: Relatively high labour costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment.
2021-23: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2019-20: First phase of third airport in Istanbul becomes operational. Slower progress made on other projects.
2021-23: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks might persist.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Spending on research and development remains moderate, at about 1% of GDP, holding back efforts to move the economy up the value-added ladder.
2021-23: Turkey's young population spurs further rapid digital transformation of the banking sector.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then, Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West. The country became a member of the Council of Europe (in 1949) and NATO (in 1952), and signed an association agreement with the then European Community (in 1963). A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but a coup attempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey currently has a presidential system of government, with parliament elected for a five-year term. To win seats, parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Since the failed coup, power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president and AKP leader, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who was re-elected as president for a second term in June 2018. Following his re-election, a presidential system of government was introduced and the post of prime minister was abolished.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability and stabilising the lira following the August 2018 currency crisis are Turkey's biggest policy challenges. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and tightening global liquidity conditions require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy tight to attract adequate capital inflows and slow down the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar. The Kurdish issue, which has blocked economic development in the south east, is one of Turkey's most pressing policy challenges, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015, and there has been a resurgence in violence. Politicisation of the judiciary since the coup attempt has undermined its independence. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The corporation tax rate has been raised in 2018, from 20% to 22%. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Reducing tax evasion was one of the elements of previous IMF programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2017 goods exports came to US$166bn and imports to US$225bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$59bn and a current-account deficit of US$47bn (or 5.6% of GDP). The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".
