Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
In June Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected for a second term in the first round of a snap presidential election. On the same day, his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a parliamentary coalition majority with its right-wing ally, the Nationalist Action Party (MHP). The election process appeared mostly free, but largely unfair. Opposition candidates received little or no media coverage; the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP) candidate, Selahattin Demirtas, had to campaign from prison; and the government restrained freedom of speech and freedom of association. Mr Erdogan secured a majority of the vote on a high turnout. Results published by opposition observers were very similar to those announced by the government.
Mr Erdogan's re-election concludes Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. This move was initiated with a constitutional referendum in April 2017, which the government narrowly won. The new system grants the president wide-ranging executive powers-including in the selection of most of the officials in the judiciary-and will greatly weaken parliament. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the AKP and Mr Erdogan, who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in July 2016, to remain in power until 2023, and possibly beyond.
Mr Erdogan will continue to clamp down on political dissent and opposition. Despite allowing the state of emergency to expire on July 18th, parliament passed a security law on July 25th that imposes stringent impediments on freedoms. These are similar to those of the state of emergency, which was introduced after the attempted coup, in a bid to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric who is accused by the Turkish government of masterminding the coup plot.
Security risk remains high, as Turkey appears vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and Islamic State (IS). Neither the government nor the PKK is interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will return to 1990s levels. Turkey's military operations in Syria seek to block the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds affiliated with the PKK but risk fuelling the conflict with the PKK in south-east Turkey. The formation of a governing coalition between the AKP and the MHP will hinder attempts to resolve the Kurdish issue, as the MHP is likely to push for hawkish policies aimed at constraining and delegitimising the HDP. In addition, the MHP will advocate repatriation of Syrian refugees and adopt a tough stance on all issues related to national security, in line with Mr Erdogan's ultra-nationalist and conservative views.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Parliamentary and presidential elections were held on June 24th, earlier than the originally scheduled date of late 2019. Mr Erdogan was re-elected as president in the first round, securing 52.6% of the vote on a turnout of 86.2%. In the parliamentary election the AKP lost its absolute majority (although it secured a coalition majority alongside its partner, the MHP) as the HDP managed to poll more than the 10% threshold needed to enter parliament. The AKP received 42.6% of the vote, the MHP 11.1%, the Republican People's Party (CHP) 22.6%, the HDP 11.7% and the Good Party (IP) 10%.
Local elections will be held as planned in March 2019, despite recent signals from the AKP pointing to an increasing possibility of bringing them forward to November or December. The shift of focus to the local polls in the aftermath of the June elections is a sign that Turkey will remain in election mood until next year.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Domestic political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign policy sphere. Although not our core forecast, there is a risk of a rupture in the country's ties with its traditional Western allies. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration in relations, including a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the failed coup; US military backing for PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurdish groups; Turkey's forging of closer relations with China, Russia and Iran; and US sanctions on Turkish government officials owing to Turkey's detention of a US pastor on terrorist charges. The government's authoritarian tendencies and confrontational approach (partly motivated by Mr Erdogan's need to appeal to nationalists) have also damaged relations with Turkey's Western allies.
Turkey's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic and transactional, rather than strategic. However, we expect Turkey and its Western allies to avoid a breakdown in relations. Turkey and the EU have a common interest in handling refugee inflows from Syria and Iraq; the fact that Mr Erdogan visited Germany on September 28th-29th lends credence to this view. However, EU-Turkey relations would deteriorate quickly if the EU suspends Turkey's moribund accession negotiations, or if Turkey closes the Incirlik air base to US forces or withdraws from NATO (not our core forecast).
Turkey's involvement in the conflict in Syria will continue to influence the direction of its foreign policy. Relations between Turkey and Russia have improved in the last two years, but the level of trust is still low. In September Turkey and Russia announced an agreement to create and jointly patrol a demilitarised zone in Idlib, the last rebel-held governorate in northern Syria. However, this does not alter our view that they are co-operating in Syria while pursuing contrasting goals (Russia backs the government led by Bashar al-Assad, the Syrian president, while Turkey provides support to rebels). As a result, we expect relations to continue to be transactional. The risk of new tensions emerging will remain high, all the more so as the Turkish government will seek to deter Russia from conducting military operations in Syria that could result in a large influx of refugees at the Syria-Turkey border.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
The government's past focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. Nonetheless, Turkey's economy has shown resilience during previous bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing largely to its solid public finances, its well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector, and its dynamic, diversified private business sector.
In the aftermath of the failed coup in July 2016, a highly accommodative policy stance has exacerbated fiscal as well as external imbalances. This, together with heightened political uncertainty, the tightening of global liquidity conditions and tensions with the US, led to a currency crisis in August 2018. The heavily pro-growth approach to economic policymaking that Mr Erdogan has espoused enthusiastically over the past decade will remain a predominant feature over our forecast period (2019-23), at the expense of inflation control and fiscal discipline. Such an approach will continue to have an important effect on, for example, monetary policy, macroprudential regulation, public-private capital investments and social spending. Shortcomings such as cronyism and corruption, skills mismatches (a key factor behind the high unemployment rate), and tax evasion are unlikely to be addressed in 2019-23, as propping up economic growth-partly to avoid social unrest-will remain the priority.
In the case of a severe economic or banking crisis (not our core forecast), Turkey's options will remain limited, as Gulf Co-operation Council (GCC) countries appear unwilling to offer financial support, partly because Turkey is forging closer ties with Iran, a country with which Saudi Arabia is at odds. Meanwhile, an IMF programme would include what the government would regard as unacceptable conditionality and would run counter to Mr Erdogan's nationalist, anti-Western rhetoric. Finally, there is little prospect of EU financial assistance, not least because there would be no consensus on this issue among EU member states. Only China, therefore, appears able at present to offer a financial lifeline to Turkey. Such assistance could come as part of China's Belt and Road Initiative, which seeks to boost transport infrastructure between Asia and Europe in order to foster trade and connectivity in the coming decades.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
The public finances have traditionally been one of the Turkish economy's most reassuring aspects. Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios reflect the positive impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past. Despite a series of tax rises this year and official promises of budgetary tightening, higher government spending on defence, security, infrastructure, public employment and social benefits will cause the deficit to widen in 2018, to 3.4% of GDP, from 1.5% in 2017. We subsequently expect a cautious approach to on-balance-sheet fiscal policy, which, alongside a recovering economy, will lead the deficit gradually to contract in the second half of our forecast period, to 1.9% of GDP in 2023.
We expect the central government debt/GDP ratio to increase this year, to 29.7% of GDP at end-2018 (from 28.3% at end-2017), owing to the widening of the fiscal deficit. The ratio will then decline gradually, to 27.6% of GDP by the end of 2023, as macroeconomic conditions normalise and the budget deficit shrinks.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
On September 13th the Central Bank of Turkey's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) raised its main policy rate, the one-week repo lending rate, to 24%, from 17.75% previously. The MPC's decision represents a response to the lira's sharp depreciation against the US dollar in August, as well as to the record rise in annual consumer price inflation. The average cost of central bank funding is likely to be above the main policy rate, however. The bank retains the option of providing some of its funding for the banking system at its overnight lending rates, which are 1.5-3% higher than the one-week repo rate.
The central bank will need to keep monetary policy tight in 2018 to dampen inflationary pressures and prevent further depreciation of the lira against the US dollar amid political volatility, higher US interest rates and balance-sheet tapering by the Federal Reserve (the US central bank). In 2019-20 the central bank will gradually lower its policy rate in response to declining inflationary pressures and a normalisation of financial market conditions. In 2021-23 we believe that it will miss its inflation target of 5%. This reflects the government's continued pro-growth stance; it will put pressure on the bank to keep nominal rates below what would credibly be required to lower inflation to the 5% target.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Real GDP growth accelerated sharply in 2017, to 7.3% (from 3.3% in 2016), supported by government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit, improved export competitiveness and a pick-up in global demand. However, the surge in economic growth has exacerbated internal and external imbalances. These imbalances-coupled with heightened policy unpredictability, foreign investors' concerns regarding the independence of the central bank, reliance on short-term capital inflows, a rising interest-rate environment in advanced economies, and a diplomatic spat with the US-have contributed to the lira losing about 40% of its value against the US dollar so far in 2018. The depreciation of the lira, which quickened in August, has caused consumer price inflation to accelerate from already high rates, and has increased input costs for corporations and raised the debt-servicing costs of foreign-currency-denominated liabilities. Higher domestic interest rates and rising risk premiums further dent the economic outlook.
High-frequency indicators for September suggest that the economy is decelerating sharply in the wake of the currency crisis. After mild growth in the second quarter (5.7% year on year, down from 7.3% in full-year 2017), we expect the economy to contract on a quarterly basis in the third and fourth quarters of 2018 and the first quarter of 2019. There are substantial downside risks to this forecast; this growth profile does not reflect the possible impact of a severe banking crisis (not our core scenario), although we expect non-performing loans to rise and credit availability to be impaired in the coming quarters.
We believe that full-year growth will decelerate to 3.1% in 2018 and that GDP will grow only slightly in 2019, by 1%, mainly owing to base effects. In 2020 we expect full-year growth to rebound to 4.9% as the economy recovers and spare capacity is depleted. In 2021-23 economic growth will average 4%, broadly in line with the economy's forecast potential growth rate in 2021-30.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Even before the lira's collapse in 2018, inflation was already stubbornly high and well above the central bank's official 5% medium-term target; it averaged 11.1% in 2017. This year, however, the currency's depreciation and rising global commodity prices have driven inflation higher, to 17.9% year on year in August. The pass-through of former lira depreciation, together with higher inflation expectations, will keep inflation elevated during the remainder of 2018. We estimate an annual average rate of 15.5%.
In 2019 we expect inflationary pressures to moderate on the back of a modest appreciation of the lira against the US dollar, a slight decline in global oil prices and the emergence of spare capacity in the economy. We forecast a slight slowdown in inflation, to an average of 14.5%, next year. The moderating trend in inflation will continue in 2020, with an average inflation rate of 8.3%, as global oil prices decline, owing to a slowdown in the US business cycle, and the exchange rate remains broadly stable (in nominal terms) against the US dollar. In the final years of our forecast period, we expect inflation to stabilise at an average of 7%-still above the central bank's medium-term target of 5%. Economic growth in these years will be close to the economy's potential growth rate (limiting upward inflationary pressures). However, an expected pick-up in global oil prices and a depreciation of the lira will maintain upward pressure on prices.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
In 2017 the lira depreciated by an average of almost 18% against the US dollar. In 2018 we estimate an average depreciation of about 30% (in nominal terms). Our baseline scenario is that the lira is likely to depreciate slightly against the US dollar in the remainder of the year, but that no further major currency collapse will take place. This outlook is underpinned by expected real GDP contraction on a quarterly basis in the final two quarters of 2018 and the first quarter of 2019, and the effects of this on medium-term inflation expectations, which will gradually decline.
In 2019, as inflation moderates and the economy rebounds, we expect the lira to appreciate and the exchange rate to reach TL5.6:US$ by the end of the year. In 2020 as nominal interest rates are lowered the exchange rate will stabilise at around this level. In 2021-23 continued high inflation as well as a suboptimal policy and political environment will keep the lira on a depreciating path. We forecast that the lira will decline to TL6.2:US$1 by the end of 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The current-account deficit as a share of GDP will narrow in 2018, to 5.2% of GDP, from 5.6% of GDP in 2017, as the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar will depress imports and boost competitiveness. In 2019-23 we expect a smaller average annual current-account deficit of 3.4% of GDP. Significant gains in competitiveness from past lira depreciation (notwithstanding the currency's forecast appreciation in 2019), moderating inflation and the emergence of spare capacity will result in a boost to exports and import compression over the medium term.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
Global data
OECD growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP growth and components: Turkstat
Population: UN Population database and Economist Intelligence Unit interpolation
Consumer prices: IMF, IFS; Turkstat
Industrial production: derived from OECD, Main Economic Indicators
Exchange rates and interest rates: IMF, IFS
External trade and balance of payments: IMF, IFS; Central Bank of Turkey; Turkstat
Central government financial balance: IMF, IFS; Turkish Treasury
Foreign direct investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report; Central Bank of Turkey

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The government-comprising the Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza, the party of the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras) and the small, right-wing Independent Greeks (AE)-has a two-seat majority in the 300-seat parliament. Mr Tsipras will aim to complete his parliamentary term, ending in October 2019.
The government is vulnerable to further defections, and there is a significant risk of an early election The centre-right New Democracy (ND) is likely to win the most seats in such an election and to form a government, but it would probably have to secure the support of at least one other party to muster a parliamentary majority.
Greece will remain subject to strict policy conditionality over the medium term and until its debt to its international creditors is substantially reduced. Protests over labour market reforms, pension cuts, privatisation, and tax and social security increases are likely to continue as the government strives to meet ambitious annual primary surplus budget targets of 3.5% of GDP until 2022 and 2.2% from 2023, as agreed with Greece's creditors.
Mr Tsipras's promises to lower tax, reverse spending cuts and abandon the pension reform agreed before Greece exited the bail-out programme in August are likely to cause tensions with the country's international creditors.
Greece faces its biggest macroeconomic challenge, now that it has exited the bail-out programme and no longer has access to official borrowing at preferential interest rates. However, Greece does not face short-term financing difficulties, as it will have sufficient funds to cover its debt repayments for almost two years after exiting the bail-out programme.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that real GDP growth will pick up from 1.3% in 2017 to a moderate 2% per year on average in 2018-23. Public debt is forecast to continue to exceed 170% of GDP in 2023. Meeting large primary surplus targets and restoring competitiveness will prove difficult.
We estimate that annual average inflation will decline, from 1.1% in 2017 to 0.9% in 2018, before rising to an annual average of 1.4% in 2019-23 (the forecast period), reflecting higher oil prices and a pick-up in domestic demand. This will result in widening, but still moderate, current-account deficits in 2018-23.

Greece's score recovers modestly in our forecast period, from a low base. The main areas of improvement are expected in the macroeconomic environment and as a result of efforts to improve policy towards foreign investment, private enterprise and competition, and the labour market.
Country forecast overview: Greece's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The country's privatisation agency, under new management, gains momentum. Deals start to make progress.
2021-23: Efforts to valorise public property through concession management and long-leasehold development agreements.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: The Investment Incentives Law of 2016 offers more tax relief and fewer subsidies, and focuses predominantly on small firms. Plans to cut down on bureaucracy make little progress.
2021-23: "Fast-track" legislation could become more important if the economy normalises. It will cover "strategic" investments in energy, tourism, transport, communications and health.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Capital controls introduced in June 2015 are eased gradually. Capital buffer of about EUR24bn sufficient to cover almost two years of the government's financing needs
2021-23: There is a significant risk of Greece leaving the euro zone in the long term if growth continues to disappoint. Grexit would probably result the reintroduction of exchange controls and, possibly, restrictions on trade.
Taxes
2019-20: Extensive efforts to widen the tax base. Government pledges to pursue aggressive tax collection, but implementation is difficult. Indirect taxes increase. Mandatory introduction of electronic point of sale terminals helps.
2021-23: Limited progress in cutting corporate income tax or value-added tax (VAT). Measures to tackle tax evasion stepped up. Independence of the tax authority remains in doubt.
Financing
2019-20: Liquidity tight. Uncertainty constrains lending capacity. Steps to reduce non-performing loans (NPLs) painfully slow, but foreign interest picks up. A moratorium on foreclosures is lifted for the majority of debtors.
2021-23: Lending hampered by need to increase provisions for still high NPLs. More Greek bank foreign subsidiaries are sold off.
The labour market
2019-20: Labour market reforms now mostly passed, but implementation is problematic. Unemployment remains high.
2021-23: EU-funded job-creation schemes, particularly for youth, raise employment, but create few productive jobs.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Energy infrastructure comes to the fore as Trans-Adriatic Pipeline (TAP) nears completion. Privatisations pick up pace.
2021-23: Despite technical assistance from the EU, problems with absorption persist.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Greece rolls out high-speed internet, at a slow pace. The private sector adopts electronic payments by law.
2021-23: Significant financial and technical assistance from the EU, but Greece remains a laggard.

Background: After 400 years of Ottoman rule, Greece emerged as a sovereign state in 1830. A devastating civil war followed the retreat of German occupying forces in 1944. A military junta ruled the country from 1967 to 1974, but since then a democracy has been in place. In 1981 Greece joined the European Economic Community, now the EU. It became a member of the economic and monetary union (EMU) in 2001, but its public finances became unsustainable, resulting in a sovereign debt crisis in 2009-10. Greece's public debt has put its continued membership of EMU in question.
Political structure: Greece is a parliamentary republic, with deputies elected for four-year terms. The prime minister and the government hold executive powers. The president is elected by the 300-member parliament for a five-year term. The government requires the support of parliament to hold office. Since the 2010 crisis the traditional party system has broken down. Voters have blamed the parties that ruled Greece after the return of democracy in the mid-1970s-New Democracy (ND) and the Panhellenic Socialist Movement (Pasok)-for causing the crisis, which led to the imposition of painful austerity by the country's external creditors. The result has been political fragmentation and the rise of populist parties such as the left-wing Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), which came to power in 2015, and far-right parties such as the neo-fascist Golden Dawn (XA).
Policy issues: The ND-Pasok government of 2012-14, like its two predecessors, imposed draconian austerity packages. It also enacted fiscal and some structural economic reforms to meet the conditions of two EU-IMF bail-out packages totalling EUR240bn. Implementation proved difficult and ultimately brought down the government. After a seven-month confrontation with Greece's creditors, the Syriza-led government negotiated a new three-year European Stability Mechanism (ESM) programme in August 2015. In 2012 Greece restructured its public debt, reducing the value of private-sector creditors' holdings by EUR107bn. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any further debt write-down. Now that Greece has exited the programme, it is subject to an "enhanced supervision" monitoring regime by its euro zone creditors.
Taxation: The tax rate on corporate profits is 29% and on distributed dividends is 10%. The top marginal personal income tax rate is 45% for income of more than EUR40,000. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at rates of 24%, 13% and 6%.
Foreign trade: In 2017 goods exports (fob) were worth EUR27.9bn (US$31.5bn) and imports (fob) amounted to EUR46.3bn. The current account registered a deficit of EUR1.4bn, equivalent to 0.8% of GDP.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
The coalition government-comprising Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza, the party of the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras) and the small, right-wing nationalist Independent Greeks (AE)-has survived since September 2015, despite having only a slim majority in the 300-seat parliament. Following the defection of two members of the AE, in protest at the agreement on the 27-year Macedonia name dispute, the government's majority has been reduced to just two seats. Mr Tsipras will aim to see through his parliamentary term, which ends in October 2019, but there is a significant risk of a pre-term election.
Tensions within the government coalition will persist, including over the continued implementation of austerity measures and the Macedonia name issue. The AE has said that it will oppose the name agreement when it is brought before parliament after the consultative referendum in Macedonia on September 30th. Mr Tsipras may struggle to obtain the required majority.
In August 2015 the government tied its acceptance of bail-out reforms under a European Stability Mechanism (ESM, an inter-governmental assistance fund for countries in the euro zone) programme to the objective of receiving debt relief from its official creditors. Three years later, on August 20th, the government exited the programme with minimal debt relief, having lost much popular support along the way.
Mr Tsipras now aims to revive his party's political fortunes, hoping that economic growth will gain momentum over the coming year and allow him to implement promises to lower taxes and increase spending. He also hopes to obtain a waiver from Greece's international creditors to postpone, or even cancel, agreed pension cuts in 2019 on the grounds that they will not be needed in order to achieve the country's fiscal targets (a 3.5% primary surplus). The Economist Intelligence Unit remains sceptical that real GDP growth will rise to much higher than 2% during the 2019-23 forecast period, and expects that any attempt to roll back on reforms agreed with Greece's international creditors would trigger tensions in the country's financial market.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Syriza trails in opinion polls behind the centre-right New Democracy (ND), led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis; the gap has been more than 10 percentage points for some time. ND's lead may narrow during the election campaign, as Mr Tsipras is a formidable campaigner and there is little overt enthusiasm for Mr Mitsotakis or his party. However, given widespread popular disaffection with the government, the election-due by October 2019-is ND's to lose. If, as we expect, ND wins the largest share of the vote, it would benefit from the 50-seat bonus rule for the winning party. Even so, it would probably have to secure the support of at least one other party to muster a parliamentary majority.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
In mid-June Mr Tsipras and Zoran Zaev, the prime minister of Macedonia (the official name of which is the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia; the constitutional name is the Republic of Macedonia), announced their agreement to change that country's constitutional name to Severna Makedonija (North Macedonia). The breakthrough is only the first step towards a resolution of the name dispute, and-given public opposition in both countries-the agreement may fail to come into effect. Even if the referendum in Macedonia on September 30th approves the proposed change, it needs to be incorporated into Macedonia's constitution with a two-thirds majority in the country's parliament by end-January 2019, and ratified in the Greek parliament next year.
Tensions between Greece and Turkey have risen recently. The risk of military hostility is high, particularly in the Aegean Sea, but both sides will seek to avoid clashes. Points of contention-such as historical territorial disputes in the Aegean Sea and the Greek courts' rejection of Turkey's extradition request for Turkish soldiers who fled to Greece on the night of the July 2016 failed coup in Turkey-have fuelled distrust. Turkey's release in mid-August of two Greek soldiers arrested for alleged espionage in March 2018 while on patrol in the border area of Evros has eased tensions, which were threatening to boil over.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
On August 20th Greece emerged from an eight-year funding period (2010-18), during which it received a total of EUR288.7bn in official financial support from European creditors and the IMF (EUR32.1bn from the Fund), and was subject to three economic adjustment programmes. Repaying the country's outstanding public debt, which totalled EUR344bn (about 180% of GDP) at the end of March, means that future Greek governments will be subject to huge policy constraints. Fiscal austerity and policy conditionality will remain in place for the next five years and beyond.
At the June 21st meeting of the Eurogroup, Greece's official creditors agreed to close the final review of the third bail-out programme, paving the way for a disbursement of EUR15bn, which was released on August 6th. Of this, EUR3.3bn will be used to pay down the more expensive IMF debt, and the balance will form part of a buffer for Greece to use while it builds up market access. The total buffer, estimated at EUR24.1bn, should be sufficient to cover almost two years of the country's financing needs. This is more onerous than a precautionary credit line would have been, as Greece will be accruing interest on money that it does not currently need. However, intense political pressure not to invite further policy conditionality led the government to choose the more expensive option.
The Eurogroup meeting agreed to further debt relief for Greece, which was granted a ten-year grace period and a ten-year maturity extension on EUR96bn of its loans (provided by the European Financial Stability Facility). It will also get a reduction in the interest rates (for loans of EUR130.9bn) and a return of profits from the securities market programme and from the Agreement on Net Financial Assets, which comprise the official sector holders of Greek debt-the European Central Bank (ECB) and national central banks of euro area countries. The value of the return is estimated to be about EUR5bn.
Greece, in response, has committed to long-term fiscal prudence. It must achieve annual primary budget surpluses of 3.5% of GDP in 2018-22 and 2.2% thereafter, until 2060. It will also be subject to an "enhanced surveillance" regime, which is a more exacting system of post-programme monitoring than those applied to other former bail-out countries. The debt-relief measures will be subject to quarterly reviews of the state of the economy and of the government's adherence to its commitments. As these reviews will be published, transgression by Greece would adversely affect market access.
After a three-year absence Greece has returned to the financial markets three times since July 2017. However, after its exit from the bail-out programme in August, it will do so without the backstop of an official credit line. Recent emerging-market turbulence and investor risk aversion highlight the difficulties that Greece could face in the future on the international capital markets. Greece should have sufficient funds to meet its financing needs in the short term, through to early 2020. However, in the medium and long term the political and, arguably, the economic price of meeting high annual primary surplus targets may become unbearable. During the past two years Greece has exceeded its annual primary surplus targets, but at the expense of economic growth, which has been disappointing. Meeting such targets will remain a constraint on growth, alongside other negative factors, such as poor demographics and a weak business environment. Grexit is not a short-term risk, but, given that Greece is highly unlikely to improve competitiveness inside the euro zone or grow its way out of its huge debt burden, it will pose a significant risk in the long term.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
In 2017 the budget surplus was equivalent to 0.8% of GDP and the primary surplus (budget balance minus interest payments) exceeded the bail-out programme target of 1.75%, coming in at 4%. We estimate a minimal budget deficit in 2018 (0.2% of GDP), but we do not expect Greece to meet its annual primary surplus targets of 3.5% of GDP this year, or in 2019-22. Although the target declines to 2.2% in 2023, it will still be difficult to achieve, owing to the fact that debt repayments become much more onerous from that year on. We forecast that the deficit will widen gradually during this period, reflecting constraints on revenue collection, a relaxation of spending restraint and only modest economic growth.
The restructuring of government debt to the private sector cut the debt/GDP ratio to 159.4% at end-2012, from 171.9% in 2011. However, large primary surpluses in 2016-17 were insufficient to arrest the growth of gross consolidated government debt, which rose to EUR317.4bn, or 179.1% of GDP, in 2017. Government debt is now almost entirely owed to official creditors. We expect that, without a debt write-down and assuming moderate nominal medium-term GDP growth rates, the public debt/GDP ratio will remain above 170% in 2018-23.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The ECB is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a quantitative easing (QE) programme that is running at EUR30bn per month in January-September 2018. It will run at EUR15bn per month in October-December before coming to an end. Economic activity in the euro zone has softened this year, but the ECB's view of the outlook remains fairly positive. Rising commodity prices and evidence of building domestic price pressure in some parts of the euro zone should mean that sufficient inflationary pressures will begin to emerge on the policy horizon in 2019-20. In response, we expect the ECB to take steps towards normalising its policy stance, with an increase of 25 basis points in the main refinancing rate to 0.25% in early 2020, followed by five more rises that will lift the rate to 2% by end-2023. An increase in the deposit rate, which currently stands at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019, easing the pressure on banks' lending margins and supporting profitability.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Compared with 2007 levels, real GDP has shrunk by more than one-quarter, government consumption by almost one-quarter, household consumption by one-fifth and gross fixed investment by almost two-thirds. The recovery, which began at the start of 2017, is fragile, and vulnerable to domestic and external developments, as shown by a marked slowdown in activity in quarterly terms in the second half of last year. We forecast that real GDP growth will pick up from 1.3% in 2017 to an average of 2% per year in 2018-23. The risks to our forecast are balanced. Upside risks include a continued strong tourism performance. Downside risks include the frailty of the banking sector and political instability.
Seasonally and calendar-day-adjusted real GDP growth slowed from 0.8% quarter on quarter in January-March (2.5% year on year) to 0.2% (1.8% year on year) in April-June, despite steady expansion of domestic consumption and a strong export of services (largely driven by tourism). We estimate that real GDP growth will reach 2% in 2018. This remains a disappointing rate of expansion in the context of the slump of the past decade. We expect a combination of more, and higher, taxes, higher social security payments, debt repayments and spending cuts to put pressure on household disposable income. Although we expect a modest acceleration in household spending in 2018-23, this will be from a low base and will be constrained by large primary surplus targets of 3.5% of GDP per year up to 2022 and 2.2% in 2023, continued high unemployment and insipid lending growth.
Quarterly gross fixed investment has been volatile in recent years, but recorded strong full-year growth in 2016-17, albeit from a low base. However, reflecting base effects and a loss of momentum, investment contracted by 7.9% year on year in the first half of 2018. We expect a pick-up in the second half of the year to reduce the contraction to 1% in 2018 as whole, followed by average annual of growth of 5.2% in 2019-23, leaving fixed investment still some 50% below its 2007 peak. Underinvestment during the crisis, and the depletion of Greece's capital stock, as well as uncertainty about the country's euro zone membership, are likely to restrict growth potential in the medium term.
Greece's external trade will be constrained by its relatively uncompetitive goods exports. Over the medium term we expect tourism to continue to support services export growth, contributing to annual average growth of exports of goods and services of 4.9% in 2019-23.
Greece will face its biggest macroeconomic challenge now that it no longer has access to official external financing at preferential rates. How the economy performs over the next five years (and beyond) will determine whether the country will remain in the euro zone. We believe that there is a significant risk that Greece might exit the euro zone in the long term, given the difficulties that it will face in attaining rapid growth while meeting large primary surplus targets, and in restoring competitiveness without a currency devaluation. Grexit would lead to a sovereign default and a severe recession in the first few years, but the economy would then grow rapidly, assuming a responsible fiscal policy guided by the necessity to achieve a primary surplus.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
After stagnating in 2016 Greece's seasonally adjusted EU harmonised index of consumer prices rose by 1.1% year on year in 2017, driven by higher global energy prices, notably in the fourth quarter. Inflation dipped sharply at the start of 2018, rising by just 0.3% year on year in the first quarter, before accelerating since then. In the first eight months of this year inflation on the EU harmonised measure rose by an average of 0.5% per month. The economy has returned to growth, but significant slack remains in the labour market and domestic demand is subdued. Despite rising global commodity prices and increased tourism, we expect annual inflation to edge down this year, to an estimated average of 0.9%. We forecast a pick-up to inflation of 1.4% per year on average in 2019-23 as the pace of growth quickens.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
In 2017 the euro rallied as the region's economic recovery strengthened and expectations of QE tapering increased, and as political risk waned in Europe but rose in the US. The exchange rate peaked at almost US$1.25:EUR1 at the beginning of February 2018, but had weakened to US$1.16:EUR1 by late May in response to the formation of a populist, Eurosceptic government in Italy, and remained close to that level in June-July before weakening to US$1.13:EUR1 in mid-August. The euro has since recovered to US$1.16-1.17:EUR1 in September, but will remain under pressure from political risk in Italy and monetary tightening in the US. We expect it to begin firming against the dollar from 2019, on the assumption that the region's recovery will continue while growth momentum in the US slows. We forecast an average of US$1.19:EUR1 in 2018-19 and US$1.21:EUR1 in 2020-21. The euro will also receive structural support from a large current-account surplus, and we expect it to appreciate to an average ofUS$1.24:EUR1 in 2022-23.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
Greece's current-account deficit has narrowed since the start of the crisis. This mainly reflects the compression of imports owing to contracting domestic demand, but is also partly the result of improved competitiveness in the tourism sector. The current-account deficit narrowed to 0.8% of GDP in 2017, from 1.1% of GDP in 2016, according to the Bank of Greece (the central bank). We expect widening deficits in 2018-23 as import prices rise and import volumes pick up in line with higher domestic demand, but these will be much smaller than the average annual deficit of 7.2% of GDP since Greece joined the euro zone in 2001.

Full text: Peru--highlights: Political outlook
The president, Martín Vizcarra, of the centre-right Peruanos Por el Kambio, assumed office in March after his predecessor, Pedro Pablo Kuczynski (2016-18), resigned amid corruption allegations. The president has a small base of congressional support-his party holds just 14 of 130 seats-and, notwithstanding efforts to build political alliances, this will complicate policymaking and hinder government effectiveness. Although Mr Vizcarra's proposal for judicial and electoral reform-by means of a referendum-poses some upside risks for institutional effectiveness in the long term, it is likely to raise tension between the executive and legislative branches, and generate congressional gridlock in the short term. The broad reach of ongoing corruption investigations will also pose a serious latent risk to political stability.
Peru--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
5.97 6.40 48 45 4 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Peru's business environment score rises in 2018-22, mostly owing to improvements in the political and macroeconomic environment, moving Peru up to 45th place in the global ranking, and third place in the regional ranking. Peru's key strengths are its openness to foreign trade-secured by multiple free-trade agreements-and its prudent macroeconomic management. The business-friendly approach that existed during the historical period (2013-17) will be deepened and enhanced under Mr Vizcarra as the government seeks to draw in foreign investment. Infrastructure will improve, although significant gaps will persist. Peru's labour market, albeit improving, will remain the weakest aspect of the business environment.

GDP growth will average 4% in 2018-22, driven by a recovery in private investment. In the longer term, growth will hinge more on productivity improvements, as commodity prices will be lower than during the 2004-12 boom. Social and political pressure for higher public spending will persist, but the fiscal accounts will remain prudently managed and characterised by one of the lowest debt stocks in the region. The stable macroeconomic outlook will also be underpinned by low inflation and a manageable current-account deficit.

The labour force will expand more quickly than the overall population in 2018-22, thereby contributing to a demographic bonus over the next two decades. The formal economy, despite having expanded relatively firmly in recent years, will struggle to absorb new entrants to the labour market. Consequently, the level of informal employment will remain high. Underdevelopment in rural areas will encourage the trend towards urbanisation, which stands at close to 80%. There should also be further improvements in education and health indicators, in line with lower levels of poverty (which has been more than halved since 2000). However, high levels of deprivation will persist in rural and indigenous communities.

Peru is a fairly small market and opportunities will remain restricted by low purchasing power measured in terms of GDP per head, as well as by high levels of poverty and inequality. However, two decades of strong economic growth have gradually led to the emergence of a growing middle class, notably in the capital, Lima. Rising demand from lower-income districts has led to a transformation in consumer patterns. Although progress will be gradual (constrained by still-low disposable incomes among much of the population), we expect this trend to continue in 2018-22. Public investment in infrastructure will support greater integration of outlying regions.
Peru--highlights: Long-term outlook

Growth in Peru's real GDP per head is forecast to slow from an annual average of 2.9% in 2018-30 to 2.6% in 2031-50. The weak institutional environment and widespread income and regional inequalities will continue to hold back stronger growth. The demographic bonus will have run its course by the early 2030s, weighing on total GDP growth. At the same time, education levels will remain low, with only modest progress forecast. Low inflation and a stable currency will contribute to macroeconomic stability. Abundant opportunities in energy, mining and infrastructure will continue to attract investment. Nevertheless, Peru will remain vulnerable to fluctuations in external demand and the prices of commodities.

Background: More than 12 years of military rule ended in 1980. Following a decade of economic and social instability, the government of Alberto Fujimori (1990-2000) ended hyperinflation, advanced reforms to liberalise the economy and defeated the Maoist Sendero Luminoso insurgency. However, Mr Fujimori subverted Peru's democratic institutions and committed grave human rights abuses. His government collapsed over a corruption scandal. The subsequent governments have been successful in consolidating macroeconomic stability, but have largely overlooked the structural reforms required to raise productivity levels. The current president, Martín Vizcarra, took office in March 2018 after his predecessor, Pedro Pablo Kuczynski (2016-18), stepped down amid mounting allegations of corruption. Mr Vizcarra's term runs to July 2021.
Political structure: The 1993 Constitution established a presidential regime with a powerful executive, elected for five years. Consecutive presidential re-election is not permitted. A 130-member unicameral legislature, elected at the same time as the president, also sits for five years. The government is decentralising revenue and responsibility to the 25 regions (including the constitutional province of Callao).
Policy issues: The Economist Intelligence Unit assumes that there will be continuity of orthodox economic policies and that the business environment will remain attractive. Mr Vizcarra is a former governor and transport minister, and we expect gradual progress on structural reform under his government. The government will focus on improving the quality of and access to the underperforming public education and healthcare systems as it seeks to promote an agenda of inclusive development. Despite government involvement in the market, private investment in transport, energy and water infrastructure will remain strong. Bilateral free-trade agreements with Peru's main trading partners-including the US, China and the EU-as well as initiatives within Latin America, will help to keep investment and trade flows strong in 2018-22.
Taxation: The corporate income-tax rate is 29.5% (mining companies that do not benefit from tax-stability contracts pay additional taxes). Dividends and other profit distribution schemes are taxed at 5%. Branch-profit tax is levied at 30% and remittance tax at 10%. Interest paid abroad stands at 5%.
Foreign trade: Tariffs are levied on imports at 0%, 6% or 11%. The World Bank's calculation of the average effective tariff was 1.4% in 2014. Most non-tariff barriers have been eliminated. In 2017 merchandise export earnings increased by 22.1%, to US$45.3bn, whereas the import bill grew more slowly, by 10%, to US$38.7bn.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
The president, Martín Vizcarra, of the centre-right Peruanos Por el Kambio (PPK), took office in March, after his predecessor, Pedro Pablo Kuczynski (2016-18) resigned after being implicated in a corruption scandal. Notwithstanding the generally weak position of the executive, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a relative improvement in political stability, which should ensure that Mr Vizcarra serves out his term ending in July 2021. PPK is the second-largest bloc in Congress, but it holds just 14 of the 130 seats in the legislature. Mr Vizcarra has sought to address the ruling party's legislative weakness by forging alliances with other parties such as the centrist Alianza Para el Progreso (eight seats), as well as with ungrouped parliamentarians (seventeen members). However, the biggest challenge to political stability will come from the opposing right-wing Fuerza Popular (FP), which holds 62 seats in Congress, and which led two impeachment attempts against Mr Kuczynski (before his ultimate resignation). That being said, FP has been weakened significantly as a result of the protracted political conflict with Mr Kuczynski.

Political outlook: Political stability
Although Mr Vizcarra assumed office under strained circumstances, he has thus far managed to improve relations with the legislature, partly through his appointment of César Villanueva, of the opposition Alianza Para el Progreso, as the new prime minister. He has also used his pro-growth agenda to build support within Congress for his policies, as evidenced by lawmakers' decision to grant the executive branch special powers to issue legislation through decrees on a number of issues.
We expect that the political scene will be relatively stable in the short term as political parties seek to minimise disruptions ahead of regional and municipals polls later this year. (Although there is little connection between local and national politics, national parties field candidates in the most populous regions.) The second reason is that approval ratings for Congress are extremely low, and the appearance of excess obstructionism at this crucial juncture in the economic recovery would worsen legislators' re-election prospects in 2021.
In the medium term, amid improved economic conditions, we expect legislative dysfunction to resume as political opportunism takes precedence over policy objectives. However, there is a high risk that increased political instability could come to pass earlier than we currently anticipate. The revelation of yet another high-level corruption scandal in July-this time in the judiciary-prompted the president to propose a referendum for comprehensive judicial and legislative reform. Included in the referendum is a proposal to bar lawmakers from consecutive re-election, a return to a bicameral legislature, and a ban on private financing of political parties and campaigns. The first point is the most politically charged, and could lead to renewed conflict between the executive and legislative branches. The risk is further heightened by the fact that the FP, the largest opposition party, recently gained three seats in Congress (after three former FP lawmakers-who became independents-were implicated in corruption scandals and replaced by FP loyalists), bringing the party closer to a legislative majority (they now hold 62 seats in Congress). If FP is able to secure the support of parties, such as the Partido Aprista Peruano, that have previously united with the party on key issues, greater political instability could follow, creating bottlenecks for Mr Vizcarra's agenda.
There are other latent risks to political stability arising from the broad reach of ongoing graft investigations. A number of prominent public officials, including the FP leader, Keiko Fujimori, are under investigation for their alleged roles in corruption cases. Moreover, four former presidents are currently being investigated for potential money-laundering and influence-peddling. All of this will contribute to public disillusionment with political and democratic institutions.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
Mr Vizcarra's government will continue to adhere to the market-friendly policies that have guided Peru for the past quarter of a century. In particular Mr Vizcarra will promote policies for inclusive development, as he seeks to recreate at the national level the success he had as governor of Moquegua (2011-14). The government will seek to deliver short-term growth by unlocking investments-particularly in infrastructure-and improving the quality and scope of public services. At the same time, Mr Vizcarra will seek to improve long-run economic outcomes through greater investment in education and healthcare.
The centrepiece of the president's policy agenda, however, will be political and judicial reform, which form efforts to improve Peru's political effectiveness and institutions. Peru has a long-standing history of structural and institutional problems, with corruption pervasive across all levels of government and highly inefficient bureaucracy. The judiciary is known to be slow, opaque, underfunded and riddled with a culture of bribery and political manipulation.
Although Mr Vizcarra himself took office under strained circumstances, with his predecessor marred by allegations of corruption, the new president has made it a point to distance himself from any appearance of impropriety. Furthermore, Mr Vizcarra has signalled that he is willing to invest all the political capital available to him in order to push for an overhaul of the political system.
The revelation of one graft scandal after the other has heightened public disillusionment with Peru's political and democratic institutions. Many of Peru's most prominent public officials, including the FP leader, Keiko Fujimori, and her brother, Kenji Fujimori (a former-FP lawmaker who has been temporarily suspended from Congress), are under investigation for their alleged roles in corruption cases. Moreover, four former presidents are currently being investigated for potential money-laundering and influence peddling. All the while, there have been virtually no high-level prosecutions, reinforcing public perception that the current political system fails to deliver any accountability for those in power.
The unearthing of yet another corruption scandal, this time in Peru's judiciary, has drawn renewed attention to Peru's weak institutions. In early July a series of taped conversations revealed discussions between judges and representatives of the Consejo Nacional de la Magistratura (the judicial appointment board) about court appointments, sentencing in criminal cases and a host of other topics that raised questions of influence-trafficking against those involved. These revelations prompted Mr Vizcarra to present a far-reaching judicial reform proposal, in his first State of the Union speech on July 28th. The president's decision to include this in the framework of a referendum, which also includes broader electoral reform, took his opponents by surprise. Mr Vizcarra decreed that voters should decide if lawmakers can run for re-election; if the country should return to a bicameral legislature; and if private funding of parties and campaigns should be legal.
The call for the referendum, which has overwhelming public support, appears to be a politically astute move on the president's part. This is because two paths exist for the referendum. Congress can approve the referendum with a two-thirds majority, or 87 votes. However, if legislators fail to do this, the constitution allows the convocation of a referendum by the collection of signatures of 10% of eligible voters, or about 2.3m people. The latter allows the president to bypass the problems posed by Peru's constitutionally weak presidency and a fragmented and hostile legislature. Mr Vizcarra has also gone on the record to state that he will not hesitate to circumvent Congress if there are excessive delays in addressing his referendum proposals. It is clear that Mr Vizcarra's gambit is having its intended effect. Many legislators now feel the pressure to substantively address Mr Vizcarra's reform proposals.
On the whole, we do expect some judicial and electoral reform to pass. However, the FP and its allies are likely to push back against many of the congressional reforms, especially a return to bicamerality, which would diminish the party's legislative authority. In addition, Mr Vizcarra's proposal to ban consecutive re-election has been criticised by even the more moderate members of Congress for being an unnecessary solution to a non-existent problem; in Peru re-election rates are extremely low (25% in the 2016 general elections).
As a result, many of the reform proposals are likely to be watered down significantly. Although the president does continue to have the option of triggering a game of brinksmanship, by trying to force a referendum through the collection of signatures, we believe that he will be more inclined to seek a negotiated compromise. This is largely owing to the fact that Mr Vizcarra will be wary of triggering another protracted political conflict, as had taken place under his predecessor's rule, out of concern for maintaining stability and supporting the ongoing economic recovery.
However, given Mr Vizcarra's rhetoric thus far, one cannot rule out the possibility that he would be willing to sacrifice short-term stability in exchange for a chance of serious institutional reform. This would present some upside risks for Peru's long-term prospects, as the reforms are ambitious in scope, and are on balance likely to boost growth through increased transparency for investors, and greater efficiency and objectivity in institutional and judicial processes.
Political outlook: Election watch
The next elections are municipal and regional polls in October 2018. Peru lacks a formal nationwide party structure, and local-level parties tend to have little affiliation with national parties, leading to disassociation between the results of local and national elections. Presidential and legislative elections will be held in mid-2021. At this early stage, we do not see a clear frontrunner for the presidential race in 2021. However, the two-round system typically favours the victory of a centrist, establishment candidate, and we have based our medium-term forecasts on the assumption of such an outcome. Nonetheless, the lack of strong party structures also facilitates the rapid ascent of personalities and political outsiders, who could yet emerge before 2021.
Political outlook: International relations
Peru will aim to take on a leadership role in the region, following its assumption of the rotating presidency of the Andean Community, a customs union also comprising Bolivia, Colombia and Ecuador, in May. It will also seek to co-ordinate efforts to develop a region-wide response to the rapidly growing spillover effects of a socioeconomic crisis in Venezuela (although we forecast little progress on this front).
Peru will continue to support regional integration efforts, such as the Pacific Alliance, an economic trade pact that also includes Chile, Colombia and Mexico. In October 2017 negotiators from the Pacific Alliance met with representatives from Australia, Canada, New Zealand and Singapore to work out details related to those countries' incorporation as associate members of the bloc. Members of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union, comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) have stated a desire for greater integration with the Pacific Alliance, but we do not currently forecast any progress in 2018-22.
In November 2017 Peru and another ten of the 12 original signatories of the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a trade agreement, agreed on a framework to move ahead despite the US's exit from the pact. In March the 11 remaining countries signed a new accord, the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership. We expect ratification of the new agreement by the member nations by 2019. In addition, Peru has 17 bilateral trade deals in place, covering nearly all of the world's largest economies, including Australia, Canada, China, the EU, Japan, South Korea and the US. The government is currently in talks to finalise a free-trade agreement with India this year.

a See Guide to the business rankings model at the end of this report. b Out of 10. c Out of 82 countries. d  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela. e New section, introduced in 2018.
The Economist Intelligence Unit's global business rankings measure the quality and attractiveness of the investment environment in 82 of the world's largest economies, including 12 in Latin America. Peru's business environment ranking improves slightly for the 2018-22 forecast period: the country rises to 45th place globally (from 48th in 2013-17), and moves up one spot, to third place, in the regional rankings. Peru's improved ranking is due to a recovery in GDP growth, stronger policies for competition and investment, and continued strides towards expanding international trade agreements. Since the 1990s Peru has developed a solid track record when it comes to macroeconomic management, which will be strengthened over the forecast period. Our forecasts assume further progress in other key areas of the business environment, including policy towards enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, and tax policy. We expect the administration of the president, Martín Vizcarra, to continue the implementation of orthodox macroeconomic policy and rules-based fiscal management. Furthermore, despite indications of rising global protectionism, Peru will maintain its openness to foreign trade and foreign investment.
However, Peru's overall improvement in both global and regional rankings will be constrained by its scores in categories in which improvements are generally difficult and take longer to bear fruit, such as infrastructure, the labour market, market opportunities and technological readiness. Although the Vizcarra administration will seek to invest heavily in infrastructure development, primarily through public-private partnerships (PPPs), corruption investigations and excessive bureaucracy will keep the country from making gains in the regional and global rankings. At the same time, a constitutional requirement for the stability of labour contracts will hinder progress in addressing labour market deficiencies.
