Business environment outlook: Peru's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Further reforms are introduced to reduce bureaucracy and improve transparency. State re-launches national policies to increase productivity and boost competition.
2020-22: Government will refocus efforts to formalise small and medium-sized enterprises. Pro-competitive policies required for OECD accession are adopted.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Changes made to hydrocarbons legislation, modifying royalties and the length of contracts, to attract investment. Extension of value-added tax (VAT) rebates during the construction phase of extractive projects to secure mining investment.
2020-22: The concession process is upgraded, guaranteeing that projects are construction-ready when tendered.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Ratification of 11-nation Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for the Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP). Implementation of a bilateral trade agreement with Australia.
2020-22: A free-trade agreement with India is signed and implemented. Companies benefit from the conclusion of the negotiation of the Trade in Services Agreement, a trade pact involving 52 countries.
Taxes
2018-19: The excise tax rate is raised for several products. Changes to deductions for income tax and new requirements for companies to report beneficial ownership in tax filings are approved.
2020-22: Tax code will be changed to close loopholes and eliminate exemptions, including those for investment in jungle regions. Government will review and maintain suspension of 5% capital gains tax.
Financing
2018-19: Changes made to legislation for capital markets, including easing conditions for infrastructure and real estate funds. 2020-22: New rules for cross-border investment through the Pacific Alliance so that private pension funds and other investment mechanism can act seamlessly in member countries, Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru, to finance projects. New options for financing become available through the CPTPP and Peru's participation in China's Belt and Road Initiative.
The labour market
2018-19: Monthly minimum wage increase to S930/month, but labour costs will not be substantively effected owing to high rates of non-compliance with the minimum wage law. Little progress made addressing labour rigidity.
2020-22: Government will enact modest changes to reduce labour rigidity as part of its OECD accession efforts. Minimum wage will rise once again 2020.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Government jumpstarts concession, awarding contracts for a new copper mine, Michiquillay, and modernisation of a port, Salaverry. "Public works for taxes" mechanism expands to waterworks and other infrastructure sectors, including tourism.
2020-22: Government will offer concessions for construction of light rails to the north and south of Lima, the capital, as well as along the northern coast. Work will begin on a new airport for Cusco and an expansion of Lima's international airport should near completion. Construction of a new mega-port on the southern coast will also get underway.
Technological readiness
2018-19: Continued expansion of broadband service nationally, with a new concession for broadband service for five northern regions. Government rolls out single digital platform for the state to promote electronic government.
2020-22: Government will offer more than 20 regional fibre optic projects, worth an estimated US$1.5bn, in tenders. The majority of government services will become electronically accessible. Implementation of electronic "single window" systems will begin at government ministries and state agencies to reduce bureaucracy.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
7.5 8.3 30 14 2 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Peru's macroeconomic performance will continue to underpin the business environment in the 2018-22 period. Barring unforeseen natural disasters, GDP will grow at an annual average of 4% during the forecast period, well above the regional average, while year-end inflation will average 2.7%, squarely within the 1-3% target band set by the Banco Central de Reserva del Perú (BCRP, the central bank). The fiscal deficit will continue to fall, moving toward the 1% legal limit set for 2021. Exports will remain strong, as will the trade surplus, as a gradual build-up of production capacity boosts mineral output, and external demand for Peru's agro-exports remains strong. The government undertook another round of tax reform in the third quarter of 2018 to boost tax collection as a percentage of GDP. The public debt/GDP ratio will remain manageable through the forecast period, and below the legal ceiling of 30%. Peru's reliance on raw material exports, however, opens it to the potential for external shocks; as does its geography, which exposes it to unpredictable ocean currents and massive flooding, as had happened in the first quarter of 2017. Corruption scandals and political gridlock could also impact the forecast, with the effects of a proposed referendum for judicial and political reform playing out from 2019 onward.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.0 6.5 39 35 3 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The score for policy towards private enterprise and competition improves during the outlook period, with Peru moving up in both global and regional rankings. The government further strengthened the Instituto Nacional de Defensa de la Competencia y la Protección de la Propiedad Intelectual (Indecopi, the competition and intellectual property rights institute), which oversees policies to foster competition and ensure intellectual property rights. Concomitantly, the legislature, first in May and then again in July 2018, granted Mr Vizcarra's administration special powers to legislate on a number of economic issues, including competition. Legislation from the special powers will be approved and implemented through the end of 2018 and beginning of 2019. Legislative decrees published in July revamped laws for public-private partnerships (to reduce distortions arising from lobbying by private groups), broadened the OxI mechanism, which allows companies to invest part of their tax bill in public works programmes, and improved the national registry of public assets. Price controls were virtually eliminated in the 1990s, and it is extremely unlikely that they will be reinstated in the forecast period. The risk from distortions created by state ownership of enterprises is mitigated by a strict adherence to legally binding fiscal targets.
The Vizcarra administration will not make substantial changes to the approach to public companies adopted by the previous four administrations. Private investment will not be allowed in emblematic state-owned enterprises, including Electroperú (state-owned power company) Petróleos del Perú (Petroperú, the state oil company) and Servicio de Agua Potable y Alcantarillado de Lima (Sedapal, the waterworks for the capital, Lima). Electroperú and Petroperú are listed on the local stock market, but shares are not traded. This will not change during the forecast period. The administration will, nevertheless, move to address problematic issues in some public enterprises. It will reform the loss-making Banco Agropecuario (Agrobanco, agrarian bank), one of four public financial institutions. The government will also attempt to secure private investment to modernise and operate the northern crude-oil pipeline run by Petroperú. The pipeline has suffered 25 ruptures since January 2016 and remains closed as of September 2017. The OxI mechanism was expanded in July 2018 to allow for investment in waterworks, including Sedapal.
The government will also focus on administrative simplification during the forecast period as Peru ramps up efforts for OECD accession. It currently takes 26.5 days to start a business in Peru, compared with 8.5 days in the OECD, according to the World Bank's Doing Business 2018 report. The government announced that it will propose changes to simplify building permits in order to reduce the time required. The average time to obtain a building permit in Peru is 188 days, compared to 154.6 days in OECD countries, according to the Doing Business report.
While continuing to guarantee private property, the Vizcarra administration approved a decree in July 2018 refining procedures for expropriating and transferring property to the state for future infrastructure projects. This will help to provide certainty about the terms of expropriation as well as the methodology for appraisal of the value of acquired, thereby improving investor confidence. A second decree establishes exceptional measure to acquire land around 18 airports currently under private management to facilitate expansion. The government also published a decree for the consolidation of the national property registry. A consolidated registry is expected in the first quarter of 2019 and will be used to design and launch public-private partnerships and facilitate investment.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
7.3 8.2 30 21 3 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Peru's score for policy towards foreign investment improves considerably in 2018-22, with the country moving up nine spots to the 21st place in the global ranking, and one spot to the 2nd place regionally. The government will maintain the broad strokes of macroeconomic policies in place since the early 1990s while making changes to encourage foreign investment, primarily in extractive sectors. Foreign investment is protected under the constitution, as well as through a network of free-trade agreements (FTAs), and bilateral investment-protection and promotion agreements. Foreign investors receive the same treatment as local investors, and can avail of most of the tax exemptions and financing options as their domestic counterparts. Risk of expropriation of foreign assets is low, and is expected reduce further owing to changes in regulatory standards.
The government will make progress in reviving foreign investment in the hydrocarbons sector, which has been suffering in recent years. Active oil and gas exploration contracts had fallen to 16 at end-July 2018, down from 24 in the year-earlier period. We expect a new organic hydrocarbons law to be approved during the forecast period, with the congressional Energy and Mines Committee approving the initial reforms in mid-2018. The changes will extend oil and gas contracts to a maximum of 60 years, up from 40, and will allow for royalties to be negotiated based on future production. The new law is expected to jumpstart oil and gas contracts during the forecast period. The administration is also working on new rules to improve citizen participation in the approval of hydrocarbons contracts. The decision to review the process came about in May 2018, when the government decided to rescind approval of five offshore exploration blocks awarded in March to Ireland's Tullow Oil. The approval of the contracts, by Mr Vizcarra's predecessor, provoked citizen protests and led congressional caucuses to file nine different bills in the legislature to void them. The new mechanism, which will be in place in 2019, seeks to better inform the population about the process through which hydrocarbons contracts are awarded so as to reduce the potential for social conflicts. The revamped citizen participation process will complement legislation from 2011 requiring prior consultation of indigenous communities before extractive projects are approved. The final decision is ultimately left to the state. The state had 17 prior consultations pending as at August 2018. Social conflicts pose a major challenge to extractive projects. The Defensoria del Pueblo (the state ombudsman's office), which monitors conflicts, listed 90 socio-environmental conflicts in its August 2018, with 60 involving mining and 14 involving oil and gas projects. The state estimates that approximately US$15bn in investment in extractive projects has been slowed because of conflicts.
In 2018 the government, for the second consecutive year, approved legislation to streamline PPPs to facilitate private investment in infrastructure, particularly in the transportation sector. The administration forecasts up to $50bn in concessions between 2018 and 2020. In addition to tenders for Lines 3 and 4 of the Lima Metro, the Vizcarra administration plans to launch international bidding rounds for a light rail system along the coast. The US$6bn Line 2 of the Lima Metro is under construction, with 20% built by August 2018 and expected completion in 2022.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
8.7 8.7 27 32 2 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The score for foreign trade and exchange controls is stable during the forecast period, with Peru maintaining its ranking regionally, but falling five places globally, to the 32nd spot. Peru will retain its commitment to trade openness, with more than 90% of its trade now covered by FTAs with most of the world's largest economies. Transactions on the current and capital accounts will remain free from restrictions and the structural strength of the external position virtually eliminates the threat of exchange controls being imposed. The BCRP will continue to ease requirements on US dollar deposits and credit from abroad, as well as continue intervening in the currency markets to manage liquidity and foreign-exchange inflows. The currency has been fully convertible since 1990. Peru has a tripartite tariff structure, with 70.4% of items entering tariff-free, and the remaining items paying a tariff on either 6% (20.8% of goods) or 11% (8.8% of goods).
Trade liberalisation has remained a pillar of Peru's economic strategy since the implementation of a watershed FTA with the US in February 2009. Peru had 15 FTAs in place as at August 2018, and has signed, but not yet implemented, two bilateral agreements, with Australia and Guatemala. It has held two rounds of trade talks with India and is looking to begin talks with Indonesia in 2019. Five rounds of talks were held with Turkey, but the process was put on hold in the first quarter of 2016. The government implemented in May 2016 the protocol for the Pacific Alliance, which also includes Chile, Colombia and Mexico. It eliminated tariffs on 92% of goods entering from member countries and will completely eliminate them over a 17-year period. It also signed in March 2018 the 11-nation Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for the Trans-Pacific Partnership, the replacement for a similar agreement that included the US until it withdrew in January 2017. Implementation is expected in 2019. Peru also remains engaged in the Trade in Services Agreement, one of the world's largest potential agreements, which involves more than 50 World Trade Organisation members. Peru, like many countries, has been affected by US protectionist measures regarding aluminium and steel exports, but the impact has been slight. We do not expect additional pressure from the US, which enjoys a trade surplus with Peru.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.6 6.6 28 38 3 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The score in this category remains steady during the forecast period. However, Peru does improve in the regional rankings, moving up one rung to the 2nd spot, while falling ten positions, to the 38th place, in the global rankings (largely reflecting improvements in other countries). The tax burden in Peru is not a deterrent to doing business in the country. The corporate income tax rate in Peru stands at 29.5%, while the highest marginal income tax rate is 30%-both of which are low by regional and global standards. Peru also offers investors tax stability agreements to stimulate private investment. The government guarantees that the statutes on income taxes in effect at the time of the investment contract will remain unchanged for that investment for ten years. This scheme is applicable for investments greater than US$10m in the mining and hydrocarbons sector (or US$5m in all other sectors), over a two-year period. The tax system also offers entities a number of income tax credits and exemptions (for instance, on pre-operating expenses, interest payments and employees' health insurance premiums). Peru's score improvement is curbed by a relatively high value-added-tax (VAT) rate, which stands at 18% and is unlikely to change in the forecast period. Meanwhile, other indirect taxes will rise, as the government seeks to raise revenues. In May 2018 Mr Vizcarra's administration increased the excise tax in five categories-alcoholic beverages, cigarettes, fuels, soft drinks and vehicles-to boost tax income. (However, the government later agreed to refund 54% of the fuel tax to transportation companies, in response to social protest.) The overall tax system will also remain complex, with the time taken to prepare, file and pay taxes well above the OECD average.
The Vizcarra administration will modify the tax code to eliminate loopholes for tax evasion and avoidance. It will focus specifically on tax breaks for jungle regions where VAT and excise taxes are currently exempted. It also plans on extending the selective sales tax to casinos and electronic betting as of 2019. In August 2018 the government approved legislation requiring companies to specify the final owner, or beneficial owner, in tax filings. It also added tax incentives for investment in real-estate funds and modified procedures for companies using digital certificates to emit electronic receipts.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
7.0 7.0 22 33 2 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Peru's score in the financing category is unchanged during the forecast period. Its regional ranking remains the same, in second place, while its global ranking falls 11 positions to the 33rd spot (owing to improvements in the regulatory environment in more developed countries). The regulatory framework governing the financial sector is solid, and is likely to be strengthened in line with the Basel III framework. Although the financial sector is highly concentrated, some of the smaller banks have developed niche positions in specific types of lending. The financial sector's balance sheet is strong-the non-performing loan ratio has remained relatively stable in recent years, at between 1.5% and 3%. The capital adequacy ratio is well above the legal minimum, and liquidity levels are adequate. Bank profitability is also high, with the average return on equity of the 16 banks in the financial system is strong, remaining above 18% in the past two years. We expect greater penetration of the banking sector in the forecast period, with legislation enacted in August 2018 requiring all purchases with a value greater than three tax units (one tax unit is equivalent to about US$1250) to go through the financial system. Capital markets are shallow, but growing. Legislation promoting capital market growth was implemented in September 2017 and the Vizcarra administration is expected to use special legislative powers, granted by Congress in July 2018, to further promote development of capital markets. A legislative decree approved in August 2018 strengthens the incentives for investing in real-estate funds. Peru enjoys an investment-grade credit rating, and the latest legislation should provide the state and private companies with ample channels to access financing.
Large domestic corporations currently enjoy captive demand for their securities from three main institutional investors: the Administradoras de Fondos de Pensiones (AFPs, private pension funds), insurance companies and mutual funds. A wider range of Peruvian companies, including mid-sized firms, have issued bonds and equity financing will become more common during the forecast period. However, a weak corporate governance culture and concerns over public information disclosure will remain the main restriction to issuance of shares.
The Bolsa de Valores de Lima (BVL, the Lima stock exchange) remains small, but is expanding. Legislation from January 2017, building on legislation from 2015 to strengthen the stock market, exonerates income tax on different securities through December 31st 2019. The BVL will continue its integration into the Mercado Integrado Latinoamericano (the Latin American Integrated Market)-&[DEVICE CONTROL STRING]a joint initiative of the bourses of Peru, Colombia, Chile and Mexico-to become a single unified equity and securities exchange. Harmonisation of rules has been slow, but a new "funds passport" will allow for easier investment in mutual funds.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
4.4 4.7 78 78 11 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Peru's score in the labour category improves slightly in the forecast period, but it remains the weakest indicator, keeping Peru's rankings (at both the regional and the global level) unchanged. Labour rigidity will continue to hamper job creation and the low quality of education has resulted in a poorly trained workforce and low productivity. As at June 2018 73% of the economically active population worked in the informal sector and only a minority of workers have access to health insurance or pensions, or pay taxes. Regional differences in employment quality and productivity levels are stark. In addition, labour market mismatch is high in Peru, with close to half the workers being either underqualified or overqualified for their job, according to OECD estimates. However, given the lack of active labour market policies in force, this is likely to remain a concern over the forecast period. One of the positives for Peru is that wages are largely market determined; although a minimum wage is in place, it suffers from high rates of non-compliance. However, as a result, despite low rates of unionisation there is a high incidence of strikes-the majority of which are related to requests for salary increases.
The Vizcarra administration is unlikely to make any major moves to reform labour laws. The last effort to reform the General Labour Law was in 2004. The government, instead, will focus on unifying existing benefits and offering some levels of flexibility. This includes allowing companies and workers on payroll to negotiate vacation days. The administration will strengthen existing programmes, such as Tu Empresa, a mechanism launched in August 2017 to facilitate labour formalisation in small businesses and micro enterprises. Efforts will continue to better educate and train the workforce. In August 2018 the government modified articles in the General Education Law to improve technical-productive education. Regional education offices will create Technical-Productive Educational Centres once the legislation comes into effect in the final quarter of 2018.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
5.3 5.3 49 60 2 4
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Peru's score for infrastructure remains the same during the forecast period, but the country loses ground globally, falling 11 points to the 60th position, and regionally, dropping two points, to the fourth spot. (Peru loses ground both globally and regionally as other countries reap the benefit of past investment in infrastructure). Although the Vizcarra administration will kickstart a number of infrastructure projects, many of these will not be completed within the forecast period, which means that the extent and quality of transportation networks will stay largely the same. Although digital infrastructure will expand slightly, this will be concentrated in Peru's urban areas.
The country's transportation infrastructure was hurt by massive flooding in the first quarter of 2017 and reconstruction has been much slower than expected. The government budgeted S25.6bn (US$7.7bn) for reconstruction, with 77% earmarked for rebuilding infrastructure, 21% for prevention and 2% to improve the disaster response of national and subnational governments. The Vizcarra government in March 2018 recognized that only 10% of the work had been completed and re-launched the reconstruction process, obtaining legislative powers from Congress in May 2018 to decentralise spending and expedite efforts. It reorganised investment, in April and May 2018, increasing the amount for local governments to 45%, up from 16% in the original plan. The government used the legislative powers to produce decrees in July 2018 modifying PPPs, expanding the OxI mechanism, which allows companies to invest a percentage of their tax bill directly in infrastructure. The mechanism was responsible for financing 340 projects, costing S4bn, between its launch in 2009 and August 2018. Other decrees modified the process for the state to expropriate property for public works projects, and established mechanisms to free up land near 18 regional airports to allow for their expansion. Nonetheless, infrastructure will remain a key weakness of Peru's business environment.
The state continues to grapple with major delays in large-scale projects that were scheduled for completion by the end of the decade. The government announced in 2018 that it had cleared up issues with land easements on several projects, allowing for the pace to quicken. This includes the US$1.2bn expansion of Lima's international airport, but as at September 2018 the administration had not finished expropriating the land required for the construction of a second runway and a new terminal. The state has also not made any moves to revive a US$560m construction of a new airport in the Cusco region or a US$7.3bn construction of the southern natural gas pipeline. The two projects were awarded in 2014 and the contracts annulled in 2017; the former because of objections in Congress to a change in the contract, and the latter because of a corruption scandal involving the concession-holder, Odebrecht (a Brazilian construction firm mired in corruption cases across the region). Also blocked by corruption-related disputes, as of September 2018, are the US$800m Chavimochic irrigation project along the northern coast and the US$650m Majes-Siguas II irrigation project in the southern Arequipa region. Regardless of the issues of corruption, the design and execution of infrastructure concessions has traditionally been poor, reflecting low technical capacity in the public sector and persistent mismanagement of public projects.
ProInversión, the investment promotion agency, announced a list of 50 infrastructure projects that it will offer in the 2018-2020 period, to draw in investment of approximately US$11.5bn. Out of these projects, 40% are in transportation, 23% in mining, 10% in hospitals, 9% in water and sanitation, and 8% in energy. It had concluded two important concessions in 2018, awarding the US$2.4bn billion Michiquillay copper project to Mexico's Southern Copper Corporation, and the US$230m concession for the Salaverry port to Peru's Grupo Romero. In August 2018 the agency presented 384 projects, for a value of US$1.5bn, available for investment through the recently strengthened OxI mechanism. In 2019 the Vizcarra government will seek to establish a new infrastructure investment fund in the Pacific Alliance, which groups together Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru. It is also working with the Pacific Alliance partners to harmonise treatment of private pension funds that would allow for cross-border investment by the funds in the four countries.
Railroad infrastructure is set to improve during the forecast period. The government has announced plans for a light rail connecting Lima to intermediary cities to the north and south, as well as a light rail that will link the northern cities of Trujillo and Piura. Peru is also working with the governments of neighbouring countries, including Bolivia, Brazil and Paraguay, to begin the construction of a cargo railroad that would link Peru's southern coast with the Santos port in Brazil. However, the project remains in the inception stage, and construction is unlikely to finish within the forecast period.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
3.3 4.4 71 69 8 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
This section, introduced as part of an upgrade to our rankings in 2018, aims to show how future-oriented the business environment is-the extent to which it is digitally connected, open to innovation and prepared for technical disruption.
Peru's score for the forecast period improves, and it moves up two places in the global rankings, to the 69th position, and one place in the regional rankings, to seventh position. Penetration of information technology remains unequal: although 90.6% of the population nationally has a mobile phone connection, only 36% of households had at least one computer and a mere 33% of households had access to internet, according to the national statistics institute. Similarly, penetration of e-commerce remains low, with only 6% of the population making online purchases in 2017.
In 2018 the state took several steps to foster digital governance in the coming years. It published legislation that will require 173 ministries, agencies and regional governments to set up digital government committees by end-2019 to guarantee e-government services. The existing 1,864 municipal governments will be required to have the committees in place by the end-2021. In 2019 ProInversíon, the private investment agency, will offer concessions for the installation of broadband services in five northern regions. The state will also offer 21 new fibre optics projects during the forecast period, with an investment above US$1.5bn, to connect 1,530 district capitals.
Peru continues to lag behind the regional average for investment in research and development (R&D). According to a May 2017 survey by the Consejo Nacional de Ciencia, Tecnolgía e Innovación Tecnológica (Concytec, the national technology council), Peru invests the equivalent of 0.08% of GDP in R&D compared with 0.38% in Chile, 0.25% in Colombia and 0.54% in Mexico, the three countries Peru that is partnered with in the Pacific Alliance trade platform. The bulk of the investment, 66.5%, is in applied research, inventions and patents, while only 7.3% is directed towards technological development. This reflects, in part, the gap between university and industry regarding innovation, as well as the low quality of the country's universities. However, higher education in Peru is improving and will continue to improve through the forecast period as a new accreditation system is introduced. In April 2018 the government approved legislation that puts a three-year moratorium on the creation of new universities and satellite campuses, so that spending on higher education is focused on improving existing capacity.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
The government's immediate task is to ensure that the improvement in political stability translates into higher economic growth. The president, Martin Vizcarra, has drawn from his previous experience as regional governor of Moquegua (2011-14) to develop a broad strategy for inclusive development. His government will focus on instituting anti-corruption measures, executing infrastructure investment and improving social policies-particularly in education, health and security. Mr Vizcarra has already shown that anti-corruption reform is high on his administration's priority list by creating the Secretariat of Public Integrity, a new agency under the prime minister's office that will direct and supervise policies regarding integrity and public ethics. The government is also working to strengthen legislation that creates mechanisms for firms under investigation for alleged corruption to continue operations, so as to provide much-needed predictability to the construction sector. In addition, the government is looking to expedite reconstruction efforts, following extreme weather events in early 2017, and has already transferred funds of US$1.9bn to regional governments to this end.
In the medium term, Mr Vizcarra will pursue structural reforms including electoral, pension and labour-market reform. However, progress on these fronts will be piecemeal at best, given the difficulties around building consensus in a very politically fragmented Congress. Nonetheless, a number of the reforms that Mr Vizcarra favours will be attempted by subsequent administrations, as they are prerequisites for OECD accession-a longstanding goal of Peru.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy

Budget balance -3.1 -3.1 -2.7 -2.0 -1.0 -0.5
Government debt 24.9 26.3 27.5 27.9 26.6 25.2
The fiscal deficit will narrow gradually over the forecast period as the government gradually pares down countercyclical policy. Non-financial public sector (NFPS) spending will remain high in the short-term, keeping the NFPS deficit in 2018 at its 2017 level of 3.1% of GDP. The deficit will narrow thereafter as the government dials down the fiscal stimulus and a stronger economy boosts revenue. To consolidate the public finances in the medium term, Mr Vizcarra is seeking tax reforms that would broaden the tax base, eliminate redundant expenses and rationalise tax exemptions. His government also aims to reduce non-essential public spending, and has already established spending limits for ministries and state-owned agencies in a number of areas including advertisement, conferences workshops and travel.
The 2018 budget calls for increased spending across the board, with particular emphasis on capital expenditure. Nearly half of the increased spending will be allocated to reconstruction efforts to mitigate damage caused by the "coastal El Niño" climate phenomenon that affected Peru in early 2017. Other significant infrastructure expenditure in the budget includes a commitment of US$1.4bn for a long-delayed expansion of the metro system in the capital, Lima, and a US$1.2bn investment in public works aimed at improving sanitation.
The government's infrastructure plan would push capital and overall expenditure to 7.8% of GDP and 31.5% of GDP respectively in 2018-19. However, there are some risks to our public expenditure forecasts, given the government's weak implementation capacity, which could result in a narrower than expected fiscal deficit. A change of local authorities after regional and municipal elections in October may also lead to greater delays in execution of public investment than The Economist Intelligence Unit currently anticipates. As for revenue, we expect improved tax collection in 2018-22. This is partly owing to an expected recovery in private consumption amid sustained growth in real wages and partly the result of efforts to reduce tax exemptions, currently valued at 2.2% of GDP. Higher tax revenue will only partly offset the rise in spending in 2018, but it will result in deficit reductions in 2019-22, when we expect public expenditure to be reined in.
We expect that the public debt/GDP ratio will rise in the medium term, from 26.3% in 2018, to a high of 27.9% in 2020, before easing to 25.2% in 2022 as the fiscal deficit narrows. Such a level is low by regional and global standards. Peru will retain good access to financing from domestic and international markets and, should external conditions deteriorate sharply (not our baseline scenario), the country would be able to access multilateral funding with relative ease.
Economic forecast: Monetary policy
Interest rates
(%)
  2017 2018 2019 2020 2021 2022
Short-term lending rate (av; %) 16.6 15.1 15.7 15.8 15.8 16.4
The Banco Central de Reserva del Perú (BCRP, the central bank) operates an inflation targeting regime, which has been instrumental in maintaining macroeconomic stability. Weaker than expected growth and falling inflation out-turns in 2017 allowed the BCRP to reduce its policy rate by 125 basis points, to 2.75%, in the 12 months leading up to March 2018, despite monetary tightening in the US. We expect rates to remain on hold, to spur credit growth, until the fourth quarter, when they will be lifted by 25 basis points as economic recovery raises inflationary pressures. The central bank will continue to lift rates in 25-basis-point increments in 2019, so as to minimise capital flight from Peru as the Federal Reserve (the US central bank) continues its tightening cycle. A loosening of monetary policy in the US in 2020 will allow the BCRP to implement more expansionary policy to support economic growth that year. Thereafter, in 2021-22 the Peruvian economy will be on an upswing, leading to a renewed tightening cycle. A key risk to our forecast stems from emerging-market volatility: although Peru has thus far been largely insulated from runs on its currency, it remains somewhat vulnerable nonetheless.

Economic forecast: Economic growth

The economy maintained its strong momentum in the second quarter, growing by 3% sequentially (and by 5.4% year on year), and we expect generally favourable domestic and external conditions to deliver an annual average rate of 4% in 2018-22. However, overall growth will be dampened by a forecast slowdown in global growth in 2020, as well as Peru's large infrastructure gaps and a lack of productivity-enhancing reforms.
On the expenditure side, private consumption will be bolstered by a recovery of formal employment, a rise in real wages and growth in consumer credit. Private investment will also grow strongly, particularly in the mining sector, which will reap the benefits of still-high metal prices. A number of public-private partnerships will boost investment in construction, transport and irrigation infrastructure. Public investment will be dynamic owing to ongoing reconstruction works and the government's large infrastructure plan. The rise in fixed investment will have a multiplier effect on growth through its knock-on effects on consumption. Historically, there has been evidence to support the existence of a virtuous investment-employment-consumption cycle in Peru. The contribution of the external sector to growth will be muted, owing to capacity constraints in the production of traditional exports.
However, there are risks to our forecasts, as investment growth is likely to be curtailed by transparency issues, congressional gridlock, and ineffective and cumbersome regulatory procedures. The construction sector is especially vulnerable to these problems, as nearly 30 domestic and foreign firms have recently been implicated in a corruption scandal pertaining to the improper awarding of tenders for public works projects. Judicial investigations into the matter have already led to six arrests and pose an ongoing threat to planned infrastructure works in 2018-19 (amounting to over US$9bn).
On the supply side, the economy will remain dominated by the mining sector, but the main productivity gains will come from the agro-industrial sector, which has grown quickly in recent years. Manufacturing will continue to face constraints related to external competition, fluctuations in global demand and a lack of skilled labour. Services growth will be supported by expansion in retail, finance, tourism and transport. The continued expansion of an emerging middle class will boost the services sector.

Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Industry will grow by an annual average of 4.3% in 2018-22, supported by strong prices for Peru's key metals exports-particularly copper. Despite a slight contraction in global copper demand in 2017 (by 0.2% according to the World Bureau of Metal Statistics), it is expected to pick up over the forecast period, sustaining growth in copper prices. China, which accounts for close to half of global copper consumption is and Peru's largest trade partner, will be pivotal in sustaining a tighter copper market. China's electric vehicle market and significant investments in renewable energy infrastructure-as officials work to reduce greenhouse gas emissions-will also help to increase copper demand. The outlook for copper consumption in India, one of Peru's fastest growing export markets, is also broadly positive owing to investment-led growth in that country. Although the copper price environment will not match up with the 2006-13 boom years, it will nonetheless be supportive of investment in the extractives industry. The government calculates that potential mining projects, principally in copper, gold, iron ore and silver, could mean as much as US$59bn in new investment. Furthermore, feasibility and engineering studies have been completed for close to half of the mining projects on offer, which should consolidate the development of a new mining cycle. We expect much more modest investment, as a number of the projects that the government is counting on are expected to face issues related to financing or face opposition from local communities. Community groups oppose the arrival of mining investment, citing concerns about damage to the environment and the fact that not enough locals are hired to work at the mines. Anti-mining protests often turn violent and mining projects suffer delays. Regardless, Peru will preserve its place as a pre-eminent copper producer (it is currently the second-largest producer in the world, behind Chile) and mining output will show consistent growth.
Manufacturing will also remain fairly dynamic, despite its vulnerability to fluctuations in demand from the US and China, given an ongoing bilateral trade war between those two countries, and competitiveness issues brought on by the combination of low productivity and myriad FTAs. As such, the areas that will see the most growth will be extractive or non-tradeable in nature. Significant investments in 2018-22, including in the expanding petrochemicals sector and gas pipeline infrastructure, will boost industrial capacity in the latter part of the forecast period. Successive administrations have moved towards the medium- to-long-term goal of developing industrial centres that will take advantage of the high quantity of ethane in Peruvian gas to produce polyethylene and other petrochemicals. The construction of large hydroelectric plants in the Amazon region will also boost growth in the energy sector. Construction, which has boomed in recent years, will continue to expand during the forecast period, although at a slower rate. This will be driven by the Vizcarra government's plans for public infrastructure projects (electrification, sanitation, housing, roads and new transport facilities in major cities), and private projects, including large retail investments in secondary cities and industrial schemes (such as a natural-gas pipeline, hydroelectric plants and mining projects).
Agriculture will record average annual growth of 4% in the forecast period, although the figure is skewed by a stronger performance at the beginning of the forecast period, as production is continuing to recover from the effects of the "coastal El Niño" in early-2017, which brought massive flooding and loss of crops. Peru is carving out a niche in international markets for agro-exports, taking advantage of growing conditions at home and new opportunities created by Peru's numerous FTAs. Considerable investment in irrigation and export capacity has gone into the sector in the past years, and output will be lifted in the latter part of the forecast period by the completion of large irrigation projects in the southern and northern coastal areas. These will add more than 100,000 ha of new farmland. The fishing sector is expected to grow moderately, with the focus shifting from traditional fishmeal and fish-oil exports towards fish for human consumption.
Services are expected to grow by an annual average of 3.9% in 2018-22, supported by expansion in retail, finance, tourism and transport. Planned expansion of large retail chains across Lima and in smaller cities will respond to the changing consumer patterns of a growing middle class. Tourism will gain in importance as infrastructure (such as the construction of a modern airport in Cusco), and hence access to the country's main tourism destinations, improves gradually. The continued emergence of a growing middle class will boost the services sector and will gradually contribute more to Peru's GDP growth as the latest wave of investment comes to an end.

Annual inflation continued to gather pace, reaching 1.6% in July, up from 1.4% in June. Prices will continue to rise owing to stronger supply-side pressures (such as higher fuel costs) as well as demand-side pressures (as consumption expenditure picks up amid strong economic growth). This will lift inflation to 2.7% by end-2018, up from 1.4% the year before. Notwithstanding sporadic volatility, we expect that the BCRP's inflation targeting framework will be effective in anchoring inflation expectations, which should ensure that inflation stays within the 1-3% target range in the forecast period. There are several risks to this forecast, including sporadic bouts of adverse weather, which could drive up food prices, as well as an unexpected bout of currency depreciation, which would lead to higher import costs.

We expect real trade-weighted exchange-rate depreciation to be modest in 2018-20, at an annual average of 1.8%, taking the currency from S3.24:US$1 at end-2017 to S3.41:US$1 at end-2020. Thereafter, the sol will appreciate slightly, reflecting a narrowing of the current-account deficit and a wider real interest rate differential with the US, to reach S3.30:US$1 by end-2022. Inflows of investment and external credit will provide support for the sol. The BCRP will continue to support the ongoing process of de-dollarisation and protection of the financial sector, which is moderately exposed to currency risk. The balance of risks is tilted towards greater weakening of the sol than currently forecast. However, the risk of sharper than expected depreciation is mitigated by confidence in the monetary policy framework, strong reserves and steady long-term capital inflows.

Although the current-account will remain in deficit throughout the forecast period, it will show signs of improvement in the latter half of our forecast period. Notwithstanding the tailwinds of high commodity prices, the trade surplus will narrow from 2.9% of GDP in 2018 to 2.5% of GDP in 2019 as capacity constraints curtail growth of traditional exports while import growth remains strong (in line with a recovery of private consumption and infrastructure-related capital imports). The surplus will deteriorate further in 2020, to 2.2% of GDP, owing to a forecast slowdown in global trade, before climbing to 2.3% of GDP in 2022 (reflecting improved production capacity and export-market diversification). The primary income deficit will remain large, averaging 4.9% of GDP in 2018-22, owing to profit repatriation by multinational firms based in Peru. The services deficit will be roughly stable, at an average of 0.8% of GDP. Meanwhile, the secondary income account (mostly inward workers' remittances) will register an average surplus of 1.6% of GDP.
As a result, the current-account deficit will average 1.7% of GDP in 2018-22. The deficit will be financed by inward flows of foreign direct investment, which will average US$7.6bn (3.3% of GDP) in 2018-19. Although inflows will fall to 2.7% of GDP in a more challenging international environment in 2020, they will recover thereafter, to 3.1% of GDP in 2021-22.
Foreign reserves stood at US$61bn on August 24th (equivalent to 13.8 months of import cover) and will rise to the equivalent of 15.7 months of cover by 2022, providing more than adequate protection against external shocks.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Peru
Stocks and flows
Foreign direct investment (FDI) peaked in 2012 at a historic high of US$11.8bn (6.1% of GDP). FDI flows have since ebbed, reflecting the end of the commodities boom, reaching US$6.9bn in 2016 (3.5% of GDP). Despite a recovery in metal prices, FDI inflows fell further, to US$6.8bn (3.2% of GDP) in 2017, reflecting the detrimental impact of a political crisis on investor sentiment that year. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects FDI inflows to increase moderately, in nominal terms, over the forecast period (notwithstanding a dip in 2020), owing to resurgent prices for Peru's traditional exports, especially copper. At the same time, strong opportunities will open up in the energy, manufacturing, retail and infrastructure sectors. However, FDI inflows will stabilise at around 3.1% of GDP in 2018-22, considerably below the average of 5.5% of GDP at the height of the commodities boom in 2007-12. The stock of inward FDI totalled US$98.2bn at end-2017, or 45.8% of GDP. Peru does not have significant outflows of FDI; these totalled only US$262m in 2017, resulting in a stock of just US$5.4bn. Despite its small size, this stock has increased sharply over the past decade.
Origin and distribution
According to the government's investment-promotion agency, ProInversión, in June 2017 Spain, the UK and the US respectively accounted for 18%, 17% and 13% of the accumulated FDI stock in the country, followed by Chile (12%), the Netherlands (6%) and Brazil (5%). The stock of FDI was dominated by the mining sector, with 22% of the total, ahead of telecommunications (19%), finance (19%), energy (14%) and industry (13%); all other sectors had low single-digit shares. This suggests that there is considerable potential outside the traditional recipient sectors, with retail, transport, and tourism considerably under-represented compared with their shares of FDI in similar economies. One notable investment in the past resulted from the sale of the national telephone company to Telefónica (Spain), which partly explains that country's (and the telecoms sector's) large share of the FDI stock.
Determinants
Macroeconomic stability and liberalisation in the 1990s allowed for large increases in FDI inflows, following a period of sharp economic recession in the late 1980s. Annual average inflows rose from the negligible amounts of the 1980s to US$1.7bn (3.5%% of GDP) in the 1990s. During the first half of the 1990s in particular, the government aggressively pursued foreign investment in privatisation, above all in communications and financial services, and the development of abundant mining and energy resources. The implementation of business-friendly policies in the early 2000s, coupled with political stability-in addition to an ongoing rise in commodity prices throughout most of the last decade-helped to boost FDI inflows to an average of US$3.7bn in 2000-10, and to an average of US$8.3bn in 2011-15. During 2018-22 the government will continue to seek to attract private investment into mining, hydroelectricity, hydrocarbons exploration and infrastructure projects. However, risks to commodities prices will persist throughout the forecast period, especially given a recent increase in protectionist sentiment across the globe, and efforts to diversify into other sectors (such as services) could prove increasingly lucrative.
Impact
Increases in FDI during the mid-1990s funded a growing share of gross fixed investment. The impact of FDI on the wider economy in terms of technology transfer has been confined mainly to the spillover effects from a much-improved telecoms sector and a more efficient financial services sector, with investment in mining having only limited links to the rest of the economy. This is changing, as foreign investment in natural gas and hydroelectricity is improving sources of energy. The award of infrastructure concessions will also promote economic development across various regions (some of which are relatively poor). An estimated US$80bn shortfall in infrastructure and communications investment will also be a driver for increased public-private partnerships (PPPs).
Potential
In the short term, increased FDI will be driven by reinvestment of profits of foreign companies amid stronger economic growth as well as robust demand for Peru's mining exports. However, attracting new investment outside the mining sector will prove more challenging. Notwithstanding ongoing efforts to streamline regulation on public tenders, PPPs in infrastructure will frequently be subject to delays, given the difficulties involved in managing various stakeholders. Regardless, Peru's improving track record of prudent policymaking, FTAs with the US and the EU (which include FDI clauses), and Peru's rich hydrocarbon and minerals resources will continue to pique interest during the forecast period. Although the pipeline of projects over the next decade includes close to US$60bn in mining projects and more than US$10bn in hydroelectric plants, the actual investment flows will be lower owing to bureaucratic delays, local opposition, governability concerns, difficulty with environmental licences and uncertainty associated with metals prices. Other areas that will receive investment include hydrocarbons exploration, transport infrastructure, water and sanitation, petrochemicals, and telecoms. Non-capital investment will be led by the financial and tourism sectors.

Working-age population will outstrip overall population growth
Population growth slowed to 1.1% a year in 2013-17, down from 2.3% in the 1980s and 1.7% in the 1990s, owing to migration abroad and a declining birth rate. Population growth will remain stable at this level in 2018-22, keeping it above the global average, reflecting high birth rates among lower income households and advances in healthcare (reflected in outcomes including lower infant mortality). The population will remain younger than in most industrialised countries. A modest rise in the old-age dependency ratio-the proportion of the population above working age-will be more than offset by a decline in the young-age dependency ratio in the medium term. The number of people of working age will therefore continue to rise faster than the growth of the population as a whole, providing a demographic dividend to the economy.
As with many Latin American countries, Peru has experienced rapid urbanisation in recent decades. In 2017, according to the latest data estimation available from the national statistics institute, 78% of the total population lived in cities, with about two-fifths of those living in Lima, the capital. Urbanisation will continue to rise during the forecast period as Peruvians seek better living and employment conditions. Informal employment, which is estimated to account for over three-quarters of the economically active population, will remain high, notably in the construction and retail sectors. Informal unemployment is expected to decline only gradually, helped by government efforts to ease labour costs for businesses via tax simplification and subsidies, but will remain high by international standards. The unemployment rate reached a record low of 6% in 2013, but has been slowly creeping up as economic growth has cooled, relative to the years of the commodities boom. Although the unemployment rate dipped once again, to 6.2% in the May-July quarter, amid an ongoing economic recovery, this masks high levels of underemployment, which affects as much as 35% of those employed, and is tied to a mismatch between labour market demands and the focus and quality of education.
Demographic indicators to improve but from a low base
Although Peru's demographic indicators will make progress in the next decade-as education standards rise, nutrition improves, and access to safe water and sanitation is expanded-they will remain relatively poor. Poverty levels have declined significantly in the past decade. The proportion of the population living in poverty fell from around 55% in 2000 to 20.7% in 2016. However, it rose once again, to 21.7%, in 2017-the result of an economic slowdown, which was worsened by a political crisis that year. There are marked regional disparities, with 44% of the population in rural areas still living below the poverty line in 2017 (down from 74% in 2007). According to official figures for 2017, 84% of the urban population had access to potable water through the public network (a further 10% are served, but water is not deemed potable). Meanwhile, only 72% of the rural population is reached by the public network, and a stark 9% of those served receive potable water. The extension of the water and sanitation network will remain one of the highest public healthcare priorities and will continue to receive substantial investment in the forecast period, as the government has planned large expenses in 2018-21.
Health status indicators have improved significantly in recent decades, although regional variations in infant and maternal mortality rates are pronounced. Average life expectancy at birth has risen to 75.5 years, according to the World Health Organisation (WHO); its figures differ from the local-source data on which The Economist Intelligence Unit's current forecasts are based. According to the World Health Statistics 2018 report published by the WHO, which for Peru contains 2015 data, maternal mortality rates have more than halved over the past 15 years (from 160 to 68 per 100,000 births), but are still above the regional average of 52. The mortality rate of children under five has been on a declining trend, reaching 15.3 per 1,000 births in 2015 (down from 40 in 2000), although it remains a serious problem, especially in the more remote rural districts. Latest cause-of-death data (2014) show malignant tumours are the single highest cause of mortality, followed by influenza and pneumonia. Cardiovascular diseases and diabetes also rank high amongst the main sources of mortality. Our projections assume that there will be some progress in health statistics in 2017-21 but that Peru will continue to lag behind most other countries in the region.

The emerging middle class will expand, but remain concentrated in urban areas
Although the Peruvian consumer market will remain characterised largely by inequality, two decades of strong economic growth have gradually led to the emergence of a growing middle class. Over the past decade, the capital, Lima, where most affluent consumers are concentrated, has seen a rapid transformation in consumer patterns. Retail and entertainment chains have expanded from the traditional wealthy areas, owing to increasing demand from lower-income districts and the emerging neighbourhoods (former slums) located in the periphery of the metropolitan area. This new consumer demand is also evident in secondary cities such as Arequipa, Trujillo, Chiclayo, Cusco, Piura, Iquitos and Ica, where economic growth has had a wider impact. However, the growth of market opportunities will remain limited to urban areas, and the majority of the population (particularly in rural areas) will continue to have low disposable income during the forecast period.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects average annual GDP growth of 4% in 2018-22-solid in historical terms, and an improvement over the average growth of 3.6% in 2013-17, when the economy was adjusting to the end of the last commodities supercycle-to contribute to the continued gradual expansion of the middle class as the number of formal-sector jobs grows, albeit from a low base. The economy is expected to generate jobs for unskilled and skilled workers alike. However, those who remain in rural areas, or are confined to the informal sector by a lack of skills (where underemployment will keep the supply of labour high and will hold down income), will continue to see fewer benefits from economic growth.
The government's efforts to reduce labour costs-especially at small firms-could help to increase formal job creation, but raising skill levels will prove challenging, given poor educational outcomes. Although a strengthening of existing conditional cash transfer programmes will increase purchasing power for lower-income groups, their access to consumer goods and services will remain limited. Despite a sharp reduction in overall poverty levels (from more than half the population in 2000 to less than a quarter today), indigenous communities in the Andes and the Amazon areas will remain isolated, and high levels of illiteracy will persist, although literacy programmes have made some progress during the past decade.

Poverty and social inequality will remain barriers to market growth
Due to still high levels of poverty and vast social inequalities, the total size of the population is a poor guide to market opportunities in Peru. The World Bank estimates the country's Gini coefficient (a widely used indicator of inequality, with zero equalling complete equality and 1 maximal inequality) at 0.438 in 2016, less than in some other regional economies, but high by global standards. Low inflation, steady growth of real incomes and targeted poverty-alleviation programmes will gradually lift more families out of poverty, allowing the share of food in overall household expenditure to slowly decline, although it will remain high by international standards. Increased household incomes will bring about a shift in consumption patterns, with food and beverages losing ground to expenses in healthcare and telecommunications. Over time, growth of credit will encourage increased expenditure on durable consumer goods by a greater proportion of the overall population and those living outside Lima.
The market is geographically skewed, with metropolitan Lima accounting for about 30% of the population, well over 50% of all economic activity and 75% of consumer bank credit. Although Lima will continue to be the focus for investors, they will increasingly tap demand in areas outside the capital. Indeed, the last few years have seen a rapid expansion of retailers in the larger cities along the coast and in the Andes, and with a pick-up in growth in 2018-22, this trend is likely to continue in the medium term. Greater market integration is also expected as the government continues to increase spending on infrastructure. Growth, macroeconomic stability, low tariffs and a plentiful supply of foreign exchange should allow Peru to become a more significant importer of consumer goods. This trend will be accelerated by greater access to the US, Chinese and European markets under free-trade agreements. Although Peru's population is ageing, it will remain much younger than in developed markets, and the ongoing demographic boom will make consumption patterns more dynamic.

Long-term outlook: The long-term outlook

Initial conditions: Peru's real GDP growth averaged 3.2% between 1982 and 2015, and growth of real GDP per head averaged 1.1%. However, these figures disguise a marked improvement in economic performance during the 1990s, when the policy environment was transformed and the economy was liberalised after a period of macroeconomic instability in the 1980s, characterised by a debt crisis and hyperinflation later in the decade. These policy improvements spurred economic growth in the 2000s and helped the economy to withstand the 2008-09 global financial crisis fairly well. Although rapid GDP growth over the past two decades has enabled Peru to catch up with the Latin American median in terms of GDP per head, it is still well below that of developed countries. Weaker external conditions and slow progress in pushing the reform agenda forward to tackle longstanding structural issues means that Peru will continue to lag behind developed economies by 2030. Peru is well endowed with natural resources-ranging from metals and natural gas to productive agricultural land. Its main weaknesses are the poor quality of its institutions, coupled with widespread income and regional inequalities. Overall education levels will remain low, and the slow pace of institutional improvement, together with lower investment in capital spending, will be the main factors behind a slowdown in average annual growth in the second half of the long-term outlook period. Opportunities in energy and mining will continue to foster investment. Nevertheless, with export-oriented industries the mainstay of the economy, Peru will remain vulnerable to fluctuations in external demand and commodities prices.
Demographic trends: The Economist Intelligence Unit expects population growth to average 1% annually in 2018-30, before slowing to 0.6% per year in 2031-50. Fertility will decline in line with continued urbanisation, but the birth rate will remain relatively high, even by Latin American standards, and well above developed-country norms. Declining fertility and increasing life expectancy point to an ageing population. However, even by the end of the long-term forecast period, the proportion of the population aged 65 and over, at around 17%, will remain much lower than in OECD countries. Lower birth-rates and the current low numbers of pensioners means that the dependency ratio (the ratio of children and elderly to the working-age population) will bottom out at 50.5% by 2032, before beginning a steady upward trend. Emigration has been substantial enough to have had an impact on population growth; each year, around 300,000 individuals are estimated to leave Peru to seek work abroad, although significant numbers have returned in recent years, as the economy has expanded rapidly and opportunities in traditional migrant destinations such as Spain have been limited. However, economic growth, by increasing disposable income for those in work, will put the option of emigration within reach of a greater proportion of the population, and the gap in economic opportunities between Peru and a variety of countries, including the US and neighbouring Chile, will remain wide. Internal migration will also have a decisive influence on the development of the economy. The level of urbanisation will rise from its present level of 79%, but it is already high by global standards, so the increase will be modest.
External conditions: The export-oriented sectors of the Peruvian economy, ranging from mining to export agriculture, have long been the most dynamic. Peru is expected to continue to benefit from free-trade agreements (FTAs) with the US, the main market for non-traditional exports, and China, which in 2014 replaced the US as the recipient of the largest proportion of total exports. FTAs with the EU and other Asian economies will provide similar benefits. Integration efforts within Latin America are also gaining pace, particularly under the auspices of the Pacific Alliance, an integration pact composed of Peru, Chile, Colombia and Mexico, which focuses not only on trade in goods, but also on services, capital and free movement of people. Global trade flows will outpace world output growth over the long term, and Peru's increasing integration with the world economy should allow the country to benefit from global demand. Although the Peruvian economy is highly exposed to world commodity prices, its vulnerability to external shocks will be somewhat mitigated by greater export-market diversification, as well as investments in supply expansion of non-traditional exports (where prices have played only a marginal role).
Institutions and policy trends: Peru's institutions were weakened during the 1990s under the rule of the then president, Alberto Fujimori (1990-2000). The media and forces in Congress became co-opted by the executive, and the political system became more authoritarian. The transition from Mr Fujimori's regime highlighted popular demands for a greater degree of effective democracy and decentralisation, made evident by rising protests in Peru's regions. Nevertheless, the quality of institutions remains weak, characterised by a politicised judiciary, widespread corruption and the lack of a strong party system, which leads to legislative fragmentation. The current president, Martín Vizcarra, is devoting much of his efforts to overhauling the system by seeking to introduce a slate of institutional reforms by means of a plebiscite. Although we expect Mr Vizcarra to face many obstacles in the process, including protracted negotiations with a hostile Congress, we nonetheless do expect progress on some fronts, particularly judicial reform, which is likely to improve investor confidence through greater efficiency and objectivity in judicial processes. Our long-term forecast assumes that improvements in the conduct of economic policy and in the policy environment will largely be sustained. We expect the public finances to be prudently managed, characterised by low debt levels. Bureaucracy will gradually be reduced and the business environment, which in some respects remains non-conducive to entrepreneurship, will improve. Increased spending on healthcare and education will gradually have productivity-enhancing effects. Private investment will lead to improvements in infrastructure. A continued commitment to inflation targeting by the Banco Central de Reserva del Perú (the central bank), along with responsible fiscal management and a low debt stock, will help to maintain macroeconomic stability, while a flexible exchange rate will help the economy to cope with external shocks.
Long-term performance: We forecast average real GDP growth of 4% per year in 2021-30, easing to an average of 3.2% in 2031-50; this is strong by regional standards. Past reforms, in particular the establishment of private pension funds, will continue to bear fruit, helping to deepen capital markets and raise the savings rate. Nevertheless, growth is likely to be focused on resource-intensive areas, export agriculture and specialised areas of manufacturing, such as textiles. Relatively low levels of education for the majority, coupled with low spending on research and development-at less than 1% of GDP-will constrain the economy from moving into higher value-added areas, despite frequent attempts by governments to improve domestic productive capacity and develop industrial clusters. Economic performance will become more dependent on productivity gains as growth in the labour force slows and the economy remains reliant on the extractive sectors. Reflecting investments made in previous years and slow but sustained institutional improvements, labour productivity will rise by an average of 2.5% in 2017-50. We expect GDP per head, measured at purchasing-power parity levels, to increase to 32.2% of the US level by 2050, up from just 20.4% in 2017.
