Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
Peru's long coastline and diverse topography leave it disproportionately exposed to the effects of climate change. It is already a warm country, given its tropical latitude, and subject to droughts and extreme weather events such as the calamitous El Niño of early 2017, which caused as much as US$3.1bn (1.5% of GDP) in damages that year. Peru is further disadvantaged by the fact that more than two-thirds of its population, and most of its economic activity, is concentrated along the Pacific coast. These risks are also exacerbated by Peru's economic structure: although the agricultural sector makes up only 7.6% of GDP, it accounts for close to 30% of total employment. Furthermore, Peru is heavily reliant on agro-industrial production for its export economy, which will be crucial to the health of Peru's external accounts. Therefore, even though Peru is responsible for close to 0.1% of global carbon dioxide emissions, it will be one of the most responsive countries in terms of implementing policy for climate change adaptation.
In April 2018 Peru became the fourth country in the Latin American and Caribbean region to legally institute a framework for climate change mitigation, in line with the commitments of the Paris Agreement (which was ratified by Peru in mid-2016). One of the key implications of the law is that it makes Peru's commitment to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 30% by 2030 legally binding. These efforts will largely be focused on reducing emissions from deforestation and forest degradation in the Amazon region, which is responsible for the majority of greenhouse gas emissions in Peru. Although the law designates the Ministry of Environment as responsible for monitoring progress on the goals for climate change mitigation and adaptation, it establishes a multi-sector approach that promotes the participation of regional governments, the private sector, civil society and indigenous groups in strategy formulation. The framework also seeks to promote research in climate change management, by making it a priority area for public spending. Climate financing rose exponentially, from US$400,000 in 2005 to US$216m in 2013, and will continue on a positive trajectory over the long term.
Technological developments
Peru's government is seeking to promote the development of new technology, both by introducing it into government services and by encouraging partnerships with the private sector. The government is currently working on developing a comprehensive regulatory framework aimed at encouraging investment into the growing industry by reducing regulatory uncertainty for investors, and therefore reducing the risk of bringing new technological developments to market.
For instance, in 2012 the Peruvian government approved law 29985, on electronic money, which has proven to be one of the foundational pieces of legislation for enabling the growth of electronic-commerce and mobile-commerce. The law allows banks and non-banking financial institutions to issue electronic money and includes a clear definition of e-money, facilitating its use by existing companies and new start-ups. The Superintendencia de Banca, Seguros y AFP (the financial oversight agency) is also currently drafting new regulation to support the growth of a financial technology (fintech) sector in Peru.
As a result, overall e-commerce usage is increasing, driven by rising internet use by the young population, with an internet usage rate of 77% among persons aged 18-25 years. The m-commerce sector is developing particularly quickly, owing largely to greater mobile internet coverage than wired internet coverage, particularly in remote and rural areas. Mobile phone penetration in Peru is high, at 71% in 2016 (according to the latest official estimates) and this is expected to increase rapidly in the coming years. Although smartphone adoption is still relatively low, at 31% in 2016, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects significant improvement over the medium and long term, especially with a growing Peruvian middle class. The expanding availability of 3G and 4G services will also be supportive of m-commerce expansion.
An example of innovative products utilising new technology are mobile money wallets, which have facilitated the growth of m-commerce. The government has led innovation in this space by partnering with financial institutions, telecommunications companies, microfinance institutions and other providers to offer Billetera Móvil (BiM)-the country's first fully operational national mobile money system. This has encouraged private investors to join the scheme and offer their own m-commerce services.
Nonetheless, despite relatively low transaction costs for services such as BiM, the cost of buying a mobile phone handset is still high for some sectors, acting as a barrier to entry. For instance, mobile ownership costs 12% of total income for the poorest 40% of Peru's population, well above the industry target of 5% of total income. In addition, efforts to broaden financial inclusion will be impeded by high levels of financial illiteracy and a lack of confidence in the financial system (related to inadequate consumer protection requirements). For logistical reasons such as these, e-commerce and m-commerce services are likely to expand most rapidly in urban areas, with take-up of new tech services being slower in Peru's most remote areas.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
BCRP: Banco Central de Reserva del Perú (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics
Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2013-17) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2018-22). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2013-17. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2018-22 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2013-17 ranges are then used to derive 2018-22 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2018-22, not to the likely situation in 2022 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2015 or 2020). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Turkey--highlights: Political outlook
In June Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected as president for a second term in the first round of a snap presidential election. On the same day Mr Erdogan's conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a parliamentary coalition majority with its right-wing ally, the Nationalist Action Party (MHP). Mr Erdogan's re-election concludes Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the AKP and Mr Erdogan to remain in power until 2023, and possibly beyond. Mr Erdogan will continue to clamp down on domestic political dissent and opposition. Security risk remains high and Turkey is vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and Islamic State (IS). We expect Turkey and its Western allies to avoid a complete breakdown in relations although they will be antagonistic and increasingly transactional.
Turkey--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
5.97 5.87 49 59 17 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Our business environment score for Turkey deteriorates slightly in the forecast period (2018-22), and its global ranking falls by ten places, to 59th. Political tensions, increased powers concentrated under the president, and inadequate policy responses to tightening global liquidity conditions and higher domestic inflation have increased the level of uncertainty about the direction of economic policy. Important shortcomings in Turkey's business environment are the politicisation of regulatory bodies and the judicial system; cronyism and corruption; mismatches between education and labour market needs; and widespread tax evasion.
Turkey--highlights: Economic outlook
  2017 2018 2019 2020 2021 2022

3-month Treasury rate (av; %) 12.8 19.5 18.5 12.0 10.6 10.0
Exchange rate TL:US$ (av) 3.6 5.2 6.1 5.6 5.8 6.0
A heavily pro-growth approach to economic policymaking will remain a predominant feature of Turkish policymaking, at the expense of inflation control and fiscal discipline. Real GDP growth accelerated sharply in 2017, to 7.3% (from 3.3% in 2016), supported by government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit, improved export competitiveness and a pick-up in global demand. We believe that growth will decelerate to 3.1% in 2018 and to only 1% in 2019, owing to the impact of the recent currency crisis. In 2018 the lira's collapse and rising global commodity prices will drive inflation to an annual average of 15.5%. In 2019 inflationary pressures will moderate owing to a modest appreciation of the lira against the US dollar, declining global oil prices and the appearance of spare capacity.
Turkey--highlights: Demographic outlook
Population (m) 2012 2017 2022
Total 74.6 80.7 85.0
 Male 36.7 39.8 41.9

Period averages (%)   2013-17 2018-22
Population growth   1.6 1.0

Labour force growth   3.9 2.2
The total population is projected to rise from an estimated 80.7m in 2017 to 85m in 2022, with the female population continuing to far outnumber the male population. The total population is expected to grow by about 1% per year during the forecast period, compared with 1.6% during the historical period (2013-17). The pace of population growth has slowed in recent decades, mostly owing to the declining birth rate, which in turn reflects the combined impact on fertility rates of higher urbanisation rates, an improvement in the education level of women and wider use of birth control measures. Nevertheless, population growth remains high by European standards.
Turkey--highlights: Market opportunities
  2017 2018 2019 2020 2021 2022

Household consumption per head (US$) 6,210 5,110 4,920 5,960 6,350 6,860
The large consumer market is one of Turkey's chief attractions as a place to do business. The population is young, growing and inclined to consume rather than save, and average incomes are rising steadily in local currency terms. In 2017 GDP per head was US$10,503 at market exchange rates and US$27,100 at purchasing power parity (PPP) rates. We expect Turkey's GDP per head to be about US$32,700 at PPP exchange rates in 2022. At this level, GDP per head in Turkey will be about 66% of the EU28 average from 65% in 2017.
Turkey--highlights: Long-term outlook
  2018-30 2031-50 2018-50
Growth and productivity (% change; annual av)
Growth of real GDP per head 2.9 2.3 2.6
Growth of real GDP 3.7 2.7 3.1
Labour productivity growth 2.4 2.3 2.3
In the long term Turkey's economic growth performance is expected to be above that of other emerging markets such as Brazil, Russia and China. In 2018-50 we expect Turkey to grow by an annual average of 3.1%. Brazil is expected to grow by an annual average of 2.1%, Russia by 1.6% and China by 2.8%. GDP growth will nevertheless be well below that recorded in 2004-07 and 2010-15. Average growth in GDP per head will be substantially lower, mainly reflecting the expected rise in the total population. Income levels will remain well below the EU28 average, but catch-up is likely to continue. As a result, Turkey will remain an attractive market for international companies throughout 2018-50.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West. The country became a member of the Council of Europe (in 1949) and NATO (in 1952), and signed an association agreement with the then European Community (in 1963). A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but the coup attempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey currently has a presidential system of government, with parliament elected for a five-year term. To win seats, parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Since the failed coup, power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president and leader of the AKP, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who was re-elected as president for a second term in June 2018. Following his re-election a presidential system of government was introduced and the post of prime minister was abolished.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability and stabilising the lira following the currency crisis that took place in August 2018 are Turkey's biggest policy challenges. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and tightening global liquidity conditions require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy tight to attract adequate capital inflows and slow down the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar. The Kurdish issue, which has blocked economic development in the south east, is one of Turkey's most pressing policy challenges, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015, and there has been a resurgence in violence. Politicisation of the judiciary since the coup attempt has undermined its independence. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The corporation tax rate has been raised in 2018, from 20% to 22%. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Reducing tax evasion was one of the elements of previous IMF programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2017 goods exports came to US$166bn and imports to US$225bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$59bn and a current account deficit of US$47bn (or 5.6% of GDP). The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
On July 24th 2017 Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the incumbent president, and his political party, the Justice and Development Party (AKP), respectively won the presidential and parliamentary elections. The AKP, a moderately conservative Islamic party, together with its coalition partner, the right-wing Nationalist Action Party (MHP), hold a majority in parliament. Mr Erdogan, who became Turkey's first directly elected president in August 2014, has dominated the political scene since the 2002 general election. Under his leadership the AKP that he co-founded in 2001 comfortably won the general elections in 2002, 2007 and 2011. This was largely because of the relative economic stability that the AKP delivered, but Mr Erdogan's personal appeal was instrumental, as was his religious and conservative outlook, which is shared by much of the electorate.
The Republican People's Party (CHP), a social democratic party, remains the main opposition party in parliament. In recent years, as democracy has backslidden, the party has taken an active yet often ineffective stance in defence of the rule of law and the independence of the judiciary. Its manifesto for the 2018 election argued that the current "one-man rule regime" was the main reason behind the country's economic woes. It thus proposed an end to the state of emergency (now expired) and the re-instatement of the independence of all regulatory and supervisory bodies to boost foreign investors' confidence and ensure future investment inflows.
In the June elections the pro-Kurdish, left-wing People's Democratic Party (HDP), managed to cross the threshold of 10% of the votes to enter parliament despite Mr Erdogan's repeated attempts to delegitimise and weaken the movement. The government has accused the HDP of having links with the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), a militant pro-Kurdish group. The fourth party to surpass the 10% threshold was the Good Party (IP). This right-wing nationalist party was formed by dissident members of the MHP in late 2017. Its leader, Meral Aksener, and her colleagues broke away from the MHP following intense conflict with MHP leadership over the MHP's continued alignment with Mr Erdogan and his policies.

Political outlook: Political stability
In June Mr Erdogan was re-elected as president for a second term in the first round of a snap presidential election. On the same day Mr Erdogan's conservative AKP secured a parliamentary coalition majority with its right-wing ally, the MHP. The election process appeared mostly free, but largely unfair. Opposition candidates received little or no media coverage; the candidate of the pro-Kurdish HDP, Selahattin Demirtas, had to campaign from prison; and the government restrained freedom of speech and freedom of association. Nonetheless, Mr Erdogan secured a majority of the vote on a high turnout. In addition, results published by opposition observers almost mirrored those announced by the government.
Mr Erdogan's re-election concludes Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. This move was initiated with a constitutional referendum in April 2017, which the government narrowly won. The new system grants the president wide-ranging executive powers-including in the selection of most of the officials in the judiciary-and will greatly weaken parliament. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the AKP and Mr Erdogan, who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in July 2016, to remain in power until 2023, and possibly beyond.
Mr Erdogan will continue to clamp down on domestic political dissent and opposition. Despite allowing the state of emergency to expire on July 18th, parliament passed a security law on July 25th that imposes stringent impediments on freedoms, similar to those of the state of emergency. The state of emergency was introduced after the attempted coup to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric who is accused by the Turkish government of masterminding the coup.
The operational capacity problems created by the purge of the Turkish Armed Forces (TSK) and the police after the attempted coup appear to have eased, but security risk remains high. Turkey is vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the PKK and Islamic State (IS). Neither the government nor the PKK is interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will return to 1990s levels. Turkey's military operations in Syria seek to block the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds affiliated with the PKK but risk fuelling the conflict with the PKK in south-east Turkey. The formation of a governing coalition between the AKP and the MHP will have a detrimental effect on attempts to resolve the Kurdish issue, as the MHP is likely to push for hawkish policies aimed at constraining and delegitimising the HDP. In addition, the MHP will advocate repatriation of Syrian refugees and adopt a tough stance on all issues related to national security, in line with Mr Erdogan's ultra-nationalist and conservative views.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
For much of the AKP's 15 years of single-party rule, political and government effectiveness improved. The economy has been well managed, and significant social reforms have been implemented. However, in recent years intensifying domestic power struggles, a resurgence of violence since mid-2015 and a failed coup attempt in July 2016 have delayed reforms. The increased concentration of power under Mr Erdogan and his party's control of parliament suggest that the efficiency of policymaking will increase. However, policy predictability and its long-term suitability, especially in the view of foreign investors, are likely to deteriorate.
In response to the failed coup the government introduced emergency rule, which remained in place until July 2018 and allowed the government to carry out an extensive purge of personnel in the military, the judiciary, the police force and academic institutions suspected of having links to Mr Gulen's movement. The extent of the purge initially undermined institutional capacity, although most gaps appear to have now been plugged. The quality of the bureaucracy remains moderate, and we do not foresee substantial improvements in 2018-22. According to the World Bank's Doing Business 2018 report, starting a business requires more time, procedures and funding than in an average high-income OECD country. Paying taxes also carries a greater burden, but registering property is simpler. Relative to some of its peers, Turkey outperforms Brazil and China in these categories, but underperforms Russia. The World Economic Forum's Global Competitiveness Report 2017-18 ranks Turkey 67th of 137 countries in terms of the burden of government regulation.
Since 2013 economic policymaking institutions have become increasingly politicised-a feature that will persist in the medium term. Despite some displays of increased monetary policy independence in 2018, the Central Bank of Turkey will remain subject to pressure from Mr Erdogan's pro-growth approach to economic policymaking. Only at some points will this coincide with the central bank acting in line with its monetary policy mandate. The use of unorthodox policy instruments will thus remain highly probable.
Concerns about judicial impartiality and efficiency unlikely to be resolved
Concerns about the impartiality and efficiency of the legal system are unlikely to be resolved over the forecast period (2018-22), given the continued politicisation of the judiciary. An AKP constitutional reform package, which was approved by referendum in 2010, changed the appointment procedure and composition of the High Council of Judges and Prosecutors (HSYK) and the Constitutional Court. The changes facilitated the replacement of conservative secularist-nationalists in the judiciary with Gulenists, who, until 2013, were close allies of the AKP. Shortcomings in the judicial process were highlighted in coup plot investigations and trials that began in 2007. These were only addressed at appeal stage and after suspected Gulenists in the judiciary began investigating allegations of government corruption in late 2013. The purge of Gulenists from the judiciary accelerated after the failed coup. Their replacements will probably display strong loyalty to Mr Erdogan and the AKP. The upheaval is likely to increase uncertainty in the judicial process and prolong cases further. The courts' tendency to interpret the law in favour of the state and at the expense of the individual is unlikely to change, especially in cases involving minority rights and freedom of speech. In our business environment ranking we expect transparency and fairness of the judicial process to remain poor and that its efficiency will deteriorate over the forecast period.
Foreign businesses operating in Turkey can reduce some of the uncertainty caused by the legal process by incorporating international arbitration clauses into their contracts. These help to shorten the time that it takes to resolve commercial dis-putes and prevent, in most cases, the need for intervention by the Turkish courts.
Corruption in the public sector is seen as a major deterrent by potential international investors; legislation has been introduced to tackle it. However, implementation will continue to be a problem, and political patronage is likely to remain widespread. The public procurement law of 2003 was drafted to meet EU standards, but has since been watered down and amended so that important sectors, such as transport and energy, have been excluded. Turkey has improved compliance with the OECD's anti-bribery convention.
Political outlook: Election watch
Parliamentary and presidential elections were held on June 24th, earlier than the originally scheduled date of late 2019. Mr Erdogan was re-elected as president in the first round, securing 52.6% of the vote on a turnout of 86.2%. In the parliamentary election the AKP lost its absolute majority (although it secured a coalition majority alongside its partner, the MHP) as the HDP managed to poll more than the 10% threshold needed to enter parliament. The AKP received 42.6% of the vote, the MHP 11.1%, the CHP 22.6%, the HDP 11.7% and the IP 10%.
Local elections will be held as planned in March 2019, despite recent signals from the AKP pointing to an increasing possibility of bringing them forward to November or December. The shift of focus to the local polls in the aftermath of the June elections is a sign that Turkey will remain in election mood until next year.
Political outlook: International relations
Domestic political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign policy sphere. Although not our core forecast, there is a risk of a rupture in the country's ties with its traditional Western allies.
Many factors have contributed to the deterioration in relations, including a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the failed coup; US military backing for PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurdish groups; Turkey's crossborder operations against PKK-affiliated groups; Turkey's forging of closer relations with China, Russia and Iran; and US sanctions on Turkish government officials due to Turkey's detention of a US pastor on terrorist charges. The Turkish government's authoritarian tendencies and confrontational approach to Western allies, in part due to Mr Erdogan's need to appeal to nationalists, have also dented relations with Turkey's traditional Western allies.
The country's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic and increasingly transactional rather than strategic, but we expect Turkey and its Western allies to avoid a complete breakdown in relations. However, this might become unavoidable if the EU suspends Turkey's moribund accession negotiations, or if Turkey closes the Incirlik air base to US forces or withdraws from NATO, none of which can be ruled out.
Turkey's involvement in the conflict in Syria will continue to influence the direction of its foreign policy. Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved, but the level of trust between them is still low, particularly regarding the conflict in Syria, where they are co-operating but have been pursuing contrasting goals. We expect relations to continue to be largely transactional. The risk of new tensions emerging will remain high.

The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment score for Turkey deteriorates slightly in the forecast period (2018-22), and its global ranking falls by ten places, to 59th. Political tensions, increased powers concentrated under the president, and inadequate policy responses to tightening global liquidity conditions and higher domestic inflation have increased the level of uncertainty about the direction of economic policy. Turkey's large external imbalances leave the economy vulnerable to shifts in investor preferences. After several turbulent months, with a currency collapse in August, the authorities adopted measures to halt speculative trades in the lira, and in September the Central Bank of Turkey raised its main policy rate by 625 basis points, to 24%. Together with the slowing economy, the tighter monetary policy stance will contribute to restoring macroeconomic stability in the medium term.
Important shortcomings in Turkey's business environment are the politicisation of regulatory bodies and the judicial system; cronyism and corruption; mismatches between education and labour market needs; and widespread tax evasion. Adding to these problems, the government has used emergency powers to seize or close a large number of firms suspected of having links to the Gulenist movement, which the government believes staged a failed coup in 2016. The seized firms will be sold off, probably to government-friendly groups. Foreign companies' assets have not been seized, but the weakening of the rule of law will deter foreign investors. Turkey lags most central and east European countries for foreign direct investment (FDI).
Major attractions for investors include Turkey's geographic location, the size of the potential market, its young and growing population, a customs union with the EU, free foreign-exchange and capital flows, and a large and dynamic private sector.
