Business environment outlook: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Political instability and adverse market conditions will delay further privatisation deals. Companies seized because of their alleged ties with the Gulenist movement likely to be sold off to government-friendly groups.
2020-22: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in several sectors.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but macroeconomic instability and concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2020-22: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Capital controls are not considered despite the scope of the currency crash. Political tensions resulting in tit-for-tat tariffs and US sanctions will disrupt Turkey-US trade and relations.
2020-22: Negotiations with the EU to update the customs union are likely to be protracted given poor Turkish-EU relations.
Taxes
2018-19: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Some tax rate rises, including on company profits, are introduced in 2018 to curb the widening of the budget deficit.
2020-22: Income tax base becomes broader as exemptions and exceptions are reduced.
Financing
2018-19: Asset quality likely to deteriorate on the back of financial market turmoil in 2018. Central Bank of Turkey to lower rates gradually as inflation moderates in 2019. Risk of the US imposing fines on several Turkish banks.
2020-22: Lending growth to pick up again as banking system regains strength. Continued reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2018-19: Relatively high labour costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment.
2020-22: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2018-19: First phase of third airport in Istanbul becomes operational. Slower progress made on other projects.
2020-22: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks might persist.
Technological readiness
2018-19: Spending on research and development remains moderate at about 1% of GDP, holding back efforts to move the economy up the value-added ladder.
2020-22: Turkey's young population spurs further rapid digital transformation of the banking sector
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.1 5.8 61 67 15 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The quality of economic policymaking and its institutional underpinnings have deteriorated in recent years. Under the executive presidential system Recep Tayyip Erdogan has used his new powers to extend his control over the central bank and other nominally independent authorities, which has resulted in inadequate macroeconomic policies and a loss of foreign investor confidence in economic decision-making. A credible and consistent return to more orthodox policies is needed over the medium term to ensure stability of the macroeconomic environment and the currency. Although we expect the country's policy stance to improve relative to that seen in 2016-18, it is likely to remain deficient given Mr Erdogan's heavily pro-growth approach to economic policymaking (not least to avoid potential social discontent).
The government has increased public borrowing to support economic activity since the failed coup, resulting in a widening of the budget deficit. Turkey's public debt remains relatively low at about 30% of GDP, giving the government some scope to support the economy in the event of a sharp downturn and/or the emergence of difficulties in the banking sector. The financial system has been well capitalised and regulated owing to reforms introduced following the 2001 crisis in Turkey, but it will remain vulnerable to political interference, financial market volatility, the sharp depreciation of the currency against the US dollar and the euro in 2018, and tightening global liquidity conditions.
Volatile domestic demand, reliance on indirect taxation, limited price competition in some sectors-particularly agriculture-and the sensitivity of prices to exchange-rate and commodity-price movements will make it difficult to reduce consumer price inflation to the officially targeted 5% in the medium term. It reached almost 18% year on year in August 2018 and is expected to rise further in the short term as a result of the sharp depreciation of the lira against most currencies in July-August.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
5.8 5.5 43 54 17 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The seizure of firms since the failed coup has created uncertainty
The state retains a significant role in many sectors, there is widespread political patronage, the legal system is politicised and corruption is rife. Private property is generally well protected, and private enterprise is encouraged. However, the use of emergency powers introduced in response to the failed coup to seize or close firms suspected of having links to the Gulenist movement have created uncertainty, particularly because of limited access to legal redress. Although the state of emergency was lifted in July 2018, the security law passed in that same month and the concentration of power under Mr Erdogan will contribute to a high degree of uncertainty in the medium term.
The government supports private-sector investment and employment with incentives such as tax breaks and social security and credit subsidies, with an emphasis on underdeveloped regions, technology, small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), production of currently imported intermediary goods and "strategic" sectors such as defence, aerospace, automotive and pharmaceuticals. State lending programmes for small businesses have expanded since the failed coup as the Treasury has expanded its guarantees for banks, allowing them to lend to riskier customers. Lending capacity has now become more limited after a prolonged period of credit expansion incentivised by the credit guarantee fund, and the government is allowing Turkish banks to securitise their existing loan portfolios to clear their balance sheets and stimulate fresh lending.
Free competition is the norm in most sectors, and the Competition Board has power over mergers and acquisitions (M&A), price-fixing and abuse of market position. Like most other regulatory agencies, however, the Competition Board has limited effective independence, being appointed by the president. The public sector still plays the leading role in gas and water, rail transport, tea and sugar production, infrastructure, and social services such as healthcare and education. The state has a significant position in banking (about 30% of total assets), mining, the defence industry, postal services and legal gambling, and retains large stakes in Turk Telekom (30%) and Turkish Airlines (49%). There is a state-owned broadcaster (TRT), a state-owned home-builder (TOKI) and a state-owned oil and gas exploration company (TPAO). There are also sectors in which one or more private firms, including privatised companies, hold strong market positions.
Despite frequent legal challenges, privatisation is well advanced in numerous sectors, which include refining, petroleum products, parts of the energy sector, steel, mobile telecommunications, and tobacco and alcoholic drinks. The sale of power-distribution networks has been completed, and the government aims to continue divesting some generation assets. The pace of privatisation has slowed amid market volatility since 2014, but despite opposition from workers and farmers the government is pressing ahead with the sale of some state-owned assets in 2018.
Price controls operate for various reasons in electricity, gas, petroleum, telecoms and pharmaceuticals, and are expected to be introduced for bank charges. Competition is also inhibited by the large shadow economy; the smuggling of petroleum products, cigarettes and many other items; and the violation of intellectual property rights in many sectors, from software to fashion.
Political patronage and exclusive business networks will continue to play a significant role in business life. Companies close to government circles may be boldest in entering public tenders or operating in sectors where major decisions are taken by politicians, regulators or bureaucrats. Industrial policy may facilitate favouritism or uncompetitive arrangements. Some companies may face higher bureaucratic obstacles or tougher tax inspections than others.
State assets transferred to the Turkey Wealth Fund unlikely to be privatised
Political constraints and financial market volatility will delay planned sales of state-owned assets during the forecast period. Those assets that have been earmarked for privatisation include operating rights for more ports, the national lottery and horse racing concession, shares in toll roads and bridges, TOKI (Turkey's government backed housing agency), Vakifbank, more power plants, municipal companies in Istanbul, and some state-owned land. Control of the three main state banks-Halkbank, Ziraat and Vakif banks-looks set to remain in government hands. The state banks may sometimes be used as a source of patronage.
The establishment in August 2016 of the Turkey Wealth Fund has removed some government assets from control of the privatisation agency. The wealth fund is designed to help to finance large public works by using its assets as collateral, making sales of the assets under its control less likely. The fund now includes assets such as the state's stake in Turkish Airlines, Halkbank and Turk Telekom, as well as Ziraat Bank, Borsa Istanbul and a pipeline operator, Botas.
Build-operate-transfer (BOT) or public-private partnership (PPP) schemes will increase the role of the private sector in the management of airports, water and irrigation facilities, and hospitals. The railways are being restructured, and the rail network has been separated from train services. The state will continue to play a dominant role in the sector for some time to come, as so far only a few freight transport licences have been granted to private operators.
Despite public ownership of major assets, a more liberalised energy sector will emerge as a result of privatisation, new investments, the Electricity Market Law of March 2013 and changes in regulations that will widen consumer choice over power providers. A wholesale trading platform aimed at setting a reliable market price for electricity has been established. Gas market reform is likely to continue to lag behind that of the electricity sector.
There is scope for further improvement in the protection of intellectual property. Legislation has been gradually brought into line with EU practices. In particular, a single, unified industrial property law came into force in January 2017 that replaced a patchwork of decrees regulating trademarks, patents, designs and geographical indications. Turkish as well as foreign companies are increasingly sensitive to this issue, so there is also likely to be progress in enforcement.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.4 6.4 49 52 17 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Foreign direct investment will continue to be welcomed in most cases
Turkey's politicised judicial system, its poor record on corruption and widespread political patronage remain major deterrents for potential foreign investors. Nevertheless, the government and most sections of society regard FDI in a positive light, and high levels of foreign ownership in industry and services are widely accepted and respected. Turkey's heavy dependency on foreign-capital inflows gives the government additional incentives to attract FDI. Foreign-ownership restrictions are limited to a few areas, including broadcasting and civil aviation. The courts and sections of the public are occasionally hostile towards foreign investors when environmental issues or natural resources are at stake. A law passed in 2012 has boosted sales of property to foreigners by easing restrictions and waiving the condition of reciprocity for most countries.
Privatisation in energy and other sectors may provide opportunities for foreign investors, often in conjunction with local partners. The government will especially promote FDI in greenfield and expansion projects that can further its industrial policy goals, including import substitution and technological innovation. Low valuations as a result of the sell-off of Turkish assets in 2018 and the depreciation of the lira against most major currencies may also attract investors, particularly export-oriented firms that have receipts in US dollars.
In principle, foreign investors will continue to have the same access to government incentives as do domestic investors. Plans to improve the general investment environment by cutting red tape and streamlining the legal system will benefit foreign as well as domestic businesses. Restrictions on repatriation of profits are highly unlikely, even at times of financial market stress.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
7.8 7.8 44 47 17 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
As a member of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) with a customs union with the EU, Turkey remains committed to a broadly open trading regime. However, global trade tensions have risen since the beginning of 2018, and political tensions with Turkey's trading partners have periodically caused disruption to bilateral trade and exacerbated exchange-rate volatility. Russian restrictions following the downing of a Russian military jet on the Turkish-Syrian border in 2015 imposed severe losses on the Turkish agriculture and tourism sectors in 2016. In 2018 escalating tensions with the US have resulted in tit-for-tat sanctions and tariffs on aluminium and steel trade between the two countries.
The Turkish lira has been fully convertible since 1989, and the authorities have not considered introducing capital-account controls, even during recent periods of severe exchange-rate and financial market volatility. There are some restrictions on agricultural imports, but concerned by high food price inflation, the authorities have in recent years been reviewing the system of tariffs on agricultural products.
Under the 1996 customs union with the EU, Turkey has customs-free trade in manufactured goods with EU member states and has adopted the EU common customs tariff, but has refused to grant Greek Cypriot ships and planes access to its ports and airports unless the EU facilitates direct trade between the EU and the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus (TRNC), which is not recognised internationally except by Turkey. Turkey's import regime reflects the EU's free-trade agreements (FTAs). It has bilateral FTAs with the European Free-Trade Association (EFTA).
The government is highly unlikely to impose capital controls; it did not even consider doing so during the latest bout of severe lira volatility, in August 2018. The authorities in Turkey are keenly aware of the reputational damage that capital controls could cause, potentially impeding Turkey's access to international financial markets for several years.
The government is unlikely to resort to outright protectionism, despite its efforts to encourage domestic production of items currently imported in large quantities. However, short-term protective measures will continue to be employed to limit imports of textiles, petrochemicals and other items from lower-cost countries.
Turkey and the EU have agreed to revisit the current customs union agreement with a view to expanding it to potentially cover agricultural goods, services and public procurement, but talks have not yet started. Some EU politicians have suggested that talks should be linked to political criteria. If this were to be the case, the chances of reaching an agreement any time soon would be low. Turkey is negotiating or pursuing FTAs with several other economies, especially countries such as Mexico and Japan, which have signed FTAs with the EU in 2018.
In the absence of a Cyprus settlement, Turkey is likely to resist EU pressure to open ports and airports to Greek Cypriot ships and planes. Similarly, without progress in its EU accession negotiations, Turkey is unlikely to lift restrictions on EU meat and used-car imports, eliminate discriminatory taxes on alcoholic drinks and tobacco products, or open up trade in services.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
5.4 5.4 57 62 16 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
As a percentage of GDP, tax revenue is low by OECD standards owing to high levels of evasion and limited administrative capacity. According to OECD figures tax revenue, including social security contributions, is about 25.5% of GDP, compared with an OECD average of about 34% (2016 data). The corporate tax rate was raised from 20% to 22% in 2018 for a period of three years. Personal income tax rates range from 15% to 35%. The tax-free allowance for wage and salary earners varies from the equivalent of 50-90% of the minimum wage, according to the number of their dependants. Seventy percent of tax revenue comes from indirect taxes, including value-added tax (VAT), which is levied at a standard rate of 18% (with lower rates of 8% and 1% for some items), and special consumption taxes on some goods and services such as petroleum, alcohol, tobacco products, motor vehicles, telecoms services and banking transactions.
Obligatory social security contributions normally consist of 20.5% of gross salary (up to a certain limit) from the employer, 14% from the employee and a combined total of 3% to the Unemployment Insurance Fund from both parties. Tax breaks, social security premium reductions and incentives are available to encourage investment in underdeveloped regions, important sectors and technological innovation, as well as to support employment.
Frequent changes in tax regulation and evasion are likely to persist
Frequent changes in tax regulation are likely to persist, as will widespread tax and social security evasion, which is encouraged by frequent amnesties and opportunities to restructure arrears. The latest example was announced in May 2018, mainly to garner political support ahead of the snap presidential and parliamentary elections. Plans to simplify the tax system have been on the government agenda for some time, but have been consistently postponed.
Foreign companies will continue to be treated in the same way as Turkish companies. Turkey is expected to expand the already substantial number of double taxation agreements that it has during the forecast period.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.6 5.9 27 58 10 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Reforms introduced under the guidance of the IMF and the World Bank transformed the Turkish banking system in the wake of the financial crisis in Turkey in 2000-01. As a result, it is well regulated, well capitalised and profitable, but it has become increasingly vulnerable in recent years to political interference, financial market volatility, currency weakness, high levels of foreign-currency debt in the private sector and tightening global liquidity conditions.
The three state-controlled banks and the four largest private banks dominate the sector, accounting for about 75% of total assets. The state banks have largely operated on a commercial basis, and government intervention in the private sector has been rare. However, the government has put pressure on banks to lend more and at lower interest rates.
In May 2018 a US court sentenced Mehmet Hakan Atilla, the vice-president of Turkish state-owned Halkbank, to 32 months in prison for bank fraud and facilitating a scheme allowing Turkish and Iranian government officials to circumvent US sanctions against Iran. Although not our core scenario, the US Treasury could decide to impose sanctions against HalkBank or other Turkish entities in relation to the case. Such a decision would further raise risks for the banking sector and accelerate Turkey's efforts to sign bilateral currency swap agreements with other countries (as it did with Iran in April and Qatar in August).
The banking system is solid, but its vulnerability has increased
Bank lending growth has recorded periodic surges since 2010, driven by falling government borrowing needs, strong domestic and global liquidity, as well as government pressure and credit guarantees. In the first seven months of 2018 bank credit to the non-financial sector expanded at an average annual rate of about 23%, but we expect credit growth to decelerate substantially as the impact of the 2018 financial market turmoil negatively affects the economy and asset quality.
The pace of share offerings on the volatile Borsa Istanbul has slowed in recent years. Market capitalisation is low, at about 28% of GDP in 2017. About 66% of the free float was foreign-owned in 2017, although this figure is likely to have declined as a result of the sell-off of Turkish assets since April 2018. As at mid-September BIST 100, Turkey's benchmark share price index, was down by 18% from end-2017.
Tighter global liquidity and high levels of corporate debt will restrict credit to the private sector, especially households and small businesses. However, the strongest Turkish companies, like banks, will continue to have access to loans from foreign banks and to local and international bond markets, albeit at high interest rates by international standards.
With economic activity likely to slow sharply and debt servicing more onerous because of the weakness of the lira and higher interest rates, non-performing loans are likely to rise in the short term, albeit from a low base of 3.1% of total loans as at August 2018. Low domestic savings will remain a constraint, but changes to the private pension system will help to increase the availability of finance with longer maturities.
Changes in bank ownership may occur, particularly among smaller banks, without changing the overall structure of the sector. The current government's antipathy towards private bank owners and sympathy for consumers and credit customers will encourage tighter regulation of certain banking activities, such as credit-card issuance.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
5.9 6.0 38 40 12 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
There is a large, young labour pool, but workforce participation is only about 53%, partly owing to traditions that discourage female employment. Despite a greater number of years of formal education, the average level of education and skills remains below average European standards, and mismatches between education and the needs of the labour market persist. Employment of foreigners is exceptional, and obtaining work permits can be problematic, but some restrictions have been eased. Informal employment and subcontracting are common ways of avoiding tax, legal obligations and rigidities, and create unfair competition, undermine safety standards and hinder productivity gains. In formal employment, hours and conditions are generally regulated and inflexible.
In response to employers' complaints about high labour costs, the government has sought to lighten the burden of social security contributions, especially for underdeveloped regions and the employment of young people, women and people with disabilities. Following rises of 30% in 2016, 8% in 2017 and 14% in 2018, the monthly gross minimum wage is relatively high in Turkish lira terms (at the equivalent of US$340). However, it has fallen sharply in US dollar terms, to about US$340, as a result of the depreciation of the lira, which has also weighed on growth in real wages owing to higher inflation rates.
The change to severance pay may take several years to implement
Companies complain that the system of severance pay, under which employers are liable to pay substantial lump sums to employees who retire, or are made redundant, is too generous, hindering formal hiring. The government's plan is to establish a severance pay fund, to which employers will contribute, but the plan has met with resistance from unions. The change to severance pay may take some years to implement.
The government aims to make the labour market more flexible while improving access to unemployment benefits. We expect the use of flexible employment contracts in the formal sector to increase only slowly.
Labour market activation and education policies will raise skills levels and workforce participation only gradually. Despite the government's commitment to reducing it, unregistered employment is likely to remain a significant issue throughout the forecast period.
Restrictions on union membership, strikes and lock-outs that are incompatible with international norms promoted by the International Labour Organisation (ILO) and the EU are unlikely to be lifted. Unions may be influential in a few sectors, but are unlikely to become stronger or more militant.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
4.0 4.8 67 64 18 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Turkey's infrastructure is broadly adequate for doing business. In recent years investment by national and local governments, as well as the private sector, have led to some visible improvements, ranging from rapid growth of domestic air travel to the gradual extension of the natural gas pipeline network to almost all provinces and the spread of broadband internet access and mobile-phone services. The AKP government's preference has been for large infrastructure projects with several grandiose projects in the pipeline. The contract for the construction and subsequent operation of a 3.9-km-long suspension bridge over the Dardanelles was awarded to a three-company consortium, including Limak, one of the contractors of the airport project, in 2017. Canal Istanbul, a canal linking the Black Sea to the Sea of Marmara, and a three-tier undersea tunnel across the Bosphorus are in the process of being put out to tender.
Fixed-line broadband internet access has expanded rapidly, but, at an estimated 14.7% in 2016, the penetration rate was still well below an average of 30-40% for most other European countries. Including large and rapidly rising numbers of mobile broadband subscriptions, the penetration rate is much higher. About 80% of all mobile subscriptions are now third- (3G) and fourth-generation (4G) technology began to be offered in 2016.
Major infrastructure projects are under way, but shortcomings persist
Infrastructure shortcomings will persist in most cities including urban overcrowding, congestion, earthquake risk and strains on water supply and waste disposal systems and the energy network. Rural infrastructure should improve a little in most places. Major irrigation works, including those in the south-east, will proceed slowly.
Improvements in road and rail transport infrastructure will be piecemeal, and as a whole it will continue to lag behind EU standards, especially given the long distances between cities. Public and private investment will ensure that seaport capacity expands, despite bottlenecks and incomplete privatisation of management rights at some state-owned ports.
Energy sector privatisation and market liberalisation will continue gradually. Legislation facilitating the privatisation of lignite reserves is being implemented. Private investment (coupled with limited public investment) may be enough to increase power-generation capacity, cut transmission and distribution losses and prevent blackouts. Policies favouring energy generation from local and renewable sources will help to reduce gradually reliance on imported fuels.
We expect legislation to encourage private-sector oil and gas exploration to lead to an intensification of offshore activity in the Black Sea and the Mediterranean. The government has begun to explore the possibility of exploiting shale gas potential in the south east and other parts of Turkey. Plans to construct two nuclear plants are highly controversial, and if they are built, they will not come on stream until the early 2020s.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
5.5 6.1 50 46 17 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
This section, introduced as part of an upgrade to our rankings in 2018, aims to show how future-oriented the business environment is-the extent to which it is digitally connected, open to innovation and prepared for technological disruption. Turkey ranks joint 46th with Romania in the global rankings for technological readiness in the forecast period, but well behind Bulgaria and Russia in joint 35th place.
E-commerce is growing rapidly, reflecting steady improvements in the online environment in areas such as security and after-sales service, but growth is from a low base with online purchases accounting for only about 4% of total retail sales compared with about 10% in developed economies. As in most countries, the number of fixed-line subscriptions has declined steadily, but mobile-phone penetration has risen rapidly, reaching 95% in 2017. Intense competition in the mobile-telecoms sector should ensure that infrastructure remains adequate and up to date, although there may be delays in adopting the latest technology or it may initially be expensive or concentrated in major cities. Computer ownership has risen rapidly. According to the Turkish Statistical Institute (Turkstat), an estimated 84% of households had access to the internet in April 2018, up from about 30% a decade earlier.
In the five years to 2016 research and development (R&D) spending averaged about 0.9% of GDP-well below the EU average of 2%. However, given that nominal GDP growth averaged 14.5% in the same five-year period, R&D spending rose strongly in nominal terms, which we expect to continue. R&D spending is significantly greater than in Romania and broadly in line with that in Greece, Bulgaria, Poland and Russia (which averaged 0.9-1% of GDP over this period). As in most emerging economies, large, export-oriented private-sector firms account for the bulk of R&D spending in Turkey. The automotive sector, which is largely comprised of joint ventures between Turkish conglomerates and major global auto producers, accounted for 14% of total R&D spending in 2017.
FDI will continue to be the main driver of investment in technology and innovation. According to data from the Turkish Patent and Trademark Office, about 60% of total patent applications are foreign. As FDI into Turkey gradually recovers in our forecast period, we expect R&D spending to increase progressively.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
The government's past focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. Nonetheless, Turkey's economy has shown resilience during past bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing largely to its solid public finances, its well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector, and its dynamic, diversified private business sector.
In the aftermath of the failed coup in mid-2016 a highly accommodative policy stance has exacerbated fiscal as well as external imbalances. This, together with heightened political uncertainty, the tightening of global liquidity conditions and tensions with the US, led to a full-blown currency crisis in August 2018. The heavily pro-growth approach to economic policymaking that Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the president, has enthusiastically espoused over the past decade will remain a predominant feature of Turkish policymaking in 2018-22, at the expense of inflation control and fiscal discipline. Such an approach will continue to have an important effect on monetary policy, macroprudential regulation, public-private capital investments and social spending, among others. In addition, current shortcomings such as cronyism and corruption, labour skills mismatches (a major factor of the high unemployment rate) and tax evasion are unlikely to be addressed over the forecast period (2018-22), as propping economic growth-at all costs, partly to avoid social unrest-will remain the government's priority.
In the case of an adverse economic scenario (not The Economist Intelligence Unit's core forecast), Turkey's options will remain limited, as countries of the Gulf Co-operation Council (GCC) appear unwilling and unable to offer financial support at present (partly as Turkey is forging closer ties with Iran, a country with which Saudi Arabia is currently at odds). Meanwhile an IMF programme would include unacceptable conditionality in the government's view and run counter to Mr Erdogan's nationalist, anti-Western rhetoric. Finally, there is little prospect for financial assistance from the EU, all the more so as there would be no political consensus on this issue among EU member states. As a result, only China appears able to offer a financial lifeline to Turkey at present; such a programme could be part of China's Belt and Road Initiative, which seeks to boost transport infrastructure between Asia and Europe in order to foster trade and connectivity in the coming decades.

The public finances have traditionally been one of the most reassuring aspects of the Turkish economy. Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios reflect the positive impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past. Despite a series of tax increases this year and official promises of budgetary tightening, increased government spending on defence, security, infrastructure projects, public employment and social benefits will cause the deficit to widen in 2018, to 3.4% of GDP, from 1.5% in 2017.
We subsequently expect a cautious approach to on-balance-sheet fiscal policy, which, alongside a recovering economy, will result in a gradually contracting deficit in the second half of our forecast period, to 2% of GDP in 2022.
We expect the central government debt/GDP ratio to increase this year, to 30.2% of GDP at end-2018 (from 28.3% at end-2017), owing to the widening of the fiscal deficit. The debt/GDP ratio will then decline gradually, to 28% of GDP by the end of 2022, as macroeconomic conditions normalise and the budget deficit shrinks.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy
Interest rates
(%)
  2017 2018 2019 2020 2021 2022
3-month money market rate (av) 12.8 19.5 18.5 12.0 10.6 10.0
Deposit rate (av) 12.4 17.8 17.1 11.5 10.5 10.0
The Central Bank of Turkey will have to keep its monetary policy tight in 2018 to dampen inflationary pressures and prevent further depreciation of the lira against the US dollar amid political volatility, higher US interest rates and balance-sheet tapering by the Federal Reserve (the US central bank).
The Central Bank of Turkey raised rates by 625 basis points in September 2018, to 24%, so we do not expect further rate increase in the remainder of the year. In spite of this, if needed the central bank will be able to tighten its stance by shifting funding from the main policy rate to the late liquidity window rate that stands 300 basis points above the main rate. In 2019-20 the central bank will gradually lower its policy rate in response to declining inflationary pressures and a normalisation in financial market conditions.
In 2021-22 we believe that the central bank will not hit its inflation target of 5%. This reflects the government's continued pro-growth stance and its influence on the central bank to keep nominal rates below what would be required to credibly lower inflation to the 5% target.

Real GDP growth accelerated sharply in 2017, to 7.3% (from 3.3% in 2016), supported by government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit, improved export competitiveness and a pick-up in global demand.
However, the surge in economic growth has exacerbated existing internal and external imbalances. Coupled with heightened political and policy unpredictability, foreign investors' concerns regarding the independence of the Central Bank of Turkey, increased reliance on short-term capital inflows, a rising interest rate environment in advanced economies and a diplomatic spat with the US, rising external imbalances have contributed to the lira losing about 43% of its value so far in 2018. The depreciation of the lira, which sped up dramatically in August, has caused consumer price inflation to accelerate from already high rates, increased input costs for corporations and significantly raised the debt servicing costs of liabilities that are denominated in foreign currency. Rising domestic interest rates (the money market rate stood at 21.8% in August) and rising risk premiums further dent the economic outlook.
High-frequency indicators from August (latest available data) suggest that the economy is decelerating sharply in the wake of the currency crisis. After mild growth in the second quarter of 2018 (at 5.2% year on year, from 7.3% in 2017), we expect the economy to contract on a quarterly basis in the third and fourth quarters of 2018, as well as in the first quarter of 2019. However, there are substantial downside risks to this fairly optimistic forecast; this growth profile does not reflect the possible impact of a severe banking crisis (not our core scenario), although we expect non-performing loans (NPLs) to rise and credit availability to be impaired in the coming quarters.
We now believe that full-year growth will decelerate to 3.1% in 2018 and that GDP will grow only slightly in 2019, by 1%, mainly owing to base effects. In 2020 we expect full-year growth to rebound as the economy recovers and spare capacity is depleted. In 2021-22 economic growth will average 4%, broadly in line with the economy's forecast potential growth rate in 2021-30.

Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
As in most developing countries, the share of agriculture in nominal GDP has declined steadily in Turkey in recent decades, but at 6.8% of gross value added in 2017 agriculture remains an important sector, especially considering the input that it makes to Turkey's food, beverages and tobacco manufacturing industry. In addition, agriculture still accounts for a substantial share of about 19% of total employment, although almost half of those employed in the sector are classified as unpaid family workers. We expect the share of output of the primary sector to shrink slightly during the forecast period, but it will remain large compared with most other European countries at just over 6% of GDP in 2022. In 2016 the sector was hit by Russian sanctions on agricultural imports from Turkey, but most were lifted by mid-2017 following the rapprochement between the two countries in June 2016. The sector would benefit from investment in irrigation in the south east of the country and in some other regions, but investment is likely to remain on hold in areas affected by the conflict with the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK). More generally, the importance of modern, large-scale agricultural enterprises will spread gradually, but the problems of traditional agriculture and unclear policymaking are likely to persist.
Manufacturing will continue to play a central role in the Turkish economy
Industry, including manufacturing, mining and construction, accounted for about 32% of GDP in 2017. The collapse in investment and export demand during the 2008-09 global crisis hit the manufacturing and construction sectors hardest. Since then manufacturing, and particularly construction, has rebounded. In 2017 manufacturing accounted for about 23% of GDP, compared with about 25% at the end of the 1990s. Having fallen as low as 6.3% of GDP in 2009, the construction sector accounted for an impressive 8.6% in 2017.
Construction has been a significant driver of economic growth in recent years. In 2017 real value added in the sector, which is dominated by housing construction, expanded by 9%, following growth of about 5% in the previous three years. The pace of housing construction has outstripped demand for several years, even after allowing for strong demographically driven growth in the number of households and the continued replacement of existing buildings. In 2017 growth was bolstered by the strong expansion in credit, in turn the result of pressures by Mr Erdogan on banks to lower mortgage rates, the indirect effect of the credit guarantee fund, the relaxation of macroprudential measures and ample global international liquidity. As at mid-2018 this has resulted in a reported 1.5m-2m new homes being unoccupied, a situation that has weakened developers' finances and reduced the incentive for new investments. Infrastructure and building investments via public-private partnerships, which have picked up significantly over the past five years, have also contributed to robust construction growth. In the first half of 2018 construction output stagnated, and this weakness is likely to persist into 2019 given the oversupply of housing, the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar, high interest rates and the slowdown in economic growth.
Although several manufacturing subsectors, such as automotive, and textiles and clothing, are strongly export-oriented and will continue to generate trade surpluses, Turkey's manufactured exports are generally import intensive; that is, a large portion of the inputs, whether energy, intermediates or capital goods, are imported, adding to Turkey's external imbalances, especially when international commodity prices are high or the lira weak, as it has been since mid-2013. This structural situation is unlikely to change much during the forecast period, as reducing the import intensity of exports and moving up the value-added chain will take time, even though these were explicit goals in the government's investment-incentive system, introduced in 2012.
Vehicle production will fluctuate in line with demand in Europe
The automotive sector was Turkey's biggest exporter in 2017, with exports valued at about US$23.9bn-up from US$21.1bn in 2016,&[DEVICE CONTROL STRING]according to data from the Ministry of Customs and Trade. That year Turkey was the 14th-largest vehicle producer in the world, just behind the UK. Output rose by 14% year on year to 1.7m vehicles in 2017, according to the International Organisation of Motor Vehicle Manufacturers. This increase was mainly due to the weaker lira, which boosted export sales by 17%, according to the Automotive Manufacturers Association (OSD). Exports in the first six months of 2018 were up by 15% in US dollar terms. Almost 80% of vehicles produced in Turkey are exported, and the bulk of these go to the EU. As a result, vehicle production will fluctuate in line with demand in Europe. Demand in Europe has picked up since mid-2013, probably reflecting the release of pent-up demand after several years of weakness. Although economic growth will soften in the EU over the medium term, the recent significant depreciation of the lira against the US dollar is likely to continue to support firm export volumes. Given its location and its trade agreement with the EU, Turkey will remain an important automotive hub, but political uncertainties will weigh on investor confidence. Over the medium term, given the growth potential of the automotive market in Turkey and the wider region, manufacturers with production plants in Turkey may start to focus more on the Turkish, Middle Eastern and North African markets. The domestic market will be supported by rising incomes and replacement demand.
We believe that most manufacturers will maintain their production facilities in Turkey. These facilities are technologically advanced, and labour costs are much lower in Turkey than in core European countries, and are probably below those in most central and east European countries, where wages have risen strongly following accession to the EU. However, if Turkey is to remain a major automotive production location in the medium to long term, manufacturers will have to move away from exporting low-end passenger cars, light commercial vehicles (LCVs) and components to north European markets, and towards developing and producing alternative energy engines and vehicles. There are signs that this transition is already happening; in 2017 sales of electric and hybrid cars rose by more than 350% to 4,528 units, according to data from Turkey's Electric and Hybrid Vehicles Association. The market will be supported by recent cuts to taxes on hybrid and electric vehicles.
The textiles and clothing industries remain important activities in the Turkish economy and in 2017 accounted for 17% of the country's export revenues. The industries have undergone restructuring under the intense pressure of competition from low-cost producers in Asia. The government has also been looking at ways to improve investment incentives and target higher value-added products. In the short term, high-frequency indicators suggest that both these industries will suffer from subdued domestic demand. However, over the medium term a more competitive currency and ample growth potential will underpin robust growth prospects. Competitive pressures from lower-cost centres of production will remain a risk.
Production of industrial machinery and of white goods and other household durables, including furniture, recovered strongly as a result of a pick-up in domestic demand and export opportunities in 2010-11. After more moderate domestic and external demand dampened growth in output in 2012-16, growth surged in 2017 alongside the boom in housing and credit. We expect Turkish consumer electronics companies to continue to be major exporters, although domestic demand will constrain the sector in the near-term. Businesses in the sector appear to have been slow to adopt technological innovations in some segments.
If security concerns diminish, growth potential in tourism is good
Tourism, one of the most important services sectors of the Turkish economy, has witnessed rapid growth in the past ten years, but it remains vulnerable to geopolitical developments and changes in the exchange rate. Having reached a new record of 37m in 2014, the number of foreign visitors (excluding Turkish citizens living abroad) dipped slightly in 2015, reflecting mainly the impact of EU/US trade sanctions on the Russian economy (visitors from Russia, Turkey's second-largest tourist market, fell by 18.5%) and perceived security concerns following a spate of terrorist attacks in the second half of the year. In 2016 tourism was hit hard by Russian sanctions, which have now been lifted, and by terrorist attacks. Ministry of Culture and Tourism figures put the total number of foreign visitor arrivals in 2016 at 25.4m, a year-on-year fall of 30%. In 2017 the number of foreign visitors increased by 27.8% to 32.4m as visitors from Russia rose to 4.7m, from just 866,000 in 2016 (when bilateral relations hit a low point and Russia imposed sanctions on Turkey), exceeding the level in 2015. Visitors from other European countries remained unchanged from 2016 levels, however, when the number plummeted by 31.1% to 13.2m, from 19.1m in 2015. In the first half of 2018 foreign visitor numbers have continued to surge, including from countries such as Germany and the UK, suggesting that security concerns are no longer deterring visitors from those key markets. The pronounced depreciation of the lira will contribute to robust growth in tourism inflows in the coming quarters.

Prior to the lira's crash in 2018, inflation was already stubbornly high and well above the central bank's official 5% medium-term target; it averaged 11.1% in 2017. In 2018 the lira's collapse and rising global commodity prices have driven inflation higher, to 17.9% year on year in August. The pass-through of past lira depreciation and higher inflation expectations will keep inflation elevated through the remainder of 2018, to an annual average of 15.5%. In 2019 we expect inflationary pressures to moderate on the back of a modest appreciation of the lira against the US dollar, declining global oil prices and the appearance of spare capacity. We forecast inflation of 14.5% in that year.
The moderating trend in inflation will continue in 2020, with an average inflation rate of 8.3%, as global commodity prices drop owing to a slowdown in the US business cycle and the exchange rate remains broadly stable in nominal terms against the US dollar. Thereafter, in the final two years of our forecast period, we expect inflation to stabilise at an average of 7%-still above the central bank's medium-term target. Although economic growth in these years will be close to the economy's potential growth rate (limiting upward inflationary pressures), an expected pick-up in global oil prices and a depreciation of the lira will maintain upward pressure on prices.

In 2017 the lira depreciated by an average of 18% against the US dollar. In 2018 we expect an average depreciation of about 30% (in nominal terms). Our baseline scenario is that the lira is likely to depreciate slightly against the US dollar in the remainder of the year, but that no further major currency collapse will take place. This short-term forecast is underpinned by the real GDP contraction on a quarterly basis in the second half of 2018 and the first quarter of 2019, and its effects on medium-term inflation expectations, which will gradually decline.
In 2019, as inflation moderates and the economy rebounds, we expect the currency to appreciate and the exchange rate to reach TL5.6:US$ by the end of the year. We expect most of the appreciation to happen by early 2020, and as nominal interest rates are lowered the exchange rate will stabilise at about TL5.6:US$1. In 2021-22 relatively high inflation rates as well as a suboptimal policy and political environment will keep the lira on a depreciating path. We forecast that the lira will reach TL5.99:US$1 by the end of 2022.

The current-account deficit as a share of GDP will narrow in 2018, to 5.2% of GDP, from 5.6% of GDP in 2017, owing to the weaker currency and slower average economic growth. We have equally revised our medium-term forecast in all years and now expect a smaller average current-account deficit of 3.3% of GDP per year in 2019-22, compared with our previous forecast of 4.7% of GDP. Significant gains in competitiveness from past lira depreciation (even with the appreciation of the lira in 2019), moderating inflation and the emergence of spare capacity will result in a boost to exports and in import compression over the medium term.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Turkey
Stocks and flows
Foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows rose dramatically in 2005-08, to 2.9% of GDP, after averaging a modest 0.5% of GDP between 1990 and 2004. In the context of the global economic and financial crisis, they slowed again in 2009-10 and have remained below the average level of 3.2% of GDP reached in 2006-08. Inflows of FDI, including sales of real estate to non-residents, declined to about US$13.4bn, or 1.5% of GDP, per year in 2012-14, before picking up to about US$18bn, or 2% of GDP, in 2015. In 2016-17 FDI inflows fell to an average of US$12.1bn, or 1.4% of GDP. With FDI inflows amounting to just US$4.9 in the first half of 2018, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the full-year figure to be slightly below that in 2017. Similarly, in 2019 we expect FDI inflows to be subdued owing to high economic and policy uncertainty. In 2020-22 we expect a gradual recovery in inflows as the economy strengthens and some delayed privatisations get under way. The stock of inward FDI stood at just 21.3% of GDP in 2017. Following a fall from US$4.1bn in 2012 to US$3.6bn in 2013, Turkish outward FDI jumped to US$7bn in 2014, largely reflecting a small number of large transactions, notably the acquisition of the UK-based United Biscuits by Yildiz Holding, a Turkish conglomerate of food manufacturers. The figure has gradually eased, falling to US$2.7bn in 2017, presumably given the high domestic funding needs and divestment by foreign firms due to greater economic and policy uncertainty. We expect outflows to remain subdued in 2018-19 and to pick up only thereafter, although to levels below those of 2012-15.
Origin and distribution
The traditional sources of foreign capital in Turkey have been multinational companies based in major EU countries, especially the Netherlands, Germany, the UK and France, and in other OECD countries such as the US, Switzerland and Japan. Individual large investments from several smaller EU countries, the United Arab Emirates (UAE), Saudi Arabia, Russia, Kazakhstan, Azerbaijan and Brazil have amended this pattern in recent years, and there have also been some significant purchases by private equity funds. A majority of foreign investment appears to go to Istanbul, the main Turkish city where most national Turkish companies have their headquarters. Investment projects of foreign capital companies are overwhelmingly concentrated in the Marmara region (which includes Istanbul), the Aegean region, the Mediterranean and Ankara, the capital. Historically, manufacturing (particularly the chemicals, food and automotive industries) and financial services attracted the most FDI. In 2012 construction figured prominently, with about 13% of net FDI inflows, although this was the result of the inclusion in this category of a single investment by the French-based Aéroports de Paris, which bought a 38% stake in Turkey's airport operator; TAV Airports; and a 49% stake in its construction arm, TAV Construction. In 2015 the share of FDI of financial services rose sharply, to 30% of the total, from about 17% in the previous year; this again reflected the impact of a single large investment in which a Spanish bank, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria (BBVA), increased its stake in Garanti Bank. Chemicals and pharmaceuticals was the second-largest category in 2015, accounting for 15% of total FDI inflows. Problems in developed economies, and the euro zone crisis in particular, together with the more recent deterioration in economic prospects in Turkey, has led to divestments by foreign financial institutions, many of which entered the Turkish market in 2005-08. As part of a plan to shore up its capital base, the National Bank of Greece has sold its 99.8% stake in Finans Bank, but because the sale, which was completed in mid-2016, was to Qatar National Bank, it did not affect net inward FDI figures in 2016. In 2017 OMV, an Austrian energy group, sold off its 100% stake in Petrol Ofisi, a Turkish petrol retailer.
Foreign property purchases, which are included in balance-of-payments statistics for FDI, have been making a solid contribution to net inflows since 2005. In 2005-13 net inflows averaged a solid US$2.5bn per year, before picking up to an average of US$4.3bn in 2014-17. In view of the excess supply and the deteriorating economic outlook, real estate inflows are likely to decline in 2018-19.
Determinants
Foreign investment is mostly motivated by the size and potential of the Turkish market, but also increasingly because it offers access to neighbouring markets. The sharp rise in FDI in 2005-07 was partly driven by favourable global financial conditions, which have since evaporated. However, the upsurge was also made possible by the conjunction of several country-specific factors. The 2001 financial crisis led to a new drive for reform and privatisation, and reforms in sectors such as energy, telecommunications and banking began to take hold. The Justice and Development Party (AKP), in power since 2002, was more willing than its predecessors to sell majority stakes in state-owned companies to foreigners, even in sectors previously considered "strategic". The economy was relatively stable and grew strongly, and EU accession talks, which were expected to lead to further reform of the business environment, got under way. The private sector was also more willing to seek foreign partners than in the past. This may have reflected the thinking of a new generation of management, strategies of specialisation in certain sectors, a desire to raise capital for privatisation bids, fear of increasing foreign competition, lost appetite for bank ownership and temptingly high company valuations. From 2008, although the government remained willing to privatise, market conditions deteriorated, resulting in less interest from foreign investors. Since 2013 potential deterrents have multiplied: less buoyant economic growth, mass anti-government protests, financial market volatility, government corruption allegations, the spillover of violence from the conflict in Syria, the collapse of the peace negotiations with the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), an attempted military coup in July 2016 and the shift to a presidential system of government. Other significant structural deterrents, which vary by the sector, size and type of investment, include regulatory uncertainty, a slow and unpredictable judicial system, weak intellectual property (IP) protection and unfair competition from smuggled goods and the informal sector.
Impact
The FDI stock as a percentage of GDP is relatively low when compared with other emerging markets such as Brazil or Russia. However, FDI has accumulated over many decades, and the outlook compared with several central and east European countries has improved. Several leading multinationals, such as Unilever and Ford, have had a long-standing presence in Turkey, and companies with foreign partners play a significant role in the economy, helping to spread modern management and business practice. In the automotive industry, foreign investment has ensured expansion, technology transfer and access to global markets, although some lament the lack of national technology or a national trademark and the focus on production of low-end vehicles. By contrast, much recent FDI has taken the form of acquisitions of existing assets in domestically oriented sectors, and has therefore had a limited direct impact on fixed investment or exports. Foreign ownership of banks has not demonstrably improved either access to international funds or services and productivity, which were already advanced, and nor have fears been realised that foreign-owned banks may attach a greater risk premium than local banks to lending to the Turkish government or Turkish companies. The arrival of Vodafone has gradually helped to increase competition and investment in telecoms, where Turkcell and Turk Telekom are dominant players. From a macroeconomic perspective, Turkey has relied on capital inflows, including FDI, to cover its large external financing requirement. In the years prior to the 2008-09 crisis, a growing share of FDI in capital inflows comforted the financial markets by reducing the vulnerability of the lira to trends in short-term capital inflows. After having declined in recent years, we expect the ratio to improve during the forecast period.
Potential
Our baseline forecast is that, assuming security and policy concerns are addressed during the forecast period, there will be a moderate pick-up driven by further privatisation and other crossborder mergers and acquisitions, as well as foreign interest in residential and commercial property, following the easing of restrictions on foreign ownership of real estate in 2012. Although the surge in foreign acquisitions in telecoms and banking of 2006-07 is unrepeatable, private corporations in many sectors may still be open to foreign investment, and several major assets remain to be privatised. We assume that the government will make further progress in creating conditions for private-sector investment in infrastructure. The energy sector in particular has the potential to attract large amounts of foreign investment. Existing investors are likely to increase their investment through further acquisitions or projects, and some greenfield investment may take place. Subdued income growth may dampen foreign investors' earlier interest in retailing, but they may also become more active in other services, such as tourism, as well as in mining and agriculture. Investors from Asia may play a larger role, in addition to Western multinationals and funds.

Population growth remains high by European standards
Turkey is the third-largest country by population in Europe, after Russia and Germany. Official population figures have been compiled using an address-based registry since 2009. These figures are lower than previous estimates from door-to-door censuses, but are believed to be more reliable. The total population is projected to rise from an estimated 80.7m in 2017 to 85m in 2022, with the female population continuing to outnumber that of males. The total population is expected to grow by about 1% per year during the forecast period (2018-22), compared with 1.6% during the historical period (2013-17). The pace of population growth has slowed in recent decades, mostly owing to the declining birth rate, which in turn reflects the combined impact on fertility rates of urbanisation, an improvement in the education level of women and wider use of birth control. Nevertheless, population growth remains high by European standards.
From an average of 17.3 births per 1,000 inhabitants in 2013-17, the crude birth rate is expected to fall to an average of 15.8 per 1,000 in 2018-22. The infant mortality rate will continue to decline, but will remain high compared with European countries, as the national average is pulled up by the south-eastern and eastern regions, as well as by rural areas. The crude death rate will remain broadly unchanged, at an average of 5.9 per 1,000 population in 2018-22.
Although ageing, the Turkish population is young in a European context, and will remain so throughout the forecast period. In 2017 those aged 14 and under were estimated to comprise 25% of the population, and the 65-plus age group accounted for just 8.2%. In 2022 the share of under-15s will still be high, at about 23.1% of the population, and the over-65s are expected to account for 9.4%.
The urban population, which is currently estimated at 74.4%, will rise further as rural families, insufficiently supported by agriculture, continue to seek better living standards in towns and cities. The drift of population from smaller and poorer urban settlements to larger and richer ones will also continue. As a result, all major cities in the west and south (including Ankara) will continue to grow rapidly. Although earthquake-prone, Istanbul and its surrounding area is likely to become the largest conurbation in Europe-the population was already 15m at end-2017, up from about 11m at end-2007. Other cities and towns to witness particularly strong population growth include prosperous industrial centres like Bursa and Konya, and Antalya, on the Mediterranean coast.
The population of the mostly Kurdish-inhabited south east, which accounts for about 10% of the total population, has increased steadily, despite strong outward migration. The still-high natural population growth rate in the region will contribute to the rapid expansion of the populations of cities like Gaziantep, Sanliurfa and Diyarbakir. By contrast, the populations of many rural areas in northern, eastern and central Turkey will dwindle. Even some of the larger urban centres in these poorer and more remote regions could lose population as birth rates slow and migration westwards and southwards continues. Some western and southern areas that are still classed as rural may maintain their populations as a result of intensive agriculture, tourism and/or proximity to major cities. This may also be true of lowland parts of the south east benefiting from irrigation schemes.
Participation rates will remain well below the OECD average
Despite solid growth in the working-age population, Turkey has the lowest labour force participation rate of any OECD country. According to the Turkish Statistical Institute (Turkstat), it averaged 52.8% in 2017 (72.5% for men, and just over 33.5% for women) compared with an OECD average rate of more than 70%. Participation rates in urban areas are lower than in rural areas, reflecting that rural women are typically classified as "unpaid family workers" and are, therefore, counted as workforce participants and employed persons. Low workforce participation rates among urban women probably reflect inadequate job opportunities and the persistence of traditional gender roles. This situation is changing slowly, as illustrated by a gradual rise in recent years in the urban female participation rate. However, the rate is expected to remain low by European standards throughout the forecast period.

The large consumer market is one of Turkey's chief attractions as a place to do business. The population is young, growing and inclined to consume rather than save, and average incomes are rising steadily in local currency terms. In 2017 GDP per head was US$10,503 at market exchange rates and US$27,100 at purchasing power parity (PPP) rates. Relative to other emerging markets, these figures are broadly in line with those of Russia and well above those of Brazil and China. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Turkey's GDP per head to be about US$32,700 at PPP exchange rates in 2022. At this level, GDP per head in Turkey will be about 66% of the EU28 average, up from 65% in 2017.
Overall spending power will rise, but income distribution will remain uneven
Income distribution is uneven by European standards. According to the official 2016 (latest available) survey of incomes and living conditions, members of the highest-earning 20% of households accounted for 47.2% of total income, up from 45.9% in 2014, and the members of the lowest-earning 20% of households for 6.2%, in line with the 2014 figure. Geographical factors contributed to the discrepancies. In general, the regions with the highest and most rapidly growing concentrations of population were also the wealthiest regions-except in the south east, where spending power is low. According to the Turkish Statistical Institute (Turkstat), greater Istanbul, which accounts for about one-fifth of the population, represents about one-quarter of household consumption expenditure. By contrast, the statistical region of south-east Anatolia, with about 10% of the population, generated only about 6% of household consumption. Income and consumer expenditure also vary widely between urban and rural areas, and within cities. These patterns are unlikely to change significantly in the forecast period (2018-22).
The household will remain the main consumption unit during the forecast period. Households typically consist of an average 3.4 people, and more than 90% of households are made up of married couples. Although these patterns will change only gradually, the number of households will tend to increase faster than the population, underpinning medium-term demand for housing construction and household durables, including basics like furniture, washing machines and refrigerators.
A large majority of Turkish consumers aspire to "Western style" consumer society, in so far as their incomes permit, although local factors affect lifestyle aspirations. Much of the population adheres to Islamic prohibitions, including on consumption of alcohol. The country has wide variations in geography and climate, which affect diet, leisure activities and demand for certain goods. Choices of entertainment vary between groups with different education levels.

Young population will encourage new products and services
The proportion of total household spending allocated to food, beverages and tobacco is high and not expected to fall much during the forecast period. Housing and household fuel, goods and services will also remain major expenditure items. The wealthiest households, which enjoy standards of living close to those of west Europeans, spend significant amounts on entertainment, education and catering, as well as on transport, because of the high cost of running a car. These households will remain an important target market for environment-friendly and wellness products and services, which are relatively new. Other population segments are starting to provide additional demand for items that have been the prerogative of upper-income groups. Rising car ownership will continue to encourage supermarket shopping, residence in suburban areas and related lifestyle trends. Demand for branded fashion items, fast food, air conditioning and holidays is also spreading. That half of the population is under the age of 30 will encourage the introduction of new products and services in communications, information and entertainment technology. Tourists constitute a significant addition to the consumer market. About 50m, including foreigners and non-resident Turks, visited Turkey in 2014 and 2015. This figure fell to a still sizeable 39m in 2016 (mainly owing to the sharp drop in Russian tourists due to tensions between the two countries in 2015-16), but picked up to 47m in 2017 and is set to continue growing.

Long-term outlook: The long-term outlook
