Initial conditions: Some of the obstacles to solid and stable growth were removed in the decade to 2010, but in recent years the government has focused on domestic power struggles and the foreign policy challenges arising from turmoil in the wider region, putting economic reforms designed to boost investment and employment on hold. Given the deterioration of Turkey's institutions of governance and the likelihood that the current domestic political tensions will continue for some time, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects only limited progress on reforms in the near term, damaging Turkey's longer-term growth potential. For similar reasons, we do not expect Turkey's EU membership bid to make significant progress, making accession a remote prospect. A relatively low level of skills and quality of the workforce compared with Turkey's main competitors for foreign direct investment (FDI) in central and eastern Europe will continue to act as a deterrent to FDI, although Turkey will enjoy substantially more favourable demographics.
Working-age population growth turns negative in 2040
Demographic trends: On current projections, Turkey will have the second-largest national population in Europe, after Russia, by 2050; and unlike in most European economies Turkey's working-age population will continue to grow up to the early 2040s. Nevertheless, Turkey's positive demographic dynamic is expected to start deteriorating from about 2030. In 2031-50 the difference between growth in the working-age population and that of the total population will become negative, which will dampen economic growth. This trend could be delayed if the bulk of 3.1m Syrian refugees currently being hosted in Turkey are integrated into the population.
Throughout the long-term forecast period, we expect an upward trend in the labour force and employment because of rises in participation rates, given the low starting levels. With the workforce continuing to expand at a steady rate, it will be a challenge to produce sufficient jobs to lower the unemployment rate substantially from an annual average of 10.5% in 2018-22.
External conditions: International developments-particularly in international financial markets, the EU (Turkey's main export market) and in global terms of trade-will continue to affect Turkey's long-term economic performance. With export-led industries playing an increasing role in growth, Turkey would benefit from greater global trade liberalisation, but the process of liberalisation is faltering and trade flows have slowed. As a supplier of the developed economies, Turkey will continue to face intense international competition, as low and medium value-added manufactured goods are likely to remain its main product lines. Its technology potential is relatively limited, and the country is not well placed to become a major supplier of services other than tourism and, to a lesser extent, construction, although improvements in (and diversification of) the domestic financial sector over the past decade may enable Turkey to develop as a provider of banking and insurance services in the wider region. Because of completed and planned pipeline construction, Turkey is expected to become a major energy hub between Russia, the Caspian region and western Europe. As Turkey shares borders with countries like Iran, Syria and Iraq, its immediate regional environment is challenging, in particular from a security perspective.
The EU's problems will dampen Turkey's interest in membership
We do not expect Turkey to join the EU, and there is a high probability that the accession negotiations may even be abandoned by one or both sides during the long-term forecast period. Given the limited progress so far in Turkey's EU accession negotiations, the strength of public opposition in most EU member states to Turkish membership and the economic and political challenges still facing the EU, we believe that Turkey's commitment to the goal of full EU membership will diminish even further. This increases the risk that government commitment to political and economic reform will weaken further. Harmonisation of Turkey's domestic legislation with EU norms is significantly more important for Turkey's long-term economic stability than actual membership. If the EU were to loosen its structure-the UK's vote to leave the EU could prompt such a move-opposition in the EU to Turkish accession might ease, increasing Turkey's chances of joining. However, this is not our core scenario.
Institutions and policy trends: Recep Tayyip Erdogan's victory in Turkey's first direct election of the president in August 2014, the approval of his presidential reform plan in a referendum in April 2017 and the presidential election of 2018 have shifted the political system from a parliamentary to a presidential system. The shift carries major implications for the country's future institutional and policy-setting framework. The constitutional reform allows Mr Erdogan to run for president for two five-year terms, which means that he is likely to be in power until 2028. Beyond that, assuming that the constitution is not amended further to allow him to run for a third term, which cannot be ruled out, the issue of his succession as leader of the AKP and president of the country could become a source of instability during the long-term forecast period.
The broadly positive management of the economy by the AKP since coming to power in 2002 has been one of the main reasons for its electoral successes. However, there is a considerable risk that economic policy will be increasingly tailored to political purposes rather than to maintain macroeconomic stability and further improvement of the business environment. Nevertheless, Turkey's public finances are structurally sounder following a decade of IMF-backed reforms in 1999-2008, which may allow the government more room to increase public investment in infrastructure and possibly to reduce tax rates further, if solid economic growth is sustained. Given the little progress that we expect to be made in Turkey's EU accession negotiations, the problems of unpredictability and inefficiency in Turkey's domestic legal and regulatory environment are expected to continue beyond 2022. Legislation is likely to remain under the scrutiny of the EU and other international bodies, such as the IMF, the World Bank, the Council of Europe and the European Court of Human Rights, although Mr Erdogan's assertive and increasingly personalised approach to foreign relations is likely to limit their influence over the direction of policies.
The government's peace negotiations with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed following the June 2015 election, and neither the PKK nor Mr Erdogan has shown any indication that they are willing to revive it any time soon. If the situation continues on its current trajectory, there is a real risk that the PKK and its affiliates will spread the conflict from the predominantly Kurdish-inhabited south east of the country to Turkey's main cities in central and western regions, where the Kurdish population has grown rapidly in recent years. The mounting death toll will probably encourage Mr Erdogan to resort to increasingly authoritarian means to retain control.
Long-term performance: Turkey's economic growth performance is expected to exceed that of other emerging markets such as Brazil, Russia and China as a result of its more favourable demographic profile alongside large productivity increases. However, at an average of 3.1% a year in 2018-50, real GDP growth will be well below that recorded in 2004-07 and 2010-15. Average growth in GDP per head will be substantially lower, reflecting the expected rise in the total population. Income levels will remain well below the EU28 average, but catch-up is likely to continue. Improvements in the policy environment could produce substantially better results, but the changes in the political environment have created significant downside risks that the necessary reforms are not implemented.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
Global land and ocean temperatures have been rising briskly since the 1980s, a trend that is widely attributed to growing greenhouse gas emissions from expanding human activity and population. In the coming decades the eastern Mediterranean and the Middle East region will be particularly vulnerable to the effects of climate change. The Energy, Environment and Water Research Centre (EEWRC) of the Cyprus Institute, a non-profit research institute, expects average temperatures in the broad region to increase by 3-5°C by 2050. This is a sharp acceleration in atmospheric warming compared with a 1-2°C rise in average temperatures from 1892 to 2010. This rise in average temperatures implies a higher number of extremely hot days in the summer period, as well as higher minimum temperatures that will lead to greater electricity consumption and a heavier burden on health services due to temperature-related illnesses and parasitic diseases that thrive in warmer climates.
Precipitation in the eastern Mediterranean has been declining steadily over the past decades and is expected to continue falling, raising the probability of extremely dry spells of weather. From 1998 to 2012 the eastern Mediterranean Levant (Cyprus, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Palestine, Syria and Turkey) experienced the worst drought in 900 years. In Turkey, in 2007 this resulted in water restrictions being imposed in Ankara, the capital, with some residents losing access for up to ten days. It also resulted in Turkey's agricultural output contracting by nearly 7% year on year and the government having to provide grants to affected farmers to compensate for the losses. In the future limited average rainfall is likely to be accompanied by torrential precipitation such as that in the first half of 2018, with devastating consequences for infrastructure and agricultural output.
The Turkish government has recently taken some steps to mitigate the weakness posed by the country's geographical location. In 2010 the government established a national climate change strategy that includes improved disaster mitigation plans and improved efficiency in water management. Specifically, a substantial number of damns have been built, and efforts have been made to improve some of the highly inefficient irrigation and water supply systems. Although such measures may help to mitigate the effects of climate change, they may also create foreign policy challenges. The construction of several damns along the Tigris and the Euphrates rivers, which feed water into Iraq and Syria, has the potential to increase significantly tensions with these neighbouring countries.
Technological development
The integration of advanced technologies in Turkey's economy is proceeding at a fast pace, yet from a relatively low base. E-commerce, computer ownership and internet access have increased rapidly in the past decade. Yet despite this progress Turkey remains far behind the technological frontier. According to The Economist Intelligence Unit's Business Environment Rankings, Turkey ranks joint 46th with Romania in the global rankings for technological readiness. According to the 2017-18 World Economic Forum Global Competitiveness Report 2017-18, Turkey ranks 53rd in technological adoption (including in categories such as availability of latest technologies) and 68th in the use of information and communications technology (this includes criteria such as the percentage of internet users).
Across sectors, large, export-oriented private-sector firms tend to be the most technologically intensive. Firms in the automotive sector, usually structured as joint partnerships between Turkish conglomerates and major global auto producers, are a major driver of research and development (R&D) expenditure. Ford Otosan, the joint venture of Ford, a car manufacturer, in Turkey has become a global hub for Ford's commercial vehicle development and output. In 2015 the company opened a US$25m R&D unit-Turkey's largest, employing about 1,500 engineers. Oyak-Renault, a joint venture between Renault, a French car manufacturer, and Oyak, the Turkish armed forces pension fund, won government financial support worth US$100m to support hybrid investments at its Bursa plant.
Turkey's technological prospects are unclear. The country has a young, dynamic labour pool, but Turkey's education system is inadequate at providing the skills demanded by employers. In fact, this is regularly one of businesses' top complaints. In addition, in recent years many of Turkey's most educated young people have emigrated abroad; this will make attracting top foreign talent and further foreign direct investment (FDI) more difficult.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
Global data
OECD growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP growth and components: Turkstat
Population: UN Population data base and Economist Intelligence Unit interpolation
Consumer prices: IMF, IFS; Turkstat
Industrial production: derived from OECD, Main Economic Indicators
Exchange rates and interest rates: IMF, IFS

Central government financial balance: IMF, IFS; Turkish Treasury

Abbreviations

IMF: International Monetary Fund

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2013-17) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2018-22). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2013-17. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2018-22 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2013-17 ranges are then used to derive 2018-22 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2018-22, not to the likely situation in 2022 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2015 or 2020). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Note. WCF (World commodity forecasts) is an index of 22 hard and soft commodities. FFB (Food, feedstuffs and beverages) is a price index of 13 soft commodities. The beverages sector has a weight of 20% in the FFB index, grains 46.4%, oilseeds 28.6% and sugar 4.9%. The FFB index has a weight of 55.6% in the WCF index.
Agricultural prices will show a faster than expected recovery in 2018
The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that its food, feedstuffs and beverages (FFB) price index will rise by 4.4% in 2018, halting a seven-year decline. This is an upward revision from our previous forecast of 3.1% growth, primarily owing to adverse weather conditions affecting wheat production in several countries, as well as rising trade tensions between the US and China. The bilateral trade war has disrupted existing trade patterns and caused the prices of some products that are subject to tariffs, including soybeans and soymeal, to diverge in various markets. A number of other markets, including grains such as rice, are also beginning to tighten slightly, which will support sustained price growth. Nonetheless, supplies in most markets remain comfortable by historical standards; several crops registered record harvests in 2016/17, including wheat and soybeans, and large carryover stocks will limit the potential for price growth in 2018. The downside risks related to expectations of a La Niña weather phenomenon appear to have largely passed. We expect the FFB index to rise again in 2019, by 1.7%, as some markets tighten further, causing prices for goods such as coffee and maize to recover. Overall, we expect rising populations and incomes to continue to support modest growth in demand (and therefore prices) in the FFB sector in the medium and long term.
FFB prices will rise again in 2019, and risks to the forecast remain mixed
Nonetheless, the road ahead will be bumpy. Agricultural markets have been well supplied for several consecutive seasons, providing ample stocks to draw on. We expect global GDP growth to remain fairly robust at an average of 2.9% per year in 2018-19, roughly on a par with 2017. However, uncertainty surrounding tightening monetary policy in major developed markets, including the US, the risk of a disorderly economic slowdown in China (which is not our core forecast) and the impact of increasingly protectionist trade policies espoused by the US president, Donald Trump, continue to pose risks to our forecast. In addition, exchange-rate trends may help to keep a lid on global commodity prices. Since April the US dollar has rallied strongly against other major currencies, and we expect the dollar (in which most raw materials are traded) to continue to remain fairly strong against most emerging-market currencies in 2018-19-especially as the sharp depreciation of the Turkish lira in recent weeks sparks concerns over potential contagion in other emerging markets. This will weigh on import demand in many emerging markets and encourage exporters to increase output, further contributing to global supplies.
Grain prices will register strong gains in 2018
We forecast that grain prices will rise by 15.7% in 2018. Maize prices rose by about 10% on average in February in response to worries about drought and rapidly shrinking production prospects in Argentina. However, as other crops come to the market and carryover supplies from the bumper 2016/17 crop remain available, we expect full-year maize price growth to average 8% per year in 2018-19. For wheat, adverse weather conditions are affecting yields across the world, changing the supply outlook significantly. As global demand growth remains strong, we expect the market to register a deficit in 2017/18. Overall, we expect wheat prices to surge ahead by 18% year on year in 2018 (from 12.6% previously) and by a further 3% in 2019 (from a decline of 0.8% previously).
Oilseed prices will fall in 2018-19
Oilseed prices fell by 1.6% in 2017, largely owing to the bumper soybean crop in major producers such as the US and Brazil. Despite strong global demand, this has driven global soybean stockpiles higher. We expect soybean prices to decline by an average of 5.2% per year in 2018-19. China's imposition in July of a 25% tariff on soybean imports from the US has created the potential for greater price volatility; for now, however, we expect China to source imports from other suppliers, avoiding a sharp increase in prices. Sunflowerseed oil prices are likely to remain fairly flat in 2018-19, reflecting comfortable supplies. Palm oil prices, however, are forecast to weaken as global output surges and changing consumer habits result in lower demand growth-particularly in developed economies, where health concerns have caused consumers to opt for alternative products.
A forecast recovery in coffee prices in 2019 will lift the beverages sub-index
We expect the beverages sub-index, which includes coffee, cocoa and tea, to fall again in 2018, for the sixth consecutive year. We forecast cocoa prices to rise by 16.2% in 2018, before declining by 9.1% in 2019; however, this will do little to erase the massive drop in 2017 of nearly 30%, which was caused by soaring global production and fairly weak demand growth. Global coffee prices (arabica) are forecast to fall by 10.5% in 2018 on the back of higher than expected production from Central America as well as the comparative strength of the US dollar, which will encourage exporters to sell their stocks. In 2019 we expect prices of higher-value arabica coffee beans to rebound by 10.8%, as several consecutive years of market deficits begin to erode global supplies.
Sugar prices will recover in 2019
Sugar prices declined by 11.3% in 2017, reflecting a market correction after a price spike in late 2016 related to fears that supply from Thailand would be heavily affected by poor weather conditions. We now expect sugar prices to fall by 21.8% in 2018, as crop-friendly weather conditions in key producer markets are fuelling expectations of a larger global sugar surplus than we had previously anticipated. Policy moves to restrict import dependence in key consumers (notably China, India and the EU) have weakened market sentiment further. However, we expect supplies to begin to tighten in 2019 as higher ethanol prices encourage farmers to divert more cane to ethanol (rather than to its rival, sugar). This should support growth in global sugar prices of nearly 8.3% year on year in 2019.

Enlarge this image.
Cocoa
Demand
Data from the International Cocoa Organisation (ICCO) show that global cocoa consumption rose by 2.4% in the 2016/17 season, following two consecutive years of decline in consumption. Although cocoa consumption in the world's largest consumers (mainly developed economies, as well as some large markets in the developing world) is now positive after contracting in 2015/16, consumption growth is weak in many of these countries, at less than 1%. By contrast, cocoa consumption growth will prove stronger in other, smaller cocoa consumers, which will drive growth in global cocoa consumption. This group of "other" countries now accounts for over 31% of world cocoa consumption, up from less than 25% in 2005/06. By region, Asia accounts for much of this increase, although rising demand in the Americas and Europe has also contributed. Assuming that this trend continues, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects continued moderate growth in global cocoa consumption, averaging 1.5% per year in 2017/18 and 2018/19. Consumption in major developed markets will be weaker, as already high per-capita consumption levels will prevent faster demand growth. Other factors precluding more rapid growth in global cocoa demand include retail prices, which may rise in response to the increase in global cocoa prices in recent months, potentially pushing some consumers towards non-chocolate confectionery. Meanwhile, the size of many chocolate bars has shrunk-partly in response to consumer concerns about obesity, but also to protect profits against a background of rising cocoa prices in previous years-which will also hamper consumption growth.
Balancing demand between cocoa powder and butter will be challenging
Asian countries will see slightly faster growth in cocoa demand than the global average, as these markets are far less saturated and GDP growth will remain higher than in developed economies. Stronger demand in Asia will have implications for global demand for cocoa butter (used in richer products, such as chocolate confectionery) and cocoa powder (used to add chocolate flavour to products such as biscuits, cakes and drinks). The demand balance between cocoa powder and butter is both delicate and cyclical. We expect demand for cocoa butter to remain strong in the short term, but it will not outstrip demand for powder indefinitely. Given that Asia accounted for 27% of the world's imports of cocoa powder in 2016/17, compared with just 11% of global imports of cocoa butter, firmer consumption growth in that market is likely to lift demand for powder.
Consumption growth will remain fairly low in more saturated markets
We forecast modest but positive growth in demand for cocoa in developed markets in 2017/18-2018/19. Health concerns, market saturation and changing retail habits will constrain demand (the rise of internet grocery shopping is eroding spur-of-the-moment in-store chocolate purchases). However, rising demand for dark chocolate-which has a higher cocoa content than milk chocolate and is perceived to be healthier-will support overall consumption. Consumers in the US (the largest cocoa-consuming country, which accounts for 18% of global demand) and in European countries, which collectively account for 46% of global demand, are showing an increasing preference for premium chocolate with a higher cocoa content, but with less frequent purchases.
Cocoa consumption growth will remain firm in Asia
China and India have huge potential for further expansion in cocoa demand, given currently low per-head consumption levels of just 35 g in India and 62 g in China in 2016/17, compared with 2-6 kg in developed markets. However, demand will be hampered by high retail prices. Chinese demand will continue to rise firmly, at a rate of around 5.2% per year in 2017/18-2018/19 on the back of a relatively firm GDP growth forecast. In India, we expect demand growth to pick up from 1.3% in 2016/17 to an annual average of 2.6% per year during the forecast period.

Supply
Data from the ICCO show that global cocoa production surged by 18.7% in 2016/17, reflecting improved weather conditions after a particularly difficult El Niño weather event and a severe harmattan season (a dry winter wind blowing from the Sahara) had cut African cocoa output in 2015/16 in many of the continent's main producers. We expect cocoa production to fall by 6.9% in 2017/18 and by 2.6% in 2018/19, reflecting a projected drop in production in Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana, respectively the world's largest and second-largest cocoa producers. Although output in both countries will remain high by historical standards, lower farm-gate prices, weaker confidence among growers and adverse weather conditions-in 2017/18 at least-will drag down cocoa output. Notwithstanding a rise in prices in 2018, the previous long-running period of weak prices is likely to have dissuaded farmers from investing in fertiliser and pesticides, raising the incidence of crop disease and contributing to the broader decline in global cocoa production.
Structural and geographical factors will hamper long-term supply
Longer-term structural problems will also constrain supply. Not only have farm-gate prices in several large producing countries begun to fall in line with lower market prices for cocoa, but farmers are also getting a much smaller share of the final retail price than in previous decades owing to higher costs further down the supply chain. In West Africa, for example, many farmers remain below the poverty line, and as a result few young people are choosing to work in the cocoa sector. Governments are trying to lift farmers' incomes to attract new workers, but it is uncertain how effective this will be in the long term.
Geographical considerations will also hamper the diversification of production. Cocoa can only be grown in certain regions (three-quarters of world production comes from regions that are located within eight degrees of the equator) under warm and humid conditions. Cocoa production is therefore likely to remain concentrated among a small group of countries, limiting the scope for strong and sustained output growth. Periodically, there is speculation that climate change will hamper production in these countries to such an extent that cocoa production will plummet. However, we believe that some countries have significant potential to expand production, mainly in Latin America, where high-quality cocoa is produced. The expansion of grinding facilities in producing countries may also encourage new investment to lift output.
Côte d'Ivoire's production is set to drop in 2017/18 and 2018/19
In Côte d'Ivoire, cocoa production jumped by nearly 28% in 2016/17 to a record of just over 2m tonnes. This record is unlikely to be maintained, with cocoa output expected to fall by 7.4% year on year in 2017/18. The projected decline is larger than the year-to-date fall in port arrivals (the amount of cocoa arriving at ports to be exported fell by 3% between October 2017 and mid-July 2018). This reflects the fact that output from the mid-year-crop that is currently being harvested is likely to be significantly lower than last year's production; the mid-year-crop in 2016/17 yielded 520,000 tonnes of cocoa, while this year's production is only likely to reach 400,000 tonnes as a result of the recent dry weather.
We expect production to fall again in 2018/19, by a more modest 3.7%, reflecting a relatively unsupportive domestic policy backdrop. Not only has the state-run cocoa authority, the Conseil du Café-Cacao (CCC), issued fewer export licences, but plans to accelerate the replacement of old crops infected by swollen shoot virus (which cuts yields) with new crops over the course of the next three years will hamper production. In addition, the CCC has kept farm-gate prices on hold for the 2017/18 harvest, with price levels around one-third lower than in the previous year. This has discouraged the use of fertiliser and pesticides, with the incidence of crop disease rising as a result. Even if farm-gate prices were raised-which is unlikely now that global cocoa prices are falling-it is doubtful whether this would come soon enough to impact output trends for the 2018/19 harvest. A stabilisation fund is supposed to protect farmers' revenue from price volatility, but the amounts have been insufficient, and given the lack of transparency over the financial reserves held by the CCC, neither farmers nor exporters are confident that losses arising from low global prices in 2016/17 will be recouped.
Ghanaian production is set to decline in both 2017/18 and 2018/19
Similar production trends are evident in Ghana. Cocoa production rebounded firmly in 2016/17, lifted by favourable weather and a mild harmattan season to 970,000 tonnes (well above the official target of 800,000 tonnes). However, adverse weather and a difficult policy backdrop are hampering production prospects for 2017/18. The cocoa authority, Cocobod, is encountering financial problems that are likely to affect the amount paid to farmers and in turn depress output. Cocobod was forced to seek a bridging loan from Bank of Ghana (the central bank) last year, and following the recent depletion of a stabilisation fund and indications that it may take on more debt this year, Cocobod has announced that it is considering amending the way in which farmers are paid. This is likely to involve the removal of a scheme that pays subsidies to farmers (guaranteeing a minimum income level). The authorities are instead considering a scheme in which farmers are paid 70% of the cocoa export price, which would expose incomes to considerable market volatility.
Given anxiety among farmers about the government's intentions to prioritise other crops over cocoa, the ongoing encroachment by gold miners, the government's decision to stop providing free fertiliser and the fact that around one-fifth of trees are affected by swollen shoot disease, production is forecast to fall by 17.5% in 2017/18 and by 2.5% in 2018/19. In light of a recent statement by the authorities that output could be as low as 700,000 tonnes in 2017/18 (implying a drop of nearly 28%), risks to our forecast are to the downside.
In the longer term, the New Patriotic Party government plans to rehabilitate cocoa farms, cutting down trees that are over 30 years old and replanting them while providing financial compensation to farmers until the trees start yielding fruit (generally 3-5 years). The authorities aim ultimately to raise production significantly, with Cocobod recently indicating that they are targeting output of 1m tonnes within the next five years (an apparent downgrade from previous statements of a target of 1.5m tonnes within four years), driven by better soil management, pest and disease control and improved irrigation. These plans are positive, since Ghana has a large share of unproductive trees (estimated at 40% by Cocobod) and consequently a low average yield per hectare (at 400 kg/ha, compared with 600 kg/ha in Côte d'Ivoire and 1 tonne/ha in Indonesia). However, it will be difficult to secure the necessary funding. We think it is unlikely that these ambitious plans will come to fruition, since the weak macroeconomic backdrop is likely to hamper public investment and external creditors are unlikely to fund the project.
Cameroon's and Nigeria's production targets will prove overambitious
After recovering to 246,000 tonnes in 2016/17, Cameroon's production is forecast to weaken during 2018-19. Cuts in farm-gate prices will be a disincentive to farmers, meaning that the government will remain significantly off track from its 2020 production target of 600,000 tonnes-a level that even the national Cocoa Development Corporation has described as "unrealistic and unattainable". Ongoing political unrest in the south-west of the country, which produces around half of Cameroon's output, will also drag down national cocoa production, as rising numbers of farmers are reported to have fled their plantations in the wake of violent clashes between separatists and the security forces. Plans to increase the harvested area by 100,000 ha each year are highly unlikely to materialise in this context. We expect production to fall by 9.3% in 2017/18 and by a further 3.6% in 2018/19, representing a downgrade from our previous forecast of declines of 8.5% and 1.3%, respectively.
Cocoa production has slumped in Nigeria in recent years as government initiatives meant to support farmers-including efforts to introduce high-yielding cocoa and to increase the distribution of free seedlings-have not been successful. The authorities have been seeking investment to raise cocoa production, thus diversifying and expanding sources of foreign-exchange earnings beyond the mainstay of oil, with the Ministry of Agriculture recently stating that it believes Nigeria can boost cocoa production above the levels recorded in Côte d'Ivoire. Its short-term goal is to lift cocoa production to 300,000-320,000 tonnes in 2017/18, with the medium-term target of raising output to 1m tonnes/year. However, investment has been slow to materialise, and reports of the dieback fungal disease in the south-west of the country-affecting trees that account for 10% of national output-will hamper production in 2017/18. This will be partly offset by favourable weather in recent months, which reportedly boosted production in the April-June mid-crop. On balance, we envisage a 1.2% increase in cocoa output in 2017/18, but structural problems with weak infrastructure, corruption, poor and expensive access to financing along with weak implementation remain unaddressed and are likely to prompt a 2.4% decline in production in 2018/19.
Production is set to recover slowly in Indonesia
Indonesia is one of the few major cocoa producers that are likely to see output rising firmly during the forecast period. Adverse weather hampered both the 2015/16 and the 2016/17 harvest, with cocoa output registering its third consecutive annual decline in 2016/17. Assuming more stable weather conditions, cocoa output should resume growth, but at a forecast 320,000 tonnes in 2018/19 it will remain weak by historical standards. The authorities have ambitious plans to triple cocoa output by 2020, from 325,000 tonnes in 2014/15, but these targets are unlikely to materialise. Indonesian firms will probably rely increasingly on imported processed cocoa from nearby Malaysia to meet domestic demand.
Strong potential for growth in Latin America will not be realised in 2018-19
The agricultural sectors of Latin America's two largest cocoa producers, Brazil and Ecuador, were affected by El Niño in 2015/16, but with better weather conditions they rebounded firmly in 2016/17. Structurally, there is scope for both countries to lift output as manufacturers look to develop production centres outside West Africa. The region's reputation for producing high-quality cocoa will help in this respect, given rising global demand for premium chocolate. However, some of this investment will be slow to materialise, which will hold back recent output growth.

Stocks and prices
We expect the surplus in the global cocoa market to narrow sharply, from 612,000 tonnes in 2016/17 to 50,000 tonnes by 2018/19. Although production is forecast to fall steadily, the fact that it will do so from such a high base (output was exceptionally strong in 2016/17) means that we continue to forecast a market surplus, despite signs of firmer demand growth. Stocks are forecast to reach around 2m tonnes at the end of the 2018/19 season. Although this is high by historical standards, the relatively gloomy production outlook is likely to bolster prices.

Ample global cocoa supplies will put downward pressure on prices in 2019
Cocoa prices traded at comparatively low levels between February 2017 and February 2018, mainly in the range of US$1,950/tonne and US$2,050/tonne. However, prices rose sharply in March-May, to US$2,600-2,700/tonne, on the back of gloomy prospects for production in Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana. Better weather conditions subsequently led to a reduction in prices to an average of around US$2,370/tonne in July, with futures prices also edging downwards (trading at just under US$2,300/tonne in late July). Although we forecast a gradual moderation in prices, we expect average quarterly prices to remain above US$2,300/tonne for the remainder of the year. Our full-year average price forecast, at US$2,358/tonne, implies a 16.2% year-on-year increase. However, we then expect prices to fall back by 9% in 2018, to an average of US$2,145/tonne.

Coffee
Demand
Global coffee consumption expanded by around 2.5% on average in 2015/16 and 2016/17 (October-September crop years), largely boosted by rising consumption in coffee-importing countries-mainly developed economies-which account for two-thirds of global demand. Indeed, data for coffee consumption in the EU and US in 2016/17 indicate that these regions accounted for over 70% of the global increase in consumption during that crop year. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects growth in global coffee demand to accelerate to 3.8% in 2017/18, marking the strongest pace of growth since 2011/12, aided by stronger underlying economic conditions in many of the large consuming markets, before easing to 2.8% in 2018/19.
Notwithstanding a likely acceleration in monetary policy tightening in some of the large coffee consumers, overall domestic demand is expected to remain firm, supporting coffee consumption. In coffee-exporting countries, many of which are emerging markets, consumption growth will be lower, averaging 2.5% per year. Tepid demand growth in Brazil, which currently accounts for around 40% of exporting countries' consumption owing to the sheer size of its domestic market, is the main factor contributing to weak overall growth in coffee consumption among coffee exporters. Consumption growth will be strongest in Asia-notably China, whose economy will continue to grow firmly. However, per-capita coffee consumption levels are low in China, so even as domestic demand rises quickly, this will contribute only modestly to global growth (China will account for only 3% of the total global rise in coffee production in 2017/18-2018/19).
Coffee habits are shifting around the world
Consumption trends will change in both the home and out-of-home sectors. In the latter, the expansion of coffee-shop chains will continue, providing a boost to demand, particularly in North America (with 46% of coffee in the US now consumed out of the home) and Europe (which saw the number of coffee shops rise by 6.4% in 2017), but store formats will evolve. Increasing demand for "on the go" beverages will result in larger numbers of smaller shops, including within petrol stations and supermarkets, as well as the spread of coffee delivery services by large chains. In some markets-including the US and China-large coffee chains are increasingly moving towards prepayment through smartphone apps, allowing customers to pick up their purchases without having to queue. These technological developments are likely to help the out-of-home sector to defend its market share at a time when a large number of consumers have single-serve coffee-capsule machines at home. This will be accompanied by the heavy marketing of other coffee beverages, including iced coffee and cold brew. Although accounting for only a small share of the out-of-home segment, sales of these products are likely to grow rapidly.
Single-serve coffee will help to drive growth in developed markets
Demand for coffee at home that rivals the quality of beverages found in cafes will result in a shift away from the consumption of instant coffee. On a global level, coffee-pod sales are approaching the total combined value of instant and ground coffee, although the higher cost of pods means that in volume terms the instant- and ground-coffee market remains larger. Despite the sharp slowdown in sales of machines and capsules after initial firm growth, the coffee-pod market will continue to provide important support for overall demand of arabica coffee (most pods contain predominantly arabica beans).
Coffee consumption growth in North America will increase steadily
We expect US coffee consumption growth to accelerate from 4.2% in 2016/17 to an average of 4.4% per year in 2017/18-2018/19. Aside from solid underlying economic growth, data from the US National Coffee Association show that the percentage of people drinking coffee is rising rapidly (up from 57% in early 2016 to 62% in early 2017, according to the latest data). Daily consumption is rising, and consumers are increasingly attracted to a variety of products; for example, US consumption of cold coffee products has risen by 75% over 2015-17. Moreover, the number of coffee shops is increasing at a rate of around 3.6% per year, while the share of 13-18-year-olds drinking coffee has gone up from 23% in 2014 to 37% in early 2017. Demand growth among 18-24-year-olds is also rising strongly, suggesting that the recent firm growth in coffee consumption is likely to continue in the medium to long term.
Similar dynamics are evident in Canada, with the share of 18-24-year-olds drinking coffee jumping from 48% in 2015 to 58% in 2016 (up from just 32% in 2009). Younger consumers, in particular, are showing a much stronger preference for speciality coffees and for drinking coffee in out-of-home locations. We expect Canada's demand growth, which has been fairly steady at around 2.5% in recent years, to pick up slightly, to an average of 2.7% in 2017/18-2018/19.
Coffee consumption in Brazil is expected to recover
Brazil is the world's second-largest coffee consumer, but consumption levels per head are still modest (at around one-third of those in most European countries), so there is scope for a significant increase in demand. However, a sharp economic recession in 2015-17 caused coffee consumption to remain fairly flat in recent years, after firm growth in 2005-15. We expect coffee consumption growth to recover in 2017/18-2018/19, but at a fairly moderate pace of 1.2% per year on average. Although the local coffee processing association, ABIC, is projecting coffee consumption growth of 3.6% in 2018 as economic growth is recovering, household consumption will remain constrained by high unemployment and rising fuel prices, which will all act as a drag on disposable income.
Continued coffee consumption growth is forecast in Japan and South Korea
Japan is the largest coffee market in Asia, with coffee boasting around the same share of the beverages market as tea. After rising by 1.5% in 2016/17, we expect coffee consumption to growth to rise by an average of 1.1% per year in 2017/18-2018/19. The slower pace of growth will reflect slightly weaker underlying economic conditions after a comparatively rapid pace of economic growth in 2017, as well as a fall in the number of coffee shops. Meanwhile, in South Korea the coffee market has expanded rapidly in recent years, with imports more than trebling in the past decade and the number of coffee shops increasing even faster. We expect the pace of growth to remain firm by global standards, at an annual average of 3.1%.
China consumption and production data
Until recently we have not included China in our list of top coffee consumers and producers, instead including it in our list of "others". This reflects the fact that the International Coffee Organisation (ICO) does not report China's coffee consumption and production, complicating direct data comparisons with other consuming and producing countries. Widespread acknowledgment of China emerging as a major player in the coffee market has prompted us to amend our tables to include figures for China. However, a lack of historical data series means that these figures should be regarded as estimates.
Consumption
We have based the historical series of our coffee consumption data on a paper written by the ICO, in which it estimates consumption based on production, export and import figures. It provides data to 2013/14, with annual consumption calculated from domestic production plus net exports. From 2013/14 onwards we have estimated coffee consumption based on growth in private consumption to provide a rough guide to the size of the Chinese coffee market. According to these calculations, China is the sixth-largest coffee consumer among coffee-exporting countries, but at 2.4m bags in 2016/17 its market is significantly smaller than those of many coffee-importing countries. By comparison, Chinese coffee consumption remains lower than consumption in the UK, despite huge disparities in population size.
Production
We have used data from the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO), which are current until 2016/17. This series indicates that coffee production rose sharply between 2008/09 and 2013/14, more than trebling, but output has since stabilised at around 1.9m bags. This makes China the world's tenth-largest coffee producer.

Demand in China and India will continue to grow
Coffee demand in China and India, which have similar levels of consumption, will continue to grow, aided by still-firm economic growth in both countries, which will lift disposable incomes. Although GDP growth is likely to be stronger in India, we expect coffee consumption growth in China to be much firmer. This reflects the fact that the middle class has expanded much more rapidly in China than in India, where disposable income levels for the most part remain extremely low. The emergence of a coffee-shop culture in urban centres is a key factor contributing to the rise in coffee consumption in China, aided by a rapid expansion of international coffee chains. Starbucks now runs 3,200 outlets in 139 Chinese cities, up from 2,300 in October 2017. Of these, around 600 are in Shanghai alone-Starbucks' largest presence in a single city. A new store which opened in the city last December, the Shanghai Reserve Roastery, is the company's highest-earning branch worldwide. Despite signs of weaker sales growth in China amid growing competition, the company is still planning to have 6,000 stores open by the end of 2022. With the out-of-home sector expanding much less rapidly in India, coffee consumption will grow more slowly. We forecast average growth of 2.2% per year in 2017/18-2018/19.
South-east Asia also has relatively low levels of coffee consumption per head, but demand is increasing rapidly in some countries, mainly in coffee-producing economies such as Indonesia and Vietnam. Rising incomes are encouraging companies such as Starbucks to expand in Indonesia and the Philippines, where consumption is increasing. Costa Coffee is expanding in Thailand, Singapore and Cambodia and opened its first store in Vietnam last October.
Asian markets will drive demand for robusta beans
Given taste preferences for soluble and instant coffee (which generally use the robusta variety) in faster-growing Asian markets, demand will be stronger for robusta beans than for the more expensive arabica blends. Improved quality of robusta will also play a part here, with such beans slowly losing their reputation for inferior taste. In addition, improvements in processing technology mean that it is possible to use a larger proportion of robusta in coffee blends while maintaining quality.
Supply
After rising by 3.7% in the 2016/17 crop year, reflecting firm output growth in Brazil, the world's largest producer, overall coffee production is forecast to drop by 0.9% in 2017/18. This mainly reflects a forecast decline in Brazilian pro-duction as the biennial crop alternates between higher- and lower-producing years (2017/18 is an "off-season" crop year), but production is also set to fall in several other main producers, including Indonesia and Colombia. However, this will be partially offset by rising output in Mexico and Central America, as well as in Africa. The recent La Niña weather phenomenon (a severe episode that can disrupt coffee output by bringing heavy rains to many of Asia's coffee producers and drought to the main Latin American growers) appears to have ended after a short-lived and mild episode, removing the risk of a sharper drop in coffee production in 2017/18. Global production growth is forecast to be much stronger in 2018/19, at 5.8%, as Brazil shifts to an "on-season" year.
Annual coffee production in Brazil is expected to remain well over 50m bags
In Brazil, production is likely to fall in 2017/18 as the crop rotates to an off-season year. Nonetheless, prospects are fairly strong, and we forecast only a modest decline of 5.5%, to 52m bags. This is higher than projections from Conab, the government's crop supply agency, but official forecasts usually prove conservative. Our forecast remains similar to local private-sector expectations and to that of the US Department of Agriculture (USDA). Although adverse weather in mid-2016-including drought in some areas and irregular rainfall in others-raised concerns that beans might be damaged ahead of the harvest, the weather has improved in the meantime, and both the quality and the quantity of beans have been good. Moreover, the still-weak local currency continues to provide an incentive to growers. Problems at some ports have hampered export capacity, but this is unlikely to have a major impact on overall supply.
Output projections for the 2018/19 crop year remain speculative. Although some arabica-producing areas reported dryness earlier in 2018-delaying harvest progress-recent weather conditions have improved. Local observers have stated that there is potential for a bumper crop in 2018/19, with some even suggesting that output of up to 65m bags is possible, which would be a record high by some margin (to date, the highest production was recorded in 2012/13, at 55.4m bags). We believe that this figure is out of reach and are forecasting coffee production of 58.5m bags for the 2018/19 season. This is above Conab's forecast of 58m bags and the 57.1m bags projected by the government statistics agency, but below the recently published projection by the USDA of 60.2m bags. The strong result is likely to reflect a firm recovery in both arabica and robusta production (which are expected to account for three-quarters and one-quarter of total output, respectively).
Coffee production in Vietnam is set to recover from a severe drought
In Vietnam, the worst drought in three decades hampered production in 2016/17, with output dropping by 11.1%. However, weather conditions stabilised for the 2017/18 crop, which should support a 9.6% increase in coffee production, based on firm export data. This reflects an upgrade from our previous forecast of 8.5%, reflecting strong export volume growth of 10% year on year in the first three quarters of 2017/18. We then expect growth to moderate to 1.1% in the 2018/19 season. The authorities remain pessimistic about the medium-term prospects for production, forecasting coffee output to stabilise or decline slightly. However, recent weather conditions have been supportive, indicating the potential for further production growth in 2018/19. In addition, government efforts to replant 140,000 ha of coffee, targeting 25,000 ha a year, as well as a rising arabica crop will support firmer output, particularly given that yields from new bushes are typically higher. Firm demand for robusta in the domestic market and other Asian countries will also encourage growers.
Output from Mexico and Central America will continue to rise in 2017/18
Coffee production rebounded strongly in Mexico and Central America in 2016/17, rising by 19.6% year on year to 19.6m bags. This was in the wake of a severe outbreak of coffee rust followed by an El Niño weather phenomenon, which had damaged plantations in the three previous seasons. Rising coffee output in most of the rest of the sub-region will contribute to a continued rise in output in 2017/18, at a forecast rate of 3.7%. Recent purchases of fungicides and fertiliser will also provide support. We expect coffee production in the sub-region to fall by 1% in 2018/19, mainly reflecting a fall in output in Honduras as well as stagnant output in some other countries, including Guatemala owing to a volcanic eruption in the south-west of the country in early June, which is believed to have wiped out 1% of the country's coffee plantations.
Colombian production is set to fall in 2017/18 but recover in 2018/19
Coffee production in Colombia has risen steadily in recent years, reaching a 24-year high of 14.6m bags in 2016/17. Prospects for 2017/18 are weaker. Cloudy weather conditions affected flowering on coffee bushes early in the season, which was followed more recently by very wet weather, prompting a 2.6% fall in coffee production in October 2017-June 2018. We are forecasting a 2.3% drop in coffee production in the full 2017/18 crop year. However, the sector's fundamentals are strong, including a comparatively high percentage of rust-resistant bushes. In addition, recent additional planting in existing plantations has focused on improving yields, which at 18 bags/ha in 2016 were much lower than in other large growers (27 bags/ha in Brazil and 35 bags/ha in Vietnam). As a result we expect production to recover in 2018/19, with output growing by 2.8% that season to 14.7m bags. In the medium term the 2016 peace agreement between the government and the then FARC rebels will allow coffee cultivation to expand in previously isolated areas of the country (the government has said that output could reach 20m bags by 2020 as a result).
Coffee production is likely to remain weak in Indonesia
Indonesia's ambitious expansion plans for the coffee sector, which include more than doubling production within five years to make the country the world's second-largest producer after Brazil, have been completely derailed. El Niño brought excessive dry weather to the main coffee-growing areas, affecting the 2016/17 harvest, when output fell by 6.7%. With recent export data indicating that production has dropped sharply so far in 2017/18, we expect output to fall by 15.6% during the full crop year. Even assuming a 9.3% increase in 2018/19, at just 10.6m bags output will remain low by historical standards. Low average yields-at only around one-fifth of the levels of Vietnam-reflect high levels of structural inefficiency in the sector, which we do not expect to be tackled during the forecast period.

Production prospects in Africa, which accounts for around 11% of total global coffee output, are relatively bright. Many of the continent's coffee producers have very low levels of output; together, Ethiopia and Uganda account for 70% of African coffee output. Production rose solidly in both countries in 2016/17, mainly on the back of better weather conditions. Although a fall in robusta production in Uganda is likely to drag down overall production in 2017/18, we expect output to bounce back strongly in 2018/19, reflecting an extensive reseeding programme in recent years, an expansion of the coffee-growing area and domestic efforts to streamline the organisation of the sector. Production is forecast to rise by an annual average of 2.1% in Ethiopia, to 7.6m bags, but this will remain well below the government's extremely ambitious target of 11.7m bags.
Stocks and prices
After rising marginally in 2016/17, we expect global coffee stocks to fall in 2017/18-2018/19 as a market deficit offsets continued sales of stocks, with producers taking advantage of relatively weak local currencies against the US dollar. By end-2018/19 we expect global stocks to have fallen to 26.2m bags (from 33.6m bags in September 2017), which will support a partial recovery in prices.

Coffee prices are increasingly reactive to changes in the strength of the US dollar
Arabica prices fell steadily over the course of 2017, from an average of US$1.69/lb in January to US$1.37/lb in December. Prices have continued to edge down so far in 2018, falling to US$1.35/lb in March, before slipping below US$1.30/lb in July. Futures prices are trading even lower, with arabica for September delivery standing at under US$1.10/lb in late July. Given that the global market is estimated to have registered its third consecutive annual deficit in 2016/17, the fall in prices-to levels not seen since 2013-is curious. We believe that coffee prices are increasingly driven by investment trends, with swings in sentiment often caused by a spate of positive or negative news on the supply side. Coffee prices are also becoming increasingly reactive to changes in the strength of the US dollar, with dollar depreciation tending to lead to higher coffee prices. In late 2017 speculation about bumper production levels in Brazil pushed prices lower. The fact that several large exporting countries are continuing to sell spare stock to take advantage of weak local currencies is also suppressing prices, because this has been accompanied by a rise in coffee stocks in importing countries, which in turn may contain demand in the future.
Speculation about a potential 2018/19 bumper harvest in Brazil and firm output growth in Mexico and Central America is likely to continue to suppress prices in the near term. We expect prices to remain suppressed for at least the remainder of the second and third quarters of 2018, recovering slightly in the fourth quarter, with a full-year average price of US$1.35/lb reflecting a 10.2% year on year decline for arabica. Given that the next off-season in Brazil (2019/20) is likely to hit market confidence during the 2019 calendar year, we forecast a recovery of prices to an average of US$1.49/lb in 2019.
Tighter supplies of robusta beans and firm Asian demand will support prices
Prices for cheaper robusta held up better during much of 2017, reflecting supply concerns in the context of disappointing weather conditions in Vietnam and Indonesia, but they dipped sharply in November-January as bean supply picked up, before stabilising at a relatively weak level. We expect prices to average 89 US cents/lb in 2018-a 12% year-on-year decline-and US$1.02/lb in 2019.

Maize
Demand
World demand for maize has increased at an astonishing pace during the past two decades, rising from a little more than 600m tonnes at the turn of the millennium to a projected 1.09bn tonnes in 2018/19, up by 2.7% compared with the previous year. Apart from 2012/13, when US crops were decimated by drought, consumption has increased each season, with growth averaging 3.3% per year over 2012/13-2016/17. While stocks mostly tightened through to 2006/07, the spike in demand has lately been more than offset by an even steeper rise in production, resulting in a build-up of supplies. Maize is primarily used as a feed ingredient, which accounts for around 55% of total usage.
Amid broad-based gains in world meat production, especially of poultry and pork, demand for high-starch, high-energy feed maize continues to trend higher almost everywhere, with growth averaging around 2% per year. Amid booming demand for biofuels, and to a lesser extent other sugars and starches, use for industrial processing has increased at an even faster rate. Led by gains in the US and China, world industrial use has surged from around 75m tonnes 20 years ago to a projected 306m tonnes in the 2018/19 marketing year. Helped by a series of large crops in Sub-Saharan Africa, food maize demand has also seen relatively firm growth in recent seasons and is forecast to reach 123m tonnes in 2018/19.
World feed demand will rise by 3% in 2018/19
Growth in global demand for meat and other animal proteins shows no sign of slowing, with consumption gains driven by population growth, greater purchasing power and changes in diets and tastes. Maize is an extremely useful ingredient in animal feed, which can contribute to rapid livestock weight gain. Following an upgraded figure for the EU, we now expect 3% annual growth in the use of maize for livestock feed in 2018/19, broadly in line with the previous year, with overall demand touching a new record of 621m tonnes, up by 20m tonnes compared with 2017/18. The EU and China are likely to account for much of the increase, with notable gains also expected in Russia, Brazil, Iran, Saudi Arabia and Vietnam.
The EU is a huge consumer of maize for livestock feed, with use seen averaging 57m tonnes/year (t/y) in recent seasons. Compound feed manufacturers across the bloc consume near-equal amounts of maize, barley and wheat in most years, with price and availability determining how much of each is used in a particular year. The 2018/19 season will in large part be shaped by the drought that has occurred across much of northern Europe. As a result, wheat availabilities are much tighter than normal, while pastures are bare in many countries, raising the need for additional feed grain supplies. Based on current price spreads, maize is best-placed to meet the shortfall. Feed consumption is seen climbing to a new record high of 62.5m tonnes, up by 7% from 2017/18. With question-marks too over the size of local maize crops, the additional supplies will come from a 25% rise in imports, seen climbing to 21.5m tonnes in 2017/18 (July-June). At that level, the EU would by some distance be the world's biggest importer of maize, surpassing the imports of second-placed Mexico by some 5m tonnes. The majority of this is likely to be sourced from Ukraine and Brazil, although additional purchases from Serbia and Canada are possible. Following the mid-June implementation of a 25% tariff on US maize imports by the EU, supplies from that country are not expected to be competitive.
World industrial demand set to rise again in 2018/19
Industrial processors are projected to use 306m tonnes of maize in 2018/19, up by 3% year on year to another record high. Robust global GDP growth continues to drive demand for maize-based industrial goods, including starch, while use for ethanol fuel is also increasing in the US and Brazil. There is the potential for a steep rise in maize-based biofuel production in China, where the authorities have announced plans for an ambitious nationwide ethanol blending programme, similar to the one that led to the recent boom in the US.
No big changes to US biofuels policy
The proposed Required Volume Obligations (RVOs) issued by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under the Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS) for 2019 were broadly in line with expectations. The blending mandate for conventional ethanol, produced mainly from maize, was unchanged from the previous year's 15bn gallons and equal to the statutory maximum. Biofuel groups and farmers were disappointed by the decision not to reallocate ethanol blending obligations waived under its small refinery exemption to larger refineries. The proposal, which could have led to additional levels of physical blending, was discussed in recent months but faced extremely stiff opposition from the oil industry. Contrary to rumours earlier this year, the authorities have also stepped back from plans to adjust current laws which prevent ethanol blended with 15% ethanol (E-15) to be sold during the summer months.
