Shifting trading relationships are a worry for many US farmers
China's proposed retaliatory tariffs on imports of a large number of US agricultural products, planes and chemicals have sent shockwaves across world commodity markets. However, with China being a relatively small buyer of US maize in recent seasons, the impact of these tariffs-the first set of which were formally announced in mid-June-is likely to be fairly minor. In 2016/17 (July-June) China imported a total of 2.5m tonnes of maize, of which 437,000 tonnes originated in the US, accounting for less than 1% of total US shipments over this period. The new 25% import tariff is likely to shift demand to other origins, most likely Ukraine, already the dominant supplier to the Chinese market. US maize farmers are instead more concerned about the potential fallout from the ongoing North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA) negotiations on the US's trading relationship with Mexico, the main buyer of US maize
Supply
Global maize production has increased by an average of 3% per year over the past two decades, rising from below 600m tonnes in 1999/2000 to more than 1bn tonnes since 2016/17. Production has only shown a year-on-year decline on five occasions during this period, typically owing to spells of difficult cropping weather. In general, production has been driven steadily upward by increases in both areas and yields. Amid strengthening demand for animal feed and industrial products, high market prices have encouraged additional plantings almost everywhere. New seed varieties, fertilisers and better farming practices have also been used with great effect to push up average yields, which are now approaching 6 tonnes/ha, compared with 4.4 tonnes/ha in the late 1990s.
The 2018/19 world supply outlook for maize currently appears fairly comfortable, especially when compared with wheat, production of which is expected to decline by around 6% year on year. However, much will depend on production prospects in the US, where final yields are still far from certain. An expected shift in feed demand away from wheat to maize places extra importance on the outcome of this year's US maize harvest. As long as yields are close to current expectations, the US should be able to meet any predicted uptick in demand, albeit with stocks still potentially declining to multi-year lows. Should yields fall short of expectations or demand spikes turn out to be even higher than currently predicted, there could be some further tightening of stocks and renewed upward price pressure. South America is the other major area of uncertainty, as 2018/19 crops are still not yet in the ground. Based on increases in August for the US, Argentina and Ukraine, our 2018/19 global crop estimate is raised by 2m tonnes, to 1,050m tonnes, potentially the second-largest crop on record.
US output is likely to drop in 2018/19
Helped by earlier good rains, soil moisture reserves across most parts of the US Midwest remained ahead of average but have declined compared with their late-June peak. Similarly, crop condition ratings have dipped, but at 72% good or excellent they remain slightly ahead of levels a year ago. A notable feature this season has been the crop's rapid development, which despite the delays to planting is around 7-10 days ahead of normal. Based on reports of good plant population and a potentially high number of ears, yields this year could potentially be better than the long-term trend. Although crop weather during August will be critical for yields, we are tentatively predicting a higher yield figure, which could see US production reach 366m tonnes (revised up from 361.5m tonnes previously). This would still constitute a 1.3% decline from the record high seen in 2016/17.
Smaller area and lower yields are expected in Brazil
While the global focus has already shifted to the 2018/19 crop outlook, Brazil's 2017/18 season is still far from over. Harvesting has advanced at a slower rate than last year but edged past the halfway-complete mark in early August, similar to the recent average. Our total production forecast for 2017/18 is unchanged at 82m tonnes, 16% down on the previous year. Following a spike in internal transport costs and a drop in the value of the Brazilian Real, the cost of farm inputs, including fertilisers, has risen sharply in recent months, boosting production costs in the run-up to planting of the 2018/19 maize and soybean crops. Continued disagreements about internal trucking costs have also slowed physical deliveries of fertilisers from the southern ports to the main producing areas. Very strong competition for soybeans is again expected to impact planting of the full-season (first) crop, predominantly grown in traditional producing areas in the south of the country. However, assuming producers expand soybean plantings in central and western parts, there could be large areas of farmland primed for sowing the second (safrinha) maize crop after the oilseeds are collected in the early part of 2018. Assuming an overall rise and area and normal yield levels, the 2018/19 next crop could potentially recover to around 94m tonnes, a 15% rise on 2017/18 levels.
Drought will limit production in Argentina
The second half of Argentina's 2017/18 maize-growing season was badly affected by drought, limiting output to around 32m tonnes, down by 22% year on year. Thanks to historically large stock levels, a substantial portion of which is thought to be stored on farms in temporary storage bags, such production shortfalls are unlikely to have a major impact on exportable availabilities, with shipments still projected at a larger than average 23m tonnes, down by 10% year on year.
Amid good profit margins and a favourable demand profile both at home and abroad, we have upgraded our 2018/19 plantings projection for Argentina to show a modest year-on-year increase in area. With seeding of the first crop expected to begin in September, farmers are currently optimistic about the improved soil moisture level, and a possible El Nino weather event later in the season-which normally results in higher than average levels of rainfall in parts of South America-might also be supportive for yields. The favourable price outlook is also likely to encourage farmers to maximise the use of fertilisers and high-yielding seeds. In any event, reflecting the increase in projected plantings, we have upgraded our 2018/19 crop forecast to 41.5m tonnes, potentially a new record.
A larger than average harvest is predicted in Ukraine
Farmers in Ukraine had originally been expected to favour barley in 2018/19 crop rotations. However, with the ideal barley planting window cut short by unusually cold early-spring conditions, many growers switched area into later-seeded spring crops, including maize. Official data recently confirmed a 1.3% increase in 2018/19 planted area to 4.6m ha. After dry weather at the start of the summer conditions have since become much more favourable. We have therefore reversed last month's small downward revision and now expect output to rise by 14%, to 27.5m tonnes. Given the potential for extremely strong demand from the EU and to a lesser extent China, exports are provisionally seen reaching 21.5m tonnes, a new record high.
Sowings in Russia dropped by 12% year on year
The 2018/19 production forecast for Russia, where maize has become an increasingly important export crop in recent years, has been cut by a further 1.4m tonnes to 12.6m tonnes (from 13.2m tonnes in 2017/18), with the risks skewed very much to the downside. Farmers had been expected to sow even more maize this season, but owing to difficult weather in recent months many have instead turned to oilseeds, planting additional acreage to sunflowerseed, rapeseed and soybeans. Hot weather in key growing regions could also affect yield potential.

Stocks and prices
World maize stocks reached a record 329m tonnes in 2016/17, following six consecutive years of increases. However, with the authorities in China now keen to reduce burdensome stockpiles, overall supplies have tightened fairly quickly, and global stocks are projected to decline in both 2017/18 and 2018/19. We expect global stocks to ease back to 266m tonnes by end-2018/19, below the 2016/17 peak and 3% below the previous five-year average. As China remains only a small player on the world stage, importing less than 3m tonnes in a typical year and exporting only limited amounts to North Korea, it is helpful to exclude notional estimates of Chinese inventories (no official data are published) in an analysis of world stocks. Because of some weather problems and overall strong export demand, cumulative inventories in the major suppliers (Argentina, Brazil, Ukraine and US) are forecast to tighten to 53.3m tonnes at end-2018/19, which would imply a decrease of 16% year on year and potentially the lowest level since 2015/16. This could help to support prices in the year ahead, but with stocks still comfortably above levels seen a decade or so ago, there is little reason to expect any sharp increase in market values, provided there is no major production shock in one of the key exporters.
Using year-end stockpiles as a gauge for measuring market supplies is the most widely used tool for evaluating the size of surpluses or deficits in a particular year. Leaving aside difficulties with definition and whether stocks can actually be accurately judged at any one particular point in the season, the differences in marketing years between the biggest producers means that any efforts to assess cumulative stocks are subject to even more uncertainties. For example, with South American stocks typically at their lowest in February and those in the US at their lowest in August, any analysis of combined stocks is inherently flawed, since inventories are never as low (or as high) as suggested by just adding together stocks in the individual countries.
China's stock estimates are highly provisional
In mid-July China's State Council announced a country-wide inspection of the quantity and quality of national and local grain reserves, to be conducted over 15 months. The checks will focus on the volume, quality and location of state stocks, and final results are due to be submitted to the State Council by the end of October 2019. According to local press reports, similar inspections were carried out in 2001 and 2009, but the results were not publicly revealed. It is therefore unlikely that the outcome of the next survey will be publicly released, although the results are likely to play a major role in determining future policy decisions. We expect stocks to be drawn down in 2018-19 as the government seeks to boost domestic consumption, particularly in the biofuels industry. However, given that these stocks are primarily held as a domestic food security measure, this is unlikely to influence global prices.
US ending stocks are expected to drop back to 41.2m tonnes by the end of 2018/19, down by 20% from the year before and potentially a five-year low. Given reduced competition from Brazil, large supplies continue to be sent for export, with ending stocks down by around 17m tonnes from the 30-year highs seen at the end of 2017/18. While supplies are tightening, it should be stressed that the absolute level of stocks remains fairly comfortable and only marginally lower than the average.

Average prices are above year-ago levels
After declining quite sharply in May and June in response to the deepening trade dispute between the US and China, world maize export prices posted a partial recovery in July, rising by a net 6% in the weeks since our previous report. Gains were linked partly to an ongoing improvement in the US export demand profile and a spillover from a rally in wheat. Despite much smaller 2017/18 crops in Brazil and Argentina, prices in South America were only a few dollars higher than equivalent US values as new crop supplies began to replenish the exportable pipeline. Traders were also keen to maintain competitiveness with exports out of the US. In light of a tighter world supply outlook we continue to expect prices to bounce higher from first-quarter levels, especially if, as expected, the US-China trade dispute has little impact on US maize exports. However, the final size of the US crop is likely to dictate price direction in the coming months. US prices (fob Gulf) are seen as averaging US$180/tonne in 2018, compared with an average of US$195/ tonne in the five-year period ending 2017.

Palm oil
Demand
In terms of price, palm oil has become increasingly competitive relative to other vegetable and mineral oils, and as a result The Economist Intelligence Unit has increased its projections of the use of palm oil in biodiesel, most notably in Indonesia and Malaysia. Sluggish growth in Indian edible consumption will continue to act as a constraint, but we have revised up our forecast for global consumption in 2017/18 to 67.4m tonnes, up 4.4% up on 2016/17 levels. Further growth in biodiesel use is expected in 2018/19, and this underpins our projection of a 3.9% increase in overall consumption in 2018/19.
India will remain the largest market for palm oil
In India, palm oil demand has been below expectations during 2017/18. Although this is in part accounted for by the imposition of higher import duties, there is concern that it represents a more fundamental shift in demand away from palm oil to other vegetable oils. We have again revised down our forecast of consumption in 2017/18, to below 9.7m tonnes. Further downward revisions are possible, although there are indications that consumption during the final quarter of 2017/18 may at least be maintained, partly as a result of a steadying of the rupee against the US dollar and partly as a result of low stocks of vanaspati (a type of thick vegetable oil used in India) at retail level. Indian import levies on palm oil are now on a par with soft seed oils. This, coupled with increasing price competitiveness at international level, should mean that Indian palm oil consumption will grow strongly in 2018/19, registering an above-average growth rate of 5.4%.
Indonesia's biodiesel sector will post solid growth in 2018-19
Indonesian biodiesel production is running ahead of expectations, reflecting the increased competiveness of palm oil as a feedstock following a build-up of local stocks. Improving biodiesel exports and greater offtake in the domestic market have both contributed to this recent growth. Our estimate of 2017/18 palm oil consumption in Indonesia is raised to 10.2m tonnes, representing annual growth of more than 11%. There is scope for further gains in 2018/19, provided palm oil retains its competitiveness. There is plenty of spare production capacity in Indonesia, and the authorities plan to increase the domestic incorporation mandate further. As a result, we expect consumption to rise by a further 3% in 2018/19.
China's palm oil demand is hindered by soybean competition
In China, palm oil continues to face strong competition from soybean oil, but falling palm oil prices and a modest recovery in the instant noodles sector have improved the outlook. We continue to expect consumption to rise by 7.4% year on year in 2017/18, ending four consecutive years of decline. The bilateral trade war between the US and China presents an upside risk to palm oil demand; China introduced a 25% tariff on imports of US soybeans in June as part of the bilateral trade dispute. If China has difficulty sourcing sufficient quantities of soybeans from other exporters such as Brazil, for example, this would raise domestic soybean prices and therefore make palm oil more competitive. We will await further details on changes to China's trade flows before revising our forecast. At the time of writing there were few signs of any increase in Chinese imports of palm oil over previously expected levels.
Energy demand in the EU will rise, boosting usage
Palm oil prices in the EU are becoming more competitive with mineral oil prices. This, along with higher admixture rates, is encouraging growth in palm oil imports and consumption, despite increased competition from biodiesel from Indonesia and Argentina. EU legislators moved closer to discouraging the use of palm oil in the biofuels sector when negotiators from the Commission and the European Parliament agreed to freeze the use of high-risk indirect land use change for the production of biofuels (ie, palm-oil based biofuels) at 2019 levels and to phase them out completely by 2030. While the immediate impact of this agreement will be negligible, it clearly has significant long-term impacts. In the food sector, palm oil demand is expected to remain stable. As a result, we expect EU palm oil consumption growth to moderate from 1.2% in 2017/18 to just 0.8% in 2018/19. The rate of growth will be heavily influenced by the use in the biofuels sectors, especially in Spain and Germany.
Biodiesel consumption in Malaysia is set to rise
Malaysian palm oil demand growth has been limited by delays in implementing biodiesel incorporation mandates. The implementation of the B10 mandate has been persistently delayed-the most recent government announcements indicate implementation in the second half of 2019. Malaysian exports of biodiesel have been higher than previously expected, and domestic demand for B7 biodiesel is also reported to be improving. We now expect consumption in 2017/18 to be 13.4% above 2016/17 levels. We have also raised our forecast for palm oil consumption in 2018/19 to reflect higher biodiesel exports and, to a lesser extent, the planned implementation of the B10 incorporation mandate.
Consumption prospects in other countries are broadly positive
The geographical markets for palm oil are diverse, with the top five consumers accounting for less than 55% of global consumption. There have been sharp increases in exports to a number of these destinations, including Pakistan, Iran, the Philippines and various other Asian and African destinations. The largest of these "other" consumers, Pakistan, is likely to show sustained growth, given that attempts to encourage local oilseeds production have been mostly unsuccessful. With palm oil prices continuing to fall, there is sustained interest in palm oil from these other consumers. We expect consumption growth in this group of countries to be higher than previously forecast.

Supply
Output trends in the two major producers continue to diverge: while output is growing steadily in Indonesia, production in Malaysia has been disappointing Overall, our forecast of palm oil output in 2017/18 has been reduced to 70.4m tonnes, although this still represents an above-average growth rate of 6.4%. By contrast, we have increased our projections of output in 2018/19, largely reflecting a higher forecast for Indonesia, although we still expect overall global growth to be very modest at 2.3%. In 2018/19 the mature area will expand, albeit slowly, but yield outcomes will be negatively affected by tree stress and potentially lower input use.
Yield cycle may offset favourable growing conditions
Indonesian production of palm oil is now rising seasonally, but our forecast of 2017/18 season output remains unchanged at 38.3m tonnes. While the 2017/18 growth rate is below recent levels, it is building on particularly rapid growth of 16.4% in 2016/17. Rainfall has been favourable and should encourage good yields over the next 6-9 months. Despite the slowdown in plantings, the mature area for next season will be higher, albeit by a modest 3.4%. However, the overall impact of favourable growing conditions may be constrained by the yield cycle. A modest yield increase would result in Indonesia's palm oil production expanding by a below-average 3.8%. Our revised forecast of output of 39.8m tonnes remains below some local estimates, which put the total above 40m tonnes.
Malaysian output continues to disappoint
Malaysia's palm oil production remains below expectations. Normally, output would be increasing at this stage of the season, but official measures of June output show a 13% fall from May levels. This would appear to be the result of some workers taking extended leave and a higher than expected replanting rate, as well as a downturn in the biological yield cycle. We have again revised down our forecast for 2017/18 production growth, although we are still expecting output to be almost 8% above 2016/17 levels. Production is unlikely to grow further in 2018/19; current tree stress will inhibit yields into the 2018/19 season, and an ageing tree population will also contribute to a disappointing outturn. On the positive side, however, recent weather conditions have largely been favourable, which will help to avoid a sharper downturn in 2018/19. We therefore expect production levels in 2018/19 to be broadly similar to those recorded in 2017/18.

Thailand output exceeds expectations
The increase in yields in Thailand during 2017/18 has been especially strong, reflecting good weather and favourable oil extraction rates. In 2018/19 we expect production to be only slightly below the 2017/18 level as tree stress and the probable use of lower inputs reduce yields. In Colombia, output is likely to grow steadily over the forecast period as its mature area expands. There remains potential for further land for palm oil cultivation without any deforestation issues. Recent yields have largely been above year-earlier levels and should show sustained growth, reflecting the changing age distribution of the trees. Some other smaller palm oil-producing countries, such as Honduras, will also see solid output growth in 2017/18.
Stocks and prices
Palm oil stocks in Malaysia, which have been on a downward trend, are now rising despite the smaller than expected local production. Indonesian stocks have been rising consistently despite increases in local consumption. The reduction in expected palm oil output in 2017/18 has lowered the end-season stocks to the equivalent of 67 days of consumption (from 68 days previously). Although stocks are below the peak of 71 days recorded at the end of 2014/15, they remain above the previous five-year average. However, we expect global stocks to climb to 74 days of cosumption by the end of 2018/19, a level last seen in the mid-1990s.

Rising stock levels will push prices down further in 2018-19
Physical palm oil prices continued their downward trajectory in July, in line with our expectations. Futures prices have also tended to be weak, although they stabilised in the second half of the month. We continue to expect global palm oil prices to decline in the second half of 2018, albeit at a slightly slower rate. Overall, we expect average palm oil prices to fall by 9.7% in 2018 and a further 8.5% in 2019. We expect prices to drop below US$600/tonne from the second quarter of 2019, which would be their lowest level since late 2015. However, further downgrades to Malaysian production forecasts could lead to a more moderate price decline. Given the scale of the 2018/19 surplus, risks to the 2019/20 price forecasts are on the downside.

Rapeseed oil
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global rapeseed oil consumption to fall in 2017/18 for the third consecutive season, to its lowest level since 2012/13. Rapeseed oil is suffering from increasing price competition from sunflowerseed oil, which has not been offset by higher mineral oil prices. We currently expect consumption to decline by 5.8% in 2017/18, and recent increases in rapeseed oil prices, following downgrades to future production prospects, are likely to constrain consumption growth in 2018/19 as well. We have reduced our projections of 2018/19 consumption in almost all of the major consumers and are forecasting an overall total of 25.5m tonnes, just 2.6% above 2017/18 levels. Further downward revisions may be necessary.
EU consumption is threatened by biodiesel imports
Rapeseed oil use in the biodiesel sector in the EU has faced strong competition from recycled cooking oil and from imported biodiesel. In the food sector, cheaper sunflowerseed and soybean oils have provided stiff competition. Thus rapeseed oil consumption in the EU is expected to fall for the third consecutive year in 2017/18, to just over 9.9m tonnes, and to decline again in 2018/19, given continued competitive pressures and downgrades to local production forecasts.
Chinese consumption is limited by supply constraints
In China, local rapeseed availability is limited, despite recent improvements in local crushing of imported rapeseed, and this is acting as a constraint on consumption. Rapeseed oil imports into China have risen in recent months, but from a low base. We have made a small upward adjustment to our forecast of China's rapeseed oil consumption, but even so consumption is expected to contract by 17.3% in 2017/18. Higher local estimates of rapeseed production in 2018/19 should help to boost consumption, following three consecutive years of decline. Crush rates should increase, helping to bridge the gap created by lower soybean imports (as China's 25% tariff on soybean imports from the US pushes up local prices). We therefore expect China's rapeseed oil consumption to rebound by 12.6% in 2018/19.
India's consumption will rebound in 2017/18
In India, we expect rapeseed oil consumption to show robust growth of 14.2% in 2017/18, encouraged by improved local availability and strong GDP growth. Rapeseed oil is the preferred oil in north and central India, which typically absorbs local production along with a small, but increasing, volume of imports. However, import volumes may be negatively affected by the recent increase in import duties. We expect that 2018/19 consumption will rise by only a small amount-less than 0.5%-reflecting the marginal rise in local production.
Only modest demand growth is likely in the US market
Biodiesel production in the US contracted sharply in June, with a consequent negative impact on imports of rapeseed oil. We have reduced our forecast of 2017/18 US rapeseed oil consumption accordingly, to 2.7m tonnes, slightly below 2016/17 levels.
Several smaller consumers which switched away from rapeseed oil in 2016/17 have recently returned to the market. However, growth in rapeseed oil consumption among this "other" consumers category during 2017/18 is likely to be constrained by more competitive sunflowerseed oil.

Supply
World production of rapeseed oil has plateaued at just above 25m tonnes. Our forecast of 2017/18 output now stands at 25.3m tonnes, very similar to output in each of the preceding two seasons. Prospects for global rapeseed production in 2018/19 are threatened by dry conditions in the EU, Canada and Australia, with a negative impact particularly likely in the EU, where harvesting has already started. Even allowing for a reduction in rapeseed stocks, rapeseed oil output is unlikely to rise much above 25m tonnes in 2018/19.
Weaker demand is weighing on EU rapeseed oil production
Crush margins for EU rapeseed in 2017/18 are poor because of weak demand for rapeseed oil from the biodiesel sector, reflecting increased competition from imported biodiesel. We now expect 2017/18 EU rapeseed oil production to total just 10m tonnes, the lowest level of output since 2012/13. For 2018/19 exceptionally hot and dry weather in recent weeks has taken a toll on the crop outlook. Estimates of the likely size of the crop are falling, with the most recent projections putting the crop less than 20m tonnes, a level not seen since the 2011/12 and 2012/13 seasons. Harvesting started in early July, with early yield reports disappointing. Even allowing for high carry-in stocks, 2018/19 rapeseed oil production will be affected by the low seed production level. We are now expecting EU rapeseed oil production to fall further in 2018/19, by some 5% from 2017/18 levels.
China will rely on imports for oil production
Chinese rapeseed oil production is becoming increasingly dependent on imported seed supplies. So far in the 2017/18 season rapeseed imports are running well above year-ago levels. While recent import levels have been insufficient to maintain the earlier crush pace, we maintain our view that rapeseed oil production will expand by 1.7% in 2017/18. The uncertainty surrounding the impact of tariffs on imports of US soybeans has so far not impacted rapeseed import levels. Dry conditions have been experienced over much of the Chinese oilseed areas, with downgrades to production prospects for most oilseed crops. Rapeseed appears to have largely avoided the dry conditions, and prospects for the Chinese 2018/19 rapeseed crop remain favourable, with a likely 6% growth in output. We expect rapeseed oil production to expand by 2.6% in 2018/19, the second consecutive year of growth. Risks to the forecast are to the upside, for example if rapeseed meal is used as a substitute to make up for any shortfall in soybean crushing as a result of the escalating US-China trade dispute.
Canada's 2017/18 harvest will rise
We continue to expect 2017/18 Canadian canola oil production to reach 4.1m tonnes, aided by strong exports of canola oil to the US, Chile and South Korea. For 2018/19, official data point to a reduction in the area planted to canola in 2018/19 as farmers return to grain crops, although some industry observers suggest that official data are overstating the level of reduction. While earlier rainfall improved soil moisture conditions, a recent dry spell means that there is again growing concern over dry conditions in Canada. Nonetheless, recent local estimates still suggest a crop approaching 22m tonnes, which would be a new record and would mean that Canada overtakes the EU as the largest rapeseed producer. Canadian canola oil production is more dependent on market develop-ments than on the availability of seed for crushing. As a result, we main-tain our forecast of 4.3m tonnes for canola oil production in 2018/19, although increased competition for available canola seed, as well as a potential slow-down in demand for canola oil for local biodiesel production, could act as constraints.
India's production is set to grow owing to higher rapeseed imports
In India, 2017/18 rapeseed oil production is still expected to jump by 14.2% year on year, helped by a relatively large local rapeseed crop. However, successful rapeseed growing requires good soil moisture levels, and while the 2018/19 monsoon season started with higher than normal rainfalls, recent rainfall totals have been disappointing. Overall, rainfall is 5% below normal levels and may discourage rapeseed plantings. The Indian government has raised vegetable oil import tariffs and increased minimum support prices in an attempt to encourage local production. However, low domestic prices for rapeseed have affected crop profitability for farmers. Despite this, it appears that the rapeseed area and production levels are likely to remain steady year on year in 2018/19. For the moment, we have retained our forecast of modest 0.8% growth in rapeseed oil production in 2018/19.
Australian production could be constrained by dry conditions
There remain doubts over the likely 2018/19 Australian canola crop, with rainfall needed to allow normal crop development. With a lower planted area, good yields will be required to maintain output. At the moment, we are expecting production to fall by more than 10% from 2017/18 levels. Despite dry conditions in Belarus and Russia, the area planted to rapeseed has increased in both countries, which should support larger than average crops. The harvesting of winter rapeseed in Ukraine is virtually complete and consistent with an overall harvest of 2.5m tonnes. Rapeseed is reportedly the most profitable of the oilseed crops in Ukraine, and further expansion of the area planted to rapeseed is expected.

Stocks and prices
We expect global rapeseed oil stocks to rise in 2017/18 on the back of a market surplus. However, when measured as share of consumption, oil stocks will remain well below the average in recent years. By contrast, rapeseed stocks will be around average levels at end-2017/18. The production downgrade for 2018/19 means that the season will now see a market deficit, with rapeseed oil stocks ending the season at very low levels. Rapeseed stocks are also expected to be below normal at the end of 2018/19, although projections suggest that there will be sufficient stocks to allow marginally higher rapeseed oil production.

Concern over production leads to firmer prices
The impending tightness of the rapeseed oil market is being reflected in increasing prices. Physical prices of rapeseed oil were especially strong in July, recording the largest increase of any of the major vegetable oils. Futures prices for rapeseed have also been firmer, especially on the European market. The substantial downgrading of the EU crop and fears over output elsewhere have changed market sentiment. The increase in prices that we expected has thus set in earlier than previously forecast, and we now expect prices to rise steadily for the foreseeable future. They are expected to exceed US$900/tonne by the second quarter of 2019.

Rice
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global rice consumption to grow by 1.6% in 2017/18 to a record 492m tonnes. Asian markets, which account for an estimated 90% of world use, will drive this expansion, notably via increased demand in India. Smaller increases are likely elsewhere in East and South Asia, as well as in Latin America and Africa. Global demand is expected to continue on an upward trajectory in 2018/19 to reach almost 500m tonnes. However, the pace of growth will moderate, albeit slightly, as higher incomes and changing dietary preferences prompt a shift to greater protein consumption at the expense of traditional staples.
Food demand will remain the main driver of total use
Accordingly, rice consumption per head is anticipated to fall in 2018/19. In terms of non-food usage, the use of rice for animal feed is expected to decline, largely reflecting a reduced uptake in China, the dominant consumer. Japan has also utilised stocks of imported rice in feed mixes, but data suggest that demand for domestic rice feed may have peaked. Overall, the non-food usage of rice (including by the industrial sector) will continue to account for only a small proportion of overall demand and will fall as a share of overall consumption.
Trade in rice will continue to grow, but at a slower rate than in 2017
Africa and Asia account for more than two-thirds of all rice imports, primarily white and parboiled grades sourced from Thailand, India, Pakistan and Vietnam. In Sub-Saharan Africa, in particular, a significant share of demand-mainly for high-quality white and parboiled supplies-is met through imports. Following record global rice purchases in 2017, of 45.4m tonnes, many Asian buyers are likely to be well stocked. Furthermore, strong demand for Thai rice from African buyers in 2017 was largely linked to availabilities of attractively priced rice from the government's stockpile. In light of strong demand from Indonesia, Bangladesh and the Philippines in the first half of the year, we expected global trade to increase by more than 2.5% to almost 47m tonnes between 2016/17 and 2017/18, with similar volumes likely the following year.
China remains the world's leading consumer
China is by far the world's largest consumer of rice, representing almost 30% of global demand. Although locally produced rice accounts for the bulk of national consumption, China is also the world's largest importer.
The potential impact of lower farmer support prices is unclear
Domestic early-season long-grain milled rice still commands hefty premiums over supplies from other major origins in Asia, owing to the easy availability of rice from major suppliers outside China. We expect China's purchases to peak at 5m tonnes in 2017/18 before declining slightly in 2018/19. Although it remains unclear how lower state support will impact rice imports, for now we think that imports are likely to fall in 2018/19 as the government seeks to reduce inventories. Nonetheless, import volumes are likely to remain substantial, given that local prices remain above international values. In 2018/19 as a whole shipments are projected at 4.5m tonnes.
Bangladesh is expected to buy significantly more rice in 2018
Bangladesh is one of the leading rice markets within Asia, with annual demand reaching at least 35m tonnes. The three domestic crops cut each year are the boro (seeded in December-January and harvested in April-May), aus (planted in March-April and cut in June-July) and aman (sown in July-August and normally threshed in November-December). Although the bulk of the country's rice needs is met by domestic crops, significant quantities are sometimes procured from the world market, especially in times of shortages. Purchases in 2018 are expected to reach 2m tonnes-more than three times the 2017 level-before falling again in 2019 as domestic supply improves.
The Philippines is expected to remain a key buyer
In the Philippines, stocks held by the National Food Authority, the grain procurement agency, have dwindled to their lowest level in about a decade. By contrast, inventories held by private households and commercial warehouses remain comfortable. Underscoring thin state reserves, imports progressed strongly in 2017 to reach 1.4m tonnes, and import levels are expected to increase again in 2018 as the Philippines aims to ensure domestic supply.
Solid growth in Saudi consumption of cereals
In Saudi Arabia, consumption of cereals, including rice, has posted strong growth over the past two decades. As the preferred ingredient for inclusion in feed rations, barley accounts for more than half of aggregate domestic demand, while growth in the use of other commodities, including wheat and maize in the food and feed sector, respectively, has been particularly notable.
Rice is a staple food, with kabsah, a traditional dish, being consumed widely. In addition, significant volumes are eaten by foreign workers, chiefly from South Asia. However, demand for white rice among middle- and high-income families has fallen, reflecting a shift towards an increased uptake of protein as well as fruits and vegetables. Overall, therefore, growth in rice consumption has been relatively modest. Consumption is forecast at around 1.3m tonnes in 2018/19, little changed on the previous year, and only marginally higher than the 1.1m tonnes seen a decade ago.
Saudi Arabia's local market is one of the largest in the Middle East
Nevertheless, the domestic rice market in Saudi Arabia remains one the largest in the Middle East-comparable in size to Iraq and second only to Iran. As climate conditions do not allow for domestic rice cultivation, local market needs are met entirely through imports, which are typically of a very high quality and consist mainly of fragrant-especially basmati-varieties. The origins of the nation's international rice purchases have changed little over the years, with South Asian exporters the most important suppliers. Purchases from India and Pakistan are predominantly of basmati varieties, with relatively smaller quantities of high-quality white and parboiled types secured from a range of origins, including Thailand, Vietnam, the US, China and Australia.

a Local marketing years.
Supply
With larger crops in a number of leading Asian producers, including India, more than compensating for disappointing harvests in other regions, world rice output in 2017/18 is forecast to expand by just under 1% year on year, to 492m tonnes. The outlook for 2018/19 remains tentative but, as in most years, it will depend on crops in Asia's main producers-primarily India, where the monsoon season began on June 1st. Given that only a small expansion of planted area is likely, an increase in global output will depend on yields. We expect world output to edge higher in 2018/19, by 0.5%, to reach a record 495m tonnes. All of our scenarios assume continued state support to farmers in Asia, as recently announced in India, although seeding in China is likely to fall as the authorities seek to reduce production to draw down excess inventories.
Global production prospects are to a large degree shaped by the outlook for India's main summer-sown (kharif) crop, which is crucial both in terms of domestic supply and the surplus available for export. According to government data, rice plantings were complete on 19.8m ha by the end of July, broadly equivalent to around half of intended acreage during the season but representing a contraction of 12% on the preceding season.
To some extent, this is linked to weaker than anticipated rains during stages of the monsoon season, with cumulative rains 8% below the long-term average as at August 3rd (more or less half-way through the season). Private forecaster Skymet has suggested that precipitation could be below average in the final two months of the season, although the India Meteorological Department, a state body, is predicting average levels, corresponding to 95% of the long-run average. Nevertheless, the outlook carries a model error ranging from -8% to +8%.
The government has raised kharif support prices
In early July the government announced that it will lift minimum support prices for all 2018/19 kharif crops, including a 13% rise for common-grade paddy (rice) to Rs1,750 (US$255) a tonne. Assuming that rains are in line with normal levels in the main rice-growing areas, all rice production in 2018/19, which also includes the relatively tiny winter-seeded (rabi) crop, is forecast at a record of 113m tonnes, up from 111m tonnes in the preceding season.
Trade with Asian buyers remains robust
Trade flows during the first five months of 2018 were marginally ahead of the previous year, with shipments totalling 5.2m tonnes. After the previous season's heavy purchases, including of old crop state reserves from Thailand, demand from African importers has been somewhat slower during the course of this year. Data show that shipments to the region fell by more than 20% year on year, with reductions for exports to Ghana, Guinea, Côte d'Ivoire and Egypt. Sales to Europe and the countries of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) also contracted, but demand from Asian buyers has increased, chiefly reflecting Bangladesh's need to secure bigger volumes owing to local shortages. Deliveries to the Bangladeshi market averaged close to 150,000 tonnes per month during January-May, compared with less than 18,000 tonnes per month in the year-earlier period.
We expect India's full-year exports to rise to 12.2m tonnes, from 11.7m tonnes in the previous season. Exports are currently running below the levels necessary for such a rise, but we expect the pace to accelerate later in the season, given that prices have fallen at most major origins, including India, during the course of this year, and that African buyers are likely to return to the world market to boost domestic stocks. Shipments could be marginally higher in 2018/19 based on the assumption that demand from buyers in Africa and Asia is robust, but the outlook is much more tentative.
Drought conditions in Pakistan harm rice production prospects
The rice production outlook for Pakistan is uncertain owing to water shortages in the main producing areas. In early June the Pakistan Meteorological Department released a drought warning, indicating that parts of the country were experiencing severe soil moisture deficits owing to persistent below-average rainfall since the tail end of 2017. Water availability in the main reservoirs was estimated to be more than 50% below average, constraining planting operations.
A smaller crop could be problematic for exporters
Rice sowings usually commence in the later stages of May and early June in southern areas of the country, while cultivation in northern areas usually takes place in late July. However, in the current season fieldwork has been running as much as 45 days behind schedule. Some growers will therefore seed much less than anticipated, and yield potential could be significantly down. While the situation may improve if monsoon rains intensify, we now expect output to fall by 2.8% year on year, to 7m tonnes (from 7.4m tonnes previously). This will have a knock-on impact on export volumes, given that around half of the crop is typically exported. We project that a crop of 7m tonnes would support exports of 3.9m tonnes, down from 4.1m tonnes in the preceding season.
The Chinese government is keen to reduce inventory levels
The Chinese government aims to reduce rice acreage by around 2% by scaling back low-quality rice production. Ultimately, this is meant to address the significant structural imbalance between domestic supply and demand. In late April the Communist Party leadership of Hunan Province stated that it aimed to reduce plantings by 200,000 ha in the province during the current year, shifting land to high-value specialty crops. This development is significant, since state policy had previously been geared towards stabilising or increasing paddy (rice) output. Acreage has changed little over the years, so a fall of 2% would represent the first significant decline since 2003/04. Furthermore, the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) outlined lower minimum purchasing prices in early 2018 across all types of rice, with falls of between 8% and 11% noted. This is important, because it represents the second consecutive annual cut in farmer support, and suggests that the government is aware that supply and demand must be rebalanced owing to burdensome inventories.
The government has also announced a reform of its minimum price support scheme for rice. This year's programme sets stricter conditions for activating minimum price procurement-which can only take place when the market price has remained below the minimum set price for three consecutive days. The scheme must be suspended once the market price exceeds the minimum support price for another three days. This latest policy shift illustrates further the administration's eagerness to reshape the rice sector by introducing market-based conditions under which rice will be procured from farmers. As with efforts to reduce the production of low-quality indica rice, this underlines the government's awareness that domestic stock levels are unsustainably high.
Procurement of early indica rice runs from August 1st-September 30th, while middle and late indica rice procurement runs from October 10th until January 31st. Japonica rice procurement commences on November 1st and must close by the end of February.
Exports offer a convenient way for China to reduce stocks
China's exports of rice have traditionally been nominal and shaped by sales of japonica varieties, including to Japan and South Korea, for example. However, there was a big shift in 2017, with shipments rising sharply, largely owing to sales of indica rice to African nations. These included particularly heavy deliveries to Côte d'Ivoire, Liberia, Mozambique, Senegal and Sierra Leone. In 2017 as a whole China's total rice exports reached 1.2m tonnes, up from less than 400,000 tonnes in 2016 and the highest annual total in a decade. Prospects for exports in 2018-19 are somewhat uncertain at this stage. Nevertheless, with the government seeking to reduce reserves, exports are likely to be significantly above-average in the next two years.
Prospects for rice production in Thailand in 2017/18 were boosted by above-average precipitation. Based on an expansion of planted area across both seasons, total production is projected to grow by 5%, to 20.5m tonnes. On the basis of another year of high global trade, combined with current prices for white rice, farmers are expected to expand the area sown to rice in 2018/19. Assuming beneficial conditions, rice output could rise by a further 5%, to close to 22m tonnes.
Thai exports are likely to slip owing to competition from India
Thailand's exports of all varieties of rice totalled 11.5m tonnes in 2017-easily its highest total and up from 9.9m tonnes the year before. The strong increase was mainly attributable to a large expansion of shipments to markets in Africa, with a portion almost certainly consisting of older intervention reserves from the government's long-held stockpile. Since the government is reported to have sold off food-quality stocks from past harvests last year, exporters will have no access to attractively priced inventories that can be sold to buyers in Africa and other regions. Consequently, total exports in 2018 could decline by 1m tonnes, to 10.5m tonnes, and remain fairly flat in 2019.
Conditions for the next US crop appear positive, with recent weekly Crop Progress Reports issued by the US Department of Agriculture estimating that 69% of paddy fields were in good or excellent condition at the end of July, matching the average for this time of the season. With nearly two-thirds of crop headed, harvesting is expected to commence during August. Based on long-grain area gains, total acreage in the US is expected to expand by one-fifth year on year, and with trend-based yields anticipated, production should rebound to reach 6.8m tonnes (up from 5.7m tonnes in the previous year). Given that a larger crop should ensure that availabilities are much improved, exports in 2019 are likely to expand to 3.6m tonnes, up from 3.2m tonnes in the previous season.
Rice production puts pressure on Egyptian water supplies
Egypt has traditionally been a relatively small but important rice-producing country. While the bulk of its crop is channelled to the local market, it is also a modest exporter of medium-grain varieties to global markets, competing with nations such as the US and Australia. The government has for a number of years been using restrictions on exports to ensure availabilities for local consumption. The government is now seeking to reduce the cultivation of water-intensive crops, including rice. According to reports, 1,400 litres of water are used in the production of 1 kg of rice, with agriculture accounting for an estimated 80% of Egypt's total water resources. In January the Ministry of Water Resources and Irrigation announced a reduction of more than 30% year on year in the approved rice area in 2018/19, to 304,080 ha. According to local reports, the heavy drop in area is linked to local farmers having grown more rice than the government's allotment during the previous year. In addition, farmers were subjected to financial penalties for exceeding the official area target.
Large-scale imports could feature in the longer term
Given that rice cultivation in Egypt is attractive for farmers, it seems possible that growers could again boost plantings above the allotted target. Nevertheless, we still anticipate a fall in output in 2018/19 of about 1m tonnes, to 3.3m tonnes, the lowest in eight seasons. Although local demand has been falling in recent years as the population increasingly turns to alternative, cheaper forms of carbohydrates, such as pasta, imports of rice are likely to rise to 300,000 tonnes, but this is still small in terms of the overall supply-and-demand balance sheet. However, on June 5th the prime minister, Sherif Ismail, announced that the country would import rice so as to increase stocks and control the market. While no timeframe was provided, the statement could be significant, potentially signalling a switch to large-scale imports as production continues to fall. Some traders and analysts have suggested that purchases from the world market could end up totalling as much as 1m tonnes per year. Exports are expected to remain officially banned in 2018-19. However, some modest amounts-in the order of 50,000 tonnes per year-are expected to find their way on to international market, as has been the case in recent years during times of restrictions.

Stocks and prices
We still expect global stocks to fall by around 5% year on year 105m tonnes by the end of the 2018/19 season. After the significant tightening of recent years, mostly on account of a drawdown of government reserves in Thailand, stocks held by the five major exporters are expected to show little change year on year. At 20m tonnes, aggregate stocks are seen down by just 1m tonnes from the season before. In China, the government is encouraging farmers to scale back production of low-quality rice and diversify into high-value varieties as a means of preventing further excessive growth of inventories. Accordingly, we anticipate some modest tightening of inventories in 2018/19 after years of accumulation.
Caution is generally advised when analysing stocks data, since the bulk of year-end figures provided are arrived at via residual calculation, as most countries do not collect or provide meaningful figures. Furthermore, inventories in China on a milled weight tonnage-equivalent could total as much as 70m-80m tonnes, but no official data are published. The exclusion of Chinese stocks, therefore, produces a more realistic figure for what is available on the world market, mostly located in the five major exporters, and specifically in India.

Asian markets for white and parboiled grades of rice generally eased in July and early August as continued arrivals of new crop supplies and slower demand from leading buyers weighed on sentiment. After the previous month's steep falls, quotations in Thailand for key white grades were only slightly weaker and in line with those from a year earlier. By contrast, export quotations for broken rice in Vietnam fell heavily during July and into early August, with 5% broken falling by US$39/tonne (some 9%) to US$386/tonne fob Ho Chi Minh. In addition to weak export interest, much of the fall reflected efforts by exporters to bring prices closer to parity with Thailand, stimulating demand from importers.
In India, meanwhile, export values were only a touch below month-ago levels. Although sluggish buying interest was a source of bearish pressure, reports suggested that exporters were holding on to stocks, given the slow pace of planting during the 2018/19 kharif season. Elsewhere in South Asia there were heightened worries about drought conditions in Pakistan, with planting of the monsoon crop as much as two months behind schedule in some parts of Sindh province, raising worries that production could be much smaller than in the previous season. While this provided a degree of support to the market, a depreciating local currency pressured US dollar-denominated values, with the 5% broken grade having falling by about 10% since early July.
Recent price declines have depressed the 2018-19 outlook
Based on recent developments in pricing-notably the continued steep falls in prices amid prospects for ample global supplies-we have revised down our forecasts for 2018. The average price of Thailand's 100% B grade for the third quarter has been cut by a further US$15/tonne, to US$395/tonne. With an adjustment for the final quarter, the full year average value is lowered to US$406/tonne fob Bangkok ports. However, this would still equate to a year-on-year increase of more than 4% and a four-year high, largely owing to demand-led gains in international prices in early 2018. Over the remainder of the forecast period through to the third quarter of 2020 export quotations are likely to range between US$400/tonne and US$410/tonne fob, with some support from a modest tightening of supplies.

Soybeans
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global soybean consumption to increase for a ninth consecutive year in 2017/18, to a record 337m tonnes, with growth of 4% broadly matching the average of recent years. In addition to the captive use of supplies in feed and other sectors in the biggest producers, the US and Brazil, growth also reflects expanding demand for soybean meal and soybean oil in global markets, with trade in both soybean products expected to be close to record highs this year. In 2018/19, further growth in consumption is anticpated, of around 4.5%, to 352m tonnes.
The principal driver of the near-uninteruped expansion of demand over the past decade has been rising use in Asia, mostly China, underpinned by the increasing uptake in that country's vast feed sector. While the poultry, livestock and dairy sectors have made the greatest contribution, the aquaculture sector has become an increasingly important source of growth, with soybean meal the feed ingredient of choice owing to its abundance and high protein content. Soybean consumption in other regions is relatively small but has also risen steadily in recent years, with notable increases in the Middle East and Africa.
However, overall consumption growth in China is likely to moderate in 2018-19 compared with recent years, assuming that rising trade barriers cause China to reduce its purchases from the world market slightly. Nevertheless, consistent with our expectations of larger shipments by the US to other markets, growth in demand in other regions, including the EU, will compensate. Furthermore, a recovery in Argentina's production would boost supplies for local processing as consumption there rebounds.
We forecast that global trade in soybeans in 2017/18 (September/October basis) will reach 151m tonnes. Although this would be a record volume, it represents a significantly slower year-on-year expansion compared with past years owing to only a marginal increase in the volume of shipments headed to China. In 2018/19, while China's purchases may actually fall, bigger imports by other buyers should more than compensate as trade rises to 154m tonnes.
Chinese purchases of US soybeans have floundered since April as bilateral trade tensions have escalated. The impact on Chinese processors has been limited, since this period coincided with the southern hemisphere export programme. Nevertheless, even before April China's imports of US supplies were much smaller than in the previous season owing to big purchases from Brazil between October and January. More recently, Chinese demand has reportedly slowed owing to heavy stocks and an erosion of processing margins. As a result, and based on known or expected shipments through to the end of the year, deliveries to China in 2017/18 are forecast at 97m tonnes, a small year-on-year increase.
The 2018/19 trade year is characterised by a great deal of uncertainty regarding China's needs owing to the implementation of a 25% tariff on soybean imports from the US, which came into effect on July 6th. Nonetheless, the US-China trade war is unlikely to dent soybean demand significantly as China will probably source more from other origins, primarily Brazil. Additionally, industry and trade sources suggest that purchases of other feed ingredients, such as rapeseed/canola, sunflowerseed and possibly even soybean meal, could compensate for any shortfall. Nevertheless, supplies at South American origins are likely to be tighter than normal from October 2018 onwards until new crops are threshed in early 2019. As a result, it is possible that, even with the import tariffs in place, Chinese buyers will be required to source as much as 15m tonnes from the US in 2018/19-although this is well below its purchases of around 30m tonnes per year in recent years. China's total imports are forecast to fall to 95.5m tonnes in 2018/19, the first fall in eight years.
We expect China's total soybean consumption in 2017/18 to expand by a robust 8% to a record 107m tonnes, with imports accounting for around 90% of consumption. The government is working to boost local production, which is typically channelled to food sectors. Despite lower imports in 2018/19 we expect higher domestic output and some destocking to support overall consumption growth of 5% year on year to 112m tonnes.
Ample domestic supplies will support demand in the US
US soybean consumption in 2017/18 is forecast to reach an all-time high of nearly 59m tonnes, after a large crop boosted supplies for processing. In addition to local feed sector needs, strong international demand for soymeal-owing to reduced supplies from drought-hit Argentina-has boosted local crushing. We expect another large crop in 2018/19 to support further consumption growth, of 1% year on year.
In South America the outlook for consumption is weak, largely reflecting trends in Argentina, where we forecast consumption to dip by 5.4% in 2017/18-the first contraction in five seasons-after a heavily reduced crop tightened availabilities for processing. While ample domestic stocks and a reduction in export volumes have helped to ease the impact on domestic availability, some growers may hold on to inventories as export taxes are gradually reduced. In 2018/19, assuming a recovery in soybean production and with firm demand for soybean product exports, domestic processing and total consumption should rebound.

Imports are central to EU requirements
The EU has achieved successive record crops in recent seasons. Nevertheless, at less than 3m tonnes, domestic outturns represent only a tiny share of overall consumption. The remainder is typically met by imports of soybeans and soybean meal, typically accounting for up to 35m tonnes. In 2017/18 soybean imports are likely to rise after the previous season's fall. In recent months EU import demand has strengthened as buyers have taken advantage of the heavy fall in US market prices. With a poor rapeseed/canola crop on the horizon, another season of increased imports is expected in 2018/19, with consumption reaching 17m tonnes, up from 16m tonnes in the previous year.
Supply
Boosted by larger plantings in the US and Brazil as well as increases in relatively smaller players such as Canada, eastern Europe, China and the EU, global sowings are estimated to have risen by 4% year on year in 2017/18 to their highest ever level. However, with yields being compromised by adverse weather in some countries-most notably Argentina, where crops were first ravaged by drought and then impacted by heavy rains and flooding during harvesting-global production is estimated to have contracted by 3.8% year on year, to 335m tonnes. Nonetheless, this is still about 30m tonnes higher than the average of the previous five seasons. The outlook for 2018/19 is tentative, but with a further expansion of seeded area likely-led by growth in South America-output could recover to 359m tonnes, a year-on-year increase of 6.9%.
US exports are lagging behind, unrelated to trade tensions
With the 2017/18 export campaign in its final stages, cumulative shipments in the US marketing year (which began on September 1st) stood at 52.4m tonnes by July 26th, around 4.4m tonnes short of the full-year forecast, with five weeks of the season remaining. The overall tally is just 4% lower year on year and appears quite respectable, considering that exports to China have dipped significantly. Weaker Chinese demand for US supplies in recent months is partially attributable to the escalating bilateral trade war; however, it is also due to the fact that China made large purchases from Brazil in the September-January period-corresponding to the bulk of the northern hemisphere's export programme-as larger than aveage supplies in Brazil helped to suppress prices. In May-July 2018, however, US exports to markets other than China (including Argentina and markets in Asia, Africa and the EU) hit a record level, helping to avoid a greater drop in total export volumes.
The June Acreage Report of the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) was broadly in line with expectations. Based on farmer surveys in the first two weeks of June, the USDA predicted that soybean plantings would amount to a total of 36.2m ha, about 200,000 ha more than in the end-March Prospective Plantings Report and just 1% below the previous season's high. This was despite well-documented uncertainties over the prospects for US exports.
Dry weather is an increasing concern for the US crop at a key time of the season
According to the USDA's Crop Progress Report for the week ending August 5th, about two-thirds of soybean fields were rated as good/excellent. This represents a downgrade from earlier weeks, largely owing to drier than desired weather in some growing regions, including in South Dakota, Missouri, Iowa and Illinois. Nonetheless, it was still above the previous-year level, when just 60% of crops were rated good/excellent. As of early August more than 90% of fields were blooming, with three-quarters of fields setting pods-both measures are well ahead of average, indicating that crops were developing more quickly than usual. Accordingly, since August is the key month for soybean crop prospects, more precipitation is needed in many regions to ensure good yield potential.
Assuming that productivity is in line with the recent trend, US soybean production in 2018/19 is forecast to decrease by a modest 1.3% from the previous season's record outturn, to 118m tonnes. Another good harvest will provide ample supplies for export to world markets. Although the US is likely to divert a greater portion of its exports to markets other than China, given the current policy situation and its implication for US sales, we have revised down our forecast for US exports in 2018/19, to 55m tonnes (from 56.3m tonnes previously). This would be the second consecutive year of decline, although volumes would still be marginally ahead of the average of recent years.
Commitments for the 2018/19 year are well ahead of 2017/18 levels
Weekly data on US export sales show that as of July 26th cumulative commitments had already reached 10.4m tonnes-nearly 4m tonnes above the previous-year level. Data show that while sales for delivery to China had more than halved, falling to 1.3m tonnes, there were significantly larger commitments on the book for shipment to Argentina, Mexico and a number of Asian markets.
Brazil is on course to smash its existing record for exports
After progressing slowly in the first quarter of Brazil's 2018/19 local marketing year (starting February 1st), Brazil's exports have surged owing to robust demand from Asia, with volumes hitting respective monthly records in May, June and July. This was achieved despite major logistical challenges and disruption to transport flows caused by industrial action by hauliers and brought cumulative exports in 2017/18 (October-July) to more than 63m tonnes, easily the biggest amount ever dispatched in that period. This suggests that the full-year total will easily exceed 70m tonnes, despite a slowdown in spot demand from Chinese importers. Although the outlook for 2018/19 remains uncertain, we have factored in further growth in Brazil's exports to a record 75m tonnes as the US-China trade war continues, allowing Brazil to capture a larger share of China's import needs.
Brazil's 2018/19 growing season will begin amid considerable uncertainty
Brazil's soybean-free period began on June 15th in the state of Mato Grosso and other producing areas. For a period of three months no live soybean plants will be permitted anywhere-in fields, along road networks or around storage and transport hubs. This policy is meant to eliminate soybean rust disease. Following the expiry of the free period in mid-September, the 2018/19 seeding campaign will begin. However, the economic and political landscape could be challenging, with exchange-rate uncertainty, higher freight costs, US-China trade relations and the 2018 presidential election contributing to market uncertainty. The Real has fluctuated significantly against the US dollar in the first half of 2018 and is down by around one-fifth compared with same point last year. On the one hand, a weaker real could-as it has in previous years-encourage expanded acreage through higher domestic prices. Highlighting this point, although export quotations (Paranagua ports) have risen modestly, the increase in local values has been much more significant, at around 30%. While area gains may come from a shift of some area from full-season corn to soybeans in southern regions, it may also be due to the seeding of soybeans on new lands. On the other hand, however, the weaker Real will inflate production costs, including imported inputs such as fertilisers. Furthermore, higher internal freight costs would also negatively affect farmers' profitability in 2018/19.
In another recent development that could impact yields, it was reported in early August that the use of products containing the agrochemical glyphosate, a widely utilised herbicide, had been suspended. A federal judge ruled that new products containing the chemical could not be registered and existing registrations would be suspended within a month, awaiting scientific analysis.
Despite all the challenges that face Brazilian growers, we still expect soybean plantings to expand for a 12th consecutive season in 2018/19, by around 4% year on year. However, there is a risk that some growers will curb their use of inputs in order to trim costs, which could harm yields. At this stage, however, the outlook is highly tentative, and growing conditions across the whole season will be crucial. Assuming that productivity is broadly in line with trend, output in Brazil is projected at a new high of 120m tonnes.
Adverse weather conditions hamper fieldwork in Argentina
In Argentina, the 2017/18 season was one that farmers will want to forget. After hot, dry weather damaged yield potential irrecoverably, heavy rains across key growing regions led to delays to harvesting, crop losses and an erosion of quality. At 35m tonnes, production is estimated to have contracted by nearly 40% year on year. This has significantly reduced Argentina's presence in the export markets for soybeans and soybean meal-despite unusually heavy purchases of soybeans from the US and Paraguay for local processing. Soybean exports in 2017/18 are expected to total only 3m tonnes, the smallest volume in many years and less than half the amount shipped in 2016/17.
A larger area and improved yields should boost output in 2018/19
Prospects for Argentina's crop in 2018/19 are highly provisional, given that the onset of early fieldwork in central parts is about two months away. Our forecasts are based on the assumption that production rebounds if weather patterns are favourable and that the government does not renege on its commitment to gradually reduce export taxes on soybeans by 0.5 percentage points per month through to the end of 2019. Local soybean prices are significantly higher than the previous year, owing to tighter supplies and local currency depreciation against the US dollar. As in Brazil, this is likely to encourage an increase in the planted area. However, yield potential will be uncertain, since the current difficult economic and financial background means that farmers will be much more cost-conscious and could be tempted to scale back expenditure on some inputs, such as fertilisers. Nevertheless, based on potential area expansion, output is tentatively expected to reach 54m tonnes in 2018/19.
Uruguay is a relatively small player among South America's soybean producers. In the 2017/18 season production is estimated to have contracted significantly, to less than 2m tonnes (from 3.3m tonnes in the previous season), owing to the impact of harsh climatic conditions. As in Argentina, growers grappled with hot and dry weather in early 2018, and since this is the time when crops are setting pods, this resulted in area losses and a heavy reduction in yield potential. In some cases there were reports of average productivity being as low as 0.5 tonnes/ha. Growers later had to contend with excessive rains. As a result, the government has declared a national agricultural emergency and activated a fund to assist the worst-affected producers.
Uruguay is a small producer, with the bulk of its supplies exported to China
Since domestic consumption of soybeans in Uruguay is marginal, the bulk of the country's crop is exported, with China by far the largest market. Other destinations include Europe and Argentina, as well as North Africa and the US. Prospects for 2018/19 are uncertain at this early stage, as the seeding campaign is months away. However, based on average productivity and an area of 1.2m ha, output may recover to 3m tonnes.
Paraguay is a small but important exporter
Paraguay is a modest but important exporter of soybeans to a range of world markets. Output has sometimes varied sharply from one season to the next but has generally trended up over the past decade. Despite increasing local consumption, this has resulted in bigger surpluses for export. Furthermore, the expansion of domestic soybean use as a result of increased processing reflects growing international demand for soybean products.
Record exports are likely in 2017/18 owing to strong Argentinian demand
In 2017/18 farmers in Paraguay planted 500,000 ha of zafrina soybeans, following on from 3.5m ha of the much more important primary (zafra) crop. However, with yields from the zafrina crop potentially below expectations, production in 2017/18 fell slightly year on year, to 9.9m tonnes. The EU is the main market for Paraguay, accounting for between 30% and 40% of all shipments, while sales to the Commonwealth of Independent states (CIS), mainly Russia, have risen strongly in response to rising local demand in the region. Elsewhere, markets in Latin America are also important. Based on the current pace of exports, mainly to Argentina, we now expect 2017/18 exports to reach a record high of 6.6m tonnes, up from 5.3m tonnes in the previous season. In the following year a tentative recovery in production is expected, but shipments may dip as Argentina's import demand falls back to normal levels.
Production in China is rising but still accounts for a small share of demand
China is by far the world's largest importer but only a minor producer of soybeans. However, potential has been capped over the years by limited yield gains compared with those of the world's big players, as well as the attraction of alternative crops such as wheat, maize and rice. Nonetheless, the government is keen to boost production of oilseeds, particularly soybeans, at the expense of corn in north-eastern areas as part of a supply-side adjustment programme. To this end, Jilin and Heiliongjiang provinces issued orders in early 2018 to increase soybean planting with the promise of public financial support. Based on an area increase of about 14% year on year, production in China in 2018/19 is projected to reach a ten-year high of 15.5m tonnes. Nevertheless, this still equates to only a small portion of overall domestic needs, the bulk of which are served by imports channelled to the country's vast feed sector.
According to the India Meteorological Department, the government forecaster, cumulative monsoon precipitation in 2018 (since June 1st) was 10% below the long-term average as of August 8th, with data for the country's important states for the cultivation of soybeans, Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan and Maharashtra, showing a similar picture. Despite somewhat disappinting rains sowings are well advanced, with government data pegging progress complete on 11m ha by August 3rd, ahead of the year-earlier performance and the five-year average. This was in contrast to rice, the main kharif crop, which was slightly behind on both measures. Based on an expected modest expansion of area for the full season and on the assumption that the monsoon is broadly favourable, production is projected at 12m tonnes, up by 9% year on year.

Stocks and prices
Following the previous season's exceptionally strong gains, global ending stocks are forecast to remain fairly flat in 2017/18, at about 120m tonnes-the largest on record and equivalent to a stocks/use ratio of 36%. While we expect some drawdown in stocks in South America, mostly in Argentina, this should be offset by a heavy increase in the US. Elsewhere, a modest fall in stocks is likely in China as consumption continues to rise and import volumes dip. In 2018/19 the global soybean market is expected to tip back into surplus, led by increases in Argentina-assuming a much improved crop-and the US.
At the time of writing there remains a great deal of uncertainty surrounding world soybean markets, owing in part to rising global trade tensions. Following the Chinese government's imposition of a 25% tariff on imports of US soybeans on July 6th, the Chicago soybean futures market fell to just US$8.14/bushel in mid-July, the lowest level in almost ten years. However, this appeared to be an overreaction, and prices rose higher over the next two weeks to reach a monthly net increase of 5%. Signs of firmer demand from other buyers, including the EU, have helped to shore up prices in recent weeks. Nevertheless, nearby futures were still trading at around 17% below the 2018 peak (recorded in early March), reflecting market concerns about future demand.
There were contrasting trends in export quotations in the past four weeks. With export premiums easing somewhat more recently on worries about future demand prospects, fob quotations at Gulf ports were up by a relatively modest 3%, to US$343/tonne. In contrast, offers in South America remained high. Export premiums in Brazil have rocketed higher on prospects for additional demand from China as that country scales back purchases from the US. After initially falling, basis levels in Brazil moved higher. Together with gains in US futures, export prices (Paranagua) were up by 5% over the month, to US$403/tonne-some US$60 higher than at Gulf ports. However, at that level there was very little interest from Chinese crushers, with many covered until October owing to ample domestic stocks and depressed margins.
In Argentina, basis levels were also firmer compared with a month ago, with Up River prices for export at about US$394/tonne fob, representing a month-on-month increase of around 7%. With the country's exportable surplus having been dramatically reduced by the smallest outturn in around a decade, quotations were largely nominal.
