Sugar
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that global annual sugar consumption will expand by an average of 1.2% per year in 2017/18-2018/19 (years ending September 30th)-below the annual average of 1.7% growth recorded over the previous five seasons. Increasing global consumption will continue to be underpinned by population growth and rising incomes in emerging markets, where urbanising populations are adopting the food and drink habits of developed countries. Sugar plays a key role in this dietary shift as a sweetener in food and beverages and a binding and preserving agent in processed foods.
However, the slowdown in demand growth stems from several factors, which are likely to remain in play over the medium term. Heightened awareness of the health implications of excess sugar in diets is putting pressure on consumption growth amid consumer calls for the food processing industry to reduce sugar and, in an increasing number of markets, the introduction of "sin taxes" on sugary products. These taxes have the potential to suppress sugar demand, although their impact will vary according to the level of taxation, the rigour of implementation and the elasticity of consumer demand. In addition, the growing supply of cheaper, starch-based alternative sweeteners in both Asia (where Chinese production is expanding rapidly) and Europe (where the market was liberalised in September 2017) will limit demand for sugar in the food and drinks industry. Meanwhile, the impact of low global sugar prices on demand will be muted by long-standing domestic pricing policies, which will limit the extent to which lower prices pass through to consumers.
China will remain a key consumer, but growth is set to moderate
Demand in China will continue to expand more rapidly than the global average. However, we expect the rate of growth to moderate, to 2.4% in 2017/18 and 2.2% in 2018/19, as the market matures. Consumption growth will also be held back by the growing supply of starch-based sweeteners and rising concerns among wealthier consumers about the health implications of excess sugar in diets.
Import demand will be constrained by higher domestic output and the government's protectionist policy agenda. Amid pressure from domestic producers to support the local industry, the government reduced import permits in mid-2017 to 1m tonnes/year (t/y), roughly half the previous level, and raised duties on some out-of-quota sugar imports from 50% to 95% in May 2017. Initially these tariffs applied only to imports from the largest global producers, but the rules were amended in August to apply 90% duty to all out-of-quota imports. Sugar imports fell by 25% year on year in 2017 to their lowest level since 2010, and even assuming China grants some tariff exemptions, a further drop is likely in 2018-19. However, China will be unable to scale up domestic production anytime soon to a level that could fully satisfy its domestic demand and preserve its strategically high levels of stocks. It will therefore continue to make purchases overseas, and with prices higher in China than the global norm, the country will remain a reasonably attractive export destination.
Urbanisation and income growth will drive Indian consumption
Potential consumption growth in India has been constrained in recent years by unsupportive policy moves (including the removal of some consumer subsidies) and high prices following the drought in the 2016/17 season. However, domestic prices have fallen sharply since mid-2017 as domestic production has rebounded. Amid pressure from producers to support prices, the government has hiked import duties, imposed stockholding limits on mills and approved plans to create a buffer stock of some 3m tonnes. These measures, coupled with the onset of the festive season in mid-2018 and a recovery of demand among bulk consumers, have lifted domestic prices. Even so, we expect domestic prices to remain well below the levels recorded in 2016-17. This subdued price environment, together with rising incomes and further urbanisation, will support consumption growth, with demand forecast to reach 25.7m tonnes in 2018/19, growing by 2% year on year.
Demand growth elsewhere in Asia is threatened by starch-based rivals
Beyond China and India, the outlook for sugar consumption in Asia is mixed. Demand growth in the more developed countries (such as Malaysia and South Korea) is expected to slow, but rising income in populous developing countries (such as Indonesia, the Philippines and Vietnam) will offset this. However, even in these developing countries demand will be tempered somewhat by policy moves. Tax measures to ensure that sugar consumption remains within recommended health guidelines will soften demand growth, with Thailand and the Philippines introducing sugar taxes in recent months. Several other Asian countries are considering similar moves, and the prospect of a tax hike will limit investment in sugar-reliant food- and drink-manufacturing industries. Sugar demand will be further dampened by a gradual shift in the food and drink industry towards cheaper, starch-based sweeteners as China (Asia's largest producer of such sweeteners) seeks export markets. In light of these pressures, we expect demand growth in Asia (excluding China and India) to moderate to a yearly average of 2% in 2017/18-2018/19, down from average annual growth of 2.7% growth over the previous five years.
Health warnings may eventually dent developed-world demand
The liberalisation of the EU's sugar regime in September 2017-when production quotas, guaranteed farm-gate prices and export caps were abolished-has limited the need for imports and brought European sugar prices (which have historically traded at a premium) closer to the global norm. Although lower prices should support demand, the production of isoglucose (a starch-based alternative to sugar) was also liberalised in 2017, and this is likely to gradually steal market share in the sweetener industry. Indeed, Europe's largest beet producer, Germany's Südzucker, has announced plans to start making a sweetener with a lower sugar content.
Health concerns are spurring this shift away from sugar. In many EU countries average consumption levels of sugar are already far higher than recommended by the World Health Organisation (WHO). In an effort to tackle this, in April the UK introduced a tax on sugary drinks, and the French government intends to hike its so-called soda tax in 2018. The WHO scrapped its non-binding recommendation to impose a sugar tax in May, calling instead on governments to improve labelling and regulate the marketing of sugary products. Regardless of policy interventions, we expect consumer pressure to make manufacturers wary of using excess sugar in their products. This will reduce sugar consumption over the medium term, and we expect sugar demand to remain broadly flat in 2017/18-2018/19-despite low prices, population growth and rising incomes.
Changing consumer tastes will boost demand growth in Africa
African consumption will continue to increase on the back of population growth, rising incomes and urbanisation. Several countries (including Nigeria, the region's largest importer, as well as Kenya and Ghana) are pursuing long-term investment plans in the sugar sector in the hope of becoming self-sufficient. However, inefficient domestic supply chains will impede the development of Africa's sugar industries, and most will be unable to compete with cheap imports. Aggregate import demand from Sub-Saharan Africa is therefore expected to remain well above 5m t/y in 2017/18-2018/19. Nonetheless, demand growth will be limited by logistical bottlenecks in some African markets. A sugar tax came into effect in South Africa in April 2018, but amid pressure from food and drink manufacturers it has been set at just 10%, and we doubt that it will have a significant impact on overall sugar demand.
Policy changes will shift global sugar trade dynamics
The overhaul in 2017 by the EU of its sugar policy will drive its emergence as a net exporter. Exporters in the EU will focus in the near term on capturing market share in European countries with a sugar deficit. This will limit exports from the EU to the global market but will also crowd non-EU producers out of the European market. The smaller producers, particularly in Africa and the Caribbean, which supply the EU under preferential trade deals, will be hit hardest by this shift. Some smaller producers have increased their market share in China since the May 2017 tariff regime was introduced, but they are unlikely to retain this market under the new rules. Several producers (notably India) are, however, hoping to negotiate tariff exemptions with China. Elsewhere in Asia, trade patterns will be influenced by the liberalisation of sugar sales under the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) free-trade agreement, which will probably cause less efficient producers (such as Vietnam) to rely more heavily on imports from elsewhere in the region (probably Thailand). Intra-regional trade in North America is likely to increase following a trade deal agreed by the US and Mexico in mid-2017.

Supply
We expect global sugar production to increase sharply in 2017/18, by 11.7% year on year, supported by another year of strong production in Brazil (the world's largest producer) as well as favourable crop-growing conditions in key producing countries in Asia and longer processing seasons in Europe. This is generating the largest global surplus in several years and is weighing heavily on prices. Most of the world's sugar producers are therefore failing to break even. Cane is being diverted to other industrial uses, notably ethanol production, where possible, but financial pressures will put some mills out of business over the coming years. However, this is unlikely to bring the market back into balance in 2018/19. Increased cane acreage and greater access to high-yielding inputs will deliver another strong harvest in 2018/19 in most markets. We therefore expect production to remain well above the five-year average, at 180.5m tonnes. The modest decline in global output, of 3.7%, is driven almost entirely by a drop in supply from Brazil, whose market share is forecast to fall to 19%, from 23% in 2012/13, as millers in that country are able to divert cane to the more profitable production of ethanol. Adding to this, drought in Brazil's crucial Centre South region and low investment in crop care are damaging the harvest, prompting to a downward revision to our projected Brazilian output in 2018/19.
Trade deals and policy measures will shift the direction of global trade flows, but trade volumes will ultimately be defined by production levels in countries such as India, which swing between being importers and exporters. The bulk of India's output is consumed domestically, but a strong post-drought crop recovery in 2017/18 is likely to lead to higher exports; much of this will probably go to emerging markets with costly local production. However, with domestic prices in India having rebounded fairly strongly in recent months (significantly above global prices), producers are reluctant to export, and overseas sales in 2017/18 are likely to be relatively small. In 2018/19, though, high stocks and a subsequent year of domestic oversupply will force exports from India sharply upwards. Shaped by these dynamics, we expect trade to edge up only slightly in 2017/18, to 59.2m tonnes, before increasing more sharply in 2018/19 to 60m tonnes. These levels of trade are higher than the average over the previous five years. There is, however, a downside risk of further protectionism in the sugar industry as governments attempt to shield their local manufacturers from cheap imports, and this could act as a major weight on trade flows.
Output in Brazil will be determined by price dynamics
Brazil had a strong cane harvest in the local 2017/18 season (April-March), and the diversion of cane to the sugar industry was above the historical norm of 44%, at around 46%. Production is therefore forecast to remain relatively high, at 38m tonnes in 2017/18 (compared with an average of 37.7m tonnes over the past five years). We then expect production to decline fairly sharply in 2018/19, by around 6m tonnes, amid drought in the crucial Centre South regions, a lack of investment in aging cane fields and low global sugar prices. Although these price pressures will be felt among sugar producers worldwide, we expect a drop in sugar output to be particularly pronounced in Brazil, because its producers can easily switch to ethanol production.
However, ethanol production cannot absorb all of the country's cane supply, and domestic prices of the biofuel are already tumbling as demand fails to keep pace with surging supply. There is a risk that ethanol prices will drop below sugar prices, particularly if the newly elected government caps fuel prices, which would prompt producers to switch back to sugar and sell more supplies into the saturated global market. However, this is not our central forecast, based on the assumption that oil prices will remain relatively high (thereby boosting demand for ethanol in Brazil) and that the depreciation of the Real will be fairly modest (thereby failing to provide a significant incentive for dollar-denominated sugar exports).
A strong post-drought crop revival is expected in India
Production in India is expected to reach an all-time high of 31.2m tonnes in 2017/18, amid favourable growing conditions. However, producers are unable to break even in the current price environment, and millers' arrears to farmers are estimated to have reached some US$3.5bn. The government has provided a bail-out package to millers, but this covers just 40% of existing arrears. Some casualties (particularly among the most debt-ridden mills) are likely, and the government will remain under political pressure from both millers and farmers to intervene.
Policies designed to restore balance in the local industry include removing export duties, setting a price floor for domestic sugar prices, subsidising a portion of millers' contracts with farmers and subsiding loans to increase ethanol production capacity. These measures are yet to have much impact on the level of oversupply or prices, however. The government is attempting to find new export markets, but low global prices mean that producers will still struggle to break even. With the government in effect subsidising an over-supplied and unprofitable domestic market, it will eventually have to allow some producers to fail. However, this correction will not happen in 2018/19, and with cane supply set to remain plentiful, we expect sugar production to remain high by historical standards, at 30m tonnes in 2018/19.
Brisk EU production growth following sectoral liberalisation
In Europe, sugar output is poised for brisk growth as producers take advantage of the lifting of the EU's 50-year-old sugar quota system. Under the new regime, which came into effect at the start of the 2017/18 season, producers (led by France and Germany) will extend their crush seasons, thereby making better use of existing capacity without significant additional investments. This will be supported by favourable weather conditions and higher supplies of beet, with some integrated sugar companies reporting that the area under cultivation has been increased by 15% year on year in 2017/18. Cane supply will remain high in 2018/19 owing to the large acreage under plantation, and this will sustain decent production of 19.6m tonnes in 2018/19. However, European producers are struggling to break even in the current price environment, with Südzucker reporting a 49% drop in profits in the first quarter of 2018. Weak global prices, coupled with the fact that the liberalisation of the sugar industry has removed the premium at which European sugar was previously traded, will eventually force some producers out of the market.
In Russia, production will continue to benefit from the significant investments that have been made in modernising sugar factories in recent years. After favourable growing conditions in 2017/18 led to record-high production, though, both cane acreage and yields are expected to fall in 2018/19, thereby dampening sugar output. Production will continue to exceed domestic consumption, but soft demand in Central Asia (Russia's main market) will lessen its export potential.
Output in Thailand is recovering but pressures are mounting
Thai sugar production is surging as both crop acreage and yields exceed the long-run averages. We expect output to reach a record-high of 13.4m tonnes in 2017/18, before dipping slightly in 2018/19 to 13.1m tonnes as more cane is diverted to the production of ethanol. This diversion reflects mounting pressures in the sugar industry, which was formally liberalised in early 2018 after Brazil successfully argued that Thailand was violating World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules on free competition. Quotas for sugar production will therefore be phased out and the domestic price-fixing system will be revoked. Mills are, however, still obliged to reimburse farmers if the final sale price drops below a pre-agreed level. This protects farmers from global volatility, but with global prices at their current lows, mills are struggling to turn a profit. This will lead to some consolidation in the industry. Moreover, weather-related risks are rising as farming moves towards more drought-prone interior regions.
China's output will rise but will still fall short of government targets
After falling sharply in 2013/14-2016/17 owing to adverse weather conditions and the impact of rapidly rising costs for labour, land and farm machinery, China's sugar output recovered in 2017/18 on the back of more favourable rains and some government support in the form of soft loans. However, producers are still operating at a loss. Production costs have increased owing to higher prices for fertilisers and pesticides, and prices have come under pressure from a rebound in local output and global oversupply. Indeed, Chinese sugar futures reached a nine-year low in July. The government has been quick to intervene to protect local producers by hiking import duties. The latest tariff hike is unlikely to have much impact in 2017/18 as the requisite imports have already been purchased, but it should provide some support to domestic prices in 2018/19. Even so, prices will remain too low to spur much investment in the sector. In addition, the sector is dominated by smallholder farmers, labour costs are high, and sugarcane areas do not lend themselves to mechanisation. We therefore expect that China will fall far short of achieving the 10% annual supply growth that would be needed for the state to meet its medium-term production goals. Nevertheless, owing to more favourable growing conditions we expect output to rise modestly, to an annual average of 10.4m t/y in 2017/18-2018/19.

Stocks and prices
After successive supply deficits and a period of relatively high global prices, global sugar stocks shrank to 87.4m tonnes at end-2016/17. As the market swings back into a significant surplus, which is forecast at 14m tonnes in 2017/18, we expect stocks to recover to their highest levels in over five years, at 101.4m tonnes. Another surplus in 2018/19, although smaller at 4.6m tonnes, will push global stocks to 106.1m tonnes. Amid subdued consumption growth, the stocks ratio is forecast to exceed 60% by 2018/19. Even so, the uneven distribution of these stock reserves will not always be available to the market, and occasional supply squeezes are possible.

Prices will drift higher, but slowly and from a low base
The prospect of significant oversupply in the sugar industry over the coming years is heaping pressure on prices. Global sugar prices fell to an average of 16 US cents/lb in 2017, down by 11.3% year on year and more than 30% lower than the 2016 peak of 23 US cents/lb. Prices have remained under significant pressure in the first half of 2018, dropping to a four-year low of 11.14 US cents/lb in April. The lacklustre price recovery in mid-2018 was short-lived, with prices falling back to 11.24 US cents/lb in late July as expectations of muted global demand set in.
Brazil is the only producer able to act as a shock absorber, given millers' ability to divert significant cane supply to ethanol production when prices drop. However, owing to Brazil's falling market share, this is insufficient to raise prices, and the link between ethanol/sugar price parity has therefore become less significant globally as a floor on sugar prices. As a result, prices are forecast to remain under considerable pressure in the coming months. Far-reaching policy interventions by Asian governments are also likely to keep unprofitable producers in the market and delay the market correction.
However, we retain our view that prices will gradually drift higher over the next three years. We expect the sugar-trading market to begin pricing in more risk, particularly as regions highly exposed to weather shocks gain prominence in global supply. More fundamentally, the market will gradually tighten over the medium term as costlier producers are forced out of the market. With traders taking their price cues from markets some two years ahead, this will provide some support to prices. Overall, we expect prices to average 12.6 US cents/lb in 2018, before a gradual recovery to 14 US cents/lb by early 2020. Risks to this forecast are to the upside, as weather-related disruption in South America, Asia or Europe could tighten markets and lift prices much more sharply.

Sunflowerseed oil
Demand
Global sunflowerseed oil consumption growth was always likely to slow in 2017/18, following record year-on-year growth of 15.1% in 2016/17. Nonetheless, consumption continues to outperform our expectations, and we now expect overall consumption in 2017/18 to expend by some 2.6% on the previous year, reaching 18.7m tonnes. This momentum is likely to be maintained into the 2018/19 season, with consumption expanding by a further 3.3% as sunflowerseed oil remains competitive against other oils. That said, lower production expectations may constrain growth somewhat in 2018/19.
Improving price competitiveness will boost EU usage
The price discount of sunflowerseed oil to rapeseed oil continues to widen, although soybean oil has become more competitive. Consumption in the EU remains buoyant, with a further increase in our 2017/18 consumption estimate to 4.7m tonnes. In 2018/19, however, consumption may be constrained by local availability. Although imports could conceivably cover some of this gap, at this stage we expect overall consumption to rise by only 1.4% on 2017/18 levels. Trends in soybean oil prices, following US-China trade tariff changes, are likely to have a strong influence on sunflowerseed consumption levels.
Russian consumption set to rise in 2018/19 with higher local output
Sunflowerseed oil is the main vegetable oil consumed in Russia, and changes in local availability influence consumption levels. Local availability is tighter in 2017/18 than in the previous season owing to lower domestic output and a firm pace of exports. This has been reflected in higher local prices, which have also dampened demand. Our forecast of 2017/18 consumption is unchanged. We expect consumption growth to resume in 2018/19, supported by higher domestic production and continued GDP growth. However, changes to trans-fat regulations may discourage the use of sunflowerseed oil in the margarine sector. We currently expect 2018/19 consumption to exceed 2.5m tonnes, representing growth of more than 5%.
Transhipment into India increases
India's previously robust pace of sunflowerseed imports began to slow in early 2018, reflecting the imposition of higher import tariffs. However, import levels have since risen again. In part this is attributable to a loophole in India's import tariff arrangements, which allow duty-free imports via countries such as Bangladesh and Sri Lanka. Transhipment of oils through these locations is reported to be rising. The impact of the higher tariff rates will depend on the extent to which the transhipment trade develops. At present, we are retaining a relatively cautious forecast of 1.7% growth in consumption in 2018/19.
Consumption growth to moderate in "other" countries in 2017/18
Many countries, including Turkey, Iran, Iraq and Egypt as well as several other smaller states, increased their purchases of sunflowerseed oil to take advantage of competitive prices. Their imports have now slowed, and total consumption of these "other" countries is likely to remain at very similar levels to 2016/17. With sunflowerseed oil production still expected to increase in 2018/19, consumption in these other countries is expected to resume its upward trend, albeit more slowly than previously projected.

Supply
Although we still expect global sunflowerseed oil production to drop in 2017/18, the reduction is relatively small from the record levels seen in 2016/17, with output projected at 18.7m tonnes, as against 18.9m tonnes in 2016/17. With sunflowerseed stocks likely to be below average at the end of the season, 2018/19 sunflowerseed oil production will be more than usually reliant on harvest results. Recent developments in the main growing areas suggest that the 2018/19 harvest will be another large one, exceeding that of the record 2016/17 outturn. There is a need to rebuild sunflowerseed stock levels, but sunflower-seed oil production should still exceed 19m tonnes.
Crush rates improve slightly
Following a mid-season slowdown, crushing activity in Ukraine continues to run marginally above expectations following an improved export outlook for sunflowerseed oil. We have thus revised up our forecast for Ukrainian production in 2017/18. Output will remain below last season's total but will still be the second-highest total ever achieved, reflecting the high base of comparison in 2016/17. The sunflowerseed area for 2018/19 is 3% larger than in 2017/18, despite earlier concerns that falling profit margins would act as a disincentive to farmers. That said, persistent dry conditions in some regions have raised concerns over likely yields. Field reports suggest that sunflowerseed crops are only in fair condition, and most estimates put the total crop at around 14.5m tonnes. This should ensure sufficient raw material to boost sunflowerseed oil output by some 7.3%, but production levels will remain below those seen in 2016/17. With sunflowerseed stocks at low levels, any further downgrading of harvest estimates will have an immediate impact on likely sunflowerseed oil production.
Russia's 2018-19 crop could be constrained by dry conditions
In Russia, crush rates continue to be consistent with our forecast of just above 4.5m tonnes of sunflowerseed oil production in 2017/18: low stocks of sunflowerseed mean that only a small upward revision of this forecast is possible. Planting conditions for the 2018/19 season have been favourable, and a record area has been planted. Normal yields would give a crop of more than 12m tonnes. However, dry conditions in southern Russia are causing some concerns over crop development, and we have thus cut our forecast of 2018/19 sunflowerseed oil output to just over 4.7m tonnes. This would still constitute a new record high but would only just exceed 2016/17 levels.
The outlook for the 2017/18 EU sunflowerseed crop remains firm
The record 2017/18 sunflowerseed crop and high carry-in stocks have supported substantial growth in EU sunflowerseed oil production. Likely 2017/18 production of 3.6m tonnes is easily a new record and more than 10% above 2016/17 output. While sowings were delayed, the area for 2018/19 is estimated to be virtually the same as in 2017/18. Normal yields would give another crop of above 9m tonnes, although this would not be as large as last season's record. In contrast with northern Europe, there has been good rainfall in south-central and south-eastern Europe, where much of the sunflowerseed crop is grown. Some observers are already suggesting above-average yields, although they are unlikely to equal those achieved in 2017/18. We have increased our forecast for EU sunflowerseed oil production slightly in 2018/19 to almost the same level as in 2017/18.
Prospects for Argentina's crop remain positive
There is no change to our forecast that Argentinean sunflowerseed production will reach 1.4m tonnes in 2017/18. We continue to expect the planted area to expand in 2018/19, especially given reported difficulties in planting other crops. More normal yields in 2018/19 would result in a crop of just above 4m tonnes. On this basis, we expect sunflowerseed oil production to rise by some 10% that year, supporting higher export levels. Local crushing could be higher if the industry is successful in its efforts to reopen access to the EU market for sunflowerseed oil.

Stocks and prices
Although global sunflowerseed stocks at end-2017/18 will be plentiful, they will be lower than at the end of the 2016/17 season. Current projections suggest that the 2018/19 season will see a further reduction in sunflowerseed oil stocks to just above average levels. However, seed stocks are likely to drop to very low levels during the 2017/18 season before recovering during the 2018/19 season. If crush rates fall below the level we are currently expecting, sunflowerseed oil stocks are likely to be drawn down to meet demand.

Upward pressure on prices is likely to be felt from mid-2019 onward
Helped by strong rapeseed oil prices, prices for sunflowerseed oil increased in July, virtually wiping out the previous months' decline. With comfortable production and stock levels, we expect that prices will tend to be easier over the next two quarters, although any price declines will be small. During 2019 prices should increase as sunflowerseed oil stocks fall and rapeseed oil prices rise further. However, any gains will be constrained by the increase in sunflowerseed stocks and a weak soybean oil market. From the second half of 2019 prices should again be above US$800/tonne.

Tea
Demand
Global tea consumption is growing steadily, driven mainly by China, which accounts for nearly 40% of world tea consumption and is consuming ever-greater quantities of green tea. However, demand is growing in other major consuming regions as well, including India, which has offset weaker growth in demand in Europe. Despite press coverage of strengthening consumer demand for high-end luxury tea, this accounts for only a tiny share of the market, with lower-cost varieties continuing to dominate. As such, demand for tea will remain less exposed to economic cycles than other commodities, meaning that tea demand will remain driven principally by demographics. This explains why The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecast for tea consumption growth, of 4.7% a year on average in 2018-19, is relatively high and in line with the long-term historical average. It also explains why our demand-side forecasts tend to remain relatively stable, since consumption of tea is driven by structural factors to a much greater degree than other beverages.
Global demand for black tea will continue to rise, driven in particular by its increasing popularity in China, but the pace of growth will be outstripped by that for green tea, fruit tea, herbal tea, rooibos (from South Africa), purple tea (mainly from Kenya) and high-end organic tea, reflecting their greater reported health benefits and heavy marketing. Iced tea and other "ready to drink" tea beverages account for a small share of the market but have seen rapid growth in sales-notably in the US, but also in traditional markets such as China.
Tea demand will benefit from changing consumer habits
The main tea-consuming countries are also the largest producers, with a rising share of output retained for domestic consumption, partly reflecting domestic marketing campaigns by various tea boards to promote tea-drinking. The premise behind these efforts is that higher domestic consumption will incentivise producers to lift output in order to raise exports. In producing countries tea will also benefit from changing consumption habits related to rising incomes, but in most places it will continue to remain a consumer staple. The fact that a smaller share of tea than coffee is consumed in the out-of-home sector-owing partly to customer perceptions that tea in cafés offers less value for money-will shield tea consumption from adverse economic developments, which tend to have less of an impact on at-home consumption.
Both India and China will continue to see robust demand growth in 2018-19
Tea consumption will remain dominated by Asian consumers, particularly China and India, which together accounted for an estimated 57% of global demand in 2017, up from 48% in 2010. In China, where growth in tea consumption has averaged over 10% per year in the past decade, we expect tea demand to continue to rise firmly, albeit by a more moderate average of 7.5% per year in 2018-19. Despite this strong growth projection, risks to our forecast are primarily to the upside; average consumption per head stands at just over 1 kg/year, ranking China 14th in the world. This leaves room for growth, particularly as only around 35% of the population drinks tea.
Given that tea is regarded as a traditional drink, it will suffer from mounting com-petition from coffee and soft-drinks retailers, owing to a growing preference for these beverages among younger Chinese consumers. Moreover, younger segments of the population are also showing a preference for black tea over green tea (black tea consumption has risen by an average of 26% per year since 2008, while green tea consumption has risen more gradually), which should bolster demand for black tea, albeit from a low base. Although ready-to-drink products are gaining market share, particularly in cities, the importance attached to the quality of tea means that sales of loose-leaf tea will continue to dominate the local market.
The latest actual UN data also show a sharp increase in India's tea consumption in 2016, to 1.05m tonnes, accounting for 19% of global tea demand. We estimate that consumption rose by a further 5% in 2017. In 2018-19 we expect strong economic growth to be accompanied by higher household spending, firm consumer confidence and supportive demographics, driving annual average growth in tea consumption of 6% in 2018-19. Structurally, the Indian market has significant potential-aside from its sheer size, average consumption per head is lower than in China, at just 740 g per year, which bodes well for longer-term demand growth. Currently the out-of-home sector accounts for just under 50% of tea consumption, compared with 85% of the coffee market. The expansion of tea bars across many cities aims to lift this share, as well as fuelling overall tea consumption growth.

Structural constraints will hamper tea consumption growth in many markets
Demand in some large consuming countries will be hampered in 2018-19 by market saturation and weakening demographics. The UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) forecasts an overall stagnation until 2027 in European markets (which together account for 4% of global consumption), despite a firmer economic performance, as well as in Russia, which accounts for 2.5% of global consumption and is the world's largest tea importer. Turkey, which accounts for around 4% of global consumption, has a particularly saturated market, with the highest consumption of tea per head in the world by some margin. The EU also registers some of the world's highest per-capita levels, particularly in the UK and Ireland. Although our forecasts anticipate further growth in demand, reflecting population growth and steady growth in private consumption, the pace will be fairly mild. In 2018-19 we forecast average annual demand growth of 0.8% in the EU and 0.5% in Turkey. Russian demand growth will be stronger, at an average of 2.1% per year in 2018-19, but this is flattered by a weak base of comparison following a sharp decline in consump-tion in 2013-16.
There is plenty of room for market growth in the US
The US is a small market for tea, accounting for just 2.5% of global consumption, and per-capita consumption is relatively low. However, with most of the larger tea markets dominated by loose-leaf tea, the US remains one of the most important single markets for instant tea and iced tea, with the latter accounting for 85% of the country's total tea consumption. It also remains one of the world's largest tea importers. We expect demand to increase by an annual average of 2.6% in 2018-19, partly reflecting our fairly upbeat forecast for US economic growth. Health concerns will also sustain demand for tea, with a continued shift away from carbonated drinks towards other beverages.
Supply
Data from many of the main domestic tea boards for 2017 (aside from China, where data are unavailable) indicate that global tea production continued to rise, but at a comparatively weak rate of 2.8%, with overall growth hampered by three principal factors: weaker growth in China, a sharp fall in output in Kenya and marginal growth in India. We expect global production to accelerate in 2018-19, rising by 3.3% in both years (a downgrade from our previous forecast of 3.8% and 4.1% respectively, reflecting a revision to our projections for tea production in China). The pace of global tea production growth will be lower than in recent years (tea production growth averaged 4.5% per year in 2006-16), with several structural factors preventing faster production growth during the forecast period. In inflation-adjusted terms, farmers' profits are lower than in past decades owing to the higher cost of inputs, which will weigh on investment. In some cases, falling real earnings mean that smallholders' incomes place them within international and national measures of poverty. Investment will also be hampered by overall market perceptions that prospects for longer-term global consumption growth are weaker than those for some other, more fashionable beverages such as coffee, despite the fact that global tea consumption growth will remain fairly strong. In addition, many local currencies will remain weak against the US dollar in 2018-19, which will hamper operating conditions for farmers.
Until recently we had believed that there were downside risks to our projections related to the La Niña weather phenomenon that could have brought unusually cold temperatures to some Chinese tea-growing regions, drought to Kenya and very wet conditions to Vietnam. However, the recent La Niña event appears to have ended after a short-lived and mild episode, removing the risk of a sharper drop in tea production in 2018-19.
Much of the forecast growth in 2018-19 will come from a rise in green tea output, where growth has outpaced black tea by a significant margin in recent years. Green tea now accounts for one-third of total global tea production, compared with less than one-quarter a decade ago. This mainly reflects rising production in China, where loose-leaf green tea accounts for 68% of domestic production, and in Vietnam, where it now represents 55% of tea output, up from 43% a decade ago. We expect these trends to continue in 2018-19.
Structural efforts in China to bolster tea production
China's tea production rose to 2.4m tonnes in 2016, implying annual growth of around 7%. Output expanded by an estimated 3.5% in 2017 after heavy rains hit several of the large tea-producing provinces in southern China in June, including Hunan, Jiangxi and Zhejiang. The rains were followed by extremely hot weather in some areas (including parts of Zhejiang), which is likely to have hampered production.
We have downgraded our forecast for tea production growth this month; although we still expect growth to pick up from 2017, the pace of expansion will be weaker than previously expected (an annual average of 4.6% in 2018-19, compared with 6% previously). This reflects broader government efforts to improve the enforcement of environmental regulations, with local authorities destroying illegally planted tea bushes. Although we do not believe that these efforts will escalate to a level that would lead to a decline in tea production, it will take the edge of what had previously been extremely strong levels of tea production growth, at an average of 9.1% per year in 2004-16. Despite the tighter enforcement of environmental regulations, the government will still seek to foster increased agricultural productivity. A focus on eliminating rural poverty is likely to be accompanied by continued efforts to improve farmers' access to credit from the Agricultural Development Bank of China, the Agricultural Bank of China and rural credit co-operatives.
Official efforts to promote innovation, increase the use of technology and lift quality standards will also help to spur production, and better availability and quality should boost exports (only about 15% of tea production was exported in 2016). Germany and the US are China's main tea export markets; although trade relations with the US have deteriorated in recent months, tea has not been included in the list of items attracting US import tariffs. We also believe that there is potential for gains in productivity, which would also increase long-term tea output growth, since China's average yield per hectare is low by global standards (at 801 kg/ha in 2014-16, compared with 2,153 kg/ha in India and 2,088 kg/ha in Kenya).
India's tea production will grow slowly in 2019
According to data from India's Tea Board, tea production rose by 0.9% in 2017. Output fell by nearly 5% in the first five months of 2018, and industry officials have indicated that this trend continued in June, reflecting dry conditions in Assam (India's largest tea-growing state), as well as in Bengal and parts of southern India. We are forecasting a 2% drop in tea production in the full calendar year on the basis that the first half of the calendar year accounts for a relatively small share of production (only around one-third), implying scope for a recovery later in the year. However, if continued poor weather has a negative impact on the tea crop during the peak output months (June-October), we may downgrade our projections.
More broadly, efforts to channel funding to tea growers and to introduce an insurance scheme for smallholders (who account for 50% of production) to protect against falls in market prices and weather-related crop disruption will provide support, but several structural factors will hold back production. There has been little progress on reforms to boost foreign direct investment (FDI) in several sectors, including agriculture. Furthermore, India's tea bushes are old: nearly 40% of existing bushes are over 50 years old, compared with Kenya, where fewer than 30% are over 40 years old, and Vietnam, where the entire tea plantation is less than 20 years old. Replanting has progressed slowly and rising input costs have eroded profits, with labour now accounting for half of total production costs (a figure that has grown by 12% in the past three years), implying that in the long term India may struggle to increase output as significantly as other major producers. With several tea manufacturers making losses in India (the world's largest firm, McLeod Russel, made losses in India compared with profits in Uganda, Vietnam and Rwanda), it is unclear how much FDI the sector will attract.
High costs will prevent a significant recovery in Sri Lanka's 2018-19 output
Tea production in Sri Lanka bounced back strongly after landslides and severe flooding in May 2017, with full-year production actually rising by 4.1%, despite alarmist warnings of a collapse in output following the heavy rains. With early indications of favourable weather conditions and tea production rising by 4.8% in the first five months of 2018, we expect Sri Lanka's tea production to rise by 4.2% in the full year. The government's decision to lift a ban on the use of glyphosate weedkiller (used by all major tea producers) in tea plantations will provide some support, since there had been speculation that some key export markets (notably Japan) would cut imports from Sri Lanka on the basis that farmers had resorted to using a replacement chemical, MCPA, which is more stringently regulated in Japan.
However, there are several structural hurdles that will restrict the pace of growth. Despite some replanting as a result of a 20% increase in subsidies to small tea farmers, the replanting rate is not high enough to lead to a significant and sustained increase in output. Local reports also show that fertiliser use has been low, and the risk of industrial unrest persists. Sharp wage rises and low mechanisation mean that production costs in Sri Lanka are some of the highest among the world's main tea producers. Reflecting these factors, we are forecasting a weaker rate of tea production growth, of 1.6% in 2019.
A strong recovery in Kenya is likely in 2018
After a massive jump in tea production in Kenya in 2016, with output hitting an all-time high of 475,000 tonnes, poor weather conditions in the first three quarters of 2017 led to a full-year decline in production of over 7.4%. Production is showing solid signs of recovery so far in 2018, with output in January-May rising by 17% year on year. The recovery is even more rapid than we had anticipated, and we expect full-year tea production growth of 13.7%, with output set to register another record, of 500,000 tonnes. In 2019 we expect only modest production growth, of 1.6% year on year, as periodic industrial action over pay disputes, combined with a change in the tea levy on farmers-which is now based on the value rather than the volume of sales-undermines profitability and prevents faster growth. The government has pledged to support small farmers and reduce the tax burden, but conflicting interests and a lack of funds will also hinder progress.
Investment will have an impact beyond our forecast period
Many countries have been investing to stimulate tea production, including large producers such as India (which is raising subsidies for plantation rejuvenation), Kenya (where processing plants are being expanded and production is being diversified to non-black varieties) and China (which is concentrating on raising black tea output for export), and even a minor producer, Ethiopia (where Saudi investment is seeking to expand tea production). Other smaller producers, such as Tanzania, Uganda, Rwanda and Bangladesh, have also seen renewed investment. However, we assume that some of these investment plans will be scaled back or suspended altogether, while others will progress only slowly, reflecting overambitious investment plans, bureaucratic hurdles and broader concerns about long-term global oversupply. In addition, it takes 3-5 years for a tea bush to become commercially productive, so the impact of recent price falls on output will be evident only after the forecast period.

Stocks and prices
With consumption growth expected to outstrip production growth in 2018-19, the market balance is expected to fall from an estimated surplus of 120,000 tonnes in 2017 to around 49,000 tonnes in 2018, before slipping into deficit in 2019. Given that there is no global measure of total tea stocks, it is impossible to gauge how significantly these movements will affect actual physical stock levels. Stock movements have only a limited effect on prices, not least because much of the increase in consumption and production is the result of consumption and output (mainly of green tea) in China. Although some of the annual production data are broken down into green and black tea, the consumption data are not, which prevents a calculation of the market balance in relation to black tea.
Only a fraction of the increase in production will be exported, and even this will not be in any of the three markets (Colombo, Kolkata and Mombasa) where our average tea price is measured. Prices in these markets respond to demand and supply dynamics in Sri Lanka, India and Kenya, respectively (essentially black tea). Often prices diverge between these three markets on the back of local developments that have an impact on supply and demand in the respective auction or to reflect the quality of tea offered at each auction. For example, prices at the Colombo and Mombasa auctions have fallen so far in 2018 as production in Sri Lanka and Kenya have risen, while prices at the Kolkata auction have fallen as Indian output has declined.

Although some of the auction houses are becoming digitised, we do not believe that the tea market will attract sufficient interest from investors to make price dynamics vulnerable to broader global macroeconomic changes. There is currently no futures market, although the latest meeting of the FAO Inter-governmental Group (IGG) on Tea, which took place in May, discussed the feasibility of introducing one in an effort to address price volatility and differentials between individual tea auctions. However, given that the IGG meets fairly sporadically (usually once a year), we do not expect the introduction of a futures market within the forecast period. Prices will therefore remain volatile and largely led by local supply-and-demand factors.
Prices will retreat in 2018-19
Average tea prices fell from US$3.17/kg in the fourth quarter of 2017 to US$2.91/kg in the first quarter of 2018, with prices stabilising around those levels in April-May. We are forecasting a moderate rebound during the third quarter before a slight retracement in the fourth quarter. However, this will be insufficient to prevent a full-year decline in average prices. After having risen by 17.8% year on year in 2017, to an average of US$3.1/kg, we expect average prices to fall by 5.6% in 2018 and by 4.1% in 2019 as production recovers.

Wheat
Demand
Global wheat consumption has nearly tripled since the 1960s, to more than 730m tonnes in recent years. However, gains in demand, mainly for food and milling purposes, have failed to keep pace with increases in production, resulting in a five-year period of stock accumulation between 2013/14 and 2017/18 (local marketing years). Although stronger demand for wheat has mainly been driven by a rising global population, it should also be noted that wheat demand growth has generally outpaced population growth. Wheat's popularity in diets has been sustained, as has its use as an animal feed ingredient. A small proportion is also used for brewing and the manufacture of starch and ethanol. Global wheat consumption is expected to increase only fractionally in 2018/19 by 0.6% year on year to 738m tonnes, as gains in consumption for food only just compensate for an expected drop in use for animal feed. While accounting for only a very small proportion of overall demand, the use of wheat for industrial processing is projected to increase, given expectations of further economic growth.
Rising food use is being driven by emerging and developing markets
Annual growth in global wheat consumption for food use has remained relatively consistent over the past decade. Urbanisation, together with shifts in diets and incomes, has also resulted in greater consumption of wheat-based convenience foods, such as noodles and Western-style bakery products, which are best produced using high-quality wheat and flour. With much of the growth in demand stemming from countries outside the main wheat-producing belts, rising demand for milling wheat and flour has been accompanied by an increase in imports in most years. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global food use to rise by 1.7% in 2018/19. Growth will be driven mostly by India, Indonesia and Sub-Saharan Africa.
World livestock feed use is expected to drop in 2018/19
Wheat is the world's second-most important grain for use in animal feed, with annual consumption roughly equal to the feed use of barley, sorghum, oats and rye combined. Wheat usage is typically equivalent to one-quarter of the amount of maize that goes into animal feed each year. Given shrinking supplies and continued strong competition from maize-especially in the EU and US-we expect feed use of wheat to drop below recent peaks to a five-year low of 133m tonnes. Demand will depend on relative pricing and overall levels of quality. Following huge crop losses across northern Europe, feed-wheat supplies are expected to be much tighter in 2018/19, and demand will potentially need to be rationed. Feed-wheat use in the EU, which accounts for around 40% of the world total, is currently predicted to drop by around 6m tonnes in 2018/19 to around 48m tonnes as users switch to more competitively priced alternatives, mainly imported maize. Strong export demand for barley may limit how much of that grain is fed domestically in the coming season. However, given this season's very short pasture and grazing availabilities, prospects for the EU feed-grain market outlook are still quite uncertain, and much will depend on how price relationships develop over the coming months. Feed-wheat use in South Korea, Thailand and Vietnam could also decline. However, feed use of wheat in China is expected to rise as more sub-standard domestic supplies are diverted into feed mills in the main southern meat-consuming hubs.
A large harvest is expected to contain Morocco's import needs
Wheat is a staple food in Morocco, where per-capita consumption has long been among the highest in the world, estimated at 216 kg annually in recent years. As domestic production is highly dependent on seasonal rainfall, there are occasionally huge swings in output from one year to the next. This was particularly evident just a few seasons ago, when a record crop of 8.1m tonnes in 2015/16 was followed by an outturn of just 2.7m tonnes in 2016/17. With annual domestic needs close to 9.5m tonnes, Morocco is a major buyer on the global market, importing an average of 4.3m tonnes per year, mainly from the EU, the Black Sea region and Canada. After an unusually dry start to the 2018/19 winter wheat planting season, which prevented some farmers from sowing the intended area, abundant rains in recent months have greatly revived crop prospects, and production should be on track to match last season's 7.1m tonnes, including 4.8m tonnes of soft milling wheat and 2.3m tonnes of durum. As part of efforts to contain third-country arrivals, the Ministry of Agriculture announced in early May 2018 that import duties on common wheat would be hiked to 135% (from 35%) until the end of October 2018.
China has imposed 25% tariffs on US-origin wheat imports
Following the souring of the US-China trade relationship in recent months, a number of US agricultural products, including wheat, are now subject to an additional 25% duty on imports into China. With purchases mainly linked to quality shortfalls in its own huge domestic crop and capped by a restrictive licensing system, China is usually not an overly large importer of wheat. Annual imports have recently averaged 4.1m tonnes per year, with the US typically maintaining a 32% share. Buying interest has almost completely dried up in recent months, mainly reflecting price considerations, but with some importers also reportedly wary of the risk of additional checks or holdups when sourcing US wheat. Instead, local buyers have so far looked to secure additional supplies from Russia and Kazakhstan.

Supply
World wheat production has reached unprecedented levels in recent seasons, with output climbing to successive highs in each of the past five years. Part of this upswing is linked to a small overall rise in plantings, with harvested area trending marginally higher, but much of it has been tied to better average yields, seen close to 3.5 tonnes/ha in 2017/18, compared with 2.8 tonnes/ha a decade ago. Despite concerns about years of underinvestment in wheat-seed technology, productivity gains have been achieved almost everywhere as farmers employ ever more advanced agronomic practices. Following extended periods of adverse weather across many key producers and exporters, world output is now predicted to drop by 5.9% from 2017/18 levels to 714m tonnes (as against a previous forecast of 735m tonnes), potentially the smallest crop since 2012/13. We have revised down production forecasts for the EU, Russia, China, Australia and Ukraine, which will more than outweigh an increased US estimate. With damaging weather affecting yields across the world, the global wheat supply outlook has changed quite dramatically in recent months. Despite an earlier build-up of stocks, the sheer scale of the drop in production, combined with a solid demand base, has quickly shrunk exportable availabilities. Prices have begun to rise, especially in Europe, with US supplies gradually turning more competitive. Given current unfavourable conditions in parts of Canada and Australia, there is the risk of further cuts in output forecasts in the months ahead.
A drop in 2018/19 plantings and yields will limit EU production
Cumulative production in the EU is forecast to slump to 135m tonnes in 2018/19, down almost 11% on the previous year and the smallest total in in six seasons. This reflects downgrades in expected yields in northern Europe, the Baltics and Scandinavia. The winter wheat harvest in Germany, typically the bloc's second-largest grower, was finished much earlier than normal. Due to a damaging drought average yields are down by one-quarter compared with the five-year average, with production seen dropping to only around 18.5m tonnes, compared to 24.2m tonnes in 2017/18. Similarly bad conditions have been reported in Poland, normally the EU's third-largest wheat exporter. Amid exceptionally hot weather in recent months, even sharper declines in yields are expected in Denmark, Sweden and Finland. Harvesting in France, by some distance the EU's largest grower and exporter, was finished by early August. While production is expected to fall slightly short of the average, cropping weather was generally more favourable than in more northern states, and output is expected to fall by only around 8%, to some 36m tonnes. The production shortfall is expected to limit exportable supplies in the 2018/19 marketing year severely, with exports potentially seen falling to just 21m tonnes, down 6% from last season and perhaps the lowest level since 2011/12.
Russia's surplus will be much smaller in 2018/19
The outlook for Russia has also deteriorated. While the 2018/19 crop is still on course to be similar to the recent average, it will fall well short of the previous year's record. With stocks declining and demand from local feed processors expected to remain strong, the 2018/19 exportable surplus will be significantly smaller, potentially limiting June/July shipments to around 31m tonnes, down by 9m tonnes from the season before but still enough to cement Russia's position as the world's largest single supplier. After downgrades in the previous two reports, we have lowered our production forecast by a further 5m tonnes to 66m tonnes, down 22% on the 2017/18 season. This reduction takes into account the latest official harvest data, which confirm a pullback in yields across all of the major southern and central growing areas. Because of earlier very warm and dry weather the harvest has progressed unusually quickly so far, with almost 30% of the total wheat area complete by the start of the August, with yields down by around 16% from the season before. With freshly harvested supplies replenishing exportable pipelines, July wheat shipments of 3.8m tonnes were easily the largest on record for that month and more than twice as high as a year ago.
Given current competitive pricing, Russia is expected to maintain a strong presence on the world market in the months ahead. Although there is some uncertainty regarding the exact size of the carryover from the previous season, we expect shipments to tail off in the second half of the marketing year, possibly opening the way for additional shipments by the US, Canada and Argentina.
US wheat production is forecast to rise slightly in 2018/19
The US winter wheat harvest was in its final stages in early August. Yields for some farmers have held up surprisingly well given the punishing season-long drought, but there remains much uncertainty as to how many fields were abandoned. The hot weather has also underpinned quality, with protein levels reported to be higher than average in most cases. The acreage report of the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) included a surprisingly large spring wheat plantings estimate, seen 20% higher year on year. Rains across the northern plains have been well received, promoting crop development and recharging soil moisture in previously dry areas. While crop condition ratings for spring crops are seen significantly better compared with last year, with 78% rated good or excellent (as against 61% last year), previous expectations for a sharp improvement in yields may not be fulfilled, with crop scouts pegging yield potential in North Dakota and in adjacent areas of South Dakota and Minnesota 16% higher year on year, but 7% below the recent average. Although we have now adopted the USDA's latest all-wheat production figure of 51.1m tonnes (compared with 48.2m tonnes previously), there is a chance of a possible downgrade in the months ahead.
Chinese output to drop in 2018/19
As part of ongoing agricultural market reforms and with a view of capping centrally held stockpiles, China's government recently outlined some further tweaking of its minimum support price programme for 2018/19. After lowering the support price late last year, the authorities announced that purchases of standard (3rd class) wheat between June 1st and September 30th will only be made once the government has confirmed that the average market price has fallen below the minimum price for three successive days. While tinkering with foodgrain price support measures remains a sensitive policy area, the current system has resulted in a sharp build-up of moderate-gluten wheat supplies and the need for costly stockpiling. More radical changes in policy can therefore be expected in the years ahead.
Based on latest production data by province, we now expect Chinese output to total 122.5m tonnes in 2018/19-a five-year low. Excessive rains badly affected yields and quality in parts of Henan, Anhui and Jiangsu provinces, where final results were even worse than previously anticipated. Local officials have reportedly been instructed to support affected farmers by procuring sub-standard wheat under the minimum support price programme. It is unclear how much wheat will be procured and exactly what it will be used for, but it is expected to be diverted into feed channels as long as mycotoxin specifications are met.
Spring wheat was an attractive choice in Western Canada
Updated data from Statistics Canada include a modest downward revision to projected 2018/19 wheat sowings, with the switch away from canola not quite as big as expected early on in the season. However, at 10m ha the all-wheat area was 10% larger than a year earlier and the largest in five seasons. Crop conditions were mixed across the three main Prairie producing provinces. Soil moisture was variable, with dryness a particular concern in southern Alberta and central parts of Saskatchewan, where drought has lingered for months. Crops have generally developed faster than normal and harvesting will start soon. We maintain our existing production forecast of 31m tonnes in 2018/19, up some 3% on the previous year.
Early dryness is a concern in Australia
Parts of eastern Australia have continued to endure extremely dry weather in recent months, with New South Wales and Queensland worst affected. New South Wales, which is sometimes Australia's second-largest wheat producing state, recorded the driest July since 2002, with rainfall below average in each of the past seven months. While rains have been better in Western Australia, sub-soil moisture levels are below average almost everywhere, and further rains will be required over the coming weeks and months. We have reduced our production forecast by 2.5m tonnes to 20m tonnes, almost 6% down on the 2017/18 total and potentially the smallest total since 2007/08.

Stocks and prices
Following five consecutive increases, the world wheat carryover is forecast to contract by 9.1% by the end of 2018/19 to around 245m tonnes, still the second-highest ever and 8% higher than the previous five-year average. Because of downgraded crop forecasts for a number of countries, including the EU and Russia, we have revised down our forecast by 10m tonnes compared with our previous projection, signalling an even sharper than previously anticipated tightening of stocks.
However, stockpiles in China are expected to grow even larger, seen rising by as much as 5% to 132m tonnes, equivalent to more than half of the global total. Since stocks there will only ever be used to satisfy local demand, many observers have argued that China should be excluded from global stock calculations. The USDA recently announced that its supply-and-demand outlook would at some point in the future include such estimates. Other organisations suggest that it is perhaps more useful to measure stocks in the eight largest exporters as a proxy for global supply. Cumulative stocks in these countries are expected to tighten by 23.1m tonnes to 58.9m tonnes, a 28% year-on-year decline. The major exporter stocks figure is slashed by 11.7m tonnes from previously as a combination of smaller crops and a relocation of export demand pushes stocks to multi-year lows in each of the eight countries. A smaller exportable surplus and the need to ration demand away from feed channels is expected to provide a floor to prices going forward, especially in the event of further crop downgrades.

The recent slump in prices has been undone
World wheat markets have become more volatile in recent months. Earlier bearish sentiment in global commodities, linked mainly to frosty US-China trade relations, seeped over into wheat prices in May and June. However, as traders began to focus on increasingly tight wheat supply-and-demand fundamentals, markets across the world turned sharply higher in July and into early August, with average milling wheat prices up by around 13% during the past month. The bull run was sparked by successive downgrades to crop estimates for Europe and the Black Sea region, where much tighter availabilities in the season ahead will have major implications for the world balance sheet, including demand rationing and a shift in global trade flows.
The sheer scale of the production shortfall in some parts of the EU suggests that the wheat market has bottomed out and price risks are now biased to the upside. Whether prices now push higher or stabilise close to current levels will depend largely on the final results from northern hemisphere harvests, and perhaps more particularly the exact size of Russia's 2018/19 surplus. Average prices are expected to spike higher in 2018, but assuming Russian shipments remain high in the coming years, world prices are expected to show only limited upside potential over the remainder of the forecast period.

Full text: South Africa--highlights: Political outlook
The ousting of Jacob Zuma as president by the ruling African National Congress (ANC) in February 2018, and his replacement by Cyril Ramaphosa, a more pragmatic and reputable figure, has positive implications for politics, society and the economy. Mr Ramaphosa faces a range of challenges, however, including boosting the economy, clarifying policy uncertainties and rebuilding ANC unity ahead of the next election in May 2019. Mr Zuma's departure will buoy ANC prospects, and The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the party to secure another majority in 2019-albeit with a smaller share of the vote than in 2014, when it won 62.2%-thereby handing Mr Ramaphosa a full five-year term, as well as a personal mandate to press ahead more vigorously with economic reforms.
South Africa--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a     Global rank b     Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22   2013-17 2018-22   2013-17 2018-22
5.82 6.03   50 56   7 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
South Africa's business environment ranking falls to 56th in 2018-22, as improvements in market opportunities and infrastructure are offset by a deterioration in the macroeconomic environment and taxes. Supporting factors include a sound banking system, disciplined monetary policy, investment in infrastructure and an expansion of the black middle class population. Key constraints include skills shortages, frequent strikes, strict labour laws and the burden of complying with black economic empowerment regulations. Other key areas of controversy are a new mining charter, which loosens the rules in some areas while tightening them in others, a new investment law, and a proposal to embrace expropriation without compensation to speed up land reform, although we believe that any such expropriation will be limited in extent.
South Africa--highlights: Economic outlook
  2017 2018 2019 2020 2021 2022

3-month Treasury rate (av; %) 6.9 6.3 5.6 6.8 6.6 7.0
Exchange rate R:US$ (av) 13.3 13.2 14.4 15.2 16.1 16.9
South Africa's economy, being relatively small and open, will remain vulnerable to global developments and commodity price fluctuations. Growth will pick up from 2019 onwards, driven by consumption and investment, and improving sentiment. However, the rate of expansion will be too slow to bring down the high unemployment rate, which continues to constrain aggregate demand. Fiscal consolidation will also impinge on growth. Global developments will put pressure on the rand, but the inflation outlook is relatively benign, and we expect interest rates to move within a fairly narrow band. The twin deficits on the budget and the current-account will trend lower in 2018-22.
South Africa--highlights: Demographic outlook

Population growth   1.4 1.1

Labour force growth   3.0 2.9
South Africa's population growth rate will remain muted in 2018-22, averaging just 1.1% a year, owing to the adverse impact of the HIV/AIDS pandemic. The number of new infections and the annual death toll from AIDS are both on downward trends, and life expectancy is rising, helped by the expansion of treatment programmes, but the damage will persist into the medium term. The labour force will grow at a faster rate than the overall population, highlighting the urgency of job creation. Rapid urbanisation will present planning challenges, but will bolster aggregate demand and business opportunities.
South Africa--highlights: Market opportunities
  2017 2018 2019 2020 2021 2022

South Africa's market will expand during the forecast period as the black majority is increasingly drawn into the mainstream commercial economy, boosting demand for goods and services across a wide range of sectors. Nonetheless, high levels unemployment will continue to be a drag on aggregate demand, aggravated by fiscal consolidation and the limited scope for monetary loosening. Opportunities will increase during 2018-22, driven by an uptick in growth, the expansion of the black middle class, higher levels of financial inclusion, the rollout of low-cost housing and improved electricity supplies.
South Africa--highlights: Long-term outlook
  2018-30 2031-50 2018-50
Growth and productivity (% change; annual av)
Growth of real GDP per head 2.4 3.4 3.0
Growth of real GDP 3.4 4.1 3.8
Labour productivity growth 2.2 3.1 2.7
We forecast that real GDP growth will average 3.4% a year in 2018-30, helped by rising life expectancy, investment in infrastructure, the expansion of the black middle class, regional integration and global demand for commodities. Technological advances, such as cloud computing and 3D printing will also drive growth and boost productivity. Growth will quicken to 4.1% a year in 2031-50, as the ICT revolution gathers momentum, and African integration deepens. Growth in capital stocks will outpace growth in labour productivity throughout the period, owing to a combination of skills shortages and investment in new technology.

Background: South Africa became a full democracy in 1994, when it held its first all-race elections. The African National Congress (ANC) won, and has dominated all subsequent elections-in 1999, 2004, 2009 and 2014. However, support ebbed from a peak of nearly 70% in 2004 to 62.2% in 2014 and a worst-ever 53.9% in municipal elections in August 2016. Jacob Zuma assumed the presidency in 2009, before standing down in February 2018, in favour of Cyril Ramaphosa, who will serve until the next election in 2019 (and beyond, if the ANC retains power).
Political structure: South Africa is a constitutional democracy with a bicameral parliament and an executive president elected by parliament. The constitution is the supreme law. The 400-member National Assembly is elected by proportional representation; the National Council of the Provinces consists of indirectly elected representatives of the nine provinces. The judiciary is fully independent and includes an 11-member Constitutional Court. The constitution provides for an independent corruption watchdog, the Public Protector, and for independent commissions on human rights, gender equality and the restitution of land rights.
Policy issues: Boosting growth, creating jobs, advancing black economic empowerment and reducing inequality-while maintaining fiscal and monetary discipline-are the main policy aims. The presidency of Mr Ramaphosa heralds deeper economic reform, but divisions within the ANC, and the approach of the 2019 election, mean progress will be erratic and uneven. Reforms to mining laws can be expected, but the labour market will remain rigid and marked by frequent strikes, exacerbated by the trade unions' political power. Skills shortages will persist, reflecting weaknesses in education. The environment for private enterprise will remain broadly accommodating, and opportunities for public-private partnerships will arise, but policy uncertainty will persist, especially over property rights, after the ANC voted to support expropriation without compensation. However, this may require a constitutional amendment and is not certain to be implemented.
Taxation: Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a flat rate of 15%-after a rise from 14% on April 1st-although some essentials are zero-rated. Apart from increasing VAT, the 2018/19 budget also lifted fuel duties, but the corporation tax rate, of 28%, and income-tax rates, are unchanged. Planned special economic zones will offer tax concessions.
Foreign trade: South Africa has a relatively open economy, with foreign trade (imports plus exports) accounting for around 52% of GDP in 2016. China, the EU, the US and Japan are among its largest trading partners. Trade with the rest of Africa has become progressively more important, and it is the only region with which South Africa has a trade surplus.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
Present government: The African National Congress (ANC) has dominated South African politics since the 1994 election brought an end to apartheid and white minority rule. The party won another comfortable victory in May 2014, albeit with a reduced share of the vote. The ANC, led by Nelson Mandela (1991-97), Thabo Mbeki (1997-2007), Jacob Zuma (2009-18) and now Cyril Ramaphosa, steadily raised its voting share to a high-water mark of 69.7% in 2004, although support ebbed to 65.9% in 2009 and 62.2% in 2014 (and fell to an all-time low of 54% in municipal elections in 2016). The ANC continues to hold a large majority of seats in parliament under South Africa's proportional representation system of voting. The party also retained eight of the nine provinces in 2014. The ANC rules in partnership with the Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU) and the South African Communist Party (SACP) in a tripartite alliance.
Opposition: The Democratic Alliance (DA), which draws most of its support from minority voters (white, mixed-race and Indian), increased its share of the vote from 16.7% in 2009 to 22.2% in 2014 and remains the official opposition. The election of Mmusi Maimane as the DA's new leader in 2015 marked a watershed moment in South African politics. As the party's first black leader, Mr Maimane could help to spread the DA's appeal to the majority black electorate, especially in urban areas. Illustrating this, the DA secured 26.9% of votes in 2016's municipal elections. The Economic Freedom Fighters (EEF), a new party led by Julius Malema, who espouses a radical agenda, came third with 6.3% of the vote in 2014. Other opposition groups include the Inkatha Freedom Party and the breakaway New Freedom Party, which are both based in KwaZulu-Natal. Support for the Congress of the People (Cope), which broke away from the ANC to win 7.4% of the vote in 2009, collapsed to less than 1% in 2014 following protracted leadership disputes.
