Next elections: The next general election is scheduled for May 2019
Political outlook: Political stability
The political focus in South Africa is shifting from the major leadership change that took place in February-when the ruling ANC obliged Mr Zuma to stand aside as president in favour of Mr Ramaphosa-to the next election in mid-2019. With the ANC at risk of losing its majority, especially given slow economic growth and high inflation, the party and the president are now expending as much of their energy on preparing for the ballot as on implementing economic reforms, which is perpetuating policy uncertainty. Illustrating this, the ANC's decision to press for a constitutional amendment to allow for the expropriation of land without compensation is geared more towards blunting the appeal of Mr Malema's radical EFF than about advancing socioeconomic transformation. Populism could backfire for the ANC, however, by stifling investment, growth and job creation, leading to lost votes and a lower turnout.
Apart from trying to nullify the opposition, Mr Ramaphosa will remain preoccupied with trying to heal divisions within the ANC, both between his supporters and those still backing Mr Zuma, and between the party's centre and left wing. The latter split, in particular, is re-emerging as a key challenge, after the two factions successfully united against Mr Zuma. Mr Ramaphosa will consequently be obliged to compromise on both politics and policy, given the shortage of time before the next election, which will be held in May 2019.
Despite the obstacles, Mr Ramaphosa will not abandon his reformist agenda and still plans to hold special summits on both jobs and investment before end-2018. Even more importantly, a series of probes into allegations of "state capture" during the Zuma presidency-including a major judge-led investigation that kicked-off in August-are gaining momentum. A recent court ruling against the now-departed head of the National Prosecuting Agency, originally appointed by Mr Zuma, marked a key win for Mr Ramaphosa in his fight against corruption. Adverse findings against other high-profile figures seem probable, leading to a further shake-up in party and government ranks. Mr Ramaphosa will nonetheless work within the law (unlike his predecessor) and will seek to compromise where possible, even at the risk of delay. His installation as president offers the hope of greater political stability and government effectiveness in future-and a rebound in the economy, but his actions will be constrained by vested interests and political imperatives ahead of the next election. Another victory for the ANC in 2019, by giving Mr Ramaphosa a personal mandate for the first time, is likely to herald more rapid progress.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
Government effectiveness declined during Mr Zuma's presidency (2009-18) because of a steady rise in corruption and patronage, and his appointment of cronies to key positions in vital institutions, such as the National Prosecuting Agency, which eroded their independence and credibility. The ANC's ousting of Mr Zuma in February 2018, and his replacement by Cyril Ramaphosa, a pragmatic, experienced and reputable figure, heralds a significant transformation, including a crackdown on corrupt networks and the rebuilding of institutional integrity, although progress will be gradual and subject to occasional setbacks, given the embedded nature of patronage networks and divisions within the ruling party. Mr Ramaphosa has, nonetheless, already taken several important steps, such as overhauling the leadership of mismanaged parastatals and suspending the head of the South African Revenue Service (who will probably be dismissed when investigations are completed). Moreover, a ruling in August 2018 by the Constitutional Court, reversing the appointment of Shaun Abrahams as head of the NPA (made by Mr Zuma in 2015), has positive implications for the rule of law.
The Constitutional Court-the arbiter of South Africa's widely respected and painstakingly negotiated post-apartheid constitution-alongside the wider judicial system, also played a key role in holding Mr Zuma to account, and was one of the few institutions, alongside the South African Reserve Bank (SARB, the central bank), that escaped being weakened by the former president. The battle against corruption and patronage will gather momentum after a key inquiry into Mr Zuma's agenda of "state capture"-led by a respected judge, Raymond Zondo-kicked off in August 2018. Backed by a range of other probes, the architects of state capture-including Mr Zuma-face exposure and possible prosecution, although Mr Zondo's inquiry, for example, could last a year or longer.
The framework of South Africa's political system, underpinned by the constitution, is robust, based on a relatively clear separation of powers (between the executive, the legislature and the judiciary) and strong, independent institutions. Despite the serious damage caused by Mr Zuma, the fightback by the judiciary and other organs of state, and by his opponents in the ANC, illustrates the underlying strength of the political architecture. There are, however, some weaknesses that work against effective government. The electoral code, based on pure proportional representation and a party list system, means that there is no direct link between members of parliament and their constituents, which gives Luthuli House (the ANC headquarters) and the executive much greater influence over legislators than would otherwise be the case. In addition, the ANC's large parliamentary majority, coupled with opposition weaknesses, means that many important debates are hidden from public view within the party hierarchy. Trends suggest that ANC dominance will fade, as opposition influence rises, which is positive for democratic deepening.
Political outlook: Election watch
A decline in the ANC's voting share to a record low of 54% at the municipal elections in 2016 highlights the risk to the party's majority in 2019, although it typically does better in national polls, helped by higher turnouts. The ANC will hope that its fortunes revive under Mr Ramaphosa, especially given Mr Zuma's loss of popularity, although leadership change alone may be insufficient unless efforts to crack down on corruption, improve service delivery and spur job creation are successful. Mr Zuma's early departure gives the party vital time before the next ballot, but the damage caused by his presidency will not be simple to rectify. The 2019 election outcome will also depend on the interim performance of the DA and its partners in the metropolitan councils they captured in 2016, but their record so far has been mixed. As The Economist Intelligence Unit expected, the challenges of expansion and of running minority administrations are testing the DA's reputation for stronger governance. We believe that the ANC will retain a national majority in 2019 (with a voting share no smaller than in 2016) and keep control of Gauteng, the opposition's main provincial target. The period of ANC hegemony is coming to an end, despite Mr Ramaphosa's ascent to the presidency, although the speed of the process and the resulting outcome are far from certain.
Political outlook: International relations
South Africa, the most advanced economy in Africa, will play an important role in regional and world affairs, facilitated by a pending (third) stint on the UN Security Council in 2019-20. The country will remain deeply engaged in Africa, particularly Southern Africa, and will continue to support peacekeeping operations in the continent's conflict zones. Zimbabwe will be high on the agenda after disputed elections on July 30th saw the ruling party and the president, Emmerson Mnangagwa, retain power, accompanied by a crackdown on the opposition. South Africa will also seek to build closer "South-South" ties, especially with fellow members of the BRICS grouping (Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa) and with other African trade blocs. The prioritisation of African ties partly explains South Africa's decision in 2016 to withdraw from the International Criminal Court (ICC), which some argue unfairly targets the continent. However, the High Court in 2017 ruled that departure would first require fresh legislation, leaving South Africa's future membership of the ICC in the balance.

Investment in critical infrastructure will facilitate business operations
South Africa's business environment rankings for 2018-22 show a decline in the country's global rating (to 56th) and no change in its regional ranking. As a key emerging market (and the most advanced economy in Africa), with vast mineral reserves, sound banks and a broad commitment to free markets, the country will remain an important business centre. However, improvements in some areas, such as infrastructure and market opportunities, will be offset by declines in the macroeconomic environment and taxes, because of subdued growth and higher tax levels, respectively. Business also confronts a wide range of policy uncertainties, aggravated by political pressures facing the government in the run-up to the next election in mid-2019. Key arears of concern (and dispute) include a new mining charter, which loosens the rules in some areas while tightening them in others, and the decision by the governing African National Congress (ANC) to press ahead with expropriation without compensation, to speed up land reform. The latter poses a potential threat to property rights, although The Economist Intelligence Unit expects any such expropriation to apply in limited circumstances only. A new investment law is also proving controversial, by limiting the rights of foreign investors to international arbitration. A major leadership change in February 2018, when the ANC forced Jacob Zuma from the presidency in favour of Cyril Ramaphosa, bodes well for the business environment, by heralding a crackdown on corruption and patronage. Mr Ramaphosa has also revived the government's private-sector-led renewable energy programme. However, disputes in the ANC between left-wing interventionists and moderates will resurface, complicating policymaking, after the two factions united against Mr Zuma. Other challenges include strict labour laws, frequent strikes and skills shortages. More positively, South Africa has several robust institutions, such as an independent central bank (the South African Reserve Bank; SARB) and an impartial judiciary.

Business environment outlook: South Africa's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Policy is broadly pro-business, but favourable moves, such as new special economic zones offering tax incentives, are accompanied by tighter competition laws and stricter black economic empowerment (BEE) rules.
2020-22: Expropriation without compensation, to speed up land reform, applies in limited circumstances only, reducing the threat to property rights. Investment incentives in selected industries (such as automotive manufacturing) remain in place.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: A new mining charter offers some concessions to business but other rules are tightened. A new foreign investment law limits access to international arbitration by giving local courts the responsibility for handling disputes.
2020-22: The government continues to encourage foreign investment and public-private partnerships but resists the full privatisation of state assets in most cases.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: The 2018/19 budget heralds a modest relaxation of capital controls on outward investment.
2020-22: Progress towards regional economic integration in Southern Africa makes some advances, but barriers persist.
Taxes
2018-19: Tough fiscal conditions lead to higher direct and indirect taxes, including a rise in value-added tax (VAT).
2020-22: Efforts continue to streamline and modernise the tax system, and expand the tax base.
Financing
2018-19: South Africa avoids a further downgrade by ratings agencies after committing to fiscal consolidation and parastatal reforms. Local banks remain sound and profitable on aggregate, and a key source of corporate financing.
2020-22: The central bank's continued independence helps to preserve financial system stability. Monetary policy remains prudent and interest rates are broadly stable. The planned nationalisation of the central bank is symbolic.
The labour market
2018-19: Labour laws stay inflexible, despite the negative impact on employment, because of trade unions' political power.
2020-22: The labour market remains tough, owing to skills shortages and BEE targets.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Investment in transport and electricity, both by the state and by private firms, boosts capacity.
2020-22: Private-sector-led investment in renewable energy gathers momentum under the government's long-term energy plan, adding diversity to power supplies and cutting reliance on coal. Rising power tariffs drive energy efficiency.
Technological readiness
2018-19: The roll-out of domestic fibre-optic cables boosts capacity and cuts costs. Investment in digital technology, including in cloud computing and high-end data analysis, gathers momentum.
2020-22: Work advances on the Square Kilometre Array, a powerful radio telescope with multinational support, giving a wider boost to science and the information and communications technology (ICT) sector.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment

The macroeconomic environment score declines during the forecast period, pushing down South Africa's global ranking to 67th (from 61st), although its regional ranking is unchanged. Real GDP growth will remain sluggish (averaging just 2.2% a year in 2018-22), but will show a broad upward trend, from 0.9% in 2018 to 3.3% in 2022, driven by consumption and investment. Nonetheless, growth will remain vulnerable to global developments-such as the UK's exit from the EU, trade wars stemming from US-led protectionism and a slowdown in China-and to domestic policy uncertainty. Growth will also be insufficient to bring down the high unemployment rate (currently 27.2%). South Africa's retention of an investment-grade credit rating in March 2018, alongside an interest rate cut in the same month, are growth-positive, but fiscal tightening in the 2018/19 budget (April-March) will act as a constraint. The current-account deficit will remain a source of vulnerability, although it will move within a fairly narrow range of about 3-4% of GDP in 2018-22, as well as showing a falling trend. The rand-a widely traded and market-determined currency-will remain under pressure, mainly because of unfavourable global developments (such as rising US interest rates), although the pace of depreciation will taper off towards the end of the forecast period. Inflation remains comfortably within the SARB's 3-6% target range, despite the weaker rand and the rising cost of oil, which suggests an interest rate rise is not imminent. We expect inflation to stay within target in 2018-22 (except for possible temporary breaches), underpinned by prudent monetary policy and weak growth in demand.
The challenge of black economic empowerment
A unique, challenging and controversial aspect of South Africa's policy environment is the black economic empowerment (BEE) programme, which aims to redress the iniquities of the apartheid era-whereby most wealth and assets ended up in the hands of the white minority-by gradually transferring economic power to the black majority. Legislation governing BEE includes sector-specific charters and broader-based codes of good conduct, both of which set targets for ownership and other variables. Broadly speaking, BEE requires firms to have 25% black ownership, although the precise figure varies by sector (and foreign subsidiaries are largely exempt from equity transfer rules). Revised BEE codes of practice, which came into force in 2015, cut the number of elements on a company's BEE scorecard from seven to five-ownership, enterprise and supplier development, skills development, management control and socioeconomic development-and reweighted the various components. Alongside other changes, this will make it harder for firms to earn (or retain) a BEE-compliant rating: non-compliant firms will be at a competitive disadvantage when bidding for government contracts or negotiating public-private partnerships.
Apart from the problems posed by changes to the rules, two key questions remain unanswered after nearly two decades of BEE: how long will the policy remain in force, and is a once-empowered company always empowered? New revisions to the mining charter in 2018 offer some clarity to the latter question, by allowing BEE deals that have subsequently lapsed (because of new black owners selling their shares) to count towards a firm's equity transfer target. This marks an important breakthrough, although it is not necessarily applicable to all sectors. Less positively, the new charter plans to lift the ownership threshold in mining to 30%. With regard to wealth transfer, the record of BEE has been mixed: the initial benefits were spread fairly narrowly (helping to create a new black elite), although a drive towards more broad-based empowerment (by including workers and suppliers, for example), is distributing the rewards more evenly. Some company BEE schemes yield higher benefits than others, however, depending on several variables, such as share price movements.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Policy towards private enterprise will remain broadly accommodating, but challenges in several areas, many policy-related, will lead to a small deterioration in South Africa's global and regional rankings. Public-private partnerships (PPPs) will become more commonplace, but obstacles such as strict labour laws, elevated strike risks and skills shortages will persist. A return to fiscal consolidation in the budget for 2018/19 (April-March) is broadly positive, but taxes are rising as a consequence. A high level of policy uncertainty surrounding a new mining charter-which eases BEE requirements in some areas while tightening them in others-and about property rights, because of the government's plan to embrace expropriation without compensation (in some cases), will deter investment pending further clarification. Proposals to revamp healthcare under a planned National Health Insurance system are a particular concern for large private-sector providers. Leadership change in February, is a positive move, heralding a clampdown on patronage and corruption. However, the government continues to face the immense difficulty of reconciling the imperatives of growth with those of socio-economic transformation, leading to policy fudges in many cases.
Powerful parastatals (such as the power generator, Eskom, and the port/rail operator, Transnet) will continue to play a key role, despite suffering from weak management, political interference and financial indiscipline. This will limit private opportunity, although there will be some openings for PPPs and independent initiatives, especially in the energy sector. The government is now attempting to strengthen parastatal management but will remain wary of outright privatisation, while proposals to inject private capital into ailing state-owned firms are not certain to advance. The government's industrial policy will continue to offer incentives in some sectors, especially for vehicles, which will be extended beyond the current 2020 expiry date. Tax concessions are on offer to investors in new special economic zones (SEZs), the first six of which were designated in August 2018 (including existing industrial development zones, such as Coega), although some restrictions apply.
Expropriation without compensation unsettles investors
The ANC's decision to push ahead with plans for expropriation without compensation, in order to speed up land reform-which has so far taken place mostly on a "willing buyer, willing seller" basis-poses a threat to property rights. However, we believe that expropriation, if any, will apply in limited, clearly defined circumstances only. The government aims to amend the constitution to allow for expropriation without compensation-rather than test whether the existing constitution allows for land seizures-but this will first require a two-thirds majority in parliament, leaving the timing and the outcome uncertain: a vote is extremely unlikely before the mid-2019 elections. Expropriation without compensation, even with clear limits imposed, is still an investment deterrent, until the details are much clearer. Adding to the confusion, a draft expropriation bill, in gestation for several years, will be comprehensively reworked, leading to further delays. Land reform remains highly sensitive, given the iniquities inherited from the apartheid era, but a cautious approach is needed to avoid damaging agriculture and investor sentiment.
Competition policy is becoming stricter
Policy towards anti-competitive practices will become stricter, as the competition authorities (comprising a commission and a tribunal)-led by the Department for Economic Development-intensify their battle against cartels and overpricing. This may yield some benefits for consumers, but the increasingly intolerant approach being taken by the competition authorities-as well as the use of competition policy as a tool to achieve wider socio-economic objectives (such as BEE)-could have an adverse impact on investment. The capacity of the competition authorities is also being stretched by a large number of concurrent, separate inquiries. A new competition amendment bill, initiated in 2017 and currently working its way through the legislative process, proposes to grant the competition authorities (and the minister for economic development) additional powers, such as launching inquiries into sectors with a high degree of concentration, and investigating cross-border mergers on national security grounds (which is becoming a global phenomenon). Not all of the new proposals will be included in the final bill, however, leaving competition policy (as with other policy areas) subject to considerable uncertainty.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment

Policy uncertainties could hamper FDI inflows
South Africa will remain a key destination for non-oil foreign direct investment (FDI) in Africa during the forecast period, in a wide range of sectors, driven by business opportunities and the country's role as a gateway to the rest of the continent, especially Southern Africa. This will facilitate a small improvement in South Africa's global ranking during the forecast period, despite the persistence of policy uncertainties. Foreign investors, for the most part, face the same challenges as domestic firms, including strict labour and competition laws, the dominant position of parastatals and concern about future property rights. Conversely, foreign (and local) investors, will be drawn by opportunities for PPPs, notably in renewable energy. A new mining charter, now approved by the cabinet, improves on the mid-2018 draft, but looser rules in some areas are matched by tighter restrictions in others. In a key concession to business, the new charter allows previous BEE deals that were subsequently unwound to count towards the 26% equity threshold, but also imposes new restrictions, such as lifting the threshold to 30%. Investors will welcome greater certainty, but the full impact of the new charter has still to be ascertained. Foreign investors seeking to acquire domestic firms can face particular scrutiny, especially from the competition authorities, which, for example, imposed several conditions on Walmart's purchase of majority stake in Massmart in 2011.
A new Protection of Investment Act, sometimes referred to as the FDI act, which came into force in July 2018 following lengthy delays, is creating new uncertainties. The law aims to provide a more streamlined environment for FDI (compared with previous ad hoc arrangements) and is based on the premise of local and foreign investors being treated more equally. However, this has a major downside, because the act limits access by investors to international arbitration and instead requires that all legal disputes be first dealt with by local courts. Investors may be assuaged by South Africa's constitution and its broadly respected and independent judiciary, but disputes could take longer to settle, with the outcome more uncertain. South Africa's termination (or failure to extend) around a dozen bilateral investment treaties with EU countries, in the belief that they have little impact on actual investment flows, is exacerbating these concerns. The new FDI act appears to be broadly negative, but full implications have still to be determined. FDI will be driven in part by opportunities for PPPs, as well as private-led initiatives, especially in the field of infrastructure provision. For example, private firms, both foreign and local, are playing a leading role in the rollout of renewable energy (especially solar and wind), having invested almost US$14bn to date, with more projects in the pipeline.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.9 7.3 55 54 6 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Exchange controls will gradually be liberalised
South Africa has progressively loosened exchange controls on capital flows in recent years, by moving from centralised directives towards prudential self-regulation. This trend is likely to continue, although some restrictions will remain in place. Liberalisation stalled during the 2008-09 global financial crisis (as the controls offered some protection, by constraining capital flight), but soon gained new momentum, driven by a new wave of Treasury-led reforms. These include removing the ceiling for outward investment; lowering the ceiling on advance payments for imports; allowing South African companies to open foreign bank accounts without prior approval; permitting banks to invest 25% of their liabilities in offshore portfolio instruments; and offering concessions to foreign firms that set up headquarters in South Africa. Liberalisation again stalled, although the budget for fiscal year 2018/19 (April-March) brought in looser rules for outward institutional investors, especially those engaged in the rest of Africa. Additional reforms are probable during the forecast period, but some restrictions will remain in place, especially given the risks that US-led protectionism-and consequent trade wars-pose to the global financial system.
Sluggish growth combined with an activist industrial policy will lead to protective measures in some cases (in the form of higher tariffs and anti-dumping duties)-such as for steel-although South Africa will seek to remain compliant with World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules. The Southern African Development Community (SADC) will progressively implement a free-trade area, but the initiative is running behind schedule because of wide economic and policy divergences between member states. Loftier ambitions for a customs union, a common market and monetary union are unlikely to be realised during the outlook period. The proposed merger of SADC, the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (Comesa) and the East African Community (EAC) into a Tripartite Free-Trade Area will potentially speed up integration by providing a harmonised framework, but a final agreement remains pending. Non-tariff barriers and poor infrastructure links are other serious obstacles.
South Africa (and other members of the South Africa Customs Union) successfully negotiated a new economic partnership agreement (EPA) with the EU in 2014. The deal will continue to facilitate deeper trade and investment ties, and provides improved access to the EU for South African agricultural exports. South Africa will also retain trade preferences in the US under the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA), which has been extended by ten years to 2025. Nonetheless, South Africa's AGOA status will remain conditional on its policies towards trade liberalisation and investment protection. A dispute about South African restrictions on US meat imports, for example, threatened South Africa's AGOA eligibility before the issue was settled in 2016. Similar clashes can be expected in future, especially given US moves towards protectionism: US tariffs on steel and aluminium imports from most countries, including South Africa, violate the spirit of AGOA, but retaliation by South Africa could be counter-productive.
Business environment outlook: Taxes

2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.4 6.1 33 51 8 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Tight fiscal conditions lead to higher taxes
South Africa's score and global ranking for taxes decline in 2018-22, as revenue shortfalls combine with spending pressures to push the tax burden higher. The budget for fiscal year 2018/19 (April-March), for example, lifted the value-added tax (VAT) rate to 15% from 14%, in the first adjustment for 25 years, and also increased fuel duties. This follows hikes in capital gains tax and income tax, including a new top rate of 45%, in fiscal year 2016/17. The corporation tax rate remains unchanged at 28%, however, and is unlikely to be raised, given pressures on corporate finances. Other levies adding to the business tax burden include property taxes, skills development levies, and contributions towards unemployment insurance and occupational injuries insurance.
Additional tax increases are probable during the forecast period, given spending pressures, although the government's room for manoeuvre is now more limited: another VAT hike would be politically damaging and there is no further scope for higher income tax rates (which could lead to increased evasion). Other forms of wealth tax will be considered, but South Africa already relies too heavily on a small number of rich individuals and firms, and instead needs to broaden the tax base. Efforts to streamline taxation, boost compliance and seal loopholes will continue during the forecast period, informed by the findings of the Davis Tax Committee, which produced a string of reports during its five-year probe, ending in April 2018. South Africa's revenue shortfalls also reflect mismanagement at the South African Revenue Service (SARS) under Tom Moyane, who was appointed by Mr Zuma in 2014. However, Mr Moyane's suspension by the new president, Mr Ramaphosa, in March 2018-and his probable removal from office-point to improvements, which could reduce the urgency of tax hikes.
Tax incentives will continue to apply in some cases, including for small firms, which have enjoyed reduced corporation tax rates since 2013. A youth employment subsidy (via tax concessions) from 2014 will remain in place until at least February 2019 and may be extended. A discounted, 15% rate of corporate tax also applies to investors in new SEZs, with the first six being formally designated on August 1st 2018. The 2018/19 budget allocated R350m to cover tax incentives in SEZs. New environmental and health-related taxes will be introduced during the forecast period, as highlighted by a new sugar tax on soft drinks imposed on April 1st 2018, alongside a higher levy on plastic bags. These will be followed by a long-mooted carbon tax, intended to curb emissions, which is currently scheduled to start on January 1st 2019. However, the final details are still pending-and a further delay is probable-given strong lobbying by industry (especially energy-intensive operations) against the levy, as currently formulated. Unless carefully designed, carbon taxes could dent competitiveness without having a significant impact on emissions.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Banks remain sound and well-capitalised
The banking system remains sound and well-capitalised, with a long-term reputation for stability, underpinned by an effective regulatory and supervisory framework, overseen by SARB. Key challenges are slow GDP growth (and hence demand for credit) and a range of regulatory uncertainties. Banks' capital-adequacy ratios remain comfortably above prescribed minimums, and profitability (as measured by return on equity) remains satisfactory after edging up to 16.2% in June 2018, an eight-month high. Despite cheaper credit, strains in the economy pushed up the non-performing loan ratio to 3.5% in June (a four-year high), although there seems little danger of the figure breaching the critical 5% threshold in 2018-22. We expect interest rates to trend mildly higher during the forecast period, with small hikes partly offset by periodic cuts. Local banks will remain a key source of funds for private investment projects, as illustrated by their participation in the financing of renewable energy projects. Other key sources of financing are the Johannesburg Stock Exchange and, to an increasing extent, local development finance institutions such as the Industrial Development Corporation.
The four dominant banks-ABSA (formerly Barclays Africa), Nedbank, Standard and First Rand-are world-class players with strong international links. They are also, to varying degrees, expanding their presence in the rest of Africa, thereby cementing South Africa's role as a gateway to the rest of the continent. Smaller banks are more vulnerable-for example Africa Bank (an unsecured lending specialist), folded in 2014, followed by VBS in 2018 (because of apparent corruption), although the SARB successfully curbed systemic risk in both cases. The withdrawal of Barclays from Africa, largely completed in 2017, poses no threat to the local banking system, although it has now been rebranded as ABSA (its former name). The implementation of an amended Financial Intelligence Centre Act in June 2017, meeting a deadline set by the Financial Action Task Force, removes a threat to the credibility and integrity of local banks and will help to tackle money-laundering. However, the phased implementation of more stringent Basel III regulatory standards in the lead-up to a 2019 deadline, alongside a new financial sector regulation bill based on a Twin Peaks model, may impose additional costs. Key challenges on the policy front are possible changes to BEE rules in the financial sector, which are comparatively loose at present, as well as amendments to the credit act (not yet implemented) that potentially offer a big debt write-off for low-income borrowers. The latter could compromise the ability of banks to price risk correctly. Government plans to embrace expropriation without compensation (for land) represent a fundamental threat to banks (given the amount of land used as loan collateral), although we expect the government to set clear limits on expropriation. The possible nationalisation of the SARB-a rare, privately owned central bank-is unsettling, but would be of symbolic value only, provided its mandate was left untouched. Other, broader dangers include the exposure of banks to heavily indebted parastatals.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
4.6 4.8 74 76 13 14
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
The labour market will remain characterised by a strict regulatory environment, partly owing to the political power of the trade unions, and despite its negative impact on job creation. The official unemployment rate climbed to 27.2% in the second quarter of 2018-rising to 35.5% with the inclusion of discouraged job seekers-partly because firms are discouraged from hiring by tight labour laws, including the employment equity components of BEE and the limits imposed on casual, temporary employment. Frequent strike action is an additional deterrent to job creation. A major split in the labour movement between comparative moderates in the Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu, an ANC ally) and their more radical counterparts in the South African Federation of Trade Unions (Saftu), formed in 2017 by disgruntled Cosatu members, somewhat weakens the labour voice. However, the split also heralds new challenges for firms, as many unionised workers in the private sector are now Saftu members. The pending introduction of a national minimum wage will have an impact on the labour market during the forecast period. The relevant bill, adopted by the National Assembly in May 2018 following lengthy negotiations at the National Economic Development and Labour Council (Nedlac)-a tripartite body comprising government, labour and business representatives-ushers in a R20 (US$1.40) per hour minimum wage, most probably starting in late 2018/early 2019. Approximately 5m workers (one-third of the total) may benefit, giving a potential income boost to poorer households, but job losses are a clear risk, which would neutralise the benefits. To mitigate the threat, a lower wage threshold will apply to farmworkers and domestic servants for a two-year period. The existing system of sector-based minimum wages will be retained, despite its complexity, to protect workers earning more than the national minimum. A new Minimum Wage Commission will monitor the impact and make recommendations on future increments (to account for inflation).
Shortages of skilled workers will remain a key constraint
In return for agreeing to a national minimum wage, business secured a commitment from mainstream trade unions to make greater use of pre-strike balloting, which could reduce incidents of labour unrest. To effect the changes, the national minimum wage bill is being accompanied by amendments to other key labour laws, including the Basic Conditions of Employment Act and the Labour Relations Act (which covers pre-strike ballots). Radical trade unions remain strongly opposed to the national minimum wage, on the grounds of it being set too low, but their objections are unlikely to derail the government's plans. The national minimum wage is clearly an experiment with a high risk of unintended consequences. Skills shortages, exacerbated by HIV/AIDS, will remain prevalent in most sectors, pushing up the premium required to attract skilled workers and leading to the poaching of capable staff. The government, in partnership with the private sector, will maintain initiatives to boost the skills base, but progress will be slow, especially given weaknesses in the education system at all levels.

Parastatals restrict opportunities in transport
South Africa's transport network is well-developed by African standards, despite some bottlenecks, although the strong parastatal presence, including Transnet (for most freight railways and ports), Prasa (for passenger railways) and Sanral (for roads), limits opportunities for private providers. Moreover, weak governance at most parastatals, including irregular tendering and project delays, can be detrimental for infrastructure efficiency. PPPs are, nonetheless, playing an important role, as illustrated by the Gauteng mass-transit railway that opened, in phases, in 2010-12 and which may be extended. The partnership between the privately owned Richards Bay Coal Terminal, Africa's largest, and Transnet, which operates the railway serving the terminal, represents a different form of PPP. The government's bid to finance Gauteng's highways via a tolling system continues to face resistance from drivers, however, leading to revenue shortfalls at Sanral. End-user pricing models clearly work better for railways (eg, Gautrain) than roads. Three broad themes will characterise South Africa's energy scene in 2018-22: a slow decline in the dominant role of Eskom (the heavily-indebted parastatal firm with a monopoly on distribution); brisk growth in renewables (led by the private sector); and slow growth in electricity demand (because of sluggish economic growth and improvements in energy efficiency). The government's flagship renewable procurement programme, launched in 2011, has attracted investment of about US$14bn to date, mainly in solar and wind, which cut Eskom's share of the power mix from 95.9% in 2012 to 91.1% in 2017. The programme stalled in 2016 (partly because of resistance from Eskom), leaving several projects in limbo, but was revived by the new president, Mr Ramaphosa, in April, leading the energy department to conclude new contracts worth US$4.7bn (for projects initially approved in 2014-15). A new, fifth bidding window may open later in 2018.
The long-delayed update in August to South Africa's Integrated Resource Plan (IRP), running to 2030, confirms the commitment to renewables but makes no provision for additional nuclear power. Eskom's coal-fired plants will continue to supply the bulk of base-load power, although the phased opening of new mega plants at Medupi and Kusile (in 2017-23) will be accompanied by the closure of ageing and less-efficient facilities. The new IRP, currently open for comment, marks a key step forward for energy planning, although resistance from Eskom to plant closures (and inevitable job losses) could pose a challenge. South Africa is no longer at risk of power shortages but rising tariffs in real-terms will remain a burden for end-users, while also driving energy efficiency.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness

ICT sector a leader in Africa
South Africa's ICT market is among the most advanced in Africa in terms of technology and service provision, highlighted by the pending opening of two cloud-computing centres by Microsoft (in Johannesburg and Cape Town) later in 2018, the first by any operator on the continent. Local data centres will reduce problems with latency (delays) and provide new options for firms, such as banks, which are obliged to hold data locally for privacy reasons. Amazon, the world's leading cloud-computing firm, is still considering a local data centre but, in the interim, is investing in a new greenfield project in Cape Town (near the firm's existing facilities), with a focus on cloud computing, machine learning and data analysis, which may open later in 2018. South Africa is also a leading destination for ICT start-ups: out of total African funding of US$558m in 2017 (in 124 ventures), South Africa claimed US$167m (in 42 ventures), according to the GSMA, a trade body that represents the interests of mobile network operators worldwide. Fintech (financial), e-commerce and edtech (educational) start-ups were the most numerous. Cape Town is emerging as a key ICT hub, helped by having one of Africa's largest, public fibre-optic networks. Key challenges are relatively high end-user charges (although these are falling over time), an increase in cybercrimes-marked by a number of serious data breaches in the private sector-and skills shortages.
In a significant boost to ICT and science, South Africa will host the majority portion of the US$2bn Square Kilometre Array (SKA) complex, a powerful radio telescope in Northern Cape. The first portion of the SKA, a 64-dish radio telescope, known as MeerKAT, opened in July to scientific acclaim following investment of US$332m, mainly from public sources, including from international partners that are part of the SKA consortium. MeerKAT is also at the cutting edge of high-performance data processing, which bodes well for technological progress and digital skills building. MeerKAT will be the central component of the SKA, which will include additional dishes and arrays in South Africa, as well as in several other African countries. Parts of the SKA will also be situated in Australia, bringing the total number of dishes to about 3,000 when complete. MeerKAT will operate independently until it is linked to the SKA in 2023, although the entire SKA project may not be finished until later in the decade. The SKA could offer clues to black holes, dark energy and the origin of the universe.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
Boosting economic growth and job creation within a context of global uncertainty, while avoiding macroeconomic imbalances, will continue to be the main task facing policymakers. Adding to the challenge, fiscal policy is becoming tighter and taxes are rising in order to keep debt under control and forestall additional credit downgrades, which will hinder efforts to boost growth. The main medium-term challenge is to overcome structural obstacles to faster growth, such as infrastructure bottlenecks and skills shortages. Targeted industrial incentives will therefore stay in place and infrastructure investment will remain a priority, but wasteful spending poses a threat. Other challenges include the persistence of labour market rigidities and the progressively stricter application of rules against anti-competitive behaviour.
The installation in February of Cyril Ramaphosa as president, and the new president's sweeping cabinet reshuffle, have positive implications for the policy environment. However, Mr Ramaphosa's room for manoeuvre is constrained by divisions within the ruling African National Congress (ANC) and the approach of the 2019 election. Labour law reform and privatisation will therefore remain sensitive topics, although opportunities will arise for public-private partnerships. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a faster rollout of independent power projects, but hopes for a more business-friendly mining charter are diminishing. Land rights will remain subject to uncertainty, given the ANC's backing for expropriation without compensation, albeit with provisos such as not damaging agriculture. Corporates face the additional challenge of complying with black economic empowerment targets, especially given ongoing changes to the legal framework. Most of the policy conundrums facing the government stem from the difficulty in reconciling the imperatives of growth with those of socioeconomic transformation.

Fiscal risks are rising ahead of the next medium-term budget policy statement (MTBPS) in October because of revenue shortfalls as a result of weak GDP growth and persistent upward pressure on spending, especially in advance of the mid-2019 election. The outlook has therefore deteriorated since the adoption of a relatively prudent budget for fiscal year 2018/19 (April-March), targeting a cut in the deficit to 3.6% of GDP-from an estimated 4.4% of GDP in 2017/18-alongside the February reappointment of Nhlanhla Nene as minister of finance by Mr Ramaphosa. The 2018/19 budget, which lifted value-added tax (VAT) from 14% to 15% in the first hike for 25 years, persuaded Moody's, a credit rating agency, to retain South Africa in the investment-grade category and to revise the country's outlook from negative to stable.
However, positive sentiment is dissipating because of below-target revenue collection in the fiscal year to date-despite tax hikes-resulting from weak economic growth and structural challenges facing the South African Revenue Service (SARS). Spending, by contrast, continues to head higher, aggravated by a three-year wage deal for public-sector workers (based on real-term increases) and the financial demands of struggling parastatals, especially Eskom, the heavily indebted power generator. The Treasury is also working on a stimulus package, which could put extra pressure on the fiscal accounts. We are therefore revising our budget deficit projections for 2018/19 and 2019/20 to 3.6% of GDP and 3.4% of GDP, respectively. The larger shortfalls also mean that public-sector debt may exceed 56% of GDP in both years, slightly ahead of the Treasury's current projections. Our central forecast still sees the deficit retreating to 2.6% of GDP in 2022/23, helped by more rapid fiscal consolidation after the 2019 election and moderately faster economic growth, but the outlook is now subject to greater uncertainty.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy

The South African Reserve Bank (SARB, the central bank) cut the benchmark rate by 25 basis points to 6.5% in March 2018, following an identical reduction in July 2017, but we expect the next move to be upward, most probably in mid-2019. The March rate cut reflects subdued GDP growth and moderate inflation, which is lying comfortably within the SARB's 3-6% target range. However, rising US rates (in 2018-20) and the need to maintain a positive rate differential with the US (in order to attract vital portfolio investment inflows), accompanied by slightly higher inflation and a weaker rand, point to a small rate rise in 2019. Tightening could come sooner if rand weakness propels inflation above the target level. Trends thereafter are forecast to follow the broad pattern of US rates, edging up in 2020 and 2022, with an intervening dip in 2021. South African rates will, nonetheless, remain fairly stable during the forecast period, marked by small up and down movements only. The SARB will retain its inflation-targeting mandate and its independence, even if the government takes the institution into public ownership.

External headwinds (such as a stronger US dollar and rising global trade tensions) and domestic constraints (including high levels of political and policy uncertainty) are stifling economic activity. Real growth slowed to 0.6% year on year in the first half of 2018, leading to a downward revision in our annual forecast to just 0.9% (from 1.5%), assuming a mild second-half rebound. An interest-rate cut by the SARB in March in response to lower inflation is growth-friendly, by offering support to credit demand and household consumption. More stable electricity supplies and satisfactory rainfall in Western Cape, ending a severe drought in the province, are also supportive. However, the boost to confidence arising from the installation in February of Mr Ramaphosa as the new president is fading, given the precedence being given to political priorities ahead of the mid-2019 election.
Growth in 2018 is suffering from a contraction in agriculture-after a bumper harvest in 2017 set a very high benchmark-and shrinkage in mining because of a tough operating and policy environment. Household spending is moderately buoyant, but tighter fiscal policy, especially a rise in VAT on April 1st, will weigh on aggregate demand, as will the persistently high unemployment rate (of 27.2% in the second quarter). Policy uncertainties in several key areas, aggravated by the ruling ANC's stated intention to allow for expropriation without compensation in order to advance land reform, will continue to unsettle investors and dampen private investment. Global uncertainties linked to US-led protectionism are another growth risk, although net exports, which detracted from growth in the first half, will benefit from a recent slide in the rand.
Political developments will be a key variable in 2019, when South Africa holds its next election. Our central forecast sees growth quickening to 1.8%, but activity will be hampered by election-related uncertainties, especially in the first half of the year. Global turbulence, including the UK's potentially disruptive departure from the EU, could also have a negative local impact. Provided the 2019 election is not destabilising, growth will quicken to 2.8% a year in 2020-22, helped by the completion of major infrastructure projects in transport and energy and stronger consumer demand for goods and services, underpinned by the expansion of the black middle class. Structural constraints, such as skills shortages and inefficient parastatals, will nonetheless continue to dampen economic activity, and a negative external balance will weigh on economic growth throughout most of the forecast period.

Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
On the supply side, services will remain the largest sector (69.5% of factor-cost GDP in 2017) and will continue to be a key source of growth. Expansion will remain subdued in 2018, at 1.1%, in line with the wider economy, before gaining momentum in 2019-22. The large banking segment (22.3% of GDP, including real estate and business services) will remain a leading segment and a key source of job creation, bolstered by rising rates of financial inclusion. Retailing/wholesaling (15% of GDP) will rebound modestly in 2018 (after shrinking in 2017), helped by lower interest rates, which are boosting household credit growth, although high unemployment will continue to supress aggregate demand. Transport and communications (9.4% of GDP) will gain from new investment in infrastructure, including in railways, ports and fibre-optic cable networks. The mobile-phone market is largely saturated, with a penetration rate of about 165 subscriptions per 100 people (as of mid-2018), but a transition to high-end services and increased data usage will underpin expansion. Tourism has considerable potential-based on South Africa's varied natural attractions and favourable climate-and is also labour-intensive, although high levels of crime remain a deterrent. Tourism rebounded in 2016-17 after the government started to ease the tighter visa restrictions imposed in 2014-15, pointing to further expansion during the forecast period.
The industrial sector (27.9% of factor-cost GDP in 2017, including mining) will remain a key part of the economy, with growth showing a broad upward trend during the forecast period, from 1% in 2018 to 3% in 2022. Manufacturing (13.5% of GDP) is broad-based by Sub-Saharan African standards, being a key employer and source of exports, although growth will remain fairly sluggish given subdued domestic demand and competition from imports. The key vehicle segment will benefit from new investment, spurred by incentives offered under the Automotive Production and Development Programme (APDP), which runs to 2020 (with an extension likely), as part of the government's activist industrial policy. Power supply constraints have now eased, helped by new plant openings, but rising tariffs are a challenge. Manufacturing will continue to face an elevated risk of strikes.
Mining makes a modest and declining contribution to GDP (8.2% in 2017) but accounts, directly and indirectly, for about 50% of export earnings. This leaves South Africa vulnerable to commodity price fluctuations and to a slowdown in China. Mining also suffers from labour militancy and a high-level of regulatory uncertainty-especially with regards to new draft mining charter-leading to a paucity of new investment. Despite South Africa's rich mineral reserves, faster growth will require a more conducive policy environment The agricultural sector is small (2.6% of GDP in 2017) and vulnerable to drought, but will continue to make an important contribution to exports (including fruit and wine), agro-industry and employment. However, erratic rainfall poses a high degree of risk: droughts in 2015 and 2016 (partly linked to the El Niño climate phenomenon) led agriculture to contract in both years, before a strong rebound in 2017. Future performance is dependent on both climate and the government's land-reform policies.

Inflation is forecast to ease slightly to 5% in 2018, helped by sluggish domestic demand and adequate rainfall, including in Western Cape, which will keep food prices in check. The decision by the energy sector regulator to cap electricity tariff rises at 5.2% in 2018 will also curb inflation. However, the VAT increase in April, alongside higher oil prices and recent rand slippage, will put some upward pressure on prices. Inflation will average about 5.3% a year in 2019-22, thereby falling within the SARB's 3-6% target range, apart from possible temporary breaches. Prudent monetary policy, spare industrial capacity, subdued demand, stricter competition laws and efficiency gains arising from infrastructure investment will help to mute price growth. However, rising power tariffs and higher real wages for those in work will prevent inflation from falling more sharply.

The rand depreciated to R14.11:US$1 in August, the weakest monthly rate for more than two years, before crossing the R15:US$1 mark in early September, largely reflecting adverse global sentiment towards emerging-market currencies, driven by US monetary tightening and a stronger US dollar. Slow domestic growth and persistent policy uncertainty are also weighing on the rand, although South Africa's modest level of external debt offers some protection. Fiscal consolidation in the 2018/19 budget (delivered in February) gave the rand a temporary boost by reducing the risk of additional credit downgrades, but the gains have now been cancelled out by emerging-market contagion. The rand will remain volatile, exacerbated by its widely traded status, although we expect a mild rebound from current levels. Our rand forecast for 2018 is revised to R13.21:US$1 (from R12.95:US$1)-leaving the local unit slightly stronger than in 2017-before a further slide in 2019 to R14.37:US$1 (revised from R13.99:US$1) in view of electoral uncertainties. Thereafter, on current assumptions, the rand will stage a more gentle retreat to an average of R16.94:US$1 in 2022.

The current-account deficit will fluctuate within a narrow range of 3-3.6% of GDP during the forecast period, with the gap peaking in 2020 before receding. The structure of the deficit, comprising a merchandise trade surplus and a larger invisible trade deficit (on services, income and current transfers), will remain unchanged. Export growth will be slower in 2018-19 than in 2017, reflecting non-oil commodity price trends and South Africa's heavy reliance on mineral sales. Non-mineral exports (such as cars) will benefit from South Africa's probable retention of trade preferences under the US African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA), although US-led protectionism poses risks. The recent slide in the rand is, nonetheless, broadly positive for exports. Imports will grow at a similar pace to exports in 2018-19, spurred by a modest pick-up in GDP growth and slightly higher oil prices, leading to a small decline in the merchandise trade surplus. Combined with a rising shortfall on invisible trade, this will lead to a widening of the current-account deficit to 3.6% of GDP in 2018. Income payments to foreign investors and transfers to fellow members of the Southern African Customs Union will continue to account for most of the invisible shortfall. We expect the current-account deficit to peak at 3.6% of GDP in 2020 before easing to 3.2% of GDP in 2021 and 3% of GDP in 2022, helped by faster earnings growth and a rise in nominal GDP.

Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in South Africa
Stocks and flows
South Africa is a prime destination for non-oil-sector foreign direct investment (FDI) in Sub-Saharan Africa. Inflows averaged US$3.8bn a year in 2013-17, but showed a declining trend to an 11-year low of US$1.4bn in 2017, partly because of uncertainties about both commodity prices and government policies. Nonetheless, annual figures can vary substantially because of the discontinuous nature of FDI. Inflows peaked at a record of US$9.9bn in 2008, boosted by the US$5.2bn purchase of a 20% stake in Standard Bank by China's state-run Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC)-the second-biggest FDI deal to date-behind the acquisition of 56% of ABSA by Barclays (UK) in 2005. Eight years later, in 2013, Barclays brought together most of its African operations, including ABSA, under the Barclays Africa banner, before subsequently announcing its withdrawal from Africa (in 2016) as part of a global restructuring exercise. The sale of Barclays' majority stake in Barclays Africa, primarily to local investors, was completed in 2017. FDI regained momentum after the 2009 recession, rising to US$4.6bn in 2012, buoyed by the purchase by Walmart (US) of 51% of Massmart, for US$2.4bn. Inflows climbed higher to US$8.2bn in 2013, the second highest on record, and remained strong at US$5.8bn in 2014, but weaker inflows in 2015 (US$1.5bn), 2016 (US$2.2bn) and 2017 illustrate heightened investor concerns about domestic and global prospects. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects FDI to be fairly buoyant during the forecast period, averaging US$3bn a year in 2018-22 (and rising towards the end of the period), helped in part by South Africa's status as a gateway to Sub-Saharan Africa. South Africa is also a major outward investor, especially in Africa, where local firms have a presence in a wide range of sectors, including services and infrastructure, as well as in more traditional natural resource exploitation. Outward FDI averaged US$6.3bn annually in 2014-17, surpassing inward FDI in all four years, which is pattern we expect to continue in 2018-22.
Origin and distribution
The UK remains a key source of FDI, illustrated by deals with Vodafone and Barclays in recent years, alongside other significant investors such as Germany (Mercedes-Benz and BMW) and the US (Coca-Cola, Ford and Walmart). Investment from non-traditional sources, especially China (ICBC) and India (Tata and Cipla), is growing strongly. Financial services, ICT, tourism, real estate, mining and manufacturing are among the most attractive sectors, helped in some cases (such as vehicles) by investment incentives. FDI in South Africa includes greenfield projects-in motor vehicles, pharmaceuticals, food-processing, ICT and beverages-and buy-outs of existing firms (such as Massmart). The economically powerful Gauteng province receives the bulk of inward FDI, followed by the Eastern Cape (including the Coega industrial zone), KwaZulu-Natal and the Western Cape, but the other five provinces attract less interest. New special economic zones may lead to a slightly more even spatial distribution.
Determinants
Several factors drive inward investment, including South Africa's status as the most advanced economy in Sub-Saharan Africa (with close links to several other regional markets), a sizeable domestic market of 57.7m people (in mid-2018), strong tourism potential and world-class mineral wealth. South Africa's preferential access to the EU market, via a new economic partnership agreement (EPA) concluded in 2014, and to the US market, under the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA), which has been extended by ten years to 2025, also helps to support investment. Set against these factors are a number of deterrents, including a high degree of policy uncertainty, labour-market rigidity (and strikes), skills shortages, widespread crime and the dominant position of parastatals in several sectors. Contentious policy areas include a new mining charter and a new FDI law that limits recourse to international arbitration, as well as proposals to allow for expropriation without compensation, which could damage property rights. Privatisation prospects are limited, although openings will arise for independent operators and public-private partnerships, mainly in energy and transport.
Impact
FDI has a strong positive impact in South Africa, especially in key sectors such as automotive, ICT, banking and mining, and has played a key role in boosting exports, facilitating growth and lifting employment. FDI provides capital, allows for the transfer of technology and skills and binds South Africa more closely to the global economy.
Potential
We expect inflows to rise steadily during the forecast period, from US$2.1bn in 2018 to US$3.8bn in 2022, helped by a pick-up in local growth, but global and domestic risks are significant. The impact on global trade and commodity prices of US-led protectionism (under the Trump presidency), the UK's intention to leave the EU (Brexit) and a slowdown in China all have the potential to impede investment flows. Wide-ranging policy uncertainty in South Africa will also inhibit investment, especially in mining, although the government will implement gradual reforms. Inflows will benefit from the government's activist industrial policy, especially in the automotive segment, and from private-sector investment in renewable energy. The retention of South Africa's AGOA status will also facilitate inflows (barring fresh disputes with the US over South Africa's eligibility), as will closer regional integration within the Southern African Development Community (SADC). The rollout of a domestic cable network will boost bandwidth and cut costs, facilitating investment in ICT, including in cloud computing and data analysis. Business-process outsourcing (given an English-speaking workforce in a similar time zone to the EU) has potential but is underdeveloped. South Africa will remain a key base for companies with pan-African operations by offering a range of services, including banking, capital-raising and trade-related functions.

The population will continue to grow relatively slowly
South Africa's population is projected to grow at a relatively modest rate of 1.1% a year in 2018-22, partly because of the ongoing impact of the HIV/AIDS pandemic. As a result, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the population to rise from an estimated 56.7m in 2017, to 60m in 2022, including positive net migration, mainly from neighbouring states. The latest official estimates for 2018 show that 7.5m people are living with HIV/AIDS-more than in any other country, and equivalent to 13.1% of the population. South Africa has significantly reduced deaths from AIDS, but progress in other areas, such as cutting the incidence rate of new infections, has been slower than hoped. AIDS-related deaths fell to 115,000 (22.1% of all fatalities) in the year to mid-2018-the lowest since the series began in 2002-from a peak of 293,000 in 2016, helped by the mass roll-out of anti-retroviral drugs. Most of those in need now receive treatment, enabling them to live longer and more productive lives, although the costs are substantial, amounting to about US$2bn a year. However, with an incidence rate of 1.2% in mid-2018 (unchanged from mid-2017), South Africa has yet to hit the key 1% benchmark that would bring about a decline in the prevalence rate. Until this occurs, the number of AIDS victims will continue to grow more rapidly than the total population.
The disease will remain a significant source of mortality into the medium term, imposing costs at the household, corporate and national levels. The loss of trained workers, either through death or extended absenteeism, is particularly damaging in a country so short of skills. This requires organisations to adopt coping strategies, such as increased expenditure on training. Any complacency with regards to AIDS is misplaced; instead, the government needs to consider fresh policy initiatives, in partnership with the private sector, to tackle the issue.
Life expectancy will rise steadily
The fall in AIDS-related deaths is accompanied by a rise in average life expectancy, which reached just under 64 years in mid-2018, from a recent low of just 54 years in 2005. The improvement moves South Africa closer to the average for upper-middle-income countries, and further gains can be expected during the forecast period. South African demographic statistics, including age profiles, growth rates and life expectancy also display large variations depending on race. The white population-typically wealthier, older and more educated-declined by 0.4% to 4.5m in the year to mid-2018 (7.8% of the total), thereby maintaining a long-term trend, driven by outward migration. By contrast, in the year to mid-2018, the Indian/Asian population grew by 1.5% to 1.4m (2.5% of the total), the coloured/mixed race population by 1.2% to 5.1m (8.8% of the total) and the black population by 1.8% to 46.7m (80.9% of the total). The black share of the total population will continue rising over time.
National Health Insurance advances
Healthcare, which is marked by costly private-sector provision for the rich and second-rate public provision for the poor majority, is on the cusp of a major shake-up, driven by the government's long-running plans for a National Health Insurance (NHI) system. Two bills in mid-2018, one covering the NHI and the other covering the future relationship between public and private provision, push the process forward, but key details are still lacking (and subject to negotiations). Reforms are clearly needed, especially given a steady rise in overall healthcare costs to about 9% of GDP (of which half is accounted for by private operators), but whether the government's plans will have adverse or beneficial outcomes depends on a host of uncertainties. Risks include making private care less affordable, and putting more pressure on overstretched public facilities and the fiscal accounts. The government intends to roll-out the NHI system, in phases, between 2019-25.
Rapid urbanisation will strain social services
South Africa has experienced urbanisation on a large scale (an estimated 65.8% of the population lived in urban centres in 2017), principally in the main metropolitan areas of Gauteng, namely Pretoria and Johannesburg, and the two coastal cities of Cape Town and Durban. Urbanisation will continue throughout the forecast period, lifting the proportion living in cities (and associated slums) to 68.5% by 2022. Urbanisation is boosting market potential but also raises challenges for policymakers, especially with regard to strengthening service delivery at a municipal level, where capacity is typically weaker. Urbanisation is being accompanied by the rapid growth of informal settlements in the vicinity of cities and towns across the country, fuelled by population movements from poorer provinces (such as Limpopo and North West) to richer ones, and migration from neighbouring countries.

South Africa's consumer market will continue transforming, as the poor black majority is increasingly drawn into the mainstream commercial economy, accompanied by an expansion of the black middle-class. The transition is happening less rapidly than previously hoped, given sluggish economic growth and high levels of unemployment (which constrains aggregate demand), although it will gain momentum during the forecast period, helped in part by government initiatives to address poverty and inequality, such as generous welfare payments, land reform and black economic empowerment (BEE) initiatives. Despite significant changes since the apartheid era, South Africa remains one of the world's the most unequal societies-with a Gini co-efficient of 63-largely because of persistent racial disparities. Policy action and faster GDP growth will erode race-based distinctions over time, as signalled by the most recent (albeit outdated) income and expenditure survey published in 2012. The survey showed that spending by black households was growing faster in real terms than spending by white households, even though the absolute gap remained large. Roughly 35% of all households are classified as middle-class, which will increase over the forecast period.
Consumer spending will show a broad upward trend
Household spending growth in real terms retreated from a recent peak of 5.1% in 2011 to just 0.7% in 2016-the weakest since the 2009 recession-because of high levels of household indebtedness, rising interest rates during the period, weak job creation and wages lost to strikes. Demand was also negatively affected by a severe drought in 2016, which squeezed household budgets, leading to a contraction in durable goods purchases. However, private consumption growth rebounded to 2.2% in 2017, a five-year high, helped by favourable rainfall and a first interest rate cut for five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a slight weakening in 2018, despite another rate cut, because of tax rises, although we forecast a steady growth rebound in 2019-22, in line with the wider economy. More generous welfare payments, rising real wages (for those in work), higher levels of financial inclusion and the expansion of the black middle class, will support the improving trend. Consumer spending will also benefit from the expansion of low-cost housing and electrification-which will boost demand for ancillary goods and services-and from the adoption of a more broad-based approach to BEE. The benefits of BEE have been spread narrowly to date, helping to create a new black elite (the so-called black diamonds, who generally display similar consumption patterns to rich whites). However, the drive towards more broad-based BEE, including employee share-ownership schemes and a focus on suppliers, will spread the gains more widely. This will facilitate the expansion of the black middle class, and boost the purchasing power of poorer market segments. The pending introduction of a national minimum wage (in late 2018 or early 2019) will also buoy consumption by lower-income groups, provided the gains are not offset by job losses. "Demonstration effect" purchasing by new middle-class entrants and blue-collar workers-and easier access to and greater reliance on credit-will buoy markets for more expensive retail goods such as electrical appliances. The spread of modern shopping malls will reinforce the trend, as will competition between the leading retailers: Pick n Pay, Shoprite, Woolworths and Massmart, in which Walmart (US) took a majority stake in 2012 for US$2.4bn.

Consumer expenditure will show a broad upward trend over the forecast period, in both rand and US-dollar terms, although the composition of consumption will not change radically. In line with conventional patterns, the proportion spent on foodstuffs will decline over time, although it will remain the largest single category of expenditure, underpinned by the entry of subsistence-level rural dwellers into the commercial economy, the rise in the spending power of lower-income groups (which typically spend more of their money on food) and growing demand by the emergent middle class for higher-value-added food products. The share of total spending accounted for by housing (and household fuels), transport and communications, and leisure and education, will all edge higher in 2018-22.
