Initial conditions: Growth will revive gradually in 2018-22, helped by a rise in confidence after Cyril Ramaphosa's installation as president, accompanied by greater policy clarity and a crackdown on corruption, which will encourage investment. However, global headwinds (including trade wars) and fiscal consolidation in South Africa, alongside lingering policy uncertainty-especially about land reform-mean that growth, despite quickening, will remain sluggish, averaging 2.2% a year in 2018-22. There is little scope for additional monetary loosening (after an interest rate cut in March 2018), especially given the global trend towards tighter monetary conditions. Growth will therefore be too slow to make a significant dent in the high unemployment rate (currently 27.2%), which will continue to dampen aggregate demand. Structural constraints such as labour market rigidity and skills shortages will persist, although electricity supplies will be adequate, helped by private-sector investment in renewable energy.
The impact of HIV/AIDS will gradually dissipate in 2031-50
Demographic trends: South Africa's population will continue to grow at a slow pace, held back by the impact of the HIV/AIDS pandemic, which may persist for another generation. However, the downward trend in new infections and deaths attributable to AIDS, and the ongoing rollout of treatment programmes, will reduce the impact of the disease in 2031-50. Life expectancy will consequently rise, although population growth will remain relatively muted, as rising disposable incomes and urbanisation lead to smaller families. The working-age population and the labour force will grow more quickly than the overall population, because of the high proportion of young people, as well as inward migration from other African states, thereby making it harder to bring down the unemployment rate. Another key demographic trend will be the rise in the proportion of urban dwellers, from 65.3% in 2016 to 80% in 2050.
External conditions: South Africa's performance, as a relatively small and open economy that is strongly reliant on mineral exports, will remain closely tied to world trends. This leaves South Africa vulnerable to disruptions stemming from US-led protectionism (under the presidency of Donald Trump), the UK's intention to leave the EU (Brexit) and a Chinese slowdown. Multilateral trade liberalisation under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation may fall victim to trade wars, although trade will benefit from bilateral and regional initiatives, including plans for a single African market. The Southern African Development Community (SADC) will continue pressing for freer trade, although ambitions for a customs union, a common market and monetary union may not be realised until after 2030 because of economic and policy divergences between member states. Intra-African trade will continue to be held back by non-tariff barriers and weak infrastructure in 2015-30, but these constraints will ease in 2031-50. Ties with the EU will continue to deepen, following agreement on a new economic partnership agreement (EPA) in 2014. South Africa will retain preferential access to the US market-given the extension of the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA) until 2025-although its eligibility will be subject to periodic reviews. South Africa's trade and investment ties with non-OECD states, especially fellow BRICS members (Brazil, Russia, India and China) will deepen over the long term, at the expense of traditional links with OECD partners.
The quality of institutions will improve
Institutions and policy trends: The quality of institutions will improve, boosting transparency and accountability, but capacity constraints will persist, especially at provincial and municipal levels. Key institutions, such as the central bank and the judiciary, will retain their independence. The wider policy framework-which is based on a partnership between private business and the "developmental state"-will remain intact. In broad terms, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects moderate, centrist voices to prevail in the policy debate in the longer term, at the expense of pro-patronage forces and the interventionist left. The process will be helped by political realignments that could see the fragmentation of the ruling tripartite alliance-comprising the African National Congress (ANC), the Congress of South African Trade Unions and the South African Communist Party-and the emergence of a new coalition between moderates in the ANC and the opposition. Many current policy challenges will persist into the longer term, including skills shortages, high unemployment and the thorny issue of land reform, although investment will alleviate infrastructure constraints.
Productivity gains will boost growth in the longer term
Long-term performance: We forecast that real GDP growth will average 3.4% a year in 2018-30, helped by rising life expectancy, investment in infrastructure, the expansion of the black middle class, regional integration and global demand for commodities. Technological advances, such as cloud computing and additive printing will also drive growth and boost productivity. Growth will quicken to 4.1% a year in 2031-50, as the ICT revolution gathers momentum, and African integration deepens. Growth in capital stocks will outpace growth in labour productivity throughout the period, owing to a combination of skills shortages and investment in new technology.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
The threat of climate change continues to rise up the national agenda, driven by water deficits, which could worsen as weather patterns become more extreme. A three-season drought in Western Cape, after the failure of winter rains in 2015-17, leading to strict water rationing, highlights the challenge. In response, the government is developing a comprehensive climate change policy, in the form of a draft National Climate Change Bill, unveiled in mid-2018, and is also a signatory to the Paris Agreement (2015), which aims to secure cuts in greenhouse gas emissions on a global basis. A proposed carbon tax in South Africa, in gestation for several years, could play a key role, but the plans are generating controversy, as shown during public hearings on a draft bill in 2018, based on concerns about denting competitiveness without bringing about a significant reduction in emissions. Industry representatives believe that national targets for reducing emissions by 13-14.5% by 2025 will be achieved without a carbon tax, given sustained improvements in energy efficiency. There seems little doubt that a carbon tax will be imposed but the current target date of January 1st 2019 is likely to be pushed forward. The government's newly worked long-term energy plan, running to 2030, although not specifically geared towards climate-related objectives will, nonetheless, have a major impact on emissions because of increased reliance on renewable energy at the expense of coal-fired power. Coal's share of installed generating capacity is expected to fall to 45% in 2030, from 72% in 2018. Major reforms in water policy and management are also required, to stem the risk of the now-ended Western Cape drought becoming a nationwide phenomenon.
Technological developments
South Africa, with the most advanced ICT environment in Africa, is well-placed to benefit from future technological progress. The continent's first cloud-computing data centres, under the Microsoft banner, are on course to open later in 2018 in Johannesburg and Cape Town-the two domestic ICT hubs-while Amazon is similarly investing in cloud computing and advanced data processing. In terms of start-up numbers and financing, South Africa leads the pack in Africa, according to recent figures for 2017 from the GSMA, a trade body that represents the interests of mobile network operators worldwide. This partly reflects the size of the local economy, but is also underpinned by South Africa's reputable legal system, strong banks and sufficiently stable power supplies. Skills shortages will, nonetheless, remain a challenge although the probable loosening (over time) of restrictions on inward migration for skilled workers may address some of the deficit. Other obstacles are comparatively high end-user tariffs (although these will trend downwards) and the global problem of cybercrime and data security. South Africa's central role in the multi-national Square Kilometre Array (SKA), a powerful radio telescope centred in Northern Cape, will make a significant contribution to technological progress. SKA's first portion, known as MeerKAT, opened in July 2018 to scientific acclaim, and will be followed by new arrays in South Africa, as well as in other African countries and Australia, over the next decade, at a total cost of at least US$2bn. The high-performance data-processing requirements of MeerKAT and SKA will help drive technological development.
Migration and urbanisation
South Africa is a net recipient of cross-border migration, unlike most African countries, driven by inflows from poorer neighbouring states (and sometimes further afield), which will continue into the longer term. The latest mid-year estimates for 2018 show that net inward migration accounted for about 25% of the total population increase (of 888,000) during the preceding 12 months. From another perspective, inward migration was responsible for 0.4 of a percentage point of the overall 1.6% annual increase. This replicates the broad pattern over the past decade, and is unlikely to change radically in future, although the relative contribution of net inward migration will ease over time for two reasons: faster economic growth in other African states than in South Africa; and a rise in South Africa's natural population growth rate as the impact of HIV/AIDS diminishes. South Africa's white population (4.5m in 2018; 7.8% of the total) continues to shrink (by 19,000 in 2018) because of outward migration, leading to a loss of skills, although migrant inflows are far larger and will also make a positive skills contribution, helped, for example, by Zimbabwe having a superior schooling system than South Africa. Inward migration will continue posing social challenges, given South Africa's high unemployment rate, leading to periodic bouts of xenophobia-tinged unrest. Net inward cross-border migration also means that remittance outflows exceed remittance inflows in South Africa, contrary to the usual African pattern. Internal migration within South Africa, mainly from poorer provinces to the economic hubs of Gauteng and Western Cape, is another key driver of population movement and urbanisation. About two-thirds of South Africans are now urban dwellers, a proportion that will continue to rise, although the proliferation of informal settlements and deficits in service provision will remain pressing issues.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historic data; the source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US & OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US & OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: Dated Brent Blend
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Dollar effective exchange rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics
Population: Based on UN data for both the historical and the forecast periods
Balance of payments: IMF, IFS
Inflation: Statistics South Africa. Based on CPIX (consumer price inflation less mortgage costs)
Exchange rate: IMF, IFS; principal rate expressed as R:US$
Real effective exchange rate index: based on consumer price index; trade partner weighted index with base period 2000=100
Interest rate: IMF, IFS; average lending rate
US$ GDP: SARB, Quarterly Bulletin; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
GDP per head: US$ GDP divided by population
Foreign direct investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report
Total external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and IMF credits
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics, year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity in excess of one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
Total debt service: principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
SARB: South African Reserve Bank
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development
Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2013-17) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2018-22). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2013-17. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2018-22 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2013-17 ranges are then used to derive 2018-22 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2018-22, not to the likely situation in 2022 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2015 or 2020). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Austria--highlights: Political outlook
An early election in October 2017 was won by the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP), led by the young minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, who has since become chancellor at the head of a majority coalition government of the ÖVP and the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ). The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to last a full five-year term. The new government will focus on integration and immigration policy, including by taking a prominent role on this issue within the EU. It will attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and introduce some additional flexibility in labour and product markets. The FPÖ's inclusion in government will not lead to significant tensions with other EU member states as it did in 2000, when the party was last part of a coalition, owing to the normalisation of the far right in Europe since then.
Austria--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
7.77 7.88 15 18 9 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Austria's business environment will improve only slightly in the 2018-22 forecast period, compared with the historical period (2013-17), but stronger improvements elsewhere lead to falls in both our global and regional rankings. The improvement is driven in large part by an improving financing environment following a challenging period for the banking system during the financial crisis. The recent strong economic recovery and related increased market opportunities also contribute to the improvement. The political environment, which is already less stable than in many of Austria's regional peers, will deteriorate further during the forecast period. However, the overall business environment remains strong, owing to high-quality infrastructure, high spending on research and development (R&D) spending, and a relatively well-functioning labour market.

After several years of underperformance compared with its regional peers, the economy has performed relatively strongly since the start of 2016, growing by 3.1% in 2017. We forecast a continuation of strong growth this year, at 2.9%, and a moderation to 1.7% on average in 2019-22. We forecast that the government budget will remain in deficit-albeit well within the EU-mandated limit of 3% of GDP-throughout the 2018-22 forecast period. We expect the current-account surplus to remain broadly stable, at 1.7% of GDP on average in 2018-22, driven mainly by a strong surplus on the services balance, supported by tourism inflows.

The population will grow by an annual average of 0.2% over the forecast period, supported chiefly by net migration. As in many other developed countries, the population will age. The share of the total population accounted for by people of working age is expected to decline slightly over the next five years. Immigration from eastern Europe will remain strong. The influx of migrants and refugees from Syria, Afghanistan and Iraq, which pushed up the population figure in 2015, is not expected to be repeated. The participation of older workers is increasing but remains below the EU average.

Austria is a wealthy country by international standards, with GDP per head well above the regional average. Household consumption growth has been subdued in recent years, and negative labour market trends and high savings rates mean that Austria has not benefited as much as other countries from oil price-related real income gains in recent years. Throughout the forecast period, the outlook for household incomes and consumption is more positive as the labour market recovers. An ageing demographic profile and a rise in the number of single-person households will continue to drive demand for housing, healthcare and leisure services. Income inequalities will remain lower than the regional average.
Austria--highlights: Long-term outlook
  2018-30 2031-50 2018-50

Growth of real GDP 1.7 1.3 1.4

Real GDP per head is forecast to grow by an annual average of 1.4% in 2018-50. An ageing demographic profile will act as a drag on long-term growth prospects, although Austria has more scope than some other EU countries to raise levels of participation in the labour force, particularly among older workers and women. There is also potential for an improvement in productivity growth, with the government encouraging greater R&D activity and investment in education. Austria's large trade and investment exposure to central and eastern Europe will be a net positive for growth in the long term.

Background: Austria became an important force in central Europe with the formation of the Habsburg empire in the 15th century and remained so until the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian empire at the end of the first world war. The Republic of Austria emerged in 1918. In 1938 Austria was incorporated into the German Third Reich. With the departure of the victorious Allied forces in 1955, it regained independence as a neutral country. In the post-war period, Austria took great strides to catch up economically with the rest of the developed world and is now one of the most advanced nations. It is a member of the EU and a participant in economic and monetary union (EMU).
Political structure: Austria is a federal republic, and the head of state is the federal president. The government is led by the federal chancellor. The national parliament has two houses: the Federal Council (Bundesrat, the upper house), of 62 members appointed by state parliaments, and the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house), which has 183 members elected by proportional representation. An early general election was held on October 15th 2017.
Policy issues: The government will focus on migration and integration issues, including in the EU context. It will also attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and implement other measures to improve the business environment, including through enabling more flexibility in the labour market.
Taxation: Austrian labour tax as a percentage of GDP is among the highest in the EU. A 2016 tax reform lowered the tax burden for low- and middle-income earners, but raised the top personal income tax rate from 50% to 55%. Social security contributions, shared between employers and employees, are high. Corporation tax is levied at a rate of 25%. Dividend and investment income is subject to a withholding tax of 27.5%. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a standard rate of 20%, and a reduced rate of 13% (raised from 10% in 2016) applies for certain goods and services.
Foreign trade: Trade relations are dominated by Germany, which accounts for about one-third of total imports and exports. The current-account surplus is driven by strong tourism exports boosting the services surplus. We expect modest current-account surpluses throughout the forecast period.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
An early election in October 2017 was won by the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP), led by the 31-year-old minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, who subsequently became chancellor at the head of a majority coalition government of the ÖVP and the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ). The political scene in the post-war period has been dominated by the ÖVP and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ), generally in coalition together. Although the SPÖ's share of the vote was almost unchanged in the election in 2017, several years of strained co-operation meant that it did not go into coalition with the ÖVP again; it is now the main opposition party. The only other parties represented in the Nationalrat (the lower house of parliament) are the liberal NEOS and List Pilz, a breakaway from the Greens, which failed to win a sufficient vote share themselves for the first time since 1986.

Political outlook: Political stability
The governing coalition consists of the ÖVP and the FPÖ. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects this coalition to prove relatively stable and to last its full term to 2022. This follows several years of minor progress on reforms, and coalition (as well as party) in-fighting under the grand coalition of the ÖVP and the centre-left SPÖ, which fell apart in May 2017. Mr Kurz took over the leadership of the ÖVP, reformed the party around himself, and moved it closer to the FPÖ on issues such as immigration and integration. As a result, he led the ÖVP to the largest share of the vote in the October 2017 election, winning 31.5% of votes-up by 7.5 percentage points on the party's result in 2013. The SPÖ's share was almost unchanged, at 26.9%. The FPÖ increased its share of the vote by 5.5 percentage points, to 26%. The liberal NEOS secured its place in parliament, with 5.3% of the vote, but the Greens failed to cross the 4% electoral threshold for the first time for 31 years, in part because List Pilz, led by a former leader of the Greens, narrowly managed to cross it.
In mid-December, after just over a month and a half of negotiations, the ÖVP and the FPÖ formed a coalition. As Mr Kurz had moved the ÖVP closer to the FPÖ in many policy areas, the negotiations went relatively smoothly. To assuage concerns from Mr Kurz and the president, Alexander Van der Bellen, over the FPÖ's previous Euroscepticism, the party has agreed not to push for a referendum on EU membership. Moreover, EU policy is handled by the chancellery instead of by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, which is headed by an FPÖ appointee.
The chancellor is from the ÖVP, but the election was nevertheless a decisive moment in the fraying of the decades-long dominance of the political scene by the SPÖ and the ÖVP, as the latter has, to a large extent, been replaced by Mr Kurz's new movement. The two parties had together ruled the country almost continuously since 1945, but a renewed grand coalition had become almost impossible following a breakdown in relations and the reform gridlock in recent years. The FPÖ has profited from this and from concerns about immigration, although Mr Kurz also owes much of his popularity to his strong stance on this issue, and his plans to curtail migration into Austria and Europe more generally.
Despite the overlap between the ÖVP and FPÖ programmes, we do not expect the government to implement significant structural reforms, as the coalition partners are likely to disagree on economic matters, on which they are significantly less aligned than on social and cultural matters. In addition, the FPÖ could struggle to translate its opposition stance on topics such as immigration and integration into firm policy proposals. The initial phase of the government's term is likely to be relatively smooth, owing in part to the country's role as president of the Council of the European Union until the end of 2018. Later in the term, the FPÖ might struggle to distinguish itself from the ÖVP, which could lead to tensions between the parties, creating a moderate risk of an early election.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
The state has a well-established division of power between its legislative, executive and judicial branches, all of which function well by international standards. The extent of interaction between the government and its social partners has varied over the past decade, but we expect this to become increasingly contentious as the fraying of the post-war consensus continues. Government decisions have at times bypassed the social partnership system (Sozialpartnerschaft), which establishes a co-operative relationship with trade unions and employers on aspects of economic policymaking. Membership of the Sozialpartnerschaft is compulsory and its role has been made explicit in law. The social partners are encouraged by government to participate in drafting proposals and bills relating to specific issues. As a consequence, they have been involved in negotiations on issues such as public healthcare reform, opening Austria's labour market to workers from new EU member states and improving education. Previous governments have even tended to delegate decisions on labour policy, such as working hours, directly to the two chambers. The framework has tended to work to the advantage of the traditional mainstream parties; its influence decreased when the FPÖ was in government in 2000-05. With the FPÖ again in government from 2017, we expect further pressure on this system, with the party likely to attempt to increase its own influence in many of the social partners' groups, in which it tends to be significantly underrepresented compared with the ÖVP and the SPÖ. Furthermore, the new government showed its willingness to work around this system as it bypassed the social partners when it relaxed rules on working hours in 2018.
Austria's nine federal states (Länder) each have an elected legislature, a state government and a governor, but have fewer direct powers than states in some other federal countries, including Germany. A high proportion of tax revenue is collected at the federal level, although there is some pressure to increase fiscal federalism. Although spending is more decentralised, decision-making is largely concentrated at the federal level, with subnational governments mainly tasked with the administration and implementation of programmes. The principle of finanzausgleich (fiscal equalisation) regulates the distribution of revenue at the federal level between the states. Co-ordination between the different layers of government is strong but also complex, and the lack of accountability and transparency contributes to inefficiencies in the fiscal framework and a high level of bureaucracy. The new government aims to centralise policymaking further, including in areas such as social security and childcare provision, but will face strong opposition from within the ÖVP as the regional governors and the social partners seek to defend their own interests and influence.
Political outlook: Election watch
The most recent general election was held on October 15th 2017. We expect the government to remain in office until the end of its term, which ends in late 2022, maintaining its majority in the Nationalrat (the lower house of parliament). There is a risk of an early election, although we believe that the probability of a snap vote is small. The next election for the largely ceremonial post of federal president will be in 2022.
Political outlook: International relations
Austria was severely affected by the European migrant crisis, and this has been the dominant issue in its domestic politics and international relations since 2015. The country has been at the centre of many of the intra-EU spats regarding the bloc's response to the large influx of migrants. Domestic pressure on the government to be seen as acting against this inflow-and thus often against other EU member states-will remain high. The new government plans to cut child benefit payments flowing abroad, potentially leading to tensions with eastern member states in particular.
Nevertheless, Mr Kurz has been at pains to point out that his government will take a pro-EU stance, and that Austria's EU membership will not be questioned in the coming years. The government wants Austria to be a leading voice in the bloc, especially on migration reform, which its role (until end-2018) as president of the Council of the European Union should facilitate. We expect the government to move forward with proposals such as tighter controls of the EU's outer borders and processing asylum applications outside the EU.
Although the previous inclusion of the FPÖ into government, in 2000, led to sanctions being imposed by other EU nations, the reception has been more muted this time. In that period, a far-right nationalist party entering government was an unusual development, but since then sister parties to the FPÖ have either entered government or supported minority governments in several EU countries, including some Nordic countries and the Netherlands. However, this will at times lead to tensions with fellow EU members, as shown by the fact that a number of countries are now sharing less intelligence with Austria because the ministries concerned are headed by the FPÖ.

Austria's score in the Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings improves marginally between the historical period (2013-17) and the forecast period (2018-22). However, Austria loses ground in the global and regional rankings, owing to more pronounced improvements in other countries. Austria falls from the 15th most attractive market globally in the historical period to 18th in the forecast period. Compared with its regional peers, Austria also suffers a three-place slide, from ninth to 12th. Nevertheless, Austria's business environment remains attractive, despite its relative decline, as illustrated by the improvement in its (already high) overall score. The uptick in our forecast rests on our expectation of a continued improvement in the macroeconomic environment; this should support better financing conditions and market opportunities. The main drag on Austria's score for 2018-22 comes from the political environment in the wake of the 2017 election and also from recent geopolitical developments, with both political stability and effectiveness likely to be negatively affected. Moreover, Austria's scores in a number of categories in our business environment index have remained broadly unchanged, reflecting the slow progress of reform in recent years.
Overall, the Austrian business environment is comparatively attractive. Its main strengths are its stable political environment, highly skilled labour force and high degree of openness to international trade. Although political stability is underpinned by a mature democratic system, the effectiveness of government continues to be hampered by the patronage system in place, which is part of Austria's post-war democratic tradition.

Business environment outlook: Austria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government works on reducing red tape, but progress is likely to be limited.
2020-22: Modest strengthening of competition authority's powers. Administrative reform cuts red tape. More transparency in antitrust proceedings. Possible increase in state involvement in the economy.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Foreign investment is generally welcome, but underlying opposition to takeovers of "national champions" persists.
2020-22: Possible erosion of barriers against foreign takeovers as a result of commercial pressure and EU legislation.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: No exchange controls. Foreign trade, governed by EU rules, should remain liberal. Risk of disruption, owing to trade dispute between the EU and the US, and possibly a disorderly Brexit.
2020-22: EU maintains focus on bilateral free-trade agreements as multilateral trade negotiations stagnate.
Taxes
2018-19: Limited changes to the tax system aimed at reducing the sizeable income tax wedge.
2020-22: Vested interests will continue to hamper large-scale reform, and the high tax burden will remain.
Financing
2018-19: Financial stability to improve amid tighter regulatory requirements and a reduction in risk from exposure to central and eastern Europe. Lending growth remains strong.
2020-22: Further uptake in corporate bond issuance. Credit conditions continue to ease as banks' profitability recovers, in part supported by a gradual uptick in interest rates.
The labour market
2018-19: More stringent requirements for early retirement and invalidity pensions. Labour market continues to improve as increase in labour supply moderates and unemployment continues to fall.
2020-22: Continued modest expansion of labour supply, primarily via net immigration, but concerns over shortages of skilled employees in certain sectors are likely to persist. Early retirement phased out.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Further take-up of broadband services. Gradual improvement of transport links with eastern Europe.
2020-22: Work continues on transport network, including on tunnel connection to Italy.
Technological readiness
2018-19: Internet use remains slightly below several regional peers, but research and development remains relatively strong.
2020-22: Further progress made on upgrading the large manufacturing sector to take advantage of new technologies.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
7.8 8.6 20 9 7 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The macroeconomic environment is improving
Austria's macroeconomic environment has improved markedly following a strong 2017 growth outturn, the momentum of which has so far carried over into 2018. However, this follows several years of only tepid expansion. The recent upturn has led to a revival in manufacturing output that has fuelled a decline in unemployment and now also an uptick in wage growth. The environment should remain favourable during the forecast period, owing to solid public finances, falling unemployment, a competitive exporting base and supportive financing terms. There will be some challenges, however. Austrian manufacturers are dealing with capacity constraints that will keep a lid on growth as long as they remain unaddressed, although capital investment has increased recently.
Risks to the outlook stem from Austria's openness to-and dependence on-international trade. A slowdown in European and international demand, compounded by the risk of an increase in protectionist sentiment, would affect Austrian growth prospects. Uncertainty over the outcome of the Brexit negotiations and beyond could weigh on business confidence.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
7.8 7.8 20 21 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Policy towards private enterprise and competition is liberal and should remain so over the forecast period. Austria's good standing in the rankings is underpinned by high levels of protection for private and intellectual property, relatively benign government regulations and high freedom to compete, low levels of state control, and good protection of minority shareholder rights. However, Austria scores poorly with regard to its overall competition policy framework and influence of lobbying activity. Austria's stagnation on the competition front was reflected in the World Bank's Doing Business rankings, in which its overall score has lost some ground in recent years, although the country is still ranked highly. Businesses find it easy to trade across borders, enforcing contracts and resolving insolvency, although procedures to start a new business are suboptimal and rank poorly. Meanwhile, policy is still restrictive in the services industry: according to the OECD's Services Trade Restrictiveness Index, Austria has a more restrictive policy than the OECD average in 11 of 21 sectors covered by the index. Although some improvements to the competition framework have been made in recent years, such as a reduction in the amount of capital needed to form a Gesellschaft mit beschränkter Haftung (GmbH; a company with limited liability), from EUR35,000 to EUR5,000 for the first ten years of its existence, which is more in line with the requirements in other EU countries, we do not expect any significant improvements over the forecast horizon.
The competition framework could be strengthened
Despite improvements to the competition framework in recent years, there is still scope to strengthen the enforcement powers of the independent Federal Competition Authority (BWB), which is one of the smallest in the EU. Some measures are planned that could boost its effectiveness. The new government has planned to merge the BWB with the Federal Cartel Prosecutor, a measure that has long been advocated as a way to improve effectiveness. There has also been an uptick in public funding in recent years. Positively, the third EU energy liberalisation programme, implemented in 2009, should gradually lead to greater price transparency and higher customer mobility in the electricity and gas sectors. As part of these reforms, Austria is working to improve internal market mechanisms by unbundling transmission system operators from generation, production and supply.
Risk of greater interference in private enterprise
The risk of political interference in private enterprise remains relatively high. On April 1st 2015 a new entity, Österreichische Bundes- und Industriebeteiligungen (ÖBIB), assumed responsibility for managing the Austrian state's holdings in several private companies, such as Telekom Austria and OMV, an oil producer. The changes allow for greater government involvement in the management of the firms. Moreover, the political composition of the nomination committee creates the potential for the selection of board members to become the subject of intra-coalition wrangling.
The retail sector has long been subject to heavy regulation, restricting the number and type of outlets, and hours of business. Although over the years there has been a significant liberalisation of shop opening hours, further liberalisation has faced opposition from a strong alliance between the trade unions and the Catholic Church, which wants to prevent shops from opening on Sundays and Catholic holidays. The conservative nature of the new government means that little progress in further liberalisation is likely.
Few privatisations of state-owned companies have taken place in recent years. Public opinion is generally sceptical towards privatisation. The new government has said that it is open to state ownership of strategic companies should the need arise. However, this is unlikely to have any significant impact in coming years in terms of the state's share in the economy.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
8.2 8.2 19 21 11 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Austria has a generally open and welcoming stance towards foreign direct investment (FDI), and we expect this to continue over the forecast period. Austria's score is underpinned by strong investor protection and very low expropriation risk, although it scores only adequately on the "openness of national culture" metric. Overall, there are no sectoral or geographical limitations on FDI flows, although there are tough environmental regulations that need to be accounted for. There are few specific restrictions on foreign ownership of companies and property, and regulations do not tend to discriminate between domestic and foreign-owned companies. The Austrian Business Agency (ABA) is the government body responsible for FDI relations and provides advisory services to prospective investors. However, in recent years there has been increasingly vocal discontent when "national champions" have been taken over. In 2013 a law was passed requiring ministerial approval when non-EU foreign investors wish to take a 25% or greater stake in a firm operating in a sector deemed of national interest.
We expect Austria to maintain its close economic ties with central and east European countries; opportunities in west European economies are limited, owing to saturated markets. Austria will also retain its attractive position as a link between western, central and eastern Europe, which will continue to offer investment opportunities. Many Austrian firms distribute to central and east European countries at the wholesale level (although there remains significant room for improvement on transport links to the region). Many Austrian banks continue to operate significant networks in central and eastern Europe-despite some retrenchment since the global financial crisis-and so can offer access to trade and investment financing for companies that want to do business there. However, exposure to central and eastern Europe entails risks, highlighted by ongoing concerns about political and security risks in Ukraine and tensions between the EU and Russia. Austria is among those countries with most to lose from a long-term decline in political relations with Russia, for example via finance, tourism, investment and construction channels.
The new government has vowed to increase Austria's attractiveness to foreign investors. Planned measures to support this aim are boosting funding to the ABA to allow it to pursue potential investors more aggressively and stepping up so-called national branding on the model of the UK's "GREAT" campaign.
Some ambivalence exists towards international trade agreements
However, there are some clouds on the horizon that will limit Austria's progress in becoming a more attractive investment destination. The new conservative government has voiced its scepticism about some of the comprehensive free-trade agreements (FTAs) being negotiated by the European Commission. Although the new government ratified the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) with Canada in June 2018, it has stated that it wants greater transparency and safeguards in future FTAs, which could hamper progress towards freer-flowing capital.
In mid-2018 the European Commission approved draft rules on establishing a regional framework for screening FDI into the EU on grounds of national security. Some member states have criticised the plans as protectionist in nature, although the Commission argues that similar initiatives exist in major trading partners such as China and the US.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
9.6 9.6 9 8 5 4
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Austria's foreign trade and exchange regimes are defined by its memberships of the EU and the euro zone. Goods, services, capital and people can move freely across borders within the EU, of which most countries bordering Austria are members, and we do not expect this to change over the medium term. No tariffs or quotas are permitted within the EU, and we do not expect any exchange controls. The EU trades with Norway and Iceland under the European Free Trade Association (EFTA), and has a range of bilateral agreements with Switzerland and a customs union with Turkey. Only agriculture is excluded from these arrangements. Bureaucratic barriers to foreign trade are low in Austria. The World Bank's Doing Business 2018 report ranks the country as a global leader in terms of the ease of crossborder trading, with the costs involved and time taken to export and import goods well below the average for high-income OECD countries.
Little further progress on global trade liberalisation expected
Trade between EU member states and third countries has been largely governed by multilateral agreements administered by the World Trade Organisation. There has been minimal progress in global trade talks over the past decade. A general increase in protectionist sentiment, notably in the US, means that little progress will be made in multilateral trade talks over the forecast period. The EU's focus will thus be on bilateral deals, and we expect further gradual progress in this area. The backdrop will be challenging, however, given the rise in protectionist measures implemented by governments around the world. These actions are likely to inhibit global trade flows, and there is a notable risk that an escalating chain reaction of measures will occur, threatening a dramatic fraying of the multilateral trade system.
The EU-Canada agreement, CETA, will gradually come into force. CETA, which the Austrian government ratified in June 2018, will eliminate most trade tariffs, ease border procedures and increase regulatory co-operation. In December 2017 the EU finalised an economic partnership agreement with Japan that will create the world's largest free-trade area. The deal will come into effect from early 2019, although there will be a lengthy transition phase for most measures over the next decade. In April 2018 the EU and Mexico agreed in principle to a trade deal that would include a significant reduction of tariffs.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.5 6.4 31 43 9 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Austria's score on taxation deteriorates marginally between the historical and forecast periods, but both its global and regional rankings fall significantly. Austria benefits from a relatively low corporate tax rate of 25% and a comparatively fair tax system. However, the tax system is held back by its complexity and high labour income tax rates, with a progressive system consisting of seven brackets, rising from 0% to 55%. Austria ranks around average in the EU for value-added tax (VAT), with a headline rate of 20%. The corporate tax rate has been at 25% since 2005, broadly in line with most regional peers. Overall, the tax/GDP ratio (which also includes social security contributions) was 42.9% in 2016 (latest available data), above the EU average of 40%. In terms of tax structure, the share of tax receipts from VAT, personal and corporate income, property and indirect taxation is in each case roughly on a par with the EU averages, whereas the share of revenue from social security contributions is considerably higher. Austria had the fifth-highest tax wedge among the 35 OECD members, suggesting that the 2015 tax reform that came into effect in January 2016 and cut a number of taxes had little overall impact.
The new government has made comprehensive tax reform one of its main goals and is aiming to lower the tax/GDP ratio to 40%. It plans greatly to simplify the tax system for households and companies and allow the latter to reduce their tax base. Through these measures, it also hopes to lower the effective tax rate for corporates and households. A number of tax relief measures for poorer households have already been included in the budget passed earlier this year. However, there is some doubt as to whether the government will be able to deliver on its promise, given the contentious nature of the reforms and their large scale. Furthermore, although the budget deficit has narrowed in recent years, fiscal space remains limited and the government is likely to struggle to find sufficient spending cuts to fully offset the decrease in taxes.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.6 8.1 27 18 10 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
A stronger banking sector will support credit growth
Austrian credit conditions are expected to improve dramatically over the forecast period, helping the country to rise by several places in the rankings. The improvement is predicated on our expectation that the banking sector and the stockmarket will become more dynamic and that financial distortions will be low to non-existent. Moreover, improvements in the regulatory framework, and to foreign access to finance and greater access to investment finance, should provide support for the uptick in financing conditions. The Austrian economy, like much of the euro area, is highly dependent on the banking sector to finance itself, although capital markets as a source of long-term credit are gaining traction. Austrian banks are on a healthier footing, as shown by their improved capital ratios, which are now well above the legal minimum for the sector. They are also relatively unencumbered by non-performing loans (which made up just 2.3% of total loans in early 2018). The banking sector's exposure in central, east and south-east Europe (CESEE) remains significant, having caused large write-downs in the wake of the global financial crisis. Positively, the CESEE region's macro-financial conditions and economic dynamics have improved significantly. The asset quality of the banking sectors in CESEE have strengthened markedly, reducing risks to the Austrian banking system.
Financial-sector supervision lies with the Financial Market Authority (FMA), the Austrian Nationalbank (the country's central bank) and the European Central Bank. To rein in banking sector risk, in 2011 the central bank announced new capital rules and lending curbs for banks. Banks are required to adhere to tighter capital requirements, to take account of the full implementation of Basel III rules from 2013. The FMA introduced a systemic risk buffer of up to 2% of risk-weighted assets, to be phased in over 2016-19, following earlier macroprudential measures that focus on stronger local funding of Austrian banks' subsidiaries abroad and fewer foreign-currency loans. Banks are subject to a loan/deposit ratio ceiling of 110% for lending in CESEE, and are required to write "living wills" to prepare for potential crises.
Bank profitability should continue to improve over the forecast period. The highly fragmented Austrian banking sector, which is very localised, carries high costs. Additional regulatory burdens placed on the sector in recent years have added to the financial burdens on many small banks, which have been compounded by the low interest-rate environment. Nevertheless, banks have improved their efficiency and also undergone some consolidation to bring costs down. This will support further lending growth in the coming years, after lending to the non-financial corporate sector began to increase in early 2017. The unwinding of the three "bad banks" that were set up in the wake of the financial crisis to clean up banks' balance sheets will continue apace.
Risks to the banking sector remain, owing to its exposure to the CESEE region and the uncertainty surrounding the impact of sanctions on Russia and their likely continuation. The economic outlook in the region is sensitive to swings in Russia's economic fortunes. However, risks relating to foreign-currency loans have receded, and should continue to do so, following the introduction of regulatory measures in recent years to restrict these kinds of loans.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.7 6.7 13 12 5 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The labour market has turned a corner after years of rising unemployment
The Austrian labour market should remain attractive and operate well over the forecast period. The labour force is well qualified and healthy, with good foreign language skills. Moreover, labour productivity is high-on a par with that in Germany. The labour market itself is underpinned by a significant degree of flexibility compared with other developed economies, with few restrictions on hiring and firing. Labour costs are high, however. There is a high degree of industrial harmony between unions and employers, underpinned by the consensual system of social partnership. However, the labour market is under increasing pressure from labour shortages, owing to the strong economic upswing, which has driven down unemployment. An increasing number of manufacturers are reporting difficulties finding qualified labour and have had to turn down contracts as a result. Like neighbouring Germany, Austria has to contend with an ageing workforce. It also suffers from low labour market participation from women, migrants and older workers.
The government has made addressing the labour shortage one of its priorities. It plans to bolster the apprenticeship framework by providing financial incentives to firms through the tax system. However, it is unlikely that the impact of these measures will be felt to any significant degree over the forecast period, given the longer time horizon labour market reforms usually require.
Owing to a lack of prioritisation by the new government, little progress is to be expected in relation to increasing the labour participation rate of women and migrants. This is likely to lead to further stress in the labour market in the short to medium term. There are plans to facilitate the recognition of foreign qualifications to allow migrants into work more easily. However, the government's heightened political hostility towards migration, reflected in its decision to cut a number of labour market programmes that are aimed at the long-term unemployed and at integrating migrants into the labour market, will make their integration harder. Furthermore, such measures risk putting off potentially highly skilled immigrants from moving to Austria.
Labour market flexibility to be increased
Plans have been announced to introduce more flexibility into the labour market. Working hours are the primary channel through which the government hopes to achieve this. Firm-level wage agreements will increasingly be applied, as opposed to branch-level ones. This risks heavy opposition from unions, which could negate the positive impact of the reforms in the short term by spoiling Austria's strong labour relations.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
8.3 8.0 10 13 8 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Austria has high-quality infrastructure and ranks well globally and regionally. Its infrastructure is well distributed across the territory, boasts excellent road and rail density, as well as good waterway and air connections. An extensive transport network provides good access to west European industrial centres. However, links to its southern and eastern neighbours suffer from underinvestment. This latter point is particularly important in view of the continuing rise in transit traffic (both east-west and north-south) through Austria, which is creating bottlenecks and raising environmental concerns about vehicle emissions. The country also benefits from excellent healthcare, telecommunications and energy infrastructure. Mobile telecoms prices have fallen in recent years, owing to increased competition, prompted by the entry of several new providers to the market.
The government does not plan to develop a large-scale infrastructure programme over the forecast period. It will focus instead on improving the efficiency of public investment in transport infrastructure. It will scale back some of the previous government's more ambitious infrastructure investments, in part because of the high indebtedness of the national railway company, ÖBB. Nevertheless, work will continue on three new tunnels, which should be completed by 2026 at the latest. This includes the Brenner Base Tunnel, a 55-km rail tunnel to Italy under the Brenner Pass, co-financed with Italy and the EU.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
9.4 9.2 3 11 3 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
This category, introduced in 2018, aims to show the extent to which the business environment is open to innovation, digitally connected and prepared for technological disruption. Although Austria's technological readiness ranks well in global and regional comparisons, its score drops slightly in the forecast period. The country has a high-quality e-commerce environment, well-developed e-government services, excellent research infrastructure and high levels of research and development (R&D) spending. It also ranks well in cybersecurity preparedness, and in terms of its number of mobile-phone and internet users. R&D intensity was 3.1% of GDP in 2016, which placed it behind only Sweden in the EU. The government is seeking to increase private-sector involvement in R&D spending. It increased the research tax premium by 2 percentage points to 14% to attract private investment into research. However, there are still too few links between Austria's research community and business, which makes it difficult to develop innovations commercially and bring them to market. Moreover, the country's digital infrastructure lags behind regional peers, primarily because of the deep "rural divide" in broadband coverage: only 45% of rural households have access to high-speed internet, compared with a national average of 90%.
The government aims to increase the links between research and business. It also plans to develop tools to attract foreign private investment in R&D. However, few firm proposals have so far emerged, suggesting that the effectiveness of government policy in matters of technological readiness will be limited over the forecast period.
There are more tangible proposals regarding the physical infrastructure underpinning the government's digital strategy. It plans on rolling out 1Gb internet connections throughout the whole country and to develop a fifth-generation (5G) network by 2025. Government services will be further digitalised, as will schools. Law and regulation changes are also planned to accommodate the changing nature of government and business.
The government is looking to upgrade the large manufacturing base
In line with its counterparts in a number of other European economies, the government set up an Industrie 4.0 initiative in 2014 to bring together parties involved in new manufacturing techniques. The relatively large share of manufacturing in the economy, with companies often deeply connected to the large German manufacturing sector, will ensure that the government will continue to focus its attention here and less on, for instance, fostering an internet start-up environment.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
The new government plans to move integration and immigration policy further to the right, including through curtailing benefits for asylum-seekers and cutting child benefits that are sent abroad. It has also presented plans that focus on improving the business environment, including by reducing corporate tax rates and introducing more flexible working hours. Furthermore, it plans to cut a number of labour market programmes that are aimed at the long-term unemployed and integrating migrants into the labour market. Although it has announced a push to centralise and streamline the welfare system-to which several major stakeholders, including state governors, are likely to object-it does not plan to reform the so-called Proporz system, under which the Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) had apportioned public entities and functions (state companies, public services, subsidies and regulatory responsibilities). This is despite suggestions from both coalition parties-especially the Freedom Party (FPÖ)-in the past that they would want to do this. The Economist Intelligence Unit therefore believes that reforms will remain limited to small-scale efforts in only a few areas, such as the labour market, and expects the government to struggle to implement significant structural reforms rapidly.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy

Driven by both a lacklustre recovery following the financial and euro zone crises and a lack of fiscal consolidation, the fiscal accounts have remained in modest deficit in recent years and within the 3% of GDP limit set by the EU. Strong growth contributed to a narrowing of the deficit to 0.7% in 2017.
The government plans to achieve a small budget surplus in 2019 by cutting spending, and reducing income taxes and the country's sizeable tax wedge at the same time. However, it has not yet clearly outlined the spending cuts that it intends to make, barring a number of smaller measures, including cutting spending on asylum-seekers. We therefore do not share the government's optimism that a surplus can be attained in 2019. Nevertheless, continued robust economic growth will contribute to a further narrowing of the deficit; we expect it to average around 0.3% of GDP in the 2018-22 forecast period.
The public debt stock is projected to decline gradually, from 78.2% of GDP in 2017 to just below 67% in 2022. Although the public finances will remain in a worse state than in countries such as Germany or the Netherlands, the low interest-rate environment and Austria's relatively strong fundamentals mean that funding risks are extremely low, in our view.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy
Interest rates

Long-term interest rate (av) 0.6 0.7 1.0 1.4 1.8 2.2
The European Central Bank (ECB) is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a quantitative easing (QE) programme that is running at EUR30bn per month in January-September. This will run at EUR15bn per month in October-December before coming to an end. Economic activity in the euro zone has softened this year, but the ECB's outlook remains fairly positive. Rising commodity prices and evidence of building domestic price pressure in parts of the zone should mean that sufficient inflationary pressures will begin to emerge in 2019-20. In response, we expect the ECB to take steps towards normalising its policy stance, with an increase of 25 basis points in the main refinancing rate, to 0.25% in early 2020, and five more rises that will lift the rate to 1.5% by end-2022. An increase in the deposit rate, which currently stands at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019, easing pressure on banks' lending margins and supporting profitability.
