Austria's initial recovery from the global financial crisis was respectable in the euro zone context, but the economy subsequently stalled and underperformed compared with regional peers-notably Germany. This was particularly striking, given the traditionally high level of synchronisation between the two countries' business cycles. A faltering reform process in recent years contributed to higher inflation compared with regional peers, and weakened productivity growth-admittedly from fairly high levels. However, the economic recovery gained significant momentum from the second half of 2016. Although in previous years the labour market had struggled to integrate the significant increase in the labour force, it seemed to have turned a corner in late 2016 and in early 2017. We expect a continued gradual improvement in labour market indicators in the coming years. This is supporting private consumption, which we expect to grow by 1.9% this year. Export and investment rates have also picked up. As a result, real GDP growth was 3.1% in 2017-above the level in Germany for the first time since 2005, and Austria's fastest growth rate since 2007.
We expect the current phase of catch-up growth-after an underperformance compared with fundamentals in recent years-to continue this year. However, we forecast slightly slower real GDP growth, of 2.9%, as we expect the impulse from the manufacturing sector to be less pronounced in 2018. Nevertheless, increasing labour shortages will contribute to business investment pushing up investment growth in the first half of our five-year forecast period. Fuelled by the improvement of the labour market, domestic demand will be the main driver of growth. In 2019-22 we expect a further moderation of growth, to 1.7% on average-close to the economy's potential growth rate. Government policy is likely to be supportive of growth in the coming years, and the main risks are external. As a highly open economy, Austria is vulnerable to global economic developments, including the negative economic impact of a potential disorderly Brexit, which is not our core forecast. If the trade dispute between the EU and the US were to escalate further (which is not our core projection, especially after the EU and the US announced their intention in late July to strike a limited trade deal), there is potential for much larger disruption.

Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Although it has shrunk in size, industry still accounts for around 28% of Austria's GDP and remains an important driver of economic growth, owing to the large manufacturing sector, which is highly integrated in regional supply chains. After a steep contraction in 2009, the industrial sector bounced back fairly strongly as global trade volumes picked up, growing by an average of 3.2% per year in real terms in 2010-12. However, Austrian industry could not escape the subsequent downturn in euro zone growth. Industrial growth averaged just 0.7% in 2013-16. The weaker performance of recent years has brought into focus a decline in competitiveness compared with some of the country's euro zone peers, and Austrian exports have lost market share. However, industrial growth accelerated sharply in 2017, to 6.5%, as the Austrian economy benefited from a synchronised global upswing and an especially strong year in its main European export markets. We forecast another year of strong industrial growth in 2018, in part reflecting catch-up after the weak post-crisis years, at 4.6%, followed by a moderation to average growth of 1.2% in 2019-22.
Tourism and finance continue to dominate the services sector
Services dominate the Austrian economy, accounting for over 70% of GDP. Two of Austria's most prominent services sectors are financial services and tourism. Austrian banks' early moves to establish a strong position in central and eastern Europe initially gave them a strategic advantage over other European competitors, although in the post-crisis years many of these investments caused problems. These have now largely passed and the sector is looking increasingly healthy and able to contribute to growth in the coming years.
Austria's tourism sector is highly developed and large by international standards. Tourism receipts were equivalent to 5% of GDP in 2016, according to the World Tourism Organisation, compared with only 1.2% in Germany and 1.9% in France. Tourism has held up well in recent years, despite the euro zone crisis. The weakness of the Russian economy and the rouble have led to a decline in the number of Russian visitors (who are often among the higher-spending tourists), but overall we expect the Austrian tourism sector to remain strong during the forecast period, partly because destinations such as Turkey and Egypt have become less attractive for European tourists. The government has made efforts to develop the tourism industry and has sought to diversify away from its traditional heavy reliance on Alpine holidays. One area of growth in recent years has been "wellness tourism", with Austria's clean air, attractive environment and top-class facilities promoted strongly as a favoured destination for health-related holidays. We expect growth in the services sector to continue closely tracking headline GDP growth, at 2% on average in 2018-22.
Agriculture will remain small as a percentage of GDP, but-unlike in some parts of western Europe-it is not expected to contract in the forecast period. However, stronger growth in other sectors will see its share of GDP fall from 1.3% on average in 2013-17 to 1.2% in 2018 and slightly further in the coming years. We expect the sector to grow by an annual average of only 1% in 2018-22.

Annual consumer price inflation (EU harmonised rate) has been subdued in recent years, but higher than in most other euro zone countries. It averaged 0.9% in 2015-16-well above average inflation in Germany and the euro zone. This largely reflects structural domestic factors, such as higher unit wage costs, more regulated markets, and a period of faster increases in taxes and duties. Rising services prices and energy price base effects caused a gradual increase in inflation in 2017, leading to a full-year average of 2.2%. We expect full-year average inflation of 2% in 2018, driven largely by the uptick in global oil prices in the first half of 2018. A strengthening of the euro will weigh slightly on inflation, but we expect price growth to stay above the euro zone average in 2019-22, at 2% on average, as structural factors seen in previous years persist.

In 2017 the euro rallied as the region's economic recovery strengthened and expectations of QE tapering increased, and as political risk waned in Europe but rose in the US. The exchange rate peaked at almost US$1.25:EUR1 at the start of February 2018, but weakened to US$1.16:EUR1 by late May in response to the formation of a populist, Eurosceptic government in Italy, and weakened further to US$1.13:EUR1 in mid-August. The euro will remain under pressure from political risk in Italy and from monetary tightening in the US, but we expect it to begin to strengthen against the US dollar from 2019, on the assumption that the region's recovery will continue while growth momentum in the US slows. We forecast an average rate of US$1.19:EUR1 in 2018-19 and US$1.21:EUR1 in 2020-21. The euro will also receive structural support from a large regional current-account surplus, and we expect it to appreciate to US$1.24:EUR1 on average in 2022.

Low oil prices and subdued domestic demand (compressing import values) helped to push the trade balance into surplus in recent years, from a deficit in 2009-13. Rising oil prices in 2017 pushed it back into a modest deficit, however, and we expect gradually widening trade deficits during 2018-22. However, the current account should remain in positive territory, largely owing to solid surpluses on the services balance, driven chiefly by robust tourist inflows This will ensure healthy current-account surpluses in 2018-22, averaging 1.7% of GDP.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Austria
Stocks and flows
Inflows of foreign direct investment (FDI) have risen steadily since Austria joined the EU. Although it remains one of the smaller hosts in western Europe in absolute terms, it has made substantial progress relative to the size of its economy. The stock of FDI increased significantly from the equivalent of 6.6% of GDP in 1994 (the year before Austria joined the EU) to 70.3% in 2017. FDI inflows posted a record of US$81.3bn in 2005, but have since dropped significantly, to US$800m on average in 2011-17. FDI outflows followed a similar pattern: after peaking at US$81.5bn in 2005 they stood at US$14.3bn (divestment) in 2010, before averaging US$7.3bn in 2011-17. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the stock of Austrian FDI abroad to rise gradually in the coming years, from US$339.7bn in 2017 to US$401.7bn at the end of the forecast period in 2022, and the stock of FDI in Austria is expected to rise gradually from US$294.1bn over the same timeframe.
Origin and distribution
Companies in other EU member states have traditionally been the largest inward direct investors, accounting for over half of the inward FDI stock in 2017. Historically, most FDI comes from the EU15, in particular Germany, and Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands have also been important sources of inflows. In terms of stock, Germany remains comfortably the biggest holder, with EUR44.5bn in 2017 (28.7% of the total), followed by Russia (EUR27bn; 17.4%) and the US (EUR11.6bn; 7.5%). Central and south-eastern Europe remains an important destination for Austrian FDI outflows, although the stock of outward investment in this region has remained relatively steady in recent years, as companies have been repatriating capital. The region now represents around 31% of the total stock of Austrian outward FDI, compared with 50% in 2008. Professional scientific and technical services activities, financial intermediation and trade were the sectors in Austria with the greatest foreign investment in 2017. The same was true for Austrian investors abroad, although financial intermediation was by some margin the largest sector for outward foreign investment, largely because of Austrian banks' deep involvement in central and south-eastern Europe.
Determinants
Austria's main strengths as a location for FDI are its central location within the EU's single market, its proximity to and historical ties with eastern Europe, its competitive corporation tax rate (25%), an educated and flexible workforce, an excellent labour relations record, advanced information technology (IT) and telecommunications infrastructure, a growing emphasis on research and development (R&D), and a high quality of life. However, negative aspects for Austria are its high level of employers' social security contributions, its significant levels of red tape, and delays in expanding road and rail infrastructure towards eastern Europe. Outward direct investment has been driven in large part by integration with other euro zone economies, particularly Germany, and by the opportunities provided by the opening up of eastern neighbours' economies, although growth in investment into the former has been stronger in recent years.
Impact
FDI has increased competitiveness by providing a boost to fixed capital formation and assisting in the diffusion of new technologies and best practices developed in multinational companies. Outward investment, particularly in the financial sector, has helped to promote growth in the banking sector and has diversified risks away from the euro zone, although there have been other problems associated with economies in central and eastern Europe, especially Hungary, Ukraine and Russia. Public opinion remains ambivalent towards inward investment, with some opposition persisting in relation to the sale of "national champions"-notably in the manufacturing and energy sectors-to foreign investors. The introduction at EU level of new measures to screen foreign investment from outside the bloc could further limit the impact of FDI.
Potential
Austria's strong links with Germany and central and eastern Europe have historically been viewed as a strength. During the 2008-09 economic crisis, these links were temporarily deemed a weakness, but as the German economy has become the main driver of economic growth in Europe in recent years, Austrian firms have benefited. Despite exposure to central and eastern Europe having been less beneficial in the wake of the 2008-09 global financial crisis, over the longer term growth in much of the region is expected comfortably to outpace that of western Europe. Austrian companies' early move into the region has given them the advantage of establishing themselves there as large and respected organisations, and they are expected to benefit from this during the forecast period. Austria is well placed to remain an attractive bridge to central and eastern Europe. The government will continue to seek to attract companies to establish their regional headquarters in Austria, and the country's favourable corporate tax environment and advantages in terms of quality of life serve as a magnet to high-tech companies in the IT sector. However, a lack of competition in some services markets and the need to expand transport links to Austria's eastern neighbours will remain challenges during the forecast period.

Austria's population was estimated at 8.8m in 2017 by Statistics Austria, an increase of around 500,000, or 6%, over the past decade. The data does not match that used in The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecasts, which come from the UN for comparability reasons and tend to lag the official data. We expect further population growth in the coming years, although this will be less pronounced than over the previous decade. Natural change (more births than deaths) has been a contributor to population growth since the mid-1980s, but the main driver in recent years has been migration. According to Statistics Austria, annual net immigration increased from 3,880 people in 1996 to a record 113,067 in 2015. This largely because of the sizeable intake of refugees in the second half of that year. As this movement came to a halt in the first half of 2016, the figure for 2016 was more in line with the years before 2015, at 64,676, and it fell further, to 44,630, in 2017. We expect this source of population growth to be less pronounced in the coming years.
The share of foreign nationals in the population is relatively high
The share of registered foreign nationals in the total population is one of the highest in Europe, at just above 13% at the start of 2017, up from 7.4% in 2001. On a national measure, which includes people with at least one parent born abroad, the percentage of the population with a migration background was 22.8% in 2017. The high proportion of foreign nationals is in part related to the naturalisation process taking longer than in many other EU countries, although the number of people granted citizenship has been increasing fairly rapidly since 2011. Around two-thirds of foreign nationals are from non-EU countries, with the majority from the former Yugoslavia and Turkey. Measures limiting access to the Austrian labour market for citizens from the ten EU member states that joined in 2004 were removed in April 2011. Restrictions on immigration from Romania and Bulgaria were removed in 2014. The inflow of refugees in 2015-16 led to an increase in people from Syria and Afghanistan, although these two groups together are still slightly outnumbered by people from Romania. The government has suggested European-wide measures to limit migration but implementation of measures to restrict migration from outside the EU has proved difficult and there is little political appetite to curb intra-EU migration. We therefore expect inward migration to continue in the forecast period, mostly from newer member states and non-EU member states in the region.
Austria's population will age as it continues to grow slowly
As elsewhere in the developed world, the population will age owing to a low, albeit slightly increasing, fertility rate (at 1.52 children born per woman in 2017, compared with 1.39 in 2007). Nevertheless, we expect the population to grow by 0.2% in 2018-22, a slightly slower growth rate than in 2013-17. The ageing population is reflected in our forecast for average life expectancy, which is projected to rise from 81 years in 2013-17 to 81.9 years in 2018-22. The number of people aged under 15 is forecast to remain almost unchanged relative to the total population between 2017 and 2022, at just over 14%. Over the same period, however, the proportion of the population aged 65 or over will rise from 19.2% to 20.5% of the total. Highlighting the demographic challenge for the economy, the size of the working-age population will broadly stagnate.
Focus is on boosting labour force participation among older workers
Faced with a declining pool of young, skilled employees, policymakers have acknowledged the need to boost employment among older workers. Reforms of the state-run pension system are an example of this shift in policy: one of the key aims is to reverse the long-standing trend towards early retirement. The effective retirement age is still three years below the statutory level, particularly for men. Currently, retirement is possible from the age of 62 for men and from 60 for women (subject to 40 years of contributions or credits). However, the legal retirement age for women will be gradually brought into line with that for men between 2024 and 2033. Additional measures have been introduced to improve labour market opportunities for older workers (where employment levels at present are below the EU average), including employer incentives to retain and hire older employees, increased funding for retraining schemes and efforts by the Public Employment Service Austria to promote the employability of older workers. As a consequence, the participation rate of those aged 60 to 64 years doubled between 2006 and 2017, to 28.2%. However, in recent years the participation rate of those aged 65 to 69 has stagnated and the participation of workers above 50 years old remains below the EU average.

Austria is a wealthy country by international standards. GDP per head measured on a purchasing power parity (PPP) basis was US$53,724 in 2017, well above the EU average. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Austria's relative position to remain broadly unchanged over the forecast period (2018-22), owing to a pick-up in real GDP growth compared with the previous five years, at 1.9% on average in 2018-22, against 1.8% on average for the EU as a whole. As a result, at US$62,803 in 2022, its GDP per head on a PPP basis means that it will remain one of the continent's (and, by extension, the world's) wealthiest countries.
Consumption growth will accelerate but remain modest
Private consumption growth was weaker than the EU average in recent years but, in line with the recovery across the bloc, accelerated from 2016, when it grew by 1.6%. We expect this upturn to last until 2019, with average growth of 1.7% in 2018-19, after which we expect it to moderate again. Consumption growth will be supported by the improving labour market, which will help to push up incomes, and tax cuts announced by the new government will support after-tax incomes in the coming years. Nevertheless, Austria's traditionally high saving rate, at around 8% in recent years according to the OECD (in line with a number of its regional peers), will mean that the feedthrough of income growth into consumption will remain smaller than in some other markets.
Austria is among the most advanced countries in the world in terms of its telecommunications and internet infrastructure. Total spending on information technology (IT) should grow more by than overall demand over the forecast period, reflecting the increased take-up of internet telephony, broadband and wireless services. The slight acceleration of economic growth and incomes will help to support demand for the latest innovative products, aspects in which Austria has at times slightly lagged some of its regional peers.
Austria's score in the market opportunities category of our business environment rankings remains relatively low in the forecast period, at 6.3 out of 10 (up from 6.1 in 2013-17). This mainly reflects the small size of the market and the relatively weak real GDP and trade growth that characterises a developed market. As a result, even its regional performance is relatively weak, and the country remains only tenth in our regional ranking.

Population ageing will have an impact on spending patterns
Austria is a mature consumer market, but demographic trends will have a large influence on spending patterns over the forecast period. With a high (and rising) life expectancy and a declining fertility rate, Austria's population is ageing. Although the total population is set to grow over the next decade and beyond, the proportion of those between 15 and 64 will drop slightly, and the proportion over the age of 65 will rise. Austria's changing demographic profile, allied to sociological trends (such as the increase in single-person households), will continue to drive demand for housing, transport, communications, healthcare and leisure services. In general, income inequalities across Austria are lower than the west European average, which helps to support private consumption.
In line with other advanced economies, an increasing share of spending is moving online. E-commerce will be a key driver of turnover growth in the coming years as retailers continue to develop their online presence. Nevertheless, the Austrian consumer market tends to be slightly slower than most of its regional peers in its pick-up of new technologies and it lags slightly in the development of the e-commerce environment. As a consequence, there is slightly more opportunity in this area in Austria than in most other western European economies.

Long-term outlook: The long-term outlook

Initial conditions: Austria is a wealthy country. Compared with some other high-income countries, it saw relatively good productivity growth in the period up to 2008, owing to reforms enacted at the beginning of the 2000s. These reforms helped to strengthen the long-term sustainability of the state pension system, lower the tax burden and improve the competitiveness of Austrian companies. However, progress on reform has stalled in recent years, and trends in productivity have been broadly negative since 2010. A number of areas still require attention if Austria is to raise its long-term growth potential. These include increasing product and labour market flexibility, boosting labour force participation rates, raising education standards, reducing high drop-out rates in tertiary education, lowering the tax on labour and continued reform of the banking sector. Although The Economist Intelligence Unit's core forecast assumes some progress in many of these areas, we nevertheless expect slightly slower total factor productivity in Austria than in a number of its regional peers, including Germany.
Migration will not compensate for negative demographic trends
Demographic trends: The total population should grow slightly, by an average of below 0.1% per year, in 2018-50, owing to immigration and higher life expectancy. However, as in other European economies, the population will age over the long-term forecast period. As a result, the working-age population will decline by an average of almost 0.5% per year in 2018-50, and so the share of the working-age population in the total population will decline from 66.7% in 2017 to around 56% by 2050, significantly increasing the old-age dependency ratio. To avoid a sizeable contraction in the workforce, Austria must raise its labour force participation rate, especially of older workers. To some extent, this is being addressed by pension reforms that came into force at the beginning of 2014. Increased net migration is also a (short-term) option, but the hostile political climate toward immigration will limit the scope for this.
External conditions: Austria stands to benefit from the faster expected growth rates of the EU's newer member states in central and eastern Europe over the coming decades, given its strong trade links in the region. Trade relations are expected to be further enhanced as the new member states become more fully integrated, despite continued political conflict between the new member states and the western EU members. However, Austria will remain dependent on the older member states of the EU for its exports. Many of these countries face the same challenges as Austria, including a negative demographic outlook (albeit not as negative in most cases as in many of the new member states) and tepid productivity growth; we therefore expect economic growth to remain moderate.
The traditional party dominance will continue to fray
Institutions and policy trends: Austria is a stable democracy with a well-entrenched rule of law that has underpinned macroeconomic stability over recent decades. Since the second world war, politics has largely been conducted as a system of grand bargains between the centre right and the centre left, which led to a stable political environment and few sharp changes in policy. The system of social partnership, offering trade unions and employers co-operative roles in aspects of economic policymaking, plays an important part in ensuring political and social stability. Although this system is likely to decline in importance as the traditional mainstream parties remain under pressure-reflected in the inclusion in government of the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ) following the 2017 election-we expect the political system to remain relatively stable. Significant reforms in the early 2000s saw Austria attempt to liberalise sheltered sectors of the economy, privatise and slim down the public sector, and encourage entrepreneurship. Liberalisation of the telecommunications sector has proceeded fairly well, but a high degree of state ownership and regulation remains in the electricity sector, and reforms of competition in the services sector also have been slow. The increasingly fluid political landscape has the potential to lead to limited reform in some areas, although some of this could be counterproductive, especially with regard to the free movement of labour and goods.
Long-term performance: Overall, long-term prospects for the Austrian economy are broadly in line with much of the rest of the euro zone. We expect real GDP per head to grow by an average of 1.4% in 2018-50. The demographic profile is not as challenging as for some other euro zone countries (notably Germany), but will nevertheless act as a drag on long-term headline growth prospects. Continued progress on pensions, labour market and healthcare reform will be crucial in this regard. Greater competition in services would boost long-term growth prospects.
Faced with global competition, increasing investment in education and improving the outcomes of research and development (R&D) activity will be crucial. There is now a stronger emphasis on R&D (Austria is third in the EU in terms of R&D spending as a percentage of GDP, at 3.1% in 2016), and education reform is aimed at accelerating the transition to a knowledge-based economy. A particular challenge will be raising the educational standards of second- and third-generation immigrants, and integrating the large numbers of recently arrived asylum-seekers into the labour market. An increase in the number of older workers should stimulate growth and employment in traditional sectors of the economy, but there may be a shortage of skilled labour in areas such as information and communications technology (ICT) and biotechnology.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
Under the EU's plans to meet the target of the international Paris Agreement, which is an agreement within the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), to limit global warming to well below 2°C, Austria is required to reduce its greenhouse-gas emissions by 16% by 2020 and 36% by 2030, compared with 2005 levels. Austria is broadly on course to meet its interim target to reduce emissions by 16% by 2020. However, this success can be attributed in part to lower than expected economic growth at the start of the target period, which began in 2013 (when GDP growth stalled). Annual emissions have come in below the annual targets since the start of the period, but have been rising since 2014. In 2016 Austria's total emissions were up by 1% on the previous year, at 79.7m tonnes of carbon dioxide (CO2) equivalent. The Environment Agency Austria forecasts that this trend will continue to 2020, but that Austria will (probably) still meet its 2020 target, as it will be able to offset any excess with its savings to date. However, the 2030 target will be much more challenging to meet.
The new government affirmed its commitment to combating global climate change and to achieving these targets in the coalition agreement published in December 2017. In May 2018 it published a national climate and energy strategy, as required by the EU, setting out how it intends to achieve its 2030 targets. The strategy foresees a range of measures and investments across different sectors, rather than any overarching headline reform. The most ambitious goal is in the energy sector, with a target (inherited from the previous government) to achieve 100% of electricity from renewable sources by 2030 and "total decarbonisation", with all energy supply coming from renewables (compared with 33.5% in 2017), by 2050. Austria has a strong starting base in terms of renewable energy, owing to its extensive hydropower network, which dates back to the 1940s and was enabled by the country's mountainous topography. Nevertheless, achieving this target will require significant infrastructural investment, notably in new renewables generation, energy storage and energy efficiency.
Political commitment to making these investments is only lukewarm and we therefore expect only a limited effort. This is despite a clear threat to the tourism sector from increasing temperatures and the associated potential negative impact on winter sports tourism. The changing climate is already affecting the skiing season, forcing ski resorts to make more use of artificial snow to extend the season and thereby earnings. As tourism earnings are equivalent to about 5% of GDP, and a significant proportion of this comes from winter tourism, climate change represents a larger risk to the economy than in many other developed economies.
Technological developments
Austria is well placed to deal with the economic impact of technological change. In our Technological Readiness Ranking, it ranked joint fourth. With a score of 9.16 out of 10, Austria scores perfectly across almost all sub-indicators, including internet use, scope of e-government and research infrastructure, only missing the threshold for the top score in cybersecurity preparedness and patent applications. The latter is driven mostly by its small size, as this indicator is not corrected for population size, and the country is thus broadly in line with countries like the Netherlands and Germany.
As with Germany, a specific challenge for Austria's government will be to encourage its strong manufacturing base, which is often highly integrated with German industry, to make use of new technologies. The share of industry in GDP, at about 30%, is among the highest in western Europe; in the Netherlands, for instance, it is only about 18%. Austria, like its northern neighbour, Germany, is faced with threats from new manufacturing centres in Asia. It has created an Industrie 4.0 platform to promote the use of new technologies in manufacturing by bringing together different stakeholders. According to research by EY, a consultancy, 60% of Austrian manufacturers already at least partly use digital technology in their production-above the share in Germany (54%). However, automation and newer technologies such as artificial intelligence play only a very limited role at present.
Another way in which the government hopes to make the economy more future-proof is through increasing spending on research and development (R&D). This is already relatively high, with total R&D spending as a share of GDP of 3.1% in 2016, compared with an average of 2% of GDP in the EU as a whole. Almost two-thirds of this spending is by the business sector; the government sector is the only one that spends less on R&D as a percentage of GDP than the EU average. The government is aiming to push up overall R&D spending to 3.76% of GDP and plans do this by increasing spending by the federal government.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2013-17) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2018-22). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2013-17. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2018-22 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2013-17 ranges are then used to derive 2018-22 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2018-22, not to the likely situation in 2022 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2015 or 2020). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Country Forecast Venezuela September 2018 Updater

Abstract: In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly. After years of ineffectual leadership, most citizens, even those opposing the PSUV, distrust opposition parties. Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Economic collapse and the erosion of the patronage scheme supporting the president, Nicolás Maduro, put the ruling regime's internal cohesion in jeopardy. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a traumatic rift that will end in regime pragmatists allowing opposition participation in a "mixed administration" as a way to remain in power from 2019 onwards. There is a risk that the existing regime will retain cohesion and cling to power beyond 2019 if it finds financing to meet its debt obligations and boost dwindling oil production.
We estimate that inflation exceeded 2,500% at the end of 2017 and will exceed 700,000% by end-2018. GDP will continue to contract in 2018-20. High inflation has led to a collapse in private consumption, and difficult operating conditions have hurt investment. Following a change in policy under a new government, we expect economic growth to resume in 2021.
The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. From 2019 a new government will stabilise the economy, but the wholesale rethink of the institutional framework needed to restore investment and confidence is unlikely.
Worsening shortages of consumer goods and hyperinflation will hit private consumption, and an increasingly difficult operating environment will accentuate a fall in fixed investment. The recession that began in 2014 will continue to deepen despite a partial recovery in oil prices as oil output slumps, and the economy will not return to growth until 2021-assuming that a new government takes power and implements reforms. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, reinforcing our forecasts of only a weak recovery.
US dollar measurements of Venezuela's market size provide an overly positive picture of the economy, given the marked overvaluation of the fixed exchange rate. In reality, recession and extremely high inflation (driven by shortages of foreign exchange and basic goods) will continue to restrict purchasing power. After 2020, under a new government, we expect purchasing power and the business environment to improve.

Venezuela is in 82nd position globally in our business environment rankings for 2018-22, making the country the least attractive investment location in our ranking. This reflects the highly heterodox macroeconomic policies of an authoritarian government, a lack of legal security and weak institutions.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government persists with bias against free markets and ad hoc recourse to heterodox measures. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition. Property rights remain weak.
2020-22: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Access to project financing is difficult and uncertainty over contractual rights persists.
2020-22: Efforts to attract foreign investment gather pace under a new government, although actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2018-19: Opaque currency controls add to uncertainty, severely restrict private-sector access to foreign exchange and impede trade. New government in 2019 starts to remove exchange controls.
2020-22: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2018-19: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite the huge fiscal deficit. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2020-22: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2018-19: Amid severely high inflation, financing remains only available in the short term and banking sector shrinks in real terms.
2020-22: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2018-19: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. An ongoing freeze on redundancies, combined with a large informal sector and skill shortages, makes the labour market exceptionally rigid.
2020-22: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Underinvestment in the water and electricity grid ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2020-22: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued water and electricity rationing.
Technological readiness
2018-19: E-government services remain almost non-existent and deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies.
2020-22: Limited regulator capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has plummeted as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices has plunged the country into a massive economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded republican institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is how to stabilise an economy mired in a years-long economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. At the same time, mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign-exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Using IMF data, The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$21.1bn in 2017 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages. We estimate the current-account surplus at 2.1% of GDP that year.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
Despite a decimated economy and spiralling hyperinflation, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) and the president, Nicolás Maduro, retain their hold on power. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects worsening economic conditions to result in a chaotic political transition, most likely ushering in a government with nominal opposition participation-a "mixed administration"-in 2019. We expect curtailed political stability in 2019-22. The opposition, of which the Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD) is the biggest grouping, remains in disarray. Apart from infighting, this reflects the PSUV's systematic campaign to disenfranchise opposition parties and sideline them from state institutions. After years of ineffectual leadership, most citizens, even those opposing the PSUV, distrust opposition parties. Thus, they are incapable of channelling the anger generated by the country's economic crisis.
In this context, the PSUV is increasingly dependent on the military for support. The country is run by civic-military alliance and a network of businessmen with military or political connections. The accord is sustained by opportunities for arbitrage and corruption made possible by foreign-exchange controls, subsidised imports, clientelism, and control of wasteful public-sector companies. Within this arrangement, factions are primarily explained by personal and patronage ties, resulting in different civic-military factions coexisting within the regime. The ultimate source of resources flowing through this patronage system is PDVSA, the state-owned oil company, whose exports account for the vast majority of foreign-exchange inflows into the country.
Jeopardising the civic-military alliance is the unrest caused by the economic crisis and its ultimate source, the decline in oil production due to mismanagement and underinvestment. Resultant strains have been highlighted by periodic purges in the military and re-organisations in the regime. In June Mr Maduro reshuffled key positions in the administration, giving increased power to Diosdado Cabello. Mr Cabello, a long-time internal rival who has extensive military and business ties, will now lead the Constituent Assembly (ANC, the country's de facto legislature). We interpret this as Mr Maduro attempting to regain internal support, even at the expense of personal power. Regardless, discontent seems to remain, as exemplified in July by unusually public criticism of the administration by other high-ranking PSUV members. Although Mr Cabello is a leading PSUV figure it is unclear if his recent elevation will quell discontent within the party.
An economic plan launched by Mr Maduro on August 20th is self-defeating, and will further place strain on the regime. Indeed, unless the administration turns PDVSA around (we see this as unlikely, as the government lacks the required expertise or financing), we believe that the patronage system supporting Mr Maduro will be at risk of collapse in 2019. This process may be hastened if exports are disrupted by external forces, such as US government sanctions on the oil trade (the US is PDVSA's largest cash-paying market) or asset seizures stemming from unpaid debts.
Regardless of the timing, what happens following the internal fracture is hard to predict. The transition is likely to be violent. The PSUV's internal stability is a concern, as the end of the current set-up is likely to unleash jostling for position between the PSUV's varied civic-military factions. If no faction secures sufficient internal consensus, a period of chaos of indeterminate duration may ensue.
Alternatively, the regime may reconfigure itself, with an outright military government or PSUV civilian figureheads fronting a military-heavy administration. Either of these would probably look to Russia and China, erstwhile backers, for aid to stabilise both the economy and PDVSA. However, we believe that the required financing-tens of billions of US dollars per year-is beyond Russia's means. Despite recent announcements, China has scaled back its financial support for Venezuela since 2015. Even with these financing sources unavailable, the reconfigured regime may still reach internal stability and-given the opposition's weakness-remain in power, albeit resigned to the impoverished state of the country and PDVSA.
However, given that the regime's raison d'etre is the enrichment of its members, stabilisation of PDVSA and the economy would be likely to take priority under a new government, and we expect regime pragmatists to seek western assistance-specifically from multilaterals and governments. As these financiers will demand democratic reforms, we believe that the most likely outcome is a "mixed administration", in which pragmatically minded regime leaders allow opposition participation to gain international legitimacy. Given past behaviour, there should be no shortage of opposition figures willing to participate.
The main risk to this "mixed administration" baseline view is that regime pragmatists will be unable to convince other regime members of the benefit of this arrangement. Democratic reforms that western lenders would insist on may not be acceptable to some PSUV figures. Similarly, foreign financing would underpin a macroeconomic programme that-by eliminating the economy's distortions-would close avenues for corruption and upset regime insiders. Other hurdles of uncertain size will remain. These include the judiciary, the ANC and violent supporters of the current regime, known as colectivos. If these risks materialise in sufficient force, our alternative scenarios-a permanently impoverished nation or chaos of indeterminate duration-could materialise.
Overall, we expect a chaotic transition starting in late 2018 or early 2019. The process will be highly uncertain and may feature several false starts, and we expect the remainder of the forecast period to be characterised by political instability.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
Mr Maduro was comfortably re-elected in elections on May 20th that were neither free nor fair. We do not expect free and fair elections in the short term. Based on our assumption that a mixed administration will take power, an electoral timetable may be announced, as international financing will almost certainly come with demands for democratic reforms.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Most regional governments have denounced the Venezuelan government, as has the EU. The most effective measures have come from the US, which has instituted country-level sanctions that deny Venezuela the possibility of refinancing its debts. Sanctions banning the oil trade outright are not part of our baseline assumption, but a hawkish US foreign policy team increases the risk of this happening. A key priority for the Maduro administration will be the maintenance of good relations with Russia and China. Both have provided financing in the past but seem unwilling to provide the several billions of dollars needed to stem the decline of oil output.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
The government remains unable and unwilling to undertake the policy changes needed to address the country's economic crisis. Monetisation of large public deficits, coupled with mismanagement of the state-dominated oil industry, has led to hyperinflation and shortages of foreign currency, basic goods and industrial inputs.
An economic plan launched on August 20th included the introduction of a new currency, the bolívar soberano (BsS), which replaced the bolívar fuerte (BsF) at a rate of BsF100,000:BsS1. The plan also announced a 5,900% increase in the minimum wage and a devaluation from BsS2.5:US$1 to BsS60:US$1. Despite promising to abolish the monetisation of public deficits, available data for September shows extremely fast growth in money supply. This and its other inconsistencies lead us believe that the plan will be ineffectual. As such, monetary imbalances will persist and foreign-exchange will continue to be rationed. Economic policy will remain interventionist in the short term, deepening the economic crisis that drives our baseline forecast of a move towards a mixed administration.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect that more orthodox economic policies will be implemented. However, the mixed administration will face the same constraints that Mr Maduro has faced: the regime's civic-military factions enjoy wealth and power owing to the state's indirect and direct control of the economy; changing the status also means upsetting the regime's internal stability. Thus, we expect a mixed administration to focus on macroeconomic essentials, such as the stabilisation of the currency and local prices, and tackling mismanagement of PDVSA.
Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and multilaterals (totalling US$19bn in 2019-22) and the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. Internal cohesiveness in the mixed administration will be key, as the PSUV is ideologically opposed to such borrowing and multilateral financing is likely to come with conditions on democratic reforms. Meanwhile, PDVSA must open itself to foreign investment to secure the finance needed to bring output up. This will require considerable political capital, as it would imply a wholesale revision of the sector's institutional framework. Pockets of resistance are likely to exist. Internal stability within the PSUV will remain a major risk to our forecast, as the success of a mixed administration would depend on PSUV pragmatists fending off more radical party members, who would oppose accepting international assistance and reforming policy.
Outside of these areas, we do not expect much success in rolling back the PSUV's strong interventionist bent in the economy. As a result, we expect extremely limited real investment inflows, the vast majority going into the oil sector, which will limit economic recovery and fuel continued unrest.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Authorities have not published official data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We estimate that the fiscal deficit is well into double figures as a percentage of GDP. The government relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency.
High inflation and the overvalued official exchange rate make debt/GDP ratios misleading indicators of fiscal stability. Considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) understates the true size of total public liabilities. Most sovereign and state-owned bonds (including PDVSA's) are in arrears. Bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy changes or, given strains in the PSUV, a change in leadership. ConocoPhillips (US) and Crystallex (Canada) are attempting to collect legal awards by attempting to seize PDVSA assets in the US and the Caribbean. Asset seizures could hit exports, the regime's economic lifeline. So far, the government has renegotiated or stalled via appeals.
Under our baseline forecast, we expect a restructuring with external creditors in 2020. Owing to the need to maintain political stability, we do not expect the closure of the various handout programmes in operation, nor the removal of utility subsidies or the reformation of inefficient state-owned firms. Therefore, we expect public expenditure to be hard to reduce; we expect the deficit to be substantial throughout the 2018-22 period.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank) to print money. In early September, after the announcement of the new economic plan, money supply (M2) grew by 99.3% month on month. Despite promises of reducing money supply growth, the government's policy has been reduced to taking five zeroes off the currency. We expect a new administration to place a much greater emphasis on tackling hyperinflation, and expect a substantial monetary adjustment in the context of a macroeconomic stabilisation plan. The introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) in such a context is possible
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Amid ongoing disruption to the productive base, we project further contractions in real GDP in 2018-20, following an estimated 14% shrinkage in 2017. Our forecast recovery in 2021-22 rests on the assumption of a political transition that, supported by IMF assistance, produces a credible macroeconomic programme with improved management of oil wealth. However, reform will be limited in scope by a weak government, and we expect only a partial rebound in real GDP, following a decline of around 50% in 2013-20.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2018, reflecting the effect on real wages-despite minimum wage increases-of hyperinflation, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will also continue to contract, reflecting the difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange. Our forecast for a recovery in investment later in the forecast period assumes a political transition and a pick-up in investment in the oil sector.
Oil output-long in decline owing to mismanagement and underinvestment-has contracted beyond expectations in recent months; we now expect it to bottom out at 1.1m barrels/day (b/d) in late 2019, down from 2m b/d in 2017. Under our baseline forecast of openness to foreign investment under a new government from 2019, production will start to recover in the second half of 2020, but will remain well below 2m b/d even at the end of our forecast period.
Export volumes will only start to recover in 2021, as an increase in domestic demand, which has been artificially constrained, will initially absorb the increase in oil output. For the same reason, import demand will rise sharply.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Decimated domestic supply, severe limits on imports and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official data have not been published since 2015, but the opposition-led National Assembly estimated that monthly inflation was 223% in August (205,496% year on year). This and the inflationary nature of the government's new economic plan has led us to significantly increase our inflation forecast for end-2018 to over 700,000%.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
Since the start of the year the government has devalued the official exchange rate by over 99%. The economic plan announced in August took the official rate from BsS2.5:US$1 to BsS60:US$1. At the same time the government announced the "free convertibility" of foreign exchange, but in practice the exchange controls remain. The official rate is determined by an auction system, but the government-which monopolises the country's exports-does not supply the system with foreign-exchange, making the system unsustainable and access to foreign exchange practically impossible. In early September the black-market exchange rate was around BsS90:US$1; the official rate stood at BsS61.5:US$1.
Under our current baseline, the introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) in such a context is possible in 2019. The exact nature and implementation of such moves is hard to foresee, but our baseline forecast includes the continuation of some currency controls for the duration of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
We expect the current-account surplus to reach US$12bn in 2018. This figure is buoyed by non-payment of interest on bonded debt (US$5.5bn) and our exclusion of repayments to Chinese lenders-a decision taken to maintain consistency with the World Bank's data on debt, on which our forecasts are based. We expect the government to continue to accumulate arrears into 2019. By 2020, with a new government in power, we expect that-following debt renegotiation-external financing will be restored and imports will begin a recovery. We expect the surge in imports to tip the current account into a deficit of US$1.2bn (or 1.5% of GDP) in 2020. As the government will then be complying with its debt obligations, the restructured debt will actually mean increased outflows in interest payments. This, coupled with the slow recovery of the oil sector and years of unmet import demand, will mean that the current-account deficit will remain high, at over 4% of GDP on average in 2021-22.
However, we expect that the new administration will secure enough financial and investment inflows to provide sufficient financing, stabilising balance-of-payments dynamics. However, there are considerable risks to this rosy outlook. In addition to assuming a pragmatic mixed administration capable of retaining power, it hinges on a substantial assistance package from the IMF, the quick implementation of a successful macroeconomic stabilisation package, the fast resolution of a debt renegotiation process in 2019-20, substantial inflows of financial and real investment into the economy in 2020-22, and a fast recovery in oil output after years of underinvestment and mismanagement.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
BCV: Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics

Full text: Norway--highlights: Political outlook
The September 2017 general election produced a centre-right majority in parliament. The Liberals joined the government in January 2018, but the administration-comprising the Conservatives, the Progress Party (FrP) and the Liberals-remains an unstable minority. The Christian Democrats (KrF) decided to go into opposition. Nevertheless, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects this government to last its full term until 2021, and does not exclude the possibility of the KrF joining the coalition at some point during the 2018-22 forecast period. The current administration will try to push for a right-wing economic agenda while keeping a tight stance on migration. Climate policy will also remain high on the agenda owing to the Liberals' presence in office. Tensions between the often populist FrP and the opposition parties, including the KrF, will remain.
Norway--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
7.94 8.17 14 11 8 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Norway's business environment outlook score rises between the historical and forecast periods, prompting an improvement in both the global and the regional rankings, to 11th and 7th positions respectively. Norway's political environment, macroeconomic backdrop and financing opportunities are expected to remain among the best in the world. The banking system is in good health. Notwithstanding the slump in global energy prices last year, Norway's enormous oil wealth acts as a financial cushion for the economy, contributing to macroeconomic stability. Despite this, the country trails Denmark, Finland and Sweden as a prime business location, held back by limited market opportunities, an excessively regulated labour market, relatively high labour costs and taxes.
Norway--highlights: Economic outlook
  2017 2018 2019 2020 2021 2022
Real GDP growth (%) 2.4 1.6 2.0 1.8 2.0 1.9
Consumer price inflation (av, %) 1.9 2.3 2.2 2.1 2.0 2.0
Budget balance (% of GDP) 4.4 5.4 5.0 4.9 5.1 5.3
Current-account balance (% of GDP) 5.5 7.4 7.0 6.8 7.2 7.2
3-month Treasury rate (av; %) 0.9 1.1 1.4 1.5 1.6 1.8
Exchange rate Nkr:US$ (av) 8.3 8.0 7.9 7.8 7.8 7.5
Annual real GDP growth is forecast to average 1.9% in the forecast period, broadly in line with western Europe. Investment and employment in the offshore sector were significantly affected by the decline in global oil prices from mid-2014, but the economy started to recover in late 2016. As the oil industry has implemented most of the difficult adjustments, petroleum-related capital spending should return to growth in the forecast period; the mainland economy (excluding the offshore sector) is also strengthening. The economic outlook will be closely tied to developments in the global energy market, but the government will continue its efforts towards diversifying the economy. The fiscal and current-account surpluses will remain substantial, albeit lower than historical levels.

Norway's demographic profile is gradually worsening, with the proportion of the population aged over 67 expected to climb to 18% by the end of the forecast period. This is in line with most developed countries, but is a lower share than in many of Norway's European peers. With a working-age share of 65.5% in 2022-higher than in Finland and Sweden-the demographic outlook seems comparatively positive. Norway has attracted migrant workers from eastern Europe-owing to the fact that the country belongs to the European Economic Area (EEA), this is likely to continue. Non-European immigration has also been high, and this is a point of contention for the far-right FrP. The party will continue to push for greater regulation, but we do not expect further tightening of the immigration law.

Market opportunities are constrained by the small size of the population (5.3m in 2017). However, Norwegian households are among the wealthiest in the world, with GDP per head of US$61,372 in 2017 measured in purchasing power parity (PPP) terms. At market exchange rates, GDP per head in US dollar terms has fallen sharply, to US$75,484 in 2017, from around US$100,000 in 2011-14. We forecast that GDP per head at market exchange rates will rise to US$99,530 by 2022.

With labour force participation rates already among the highest in the world, Norway has less scope to increase labour utilisation than most other developed economies. After being relatively subdued since 2007, labour productivity growth has picked up in recent years, and we expect it to remain broadly stable throughout the forecast period. Over our long-term forecast period, which runs until 2050, growth in the capital stock will make the greatest contribution to real GDP growth, which we expect to average 1.7% per year.
