Background: The Labour Party governed almost without interruption in 1935-65 and largely dominated politics until 2001, when a minority coalition comprising the Conservatives, the Christian Democrats (KrF) and the Liberals swept to power. In 2005 Labour returned to office in a centre-left coalition with the Socialist Left Party (SV) and the Centre Party (Sp)-the first majority government for two decades, and the coalition was re-elected in 2009. The September 2013 election led to a regime change, with a minority right-of-centre coalition of the Conservatives and the Progress Party (FrP) taking office. They remained in power after the September 2017 election, but the Liberals decided to join the coalition in January 2018.
Political structure: A general election is held every four years and there is no right of dissolution between elections. Norway uses a modified proportional representation system in which 150 out of the 169 members of the Storting (parliament) are "district mandates" elected by open-list proportional representation. The remaining 19 seats, the "levelling mandates", are distributed only between the parties that get more 4% of the national vote and whose initial count seat (out of 150) is not proportional to their share of the vote. The Storting has only one chamber.
Policy issues: Another centre-right government will try to implement additional business-friendly policies, as well as tax cuts. Near-term efforts will be focused on further reducing the negative spillover effects of the lower oil price on wider economic activity and on strengthening the mainland economy. Spending from Norway's oil fund will remain higher than before 2016, but it will remain comfortably within the country's fiscal guidelines. Despite a cross-party agreement on tackling climate change, tension will persist in the Storting about the balance between industrial development and environmental protection.
Taxation: The gradual phase-in of lower corporation tax has been completed. As of 2018, Norway has a 22% rate, down from 27% in 2015. Oil companies pay an additional flat-rate tax of 50% on income derived from the extraction, processing and transport of oil, but benefit from a 78% tax refund on the costs of exploration of oil and gas. Capital-gains tax was cut from 28% to 27% in 2014. The ordinary rate of value-added tax (VAT) is 25%. The top marginal income tax rate is 54.3% (including employers' social security contributions).
Foreign trade: Oil and gas output and prices greatly affect Norway's trade flows. The petroleum industry contributes around half of total goods export revenue. The trade account registered a surplus of US$8.3bn in 2017, the lowest level since 1999, but is set to rebound from this year and continue to rise gradually thereafter on the back of higher oil prices.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
The 2017 election delivered a win for the centre right, which now controls 88 seats out of 169, compared with 80 held by the centre left. The Labour Party remains the biggest party in parliament (49 seats), followed by the Conservatives (45) and the far-right Progress Party (FrP), with 27. The Liberals decided to join forces with the previous government-the Conservatives and the FrP-and entered the coalition in January 2019, with the aim of influencing environment policy. The ambition of Erna Solberg, the prime minister and leader of the Conservatives, is to lead a coalition involving the four centre-right parties, that is the Christian Democrats (KrF); however, the party opted to go to opposition, although it still leans more towards the right, meaning it will hardly side with the centre-left to topple the current administration, which has had an unstable term so far. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not exclude the KrF joining the government at some point during the 2018-22 forecast period.

Political outlook: Political stability
Norway has a history of coalition governments and cross-party consensus that typically delivers a high level of political stability. The Storting (parliament) cannot be dissolved before completing its full four-year term. The September 2017 election was followed by a period of protracted talks that culminated in the Liberals joining the Conservatives and the Progress Party (FrP) in government in January 2018, in exchange for concessions on environmental policy. The ruling coalition is one of the weakest in years, controlling only 80 seats in the 169-seat parliament-five short of a majority. Nevertheless, we expect it to last its full term, to 2021.
The grand ambition of Erna Solberg, the prime minister and leader of the Conservatives, was a "bourgeois" coalition-involving all four centre-right parties. However, the KrF, which secured eight seats in parliament, decided to break with the centre-right bloc, owing to ideological differences with the FrP on migration and climate policy; the party currently holds the balance of power in the parliament.
The coalition's first few months in office have been plagued by political instability. In March the outspoken immigration critic, Sylvi Listhaug, from the FrP, resigned as justice and immigration minister, after making the statement that the Labour Party prioritised the rights of Islamic terrorists over national security. In mid-August the government suffered another blow with the resignation of Per Sanders from his post as fisheries minister and FrP's deputy leader, after it surfaced he had breached security protocol while travelling. This brought security-which remains a very sensitive issue in Norway following the far-right attacks conducted by an extremist, Anders Breivik, in 2011-back to the top of the political agenda. It is currently perceived that Ms Solberg has failed to improve "preparedness" and secure crucial infrastructure during her (almost) five years in office. Opposition parties have tried to use this to undermine the ruling coalition, and could put forward a no-confidence vote when parliament re-opens in October. Nevertheless, we expect the government to survive the censure motion, since the KrF is unlikely to side with the centre left on this.
Political instability will persist in the short term, especially as the government continues its controversial state reform-which involves the forced merger of some municipalities and counties. Moreover, Ms Listhaug could return to active political life as she is likely to be nominated as FrP's next deputy leader. This could lead to a deterioration in relations between the coalition parties. Despite this, we expect the government to serve a full term, benefiting from a strong economy (on the back of rising global oil prices and a dynamic labour market). Although the KrF has chosen to remain in opposition, it remains mostly aligned with a liberal economic agenda, and is likely to continue to prefer the current centre-right government to a Labour-led one. Support for the party has been declining, to below the 4% parliamentary threshold in the latest opinion polls. The KrF's decision to go into opposition is contested, and the party is divided on the issue (an estimated 22% of members prefer a centre-left government over a centre-right one). Intra-party tensions could rise further, and Knut Arild Hareide may be forced to resign as the party's leader. We do not exclude the possibility of the KrF joining the government at some point during the forecast period.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
Norway will continue to score highly for the effectiveness of its governmental system for policy formulation and implementation. The government delivers high-quality services, and corruption is largely absent from political and business life. However, one flaw of the system can be excessive bureaucracy.
Legislation passes through a committee system in the Storting (parliament); the aim is usually to build a cross-party consensus, and only the most controversial measures lead to a parliamentary vote. One exception concerns EU legislation, which is transposed into Norwegian law through the country's membership of the European Economic Area (EEA). In the past, the Storting often did not examine this legislation, but since 2007 there has been more stringent scrutiny. Norway is unlikely to apply for full EU membership during the forecast period. There are concerns in the FrP about EU immigration but, despite the party's participation in government, we do not expect Norway to hold a referendum on EU immigration (as Switzerland did in February 2014).
Policymaking is mainly centred in the capital, Oslo, but policy is implemented by a well-functioning decentralised governmental system. Norway's two-tier subnational government system is composed of municipalities and counties, which-regardless of their size-have equal rights and responsibilities. Municipal functions include first levels of education, health and social care, and local town planning and infrastructure. County functions comprise regional planning and development, roads and public transport, and upper-secondary education, among others. The Conservative-led government undertook a "municipal reform" (kommunesammenslaing) in 2014, to reduce costs and bureaucracy, as well as to provide better services. Thus, this reform is aimed at merging some of the 428 municipalities to give local governments better economies of scale. In June 2017 the central government formally received parliamentary support to reduce the number of municipalities to 354 and to merge some of the 19 counties by 2020, which will leave Norway with half the current number of counties. The reform will continue to be highly controversial for some voters, and around ten of the new local governments will result from forced mergers of some municipalities. We expect these centralisation efforts to continue in the coming years.
Political outlook: Election watch
The next local elections will be held in 2019, and the next general election will take place in 2021.
Political outlook: International relations
Relations with the EU will remain one of the principal foreign policy issues, particularly in the light of the UK's vote to leave the bloc. As a member of the EEA, Norway has access to the single market (for a fee), but must accept most EU regulations without having any influence over them.
Tensions between the US administration and the EU have risen since early 2018, owing to the sharpening of protectionist rhetoric of Donald Trump, the US president. However, pressure has eased since Jean-Claude Juncker, the president of the European Commission, and Mr Trump agreed to hold talks in late July on eliminating barriers to bilateral trade. We expect the US and the EU to reach a limited trade agreement that reduces trade tariffs in some non-automotive sectors. However, there is a substantial risk that Mr Trump will break off negotiations if he does not consider the potential deal to be sufficiently beneficial to the US.
Norway has imposed sanctions on Russia in response to the conflict in Ukraine and Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea in 2014. We believe that EU, US and Norwegian sanctions are likely to remain in place in the medium term. National security has become a greater priority since Russia's annexation of Crimea and its subsequent increase in military activity along the 196-km border that it shares with Norway. US marines have been stationed in Norway (about 1,500 km from the Russian border) since January 2017 in six-month deployments for cold-weather training and exercises with Norwegian forces, which have been perceived negatively by Russia.

Norway's score in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings rises solidly, from 7.94 in the historical period (2013-17) to 8.17 in the forecast period (2018-22), underpinned by a significant strengthening of underlying macroeconomic and financing conditions, as well as an improved tax environment. This prompts Norway to climb in our global ranking, from 14th to 11th. However, the improvement in the country's business environment only lifts it up by one position, to 7th, in our regional ranking. This leaves Norway's business environment behind those of its Nordic neighbours. Indeed, Denmark, Sweden and Finland take up the top three positions.
In the forecast period there will be significant increases in the scores for macroeconomic environment, taxes and financing. There will be modest improvements in Norway's market opportunities, labour market and technological readiness categories. The only score that we expect to decrease is that for political stability, reflecting the weakness of Norway's current government and recent political uncertainty, which we expect to continue over the forecast period. All other scores will remain stable.
Despite the marginal deterioration in the political landscape, Norway will remain among the world's top business locations, owing to a strong record of pro-business policy orientation, a welcoming attitude to foreign investment, a modest regulatory burden and excellent transport, energy and digital infrastructure. Weaker aspects include the country's high personal tax burden (albeit supporting high-quality public services and social welfare), limited market opportunities, a somewhat rigid labour market and emerging shortages of skilled labour. A moderately less stable political environment poses the risk of a further gradual dilution of government effectiveness.

Business environment outlook: Norway's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: The Norwegian Competition Authority (NCA) maintains investigative vigilance to ensure effective merger control. Efforts in favour of privatisation remain modest.
2020-22: A strategic plan guides the NCA to improve competition in numerous sectors and in the procurement process.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: The government announces offshore oil and gas licencing awards for new acreage in predefined, mature areas. Efforts intensify to source investment from outside of Sweden and from other traditional markets, principally from China.
2020-22: A new national security law starts to have an impact on Norway's attractiveness as a business destination.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Progress is made on a US-EU trade agreement. The risk that the US administration breaks off negotiations, however, is substantial. Focus on Brexit talks and the implications for Norwegian trade.
2020-22: No change in policy towards joining the EU or leaving the European Economic Area (EEA). A reassessment of EEA membership is a more realistic alternative, but remains unlikely. Efforts to promote bilateral trade deals continue.
Taxes
2018-19: The government looks into reducing income tax, now that the corporation tax has been lowered. Generous state subsidies provided to oil and gas companies are reviewed.
2020-22: Greater use of environmental taxes to meet climate-change goals.
Financing
2018-19: New capital requirements for financial institutions are implemented. Tighter credit standards on high-risk oil and gas, real estate, and shipping sectors. Rise in fees and equity capital requirements for commercial borrowers.
2020-22: Norges Bank (the central bank) raises interest rates further to mitigate inflationary pressure as economic growth strengthens. Financial sector regulation further improved. Foreign-exchange access unhindered.
The labour market
2018-19: Reforms introduced to increase workforce supply. The Working Environment Act, tackling flexible contracts, is maintained.
2020-22: Bargaining between social partners is dominated by demands for catch-up wages. Skills shortages remain an issue.
Infrastructure
2018-19: A ten-year transport plan (2018-29) focuses on maintenance, climate change and the introduction of new technologies. More opportunities for public-private partnerships.
2020-22: Investments in new road and rail transport links, and upgrades to existing transport infrastructure. Digital infrastructure upgrades continue.
Technological readiness
2018-19: Bolstering of Norway's cyber-defence strategy, after several cyber-attacks targeting crucial public infrastructure.
2020-22: The Open Artificial Intelligence (AI) lab grows in size and importance, underpinning Norway's AI preparedness.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
8.6 9.2 2 1 2 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The macroeconomic environment has strengthened steadily in the past two years, supported by a recovery in global energy prices, which has had positive spillover effects on the labour market, consumer and business confidence, the public finances and capital spending. Underlying conditions point to a reasonably stable economic outlook, with continued solid public finances, a large current-account surplus, substantial corporate and household savings, and reduced imbalances (the housing market is of concern to policymakers). Domestically, the main risks stem from highly indebted households (in the context of a dynamic housing market and monetary policy tightening) and increasing capacity pressures in the labour market, which could constrain medium-term growth potential. In the long term, however, the main risk will be Norway's lack of economic diversity, with oil and gas (and related activities) still accounting for more than 50% of the country's total exports. An increase in global trade protectionism and a downturn in global stockmarkets represent the biggest near-term external risks.
Structurally, public finances will remain in better shape than in most peer economies, owing to prudent fiscal policy and Norway's huge sovereign wealth fund-which acts as a financial cushion. Although Norway runs a fiscal surplus, its debt level is higher than might be expected, at around 36% of GDP; although this is mainly explained by monetary policy operations conducted by Norges Bank (the central bank). The conduct of monetary policy will remain credible, and the bank will continue operating a free-float currency regime. Interest rates are expected to rise gradually throughout the forecast period against a backdrop of close-to-target inflation and firm real GDP growth. However, the bank will have to balance policy tightening against a potential appreciation in the krone.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
8.3 8.3 13 13 6 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Competition is encouraged, but strongly policed
Norwegian governments of all persuasions tend to be strongly committed to competition, legislating in line with EU law as required by the country's membership of the EEA. The current centre-right government will continue its efforts to defend private-enterprise culture; however, major privatisation attempts will be muted. The power to investigate competition and enforce competition law will remain vested in the Norwegian Competition Authority (NCA), operating independently under the auspices of the Ministry of Trade & Industry, and the Ministry of Fisheries. The NCA is well-staffed (with more than 100 employees; mostly economists and lawyers), making it effective in merger control, the policing of cartels and abuse of market dominance, as well as in the investigation of the impact of government policy on competition. The NCA raids office premises when necessary, and has stepped up its merger control by banning three prospective mergers (a record number) in 2016 in the ferry, forestry and pizza markets. The NCA has taken action against bid rigging, imposed large fines for collusion in the publishing industry and fined Telenor, Norway's largest telecommunications provider, for the abuse of its dominant position. The authority works closely with European regulators on cross-border mergers, and the newly established Competition Appeals Committee will improve the process of legal redress for companies contesting decisions. Another revision to the Competition Act, passed in 2016, harmonises merger control with EU law and allows for Norwegian settlements in cartel cases.
Plans by the right-wing government to privatise some of the state-controlled companies have seen modest to zero progress over the past five years. The Conservatives' attempt partially to privatise Statkraft, a renewable-energy company, was criticised by the opposition. The government did sell the state's remaining stake in SAS, the Scandinavia airline, but this move should not be seen as a privatisation drive by the government. The state's stakes in crucial sectors are still significant, including Equinor (formerly Statoil, 67%), a petroleum company; Telenor (54%), Yara (36%), a fertiliser manufacturer; Norsk Hydro (43.8%), an aluminium producer; and DNB bank (34%). Statkraft, a renewable energy company, and Statskog, a forestry and land-management company, remain fully public.
Under its strategic plan through to 2021, the NCA will aim to improve competition in numerous sectors, including fuel, retailing, health services and waste management, focusing on encouraging the supply of goods and services, and amending regulation. It will attempt to ensure that the procurement process is more cost efficient and less susceptible to abuse, looking intently into the effects of joint bidding, and on preventing firms from colluding.
In view of Norway's unique geography, the impact of local mergers will remain a priority. The NCA will also assess how changes in government policy affect competition between large and small companies, and review how financial penalties, regulation and legal redress can be combined to achieve its aims (for instance, by ensuring competition among taxi services).
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
8.7 8.7 10 11 8 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The new government will continue to promote business-friendly measures
Norway has long had a co-operative stance towards foreign investors, abiding by its obligations as an EEA member, and broadly welcoming foreign capital and know-how, but with some political resistance to takeovers in strategic sectors. The long-term depletion of offshore hydrocarbon reserves and the pressing issues caused by the oil price crash in 2014 have given impetus to government efforts to pursue foreign investment to diversify the economy and complement the crucial offshore energy sector with new sources of wealth. The government is concentrating on attracting investment from China, principally in the seafood industry. However, these efforts have not been as fruitful as expected, leaving the oil and gas sector as the most important for foreign investors for the foreseeable future.
A new national security law was introduced in June 2018, which gives the government power to stop any foreign acquisitions of crucial sectors that may threaten national security. Companies wishing to acquire one-third of any business of vital security interest will be required to notify the relevant ministry. This is in line with an increasingly general trend of political interference in business acquisitions. The new law is likely to lead to an increase in workload for the affected Norwegian businesses in terms of notifications, assessments and dialogue with the authorities. It could also impair the competitiveness of, and reduce the investment risk appetite for, Norwegian companies that will be subject to the new regime.
The government established a dedicated inward-investment agency, "Innovation Norway", in 2004, which was the country's first. The government is focusing on attracting high-tech start-ups through the agency to compete more effectively with its Nordic neighbours. Investment in Norwegian start-ups has increased, facilitated by easier access to capital. The authorities will continue to encourage business formation via increasing funding for research, improving tax incentives and tackling red tape to overcome traditional blocks on the development of non-oil-related business.
Although Swedish investors have historically dominated Norway's inward foreign direct investment (FDI), US investment is reportedly underestimated. The authorities will seek investment from elsewhere in Europe, and increasingly from China and the rest of Asia. "Invest in Norway" is a governmental investment promotion agency. It will focus on attracting investment in non-oil sectors, including the maritime and seafood, renewable energy, medical, biotechnology, and "clean-tech" industries.
The government has released a list of rail services to be put out to tender from December 2018, with foreign companies able to bid against the Norwegian State Railways for routes that will be bundled into two packages.
Foreign investors will continue to be offered new blocks to explore for oil and gas on the Norwegian continental shelf, based on ordinary concession licensing rounds held every two years in frontier areas. In June 2018 the Ministry of Petroleum and Energy offered 12 new production licences to 11 companies in the 24th licensing round. The number of applicant companies fell to 11, from 26 in the previous round, which created some concern regarding interest in the Norwegian shelf. Nine of the licenses are focused on the Barents Sea and three in the Norwegian Sea. A ban on exploring for oil off the Lofoten, Senja and Vesteralen islands will continue on environmental grounds.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
9.1 9.1 12 19 7 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Norway favours free-trade policies and a lack of foreign-exchange controls
As Norway is a net energy exporter, with only a small domestic market and limited manufacturing capabilities, Norwegian governments of all persuasions adopt broadly pro-free-trade policies, despite the long-standing reluctance to join the EU and the protectionism afforded to home-produced agriculture. Except in extremis, foreign investors in Norway are guaranteed the absence of foreign-exchange controls, with an independent central bank overseeing a free-floating krone. Profits and dividends earned in all areas of the economy, including oil and gas, may be repatriated without obstruction, with no restrictions on capital inflows or outflows. Through Norway's membership of the EEA, Norwegian and foreign-owned companies in Norway gain full access to the single market. EU access guarantees the free movement of persons, goods, services and capital between Norway and EU member states. Norway adopts around three-quarters of all single-market legislation, with the notable exceptions being laws that govern agriculture and fisheries. Norway will continue to work in favour of free trade, harmonising its duties and tariffs structure in line with World Trade Organisation (WTO) and EU agreements, and giving high priority to making new EEA rules applicable in Norway. This will allow it to maintain its excellent record of transposing EU rules into national law. Free trade outside the EU will be promoted mainly through the European Free-Trade Association (EFTA) by negotiating free-trade agreements (FTAs). There are currently 27 FTAs covering 38 countries. Norway has preferential trade arrangements with a growing number of countries outside of the EU, and has revived trade talks with China concerning energy sector co-operation and opening up the Chinese market for farmed salmon, as relations have thawed since 2017. Norway has followed the EU's lead in placing sanctions on Russia since mid-2014, leading to countervailing moves from Russia to block EU (including Norwegian) food imports and other items.
Norway may reassess its EEA membership
Norway is not a member of the EU and will not consider joining over the forecast period, as an increasing number of parties opposes membership. In addition to the well-known position of the Socialist Left Party (SV) and the Centre Party (Sp), the Progress Party (FrP) has also made public its opposition to EU membership. Given insufficient political and public support, the Conservatives have set aside plans for another referendum on membership (the last one was held in 1994 and membership was rejected). A more realistic, but still unlikely, scenario is a reassessment of EEA membership.
The protectionist rhetoric and "America First" stance of the US administration have translated into the imposition of targeted measures (in March 2018 the US announced plans to impose import tariffs on steel and aluminium imports). However, tensions between the US and the EU have eased since, and the two factions agreed to hold talks on eliminating barriers to bilateral trade. We expect the US and the EU to reach a limited trade agreement that reduces trade tariffs in some non-automotive sectors, given the economic importance of this relationship. However, there is a substantial risk that Donald Trump, the US president, will break off negotiations if he does not consider the potential deal to be sufficiently beneficial to the US.
Lobbying will intensify from businesses in northern Norway to withdraw from the EU's trade embargo on Russia, but Norway will remain party to the embargo as long as the EU's relations with Russia remain tense; retaliatory measures by Russia will continue to deprive Norwegian-based firms in the fisheries sector of an important market.
The EU-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) will gradually come into force in 2018-22. It will eliminate most trade tariffs, ease border procedures and increase regulatory co-operation. In December 2017 the EU finalised an economic partnership agreement with Japan, to create the world's largest free-trade area. The deal will come into effect in early 2019, although there will be a lengthy transition phase for most measures over the next decade.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.0 7.2 42 21 12 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Tax reforms will scale back the overall tax burden
The tax system still contains distortions and is considered uncompetitive from an international perspective, which explains why, despite the improvement, Norway scores relatively poorly in this category. The government has undertaken reforms to make the business environment more attractive, and to shift the burden from direct to indirect, and to create more more growth-friendly, taxation.
As part of a multi-year programme of cuts designed to make Norway more tax competitive, the government has reduced the headline rate of corporate income tax from 27% in 2014 to 25% in 2016, and to 24% in 2017. In 2018 a further reduction (to 23%) was introduced. According to the IMF, this will bring Norway's effective tax rates closer to its regional peers. Offshore petroleum companies now pay a higher rate on income, which was raised to 54% in 2017, from 53% previously, with a lower rate of investment-based depreciation, the "rate of uplift", reduced from 5.5% to 5.4%. The tax on economic rent from hydropower production was raised by 1.3 percentage points, to 34.3%. Although the government is not likely to raise taxes further on hydrocarbon extraction, there is a strong possibility that it could review the incentives available for petroleum firms investing in discoveries-currently, the government covers 78% of the costs of searching for oil reserves if the company conducting the discovery does not make a profit.
The ordinary personal income rate has also been reduced, to 23% in 2018. Since 2016 the bracket tax is applied to four income brackets: 0.93% on incomes between Nkr164,100 (US$21,087) and Nkr230,950, 2.41% on incomes between Nkr230,950 and Nkr580,650, 11.52% on incomes between Nkr580,650 and Nkr934,050, and 14.52% on incomes above this threshold. This replaced the surtax system (an additional tax that applied only to the two highest income brackets). A financial activities tax also came into force in 2017.
Under a Conservative-led government, there are likely to be further tax reductions. In the election campaign, Erna Solberg, the prime minister, stated that she would pursue a more moderate reduction than the one implemented in 2013-17, worth Nkr22.4bn (US$2.4bn). Although a "wealth tax" is a long-term goal of the Conservatives, the party has already said that it will not seek to introduce it over the next parliamentary term.
The SkatteFUNN scheme acts as the framework for Norway's support for business innovation and targets enterprises that are at their early stage of development. It is a tax-deduction scheme for companies that are engaged in research and development activities. This fiscal framework is qualification-based and regulated in the statutory framework, and is open to all branches of industry and all types of companies-regardless of size.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
8.5 9.3 3 1 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Norway is strengthening its macroprudential framework
Norway improves its score in the forecast period, as the financial regulatory framework continues to strengthen-keeping its top position in the regional ranking. There are few distortions in the financial system, which is run on sound market principles with adequate supervision. In most cases, banks not only meet, but exceed, Basel III requirements for Tier-1 capital-adequacy ratios, containing the risks stemming from commercial banks' exposure to the mortgage market and high household debt levels. The banking system has remained in a healthy state since the global financial crisis. This is because of lower risk exposures and only limited holdings of high-risk European government securities. Shared counterparty, and foreign-exchange exposure, risks are low, although Norway's banks may be vulnerable because of their exposure to oil and gas, property, and shipbuilding loan portfolios. Foreign companies have access to the same capital sources as domestic companies, but often work through foreign banks, which tend to have offices in Oslo, the capital, and in cities where the oil industry is based, especially Bergen and Stavanger. Access to investment finance is adequate, since tighter rules were established in the wake of the global financial crisis. Companies are able to obtain bank funding (subject to risk limits) and can also access the equity or bond markets, which-owing to the government's strong fiscal position-are more stable than in other countries. Foreign-exchange access will remain unhindered as the authorities maintain a free-float currency outside the euro zone, with no capital controls.
Bank lending will remain the primary source of credit for commercial enterprises. Regulation will be tightened further, but mainly targeted towards higher-risk household and personal mortgage borrowing. New measures were introduced in 2017, such as an interest-rate stress test (a sensitivity test) when assessing the borrower's repayment capacity, a cap on the loan-to-value ratio (at 85% for new homes, and at 60% for second homes) and a loan-to-income requirement. The countercyclical capital buffer requirement increased by 0.5 percentage points in 2018, to 2%. Equity capital requirements and fees for commercial borrowers will rise proportionately, mitigated by healthy competition in the market for company loans.
Bank financing of existing small and medium-sized enterprises, and new start-ups, will remain restricted. However, low-cost financing will continue to be available from other sources, including the debt and equity markets, non-resident banks and, increasingly, venture capital to facilitate the development of high-tech, niche sectors.
Borrowing rates will remain low, but will rise gradually throughout our forecast period. Regulation of the financial sector will be continually improved, which may affect the ability to lend, but non-resident access to the financial system is assured for well-known corporations, and for those with viable business plans and/or solid track records.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
6.1 6.2 34 32 11 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Skills mismatches among immigrants will have to be addressed
Benefiting from its high-quality education system and controlled immigration, Norway's labour market offers high levels of managerial expertise and language skills, as well as one of the highest productivity growth rates in Europe. Central-level bargaining between the government, the Confederation of Norwegian Enterprise (NHO) and the Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions (LO) involves a high degree of co-ordination, with blue-collar manufacturing wages providing the bench-mark for sector-specific and company-level bargaining. On the negative side, there is a large public sector and a scarcity of skills in private industry stemming from low unemployment rates, a lack of labour mobility restricting opportunities for the economic development of remote regions, and a mismatch of education and skills among immigrants and asylum-seekers settling in Norway. High aspirations for wages and entitlements contribute to workforce welfare, but also add to business operating costs. According to the OECD, unit costs remain comparatively high despite the major currency depreciation in 2014. Strike action is a familiar feature of the main and intermediate settlement process in the public sector and among offshore petroleum industry workers seeking higher pay rates and benefits-which contributes to bringing the score on this category down. However, the government reserves the right to enforce arbitration in disputes that are likely to have a major impact on the economy or to be detrimental to public health. Industrial action is possible but is likely to be avoided through arbitration. We do not expect the government to seek to curb trade union power.
Tighter immigration control, an improving labour market, and divergent sectoral trends will contribute to the mismatch of demand and supply of crucial skills. The government is likely to take additional measures to close this gap.
High labour costs remain an important challenge. There has been a shift in businesses in developed countries; they are moving towards the high end of the value chain in order to ensure survival in an increasingly competitive world. However, given Norway's production costs, prices rose to a higher level in the economy. According to the OECD the average wage remains comparatively high-at around EUR50/hour- with Sweden and Denmark registering EUR40/h, and other countries in Europe EUR30/h. The problem has been accentuated in recent years by wage growth outpacing productivity growth.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
8.5 8.5 7 7 6 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Norway's physical transport and digital infrastructure networks are adequate for a well-equipped, modern and advanced industrialised nation, with few of the problems, such as traffic congestion, affecting countries with higher population densities. Good ferry and internal air transport services, including oil-rig helicopter links, help to prevent Norway's diverse topography and weather-related vulnerabilities from creating logistical problems. Rock fall, flooding and landslide risks, alongside the ongoing requirement to increase the connectivity of cities and regions, place constant demands on the public purse to maintain roads, bridges and tunnels, and rail, air and maritime transport systems, as well as public transport links. Norway's digital infrastructure is among the most highly advanced in the world. In recent years, many rapidly expanding start-ups have emerged, enhancing household and business online usage, with almost all basic services available digitally in the present day. Telecommunications coverage and quality is very high. Providers are quick to roll out improvements to the high-speed broadband network.
Infrastructure policy will be steered by a National Transport Plan for 2018-29, which focuses on maintenance of transport infrastructure, pollution reduction and stronger public-private co-operation, as well as the increasing use of intelligent transport systems. The plan's baseline scenario allocates 58% of the total budget of Nkr418.5m (US$45.6m) for road improvements; 32% for railways (which includes new double-track lines for intercity routes, Oslo-Skien and Halden-Lillehammer, and a second light-rail line in Bergen, to Fyllingsdalen, a borough in the south of the city); and another 3% to sea infrastructure that will benefit the fishing and shipping industries.
The main international airport, Gardermoen, has undergone an expansion programme to enable it to cater for 32m passengers per year, and it was officially reopened in 2017. This has delivered an expanded arrivals and departures hall, a new baggage system and a modified, adjoining rail station, at a total cost of Nkr14bn. Bodo Airport in the northern, coastal region is being relocated, releasing prime real estate on the existing site for development.
There are ambitious plans for "floating fixed tunnels" to be constructed under seven fjords by 2035. The government will also invest in new transport-related technologies to improve efficiency and road safety, and to meet environmental targets.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22 2013-17 2018-22
8.6 8.9 15 18 9 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Denmark has one of the highest spending levels on R&D in the EU
This category of our ranking, introduced in 2018, aims to show the extent to which the business environment is open to innovation, digitally connected and prepared for technological disruption. Norway scores decently on a regional and global basis, reflecting the quality of e-commerce business and scope of e-government services; widespread internet usage and a high number of patent registrations. Norway's score for cybersecurity preparedness, R&D spending and quality of research infrastructure are weaker, but still high by regional comparison. Total investment in R&D was 2% of GDP in 2016, slightly below the OECD average of 2.3%, and well below its Nordic neighbours' levels, at 2.9% for Denmark and 3.3% for Sweden. In the European Innovation Scoreboard 2017 the country scores particularly well for lifelong learning, small and medium enterprise's in-house innovation, and sales of new innovations. Weaker aspects include the level of business R&D spending and the quality of tertiary education.
In January 2018 the government contracted Telenor to propose best practice in the implementation of effective cyber-defence strategies, with the aim of protecting critical Information and Communications Technology (ICT) systems. This was done in the context of an increasing number of cyber-attacks on state-run infrastructure, including the public transport company, NSB, military sites and hospitals. Telenor is working closely with the Norwegian Defence Forces (NDF), in particular with its cyber-defence unit, in this area. The company plans to roll out advanced cyber-security tools ahead of NATO's upcoming Trident Juncture 2018 exercises, scheduled for November.
In August 2018 some of Norway's biggest companies announced that they would join forces to establish a national powerhouse for artificial intelligence (AI) to improve the country's quality and capacity for research, education and innovation in the field. The platform's name is the "Open AI Lab", and it is supported by Telenor, the NTNU (Norwegian University of Science and Technology) and SINTEF, a research company. The lab is an expansion of the Telenor-NTNU AI-Lab, created back in 2016. Other partners will be DNB, a financial services company, DNV GL, a registrar and classification company, Equinor, and the Kongsberg Group, a technology firm.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
Norway was strongly affected by the negative global energy price shock in late 2014, which had knock-on effects on the petroleum industry and its suppliers. Investment in the sector fell by an annual average of 11% in 2015-17, unemployment peaked at 5% in mid-2016 and industrial production remains subdued, with output of machinery and equipment registering heavy declines in 2016-17. Norway's need for economic diversification has been brought into sharp relief. In recent years the government's main priority has been to improve the country's competitiveness by trying to bring tax and wage levels closer to those of its peers. A multiparty agreement in 2015, aimed at reducing the headline rate of corporate tax from 27% to 23% in 2018, was gradually implemented, and efforts have been made to reduce bureaucracy and public-sector inefficiencies. The government has identified the aluminium industry, the healthcare sector, fish farming and fisheries, and green technology as potential areas for growth.
Norway's financial system is solid and well capitalised, but high household debt levels will continue to pose risks to medium-term macroeconomic stability. After years of spectacular growth, in February 2018 house prices declined by 2.3% compared with their year-earlier peak. Since then prices have recovered, in line with The Economist Intelligence Unit's view that the market was correcting only temporarily. Tighter credit standards that came into effect in 2017-a cap on the loan/value ratio at 85% (and 60% for second homes in Oslo, the capital)-reined in primary demand and speculation. Nevertheless, with household debt at 230% of disposable income, further price corrections or a potential interest-rate rise, expected in the second half of this year, by Norges Bank (the central bank) could affect macroeconomic stability and weigh on economic activity.

General government debt 35.9 33.8 33.0 33.5 33.1 32.3
Norway's fiscal policy framework is designed to insulate the budget from fluctuations in oil and gas revenue, with the government responsible for transferring the state's net oil revenue to the Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG), currently valued at Nkr8.8tr (US$1.1tr).
After a budget surplus equivalent to 4.4% of GDP in 2017, we expect the surplus to rise in 2018, to 5.4%. Economic growth will remain broadly stable, and although tax cuts will put pressure on the budget, their impact should be offset by a less expansive fiscal policy and a pick-up in global oil prices. The 2018 budget contains a set of growth-friendly measures aimed at improving competitiveness (the base tax rate on both personal and corporate income was lowered to 23%, from 24% and 25% respectively). This implies a lower fiscal impulse (the budget's contribution to economic growth) than the expansive 2016-17 period. As with many previous budgets, the 2018 budget complies with the fiscal rule, which limits the government's withdrawals from the GPFG to 3% of its value. In 2018 withdrawals are set to amount to 2.7%, but this will be the third consecutive year in which they will offset annual net oil revenue.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy

Norges Bank's main policy rate-on sight deposits-has been at a record low of 0.5% since March 2016. At its latest policy meeting, on August 3rd, Norges Bank left its policy rate unchanged. The bank has a broader remit than some of its peers, with a focus on bolstering output, as much as on controlling inflation. In early March its remit was adjusted, reducing the inflation target from 2.5% to 2% and removing exchange-rate stabilisation as an objective. The build-up of financial imbalances will be considered when deciding on policy.
We expect the next policy rate rise to occur in September. Headline inflation has been above its target through most of the year thus far; the mainland economy (excluding the offshore sector) has strengthened significantly and is likely to accelerate this year; and prospects for the petroleum sector are positive. From 2019 onwards we believe that the key rate will increase gradually, to about 2.5% in 2022. Norges Bank's challenge in the medium term will be to gradually tighten monetary policy without triggering a sharp appreciation of the krone.

Norway's economic recovery has gathered steam, with real GDP growth accelerating to 2.4% in 2017 (revised up from 2%), from 0.9% in 2016. The main contributors to growth were private consumption and business investment (supported by buoyant construction activity).
In the medium term real GDP growth should remain broadly stable. Revisions to 2017 data and to statistics for growth in the first quarter of 2018 (down to 0.2%, from 0.6% previously) have led us to revise down our forecast for full-year growth, to 1.6%, from 1.9% previously. The mainland economy is likely to grow at a faster pace. Owing to a strong base in 2017, gross fixed capital formation growth will decelerate significantly, as the 6.4% quarterly contraction in investment in January-March 2018 illustrates (although firm growth throughout the remaining year should offset this). Recent surveys point to an acceleration in capital spending in the oil and gas sector, non-oil related services, retail, and public administration. Private consumption growth will remain firm, as consumer confidence levels are at their highest since the slump in oil prices in late 2014. Wage growth is set to accelerate significantly, and at a faster pace than inflation, on the back of an increasingly tight labour market.
Over our 2018-22 forecast period, private consumption and investment will remain the main drivers of economic advancement-GDP growth will average 1.9% annually in 2019-22. Real wage growth should accelerate from 0.6% this year to 1.2% by 2022 as the unemployment rate continues its downward trend (we expect it to reach 3.6% in 2022, from 4.2% in 2017). Investment will remain firm in response to gradually higher capacity constraints and as new petroleum projects begin.
Risks to our forecast are balanced in both the short and the medium term. Downside risks stem from the trade dispute between the US and China, and the increasingly protectionist rhetoric from Mr Trump, which could affect global trade flows more negatively than we currently expect. In contrast, a more robust pick-up in investment than we are forecasting, and faster wage growth than expected (as a stronger performance in the labour market could prompt revisions to the wage agreements) could lead to stronger domestic demand growth and, in turn, boost real GDP growth.

Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Norway's sectoral split has altered little over the past decade, and significant changes are unlikely during the forecast period. By far the largest sector is services, which accounts for over 64.8% of total output. Industry (including construction) represents 33% of GDP, and the petroleum sector accounts for the majority of this share. Oil and gas extraction (including related services) makes up one-quarter of Norway's gross value added. Agriculture, fishing and forestry account for 2.3% of GDP, although the fisheries sector is large by European standards, and makes an important contribution to the country's food-processing sector. Food and live animals account for 11% of total goods exports.
The most important parts of the services sector in terms of gross value added are business services; wholesale and retail trade; financial intermediation (mostly banking and insurance); property; and shipping, pipeline and other transport activities. Public administration and defence, provision of education, healthcare, and social services account for over one-fifth of total gross value. Our forecast for firm private consumption growth over the forecast period suggests continued growth of the services sector.
Agriculture and manufacturing will become less important to the economy
Norway's agricultural sector is smaller than those of its neighbours, with the arable land area around one-third of that in Denmark, Finland or Sweden. A decline in agricultural holdings has taken place over successive decades, but this has simply resulted in farms becoming far bigger. The importance of agriculture and forestry has decreased in recent years, whereas that of fishing and fish farming has risen. This trend is likely to continue, as the government will continue its efforts to attract more foreign investment and knowledge into the seafood industry.
As a result of the slimming down of formerly large industries-such as beverages and tobacco, textiles and clothing, and wood products-the manufacturing sector has declined in importance since 1970. Over the same period, Norway's oil industry has developed, and the supplier industry has become established. Manufacturing now accounts for just over 7% of gross value added, down from around 10% in 2000, with the pace of the reduction having picked up considerably during the global financial crisis. The two largest categories within manufacturing are the food industry and machinery groups. Machinery has suffered as the impact of the slump in the oil and gas sector since 2014 has filtered down the supply chain, with output contracting on a yearly basis until early 2018. The government would like to move away from its dependence on oil and gas, encouraging investment in high-skilled, high-value areas such as machinery and shipping, but any change is likely to take time. Hindered by Norway's high domestic wages, manufacturing expansion will be slow and, owing to dependence on oil and gas, as a proportion of gross value added it will continue to decline.
Investment in oil will pick up in 2019
The oil and gas sector is a major contributor to the economy, but has been losing importance in recent years, particularly since the oil price slump in 2014. In 2017 the petroleum sector accounted for 14% of GDP (down from a post-crisis peak of 22% in 2011-12), 17% of state revenue (down from 33% in 2012) and 40% of Norway's exports (down from a post-crisis peak of 52% in 2013). Nevertheless, with 85 offshore oilfields in production at end-2017, Norway is the tenth-largest oil exporter and the 15th-largest oil producer globally. It is also the third-largest gas exporter and the sixth-largest gas producer. The proceeds of hydrocarbons production have allowed huge transfers to the sovereign wealth fund, the market value of which totalled Nkr8.6trn (US$1.trn) in September 2018. Growth in discovered resources is ongoing, and the announcement in early 2011 of two new major discoveries-one in the Barents Sea and another in the North Sea-enlivened interest in the oil and gas sector.
According to Statistics Norway total investments in oil and gas activity in 2017, including pipeline transportation, came to Nkr150.95bn (US$17.9bn), which was 8.7% down from the previous year (albeit a much smaller contraction than the 18% decline registered in 2016) acting as a drag on real GDP growth, and negatively affecting employment. The scale back in investment was owing to several factors: many major development projects were finalised, or are close to being finalised; some new projects were postponed owing to uncertainty in the oil industry; and measures were being taken to improve efficiency and reduce operating costs. Investment will continue to decline this year, but we expect it to pick up from 2019 onward. Oil prices have recovered since last year, but will remain broadly flat over the medium term; after averaging US$54.5/barrel in 2017, we forecast that they will reach US$73.5/b this year, and average US$73.6/b in 2018-22.
The long-term trend for oil and gas production is subject to considerable uncertainty. Norway's crude oil output peaked at 3.4m b/d in 2001, according to the International Energy Agency (IEA), and oil production will decline in the short to medium term. This will be partly offset by a rise in output of natural gas. However, the combined production of oil and gas could rise again beyond 2022 if further large discoveries are made.
At end-2017, 85 fields were in production, 66 in the North Sea, 17 in the Norwegian Sea and two in the Barents Sea. Five new fields started producing in 2017, with another nine under development at end-2017. The North Sea is estimated to account for around 51% of the total remaining resources. The remaining reserves in the Norwegian and Barents seas are estimated to have 25% of total remaining resources each. Although these can be no more than estimates based on seismic surveys and experience, substantial investment in these areas is expected to flow from the forthcoming licensing rounds and the smaller annual awards in pre-defined areas. At the same time, the government is under pressure from the petroleum industry to open up the area around the Lofoten islands for exploration, although in view of environmental concerns, the development of petroleum resources is politically controversial. In 2013-17 an agreement to prevent impact assessments taking place in the Lofoten islands was reached by the junior centre-right parties-the Liberals and the Christian Democrats (KrF)-in exchange for external parliamentary support for the right-wing government. This agreement was renewed in early 2018 and will remain in place until the end of the legislature. Both the Liberals and the KrF are aware that the three largest parties in parliament-the Labour Party, the Conservatives and the Progress Party (FrP)-have the majority needed to approve impact assessments in Lofoten.

Consumer price inflation (national measure) decelerated to 1.9% in 2017, from 3.6% in 2016. In January-July annual inflation picked up, as we had anticipated, reaching an average of 2.3%. In the second half of 2018 higher energy prices and firm wage growth should mean that inflation will remain strong. Risks are on the upside, owing to the potential pass-through of the krone's depreciation in the second half of 2017.
Although core inflation is weak, at 1.3% year on year in January-July (well below the 2% target), we expect it to pick up in the coming months. In 2019-22 inflation should remain stable, at an annual average of 2.1%, underpinned by firm wage growth.

The krone has been appreciating marginally against the euro since early 2018, after it depreciated significantly throughout 2017 owing to the economic upswing in the euro zone. We expect the krone to continue to appreciate against the euro throughout the rest of the year, especially in light of higher global oil prices and an expected tightening of Norges Bank's monetary policy.
In 2019-22 the krone will appreciate both vis-à-vis the euro and the dollar. The central bank will keep a tighter accommodative stance than the European Central Bank throughout 2018-22. The US economy is set to lose momentum in 2019, owing to a business cycle slowdown and the bilateral trade war with China, which should make the Federal Reserve (the US central bank) adopt a more cautious tone. Of note is that movements in the krone will remain closely linked to developments in energy prices. However, given that global oil prices are projected to remain broadly stable in the medium term, global monetary policy stances and the economic outlook will weigh more on currency fluctuations.

Norway's current-account surplus rose to 5.5% of GDP in 2017-a reversal from the shrinking trend recorded in 2015 and 2016 (in 2016 the surplus was near a two-decade low). The current account was boosted mainly by a growing goods surplus, driven by rising domestic demand and higher energy prices. The primary income surplus also contributed positively and should remain substantial, underpinned by the growing GPFG. The structure of the current account will remain broadly unchanged in 2018-22.
A further pick-up in oil prices in 2018, to an average price of US$73.5/barrel, from US$54.4/b last year, means that the trade surplus should rise, propelling the current-account surplus upwards, to 7.4% of GDP. In 2019-22 we expect the surplus to average around 7%.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Norway
Stocks and flows
Inward foreign direct investment (FDI) reached US$24.8bn in 2007, before falling sharply during the global financial crisis, to US$8.6bn in 2009. A recovery thereafter saw inward FDI peak at US$26.9bn in 2012, but it has crashed since then, even turning negative in 2016. The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts a gradual pick-up in investment throughout the forecast period (2018-22), although inflows are unlikely to return to their highs prior to the crash in oil prices. At the end of 2017 the stock of inward FDI stood at US$236.5bn, equivalent to about 59% of GDP. Norway's stock of inward FDI per head, at US$44,698 in 2017, was above the average of the EU15, slightly higher than the level seen in Sweden, and significantly higher than in Denmark and Finland.
Origin and distribution
Norway's abundant offshore resources mean that a significant share of inward FDI is directed towards the hydrocarbons sector, as well as towards ancillary services such as oil and gas insurance, and onshore infrastructure. Many of the world's major foreign oil and gas companies are involved in developing the sector, including Chevron, ConocoPhillips, ExxonMobil, Marathon (all US), BP, BG (both UK), Eni (Italy), RWE Dea (Germany) and Engie (France). According to 2016 data from Statistics Norway (latest available), mining and quarrying account for around 28% of inward FDI-owing to the petroleum sector-with the manufacturing sector accounting for a further 14%, much of which relates to the oil and gas sector. Inward FDI has also been important in the financial and business services sector (banks, insurance and property), which accounts for around 12.6% of the total stock. Based on equity capital, the EU member states account for 75% of Norway's total stock of inward FDI, and the US for a further 7%. The most important sources of FDI within the EU are Sweden, the Netherlands, the UK, Denmark and Luxembourg.
Determinants
Offshore investment results from the North Sea awards, a system of government licensing that regulates exploration and petroleum production. The government awards annual licences for the predefined, or mature, areas of the North Sea, Norwegian Sea and Barents Sea. These differ from the numbered licence rounds held every two years concerning new ("frontier") areas, and have been awarded since 2003. The government is keen for petroleum companies to maximise the exploration potential of previously explored areas. Its reluctance to cut the special tax on petroleum exploration is offset by rules introduced in January 2005 that waive any tax on unsuccessful exploration. Norway's rich resource endowment also compensates for factors that would otherwise inhibit FDI, such as the onerous tax burden, uncompetitive wages, small market size, the high cost of living and high property prices. Norway's membership of the European Economic Area (EEA) provides companies established there with the same access to the EU market as those in EU countries. Some exchange-rate risk results from being outside the euro area, with the krone affected by large movements in oil prices and its treatment as a safe-haven currency.
Impact
Foreign investors have made a major contribution to the development of the offshore oil and gas sector, notably by transferring technology and know-how that complements local knowledge and expertise. The "ripple effect" from large discoveries-such as Goliat, Ormen Lange, Skarv and Snohvit-has provided new business opportunities for local companies, created an internationally competitive supplier industry and led to the development of Norway's pioneering subsea technology, which extends the life of existing platforms and facilitates development into new deep-sea areas. Given the high taxation on offshore petroleum production, foreign investors also contribute to Norway's sizeable budget surplus and its sovereign wealth fund, the Government Pension Fund Global, which acts as a "nest egg" for future public spending. However, the impact on employment has been relatively limited, as only about 1% of the labour force is involved in offshore activities. Much FDI outside sectors related to the oil and gas industry is through purchases of existing companies rather than the setting up of new companies or facilities. Slow progress on selling government stakes in a number of part publicly owned companies may dampen FDI flows.
Potential
Despite Norway's highly educated and well-trained workforce, and the recent reduction in overall taxation, the country's attraction outside the offshore oil and gas sector will remain limited for foreign investors because of high labour costs. The government attaches priority to the economic development of the High North of Norway, the areas adjacent to the Arctic, offering a number of incentives for businesses, including reduced employer contributions and grants. The main opportunities for foreign investors are in the development of offshore oil and gas resources, and of windpower-the government refers to the region as "Europe's new energy province"-although it also hopes to attract investment into the maritime, seafood, green information technology and healthcare sectors.

Norway's demographics will remain relatively favourable until 2022
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects population growth to decelerate in the coming years, although future immigration levels are subject to considerable uncertainty, and will have an effect on the pace of change. Norway's total population is currently at 5.3m. Population growth exceeded 1% per year in 2007-14, but has since slipped back, to around the 0.85% mark in 2015-17. Immigration growth reached a peak in 2008, up by 11.4% from the previous year, largely explained by the 2004 and 2008 EU enlargements. Since then, immigrant flows have remained considerable, but growth decelerated in 2016-17 as tight immigration policies and border controls were put in place following the 2015 refugee crisis. According to Statistics Norway, as at January 1st 2017 the annual increase in the number of immigrants, and Norwegians born to immigrant parents, had slowed to 35,544, (compared with increases of 43,244 in 2016 and 45,778 in 2015). Last year a total of 58,200 people immigrated to Norway, 8,600 fewer than in 2017. The two groups accounted for 16.8% of the total population, up from 16.3% a year earlier.
In 2016 Syrian immigrants registered the highest growth owing to the refugee crisis. However, Polish immigrants remain the largest group within Norway's immigrant population, at 97,200. The second largest group is Lithuanians (37,600), followed by Swedes (36,300) and Somalis (28,700). During the forecast period (2018-22) population growth is expected to average 0.9%, slightly below the increase of 1% in the historical period. A forecast birth rate of around 12 per 1,000 is fairly high by European standards, but a fertility rate of 1.62 children per woman in 2017 (down from 1.71 in 2016) is below the replacement rate for developed countries, of around 2.1. The fertility rate has been falling since 2009 (when it was 1.98), and with life expectancy continuing to increase, the potential impact on Norway's demographic profile will be an ever-increasing political concern in future decades. We expect a sharp slowdown in the growth of the working-age population, from 0.9% per year in 2012-16 to just 0.6% in 2018-22.
Despite these trends, in the short to medium term Norway's demographic profile is comparatively favourable. In 2017 the share of the population below the age of 15, at 17.8%, was one of the largest in Europe (compared with 14.6% for the EU28). In the short term this should support growth in demand for consumer goods, services and housing. In the longer term the relatively large youth population will help to mitigate the economic impact of population ageing. The share of the population over 67 (the official retirement age) is low by European standards, but is set to increase steadily. Similar to most other developed countries, Norway will face long-term problems caused by the ageing of its population, but these will only really take effect after 2022. Nonetheless, demographic developments have been a major concern for policymakers, and were partly responsible for the creation of the country's sovereign wealth fund (the Government Pension Fund Global) in 1990.
The impact of weakening demographics is exacerbated by a propensity among some workers to take early retirement or to retire on disability benefits. These factors have compounded serious labour shortages in sectors such as healthcare and other public services. Measures to counter these trends are an important part of a programme of fundamental reform of the pension system, the phasing in of which began in January 2011 and will be fully in place by 2025.
Stronger urbanisation trends will demand a response by policymakers
Norway has one of the lowest population densities in western Europe. With a mainland area of 323,758 sq km, the average population density in 2016 (latest available data) was 14 people per sq km, according to the World Bank. However, the population is unevenly distributed, with 50% concentrated in the south-east (in and around Oslo, the capital). In contrast, population levels in the far northern districts, such as Finnmark, are extremely low. The majority of the Norwegian population (80.8%) lives in urban areas, and the increasing urbanisation of the population has been a persistent concern for policymakers in recent years, as the more remote areas have been losing their younger inhabitants to the urban south, despite large transfer payments from richer to poorer areas. Many young people attending university in the south fail to return to their home towns after graduation, and people in vocational training have tended to move to the urbanised south-east, where most skilled jobs are found. These trends are likely to persist in the forecast period and beyond.

Norwegian consumers' purchasing power offsets limited market opportunities
With a population of just over 5m, Norway's economy is relatively small in terms of total GDP, and market opportunities are limited compared with most other OECD countries. Norwegian households enjoy one of the highest levels of GDP per head in the world, but the krone's sharp depreciation since 2014 meant that, in US dollar terms, GDP per head at market exchange rates fell from close to US$100,000 in 2011-14 to US$72,401 in 2015-16. This figure started to recover in 2017, to US$75,484, and should gradually pick up during the forecast period (2018-22), as The Economist Intelligence Unit expects some krone appreciation. Even in terms of purchasing power parity (PPP), GDP per head is high, at US$61,372 in 2017, making Norway one of the richest countries in western Europe. Moreover, income distribution in Norway is generally even, reflecting high levels of public welfare provision, generous redistributive policies and narrow wage differentials. The OECD gives Norway a Gini coefficient of 25.7% in 2014, the fifth lowest among the OECD countries (a Gini coefficient of zero represents perfect income equality and 100 displays total income inequality). With manual and lower-skilled workers enjoying comparatively high incomes, consumption is spread evenly across the population.
Norway's consumer market is on a par with those of other Nordic countries. Looking at overall (mainland and offshore) GDP, private consumption accounts for a similar share of economic activity in Norway (around 45%) as in Sweden or Denmark. If the importance of Norway's petroleum sector is excluded, private consumption accounted for about 53% of mainland GDP in 2017. Norway experienced a consumer boom in 2004-07, when real private consumption expanded by an average of 5.1% per year, which compares with 2.6% in 2010-16. Growth rates are likely to slow slightly in the forecast period, to an average of around 2% in 2018-22. Nevertheless, consumer spending will remain an important contributor to real GDP growth until 2022, although investment will take the lead. Low unemployment, and low interest rates and inflation, will all help the Norwegian economy as it continues to outpace its European peers. By 2022 GDP per head is forecast to reach US$99,530 at market exchange rates and US$69,160 at PPP.

Living standards will remain among the highest in the world
Norway is a mature economy, and consumers are widely equipped with most household hardware, such as white goods, television sets, home entertainment equipment and personal computers. Mature market growth will be driven by the need to replace durables, but also by technological innovation. The non-food retail market is relatively open to competition, with many small, medium-sized and niche players. Most consumer goods are imported. Few local companies are involved in consumer goods manufacturing, and only a small number of multinational companies has local manufacturing facilities, owing to Norway's high labour costs in this sector. From an employer's perspective, high wages are one of the least attractive features of the Norwegian economy; only Switzerland's workers are paid more, according to estimates. Owing to topographical and climate factors, Norway is a net importer of many agricultural products, especially fruit and vegetables, although a large share of meat is produced domestically. The one exception to this is the seafood sector, in which Norway has established itself as one of the world's largest exporters, especially of farmed fish, such as salmon.
Norwegians tend to spend a higher proportion of their total income on food than people in most other European countries, although we expect that this figure will fall during the forecast period. In part, this will reflect high tariffs and taxes on food products, as well as limited competition within the food retail sector. A higher proportion of spending is directed towards leisure, including hotel stays and restaurants. The standard of living is generally high, with two out of ten households owning more than one car, and a similar proportion owning a second (holiday) home. Among the sociological trends that will have an impact on consumption patterns are a rise in single-person households and the gradual ageing of the population.
