The ageing of the population will become an issue from 2020
Initial conditions: Over the past decade, Norway's economic performance has been strong relative to that of most EU countries. Economic growth has been helped by Norway having a rich endowment of natural resources in its offshore oil and gas reserves. Given that only around 48% of expected petroleum resources have been extracted to date, the country will remain a significant producer and a net exporter of crude oil throughout The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term forecast period, to 2050. However, the pace of oil production from the Norwegian continental shelf is expected to slow more significantly from 2019. Stronger growth can also be attributed to rising labour utilisation, as the number of hours worked has increased and absenteeism has been slightly reduced. Although participation rates are already high, one long-term challenge for the government will be to reverse the trend among older workers to take early retirement. To this effect, the pension system is undergoing reform, including by reducing longevity risk through a pension adjustment linked to life expectancy, and will be fully implemented by 2025. Another driver of Norway's economic performance has been productivity growth, in part stemming from greater use of information and communication technology in the production of goods and services. However, the tightness of the labour market could have a dampening effect on productivity growth in the near term, as marginal workers are drawn into the labour market and skills shortages appear in some sectors. Further risk factors are a slower pace of product market reforms in recent years and Norway's comparatively poor record of investing in research and development (R&D), which accounts for about only 2% of GDP, and lifelong learning. Improving the skills and knowledge of the workforce will be vital, given the diminishing opportunities for boosting GDP growth through increased labour utilisation.
Demographic trends: Compared with other OECD countries, Norway's starting position is more favourable in terms of the problems presented by an ageing population. Overall population growth is expected to be maintained for the entire long-term forecast period. Norway's labour force is expected to increase throughout the forecast period, although the rate of growth will decrease from the 2020s. There will be a similar fall-off in the rate of growth of the working-age population, from around 1% in 2000-16 to around 0.5% in 2018-50. As the proportion of those aged 67 or above and the old-age dependency ratio (those 67 and over relative to those aged 15-66) will increase, Norway will have to finance a larger volume of services and transfers to the older age groups relative to its contributions base, unless incentives to remain in the labour force longer are effective (a scenario we consider fairly unlikely, given that participation rates are already among the highest in the world).
Even taking into account the flow of oil revenue, pension liabilities will greatly exceed the expected assets of the entire Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG, the sovereign wealth fund that was created to ensure that future generations would benefit from the country's oil riches). There is concern that current pension reforms do not go far enough in tackling the problems relating to work incentives and the generous scale of public-sector pensions. The government will need to take further action over the coming decade to avoid a sharply rising tax burden from 2022.
External conditions: As a small country that is highly dependent on open markets and free trade, Norway stands to benefit from its European Economic Area (EEA) agreement, which extends the EU's single market to include it. The EU is the world's largest and most integrated regional market, and accounts for the vast majority of Norwegian exports and imports. Set against this, the EU's long-term rate of growth is likely to remain moderate. Another uncertainty over the forecast period concerns Norway's position with respect to the EU. Within the EU, although some progress will be made in further advancing trade in goods and the liberalisation of trade in services, the focus-particularly in the next decade-will be on ensuring that there is no reversal of these policies, and especially on trying to prevent the break-up of the euro zone and on preserving the single market. In this context, the migration crisis in 2015 and the UK's withdrawal from the EU (set to happen in 2019) have the potential to be politically destabilising, and are likely to disrupt the EU's policymaking framework. In a worst-case scenario, a disorderly break-up of the euro zone, combined with the rise of Asian exporters (particularly China), or an extreme policy move by the current US administration could unleash protectionist forces in Europe that could threaten a reversal of the gradual freeing of global trade since the end of the second world war, which would be a serious concern for such a small and open economy.
Norway's efforts to improve market competition have been modest
Institutions and policy trends: Norway has a long democratic history and enjoys stable, democratic and transparent institutions, along with a well-entrenched justice system. Corruption is largely absent from Norwegian political and business life. The prospects for stable growth are enhanced by high levels of benefits and state-funded education, including at tertiary level, which ensures a healthy and well-educated workforce. In the long term, however, the welfare state may not be as well funded as it is currently. Norway favours free enterprise and market competition to a lesser extent than Denmark and Sweden. The state remains a significant player in many sectors, such as telecommunications, banking, energy and the offshore sector, and progress on the government's plan to reduce its stakes in some companies has been slow. Norway also lags behind neighbouring countries in efforts to promote com-petition in major product and labour markets, in part because the country's oil riches provide little incentive for policymakers to enact potentially unpopular structural reforms. Similarly, there is a risk that the existence of the GPFG will mask the need for reforms to the social security system. A pension reform in 2011 improved incentives to work beyond retirement age and cut the link between pension payments and wages; further adjustments are expected in the coming years. However, government projections indicate that the assets of the pension fund will be insufficient to cover the state's liabilities arising from pensions and other demands on the public purse (such as healthcare) in the absence of further reform of both the pension system and the labour market. Measures would have to include further discouragement from taking early retirement or drawing disability benefits. The proportion of the workforce drawing disability benefit in Norway is almost double the average for the OECD. Ensuring the sustainability of Norway's generous welfare state will be an important challenge for future governments.
Long-term growth will depend largely on productivity increases
Long-term performance: As Norway has less scope than most other developed economies for raising its labour force participation rate, its long-term economic prospects will depend on a continued high rate of investment, as well as improvements in productivity, which we expect to rise during the forecast period (at an average rate of 0.5% in 2018-50), having been sluggish for much of the past decade (-0.5% in 2008-17). Long-term economic performance will also depend on how successive governments meet the challenge of structural reform. Given the current large surpluses on the general government budget, it is often easy for policymakers to ignore non-oil budget deficits. A failure to adapt social security and welfare systems to the challenge of population ageing would lead to large fiscal deficits towards the end of the long-term forecast period, which would necessitate a rising tax burden and dampen growth. This would be exacerbated, should oil production decrease markedly, making continued investment in exploration important.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
Norway's emissions mainly result from oil and gas production as well as from chemical processes used in aluminium production. Electricity needs, however, are all met through abundant hydropower. The Government Pension Fund Global, Norway's sovereign wealth fund, will play an increasingly large role in environmental policy. In 2016 two new criteria were established by the fund, making it move away from, firstly, companies with unacceptable greenhouse gas emissions and, secondly, companies for which at least 30% of revenue are derived from, or operations based on, thermal coal.
Norway has also provided several electric vehicle (EV) incentives, which have contributed to it having the highest number of EVs per capita in the world. Incentives come from value-added tax (VAT) and registration-tax exemptions, and a reduction in the annual motor vehicle tax, among others. In fact, Norway uses taxes as the main tool in its efforts to become more environmentally friendly. The OECD, in its latest policy recommendations, put forward what more could be done in terms of taxation on the environment front. The recommendations include reducing red-meat production grants, terminating grants for logging roads and cableways and preferential VAT rate for passenger transport, and increasing the usage of grants to finance environmental technology.
Despite solid efforts by successive governments to bolster environmental policy, a limitation in oil-related activities is unlikely. The oil and gas sector is at the core of the Norwegian economy, and the three biggest parties in parliament do not seem ready to make radical changes to it. Only smaller parties like the Liberals and the Christian Democrats will continue to push for more measures to be taken in that direction. Opening up the Arctic for further oil-drilling will continue to be a sensitive issue, but the impact of the smaller, centrist parties and environmental non-governmental organisations will be modest.
Technological developments
Norway's society has been relatively resilient to globalisation-driven changes, in part thanks to the welfare support provided by the state. At the same time, it has been one of the countries that has paid more attention to the impact of the sharing economy. The government created a committee to assess the sharing economy and taxi-market reform, although the latter will take a long time to progress, as the legal framework is still very unfriendly towards companies like Uber. The levels of research and development intensity as a percentage of value added are relatively low, but this mainly due to Norway's industrial structure (and the size of the extraction sector). Adjusting for that R&D intensity would be marginally above the OECD average.
Technological developments in the oil sector have also been significant over the past decades. The innovation in the petroleum sector had spill over effects in other industries such as maritime and renewable energy. The authorities promote research and technology development, through legislation and direct allocations to the Research Council of Norway. PETROMAKS 2 is a research program that funds a wide range of projects, from basic research at the university and research institute level to innovation projects in the private sector. At the start of 2018, there were around 120 active projects in PETROMASKS 2 portfolio-which has a budget of Nkr270m (US$33m) this year. The DEMO2000 programme is smaller in scale but counted with 70 ongoing projects at the start of the year and a budget of Nkr70m.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2013-17) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2018-22). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2013-17. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2018-22 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2013-17 ranges are then used to derive 2018-22 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2018-22, not to the likely situation in 2022 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2015 or 2020). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The ruling centre-right Cambiemos coalition is under increasing political pressure amid currency pressure and an IMF bailout (the Fund is unpopular in Argentina), but will be hoping to get its policy agenda back on track in time for the presidential election in October 2019, when Mauricio Macri will seek a second term. However, the opposition will increasingly obstruct policy. Cambiemos lacks a congressional majority, meaning that the administration has to negotiate support for its legislative agenda on an ad hoc basis with various factions of Argentina's dominant Partido Justicialista (the Peronist party).
Amid a severe crisis of confidence, the government has doubled down on austerity measures and announced a package of tax increases and spending cuts intended to eliminate the primary fiscal deficit by 2019 and produce a primary fiscal surplus of 1% of GDP in 2020. In combination with recent currency devaluation, which should prompt external sector adjustments, the latest emergency economic package should, in theory, be sufficient to reduce concern over the twin deficits and the inflation problem. It will come at the cost, however, of tipping Argentina into a deeper recession than previously expected, and will be subject to substantial implementation risks amid a strong likelihood of public resistance to ever-deeper austerity.
With public spending set to contract, and high interest rates contributing to much weaker credit demand and availability, The Economist Intelligence Unit's expectation is that GDP will contract in 2018 by 2.2%, with a recovery getting under way in early 2019. Our forecast for recovery in 2019 rests on a number of key assumptions, including a return to normal harvest levels next year; an improvement in sentiment and in conditions for consumers, which will require a sustained decline in inflation; and a positive contribution of net exports to growth, reflecting a combination of import compression and a pick-up in export-related industry in response to much-improved competitiveness.
Argentina's GDP per head remains high by regional comparison. Combined with improved access to credit, moderate rates of economic growth in the medium term will boost purchasing power and create market opportunities. Still-high poverty rates and income inequality will restrict the pool of consumers, but to a lesser extent than in many other countries in the region.

Argentina's global business environment score improves in 2018-22, and the country jumps 12 places in the global ranking. Policy adjustment is under way as the government works to tighten macroeconomic policy, reduce state intervention in the private sector and encourage private investment. But in many areas improvements will take time to materialise.
Country forecast overview: Argentina's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: The administration of Mauricio Macri works to address key weaknesses, including weak competition policy, the heavy burden of red tape and restrictive price controls.
2020-22: Continued work to build faith in legal and regulatory frameworks. State participation in key sectors continues.
Policy toward foreign investment
2018-19: Proactive, welcoming approach to foreign investment. Attempts to resolve outstanding disputes with creditors.
2020-22: Foreign direct investment is welcome. Improvement made in investment dispute settlement and availability of investment-protection schemes.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Continued efforts to improve the workings of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union) and develop closer relations with the Pacific Alliance, comprising Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru.
2020-22: Possibility that new free-trade agreements are signed with the EU and Canada.
Taxes
2018-19: Temporary generalised export taxes implemented to narrow the fiscal gap. Delays to implementation of tax cuts envisaged in 2017 tax reform.
2020-22: Temporary export taxes eliminated in 2021. Only very gradual cuts elsewhere to reduce tax pressure.
Financing
2018-19: Banking penetration remains weak and long-term credit restricted, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises, owing to weak long-term deposit base.
2020-22: Non-bank financing grows, but is constrained by a relatively small pool of institutional investors.
The labour market
2018-19: Tension with unions, owing to inflation. Political and bargaining power of unions remains strong.
2020-22: Limited progress on labour reform. Continued potential for conflicts with unions. Some skills shortages.
Infrastructure
2018-19: The Macri administration continues to improve contract rights and deficient regulatory regimes.
2020-22: Some public and private investment set to improve energy supply and upgrade export infrastructure, but the risk of energy shortages will persist as demand grows.
Technological readiness
2018-19: Quality of e-commerce business environment is good. Upgrade of 4G capabilities.
2020-22: More progress on increasing scope of e-government as part of process to reduce red tape. Increase in research and development spending as percentage of GDP, but still relatively low compared with more developed markets.

Background: Democracy was restored to Argentina in 1983, after 50 years of instability and military regimes. Economic liberalisation in the 1990s drove firm growth, but an inflexible exchange-rate mechanism and failure to deepen structural reform left the economy vulnerable to shocks, contributing to the collapse in 2001 of the centre-left government and a deep economic crisis. An interim government took power until Néstor Kirchner of the Partido Justicialista (the Peronist party) began a term in 2003. He presided over an economic rebound, which enabled his wife, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, to win the presidency in 2007 and secure re-election in 2011. Economic policy mismanagement drove a change of government in 2015, with a centre-right candidate, Mauricio Macri, taking office in December 2015. Mr Macri has struggled to restore macroeconomic stability and sharp policy tightening has been required in 2018 amid currency pressures.
Political structure: A strong presidential system is in theory checked by a bicameral Congress, comprising a 257-member Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) and a 72-member Senate (the upper house), but in practice the presidency dominates. The 23 provinces and the Buenos Aires federal district each has its own government.
Policy issues: Pro-cyclical expansionary policies and the commodity supercycle contributed to GDP growth of an annual average 6.6% in 2005-11. But expansionary policy also produced significant imbalances. Amid currency pressures, the Fernández government resorted to controls and ad hoc interventionism, to the detriment of the business environment. Macroeconomic adjustments to try to reduce economic distortions are taking place under Mr Macri, but the pace of adjustment has been insufficient to prevent severe currency pressure, and in mid-2018 the government was forced to turn to the IMF for a stand-by lending arrangement involving tighter fiscal targets, but this deal failed to restore market confidence, amid large fiscal and external imbalances. In September 2018 the government was forced to announce steep spending cuts and temporary export tax increases.
Taxation: The value-added tax (VAT) rate is 21%, although VAT on some goods and services is charged at 10.5%, and some services are taxed at a higher rate of 27%. Corporate income tax is levied at 35%, and personal income tax at progressive rates between 9% and 35%. Under a tax reform approved at end-2017, the corporate income tax rate was scheduled fall to 30% in 2019 and 25% in 2021, but this schedule of cuts may be pushed back amid fiscal difficulties. A temporary tax on exports of Ps3-4 per dollar of exports is set to last until end-2021. There is a 0.6% tax on financial transactions.
Foreign trade: The current account moved from surplus to deficit in 2010. By 2017 the deficit had widened to 4.9% of GDP.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
Amid a crisis of confidence in the economy, the president, Mauricio Macri, has committed to an austerity programme that will dominate the remainder of his term of office-and determine his chances of winning a second term in the October 2019 presidential election. Although it includes provisions for social safety-net spending to protect the most vulnerable, the package of budget cuts and tax increases, intended to eliminate the large fiscal gap, will deepen the recession and hit the public hard. Voter disillusionment with the government and the results to date of its austerity measures, in place now for almost three years, is rising. In this context, the potential for social unrest, and potentially severe political instability, in the period leading up to the presidential election will be high.
In the short term, the 2019 budget process will be a key test of political stability and governability. The budget is due to be presented to Congress by September 15th, and must be passed by the time Congress goes into its summer recess in December. The government, which is in a minority in both houses of Congress, must negotiate with the opposition to pass its budget; until this year's crisis, the ruling Cambiemos coalition was extremely successful in negotiating support for its legislative agenda by courting moderate centrist members of Argentina's dominant party, the Peronist party. There are signals that some moderate Peronists, including some influential Peronist governors, might continue to support the government's adjustment programme. But, sensing the government's weakness, the left wing of the Peronist party will be in stark opposition, as will powerful unions, and difficult negotiations seem likely.
In this environment, the government's reform agenda will remain on the back burner for the rest of Mr Macri's first term. Following solid progress on tax, pensions and competition reform in 2017, the structural reform agenda came to a standstill in early 2018. For now, on the benign assumption that Mr Macri is successful in steering the economy through difficult waters and secures a second term of office, The Economist Intelligence Unit assumes that later in our forecast period there will be a renewed emphasis on much-needed reforms to increase the flexibility of labour markets, improve the effectiveness of the judiciary, and enhance investor confidence in institutions and contract rights, which will start to lay the groundwork for more solid long-term growth rates. But this is a benign assumption, and the policy outlook would not be as positive under a new government (which would presumably come from the Peronist party).
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
There are large and growing risks to our benign assumption that Mr Macri will win a second term in October 2019. This forecast is underpinned by an assumption that an economic recovery, driven by the export sector and by a recovery in agriculture from drought, will be well under way in a year's time, and that consumers will be starting to feel the beneficial impact in the form of a shift to positive real wages and employment growth. But Mr Macri's position is a difficult one. Reflecting the challenges faced by minority governments in Argentina, no non-Peronist party has been able to complete two consecutive terms in office since the 1920s. The emergence of a strong challenger from the Peronist party is therefore likely (although it is as yet unclear who this will be), and the election will be closely fought. The strongest Peronist challenge seems most likely to come from its moderate, pragmatist wing, given recent corruption allegations engulfing the former president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, and high-ranking officials in her government, who dominate the left-wing populist branch of the party. This may actually work against Mr Macri as, in a probable second-round vote, he would face a stiffer contest from a moderate pragmatist, such as the Salta governor, Juan Manuel Urtubey, than from the populist wing of the party, which retains a loyal base of supporters but also has high rejection rates among the wider population.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Mr Macri has made considerable efforts to mend relations with investors and to seek trade and investment commitments from key international partners during his time in office. Although this has not yet produced major foreign direct investment (FDI) commitments or breakthroughs in trade deals, these efforts will at least bear some fruit in the short term in the form of support for the government's adjustment programme. This was in evidence in early September, when the US president, Donald Trump, issued a statement of support for the Macri administration and its IMF deal. But other foreign policy priorities will take a back seat to emergency adjustment measures. An EU-Mercosur free-trade deal, for example, seems increasingly improbable in the short term. The window of opportunity for a deal is unlikely to open again until after Argentina's presidential election in October 2019 (assuming that the new Brazilian government is also keen to move forward on free trade).
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
Amid a severe crisis of confidence in a context of tougher external conditions for emerging markets (and a resulting souring in investor appetite towards them), the government has doubled down on austerity measures. Adjustment is centred on a package of tax increases and spending cuts intended to eliminate the primary fiscal deficit by 2019 and produce a primary fiscal surplus of 1% of GDP in 2020. In combination with recent currency devaluation, which should prompt external sector adjustments, the latest emergency economic package should in theory be sufficient to reduce concern over the twin deficits and the high inflation problem. It will come at the cost, however, of tipping Argentina into a deeper recession than previously expected, and will be subject to substantial implementation risks amid a strong likelihood of public resistance to ever deeper austerity.
Adjustment will take place under the auspices of an IMF lending deal, which will provide the financial breathing space that the government needs this year and next (after which we currently assume that external financing conditions for Argentina will improve). A US$50bn three-year stand-by arrangement (SBA) was inked in June, but amid a collapse of domestic confidence, triggered by weak economic data in August, the government has gone back to the Fund seeking adjustments to targets and the disbursement schedule in a revised deal; a more frontloaded disbursement of funds is likely.
We expect that programme targets will, on the whole, be met, and will gradually reduce inflation and engender macroeconomic stability over time. The biggest risks to this outlook are political, and reflect the possibility that a loss of confidence in the Macri administration and the economic outlook will feed into further market volatility. This would not only complicate the adjustment process, but also threaten our assumption that Mr Macri will secure a second term, raising questions as to the future direction of economic policy.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
In early September, in an effort to assuage concerns over the government's ability to steer a course towards economic normalisation, Mr Macri announced a series of austerity measures that sounded a death knell for gradualist adjustment. The plan centres on a deep fiscal adjustment, to accompany the ongoing currency and external sector adjustment, split fairly evenly between spending cuts and tax increases. In total, to get to primary fiscal balance in 2019, the government is planning 1.4% of GDP in spending cuts (centred on capital spending and economic subsidies) and 1.3% of GDP in increased revenue from temporary, across-the-board export taxes. The latter will last through 2020 and will be taxed at a rate of Ps4 (around 10 US cents at the current exchange rate) for each dollar of revenue for primary and services exporters, and Ps3 per dollar for other exports.
In our view, the plan introduces realistic measures that are sufficient, in theory, to allow the government to meet its targets, and our forecasts assume a return to balance in line with the government's targets. However, there are substantial risks to our forecasts, as the plan's success will depend to a large extent on restoring domestic confidence, and on the government's commitment and capacity to push through difficult measures such as continued subsidy cuts (which imply higher utilities tariffs for consumers). The government has included provisions in the fiscal programme for increased social safety-net spending for pensioners and recipients of conditional cash transfers, and this could help to secure the programme's political acceptance. Even so, the government will have a tough task ahead of it, particularly in 2019, an election year, and the risk of policy setbacks will be high.
A major factor in the government's new plan for rapid fiscal adjustment is the deterioration of public debt indicators. Reflecting the impact of this year's 50% currency depreciation, we now expect public debt/GDP to rise sharply, from 57% of GDP last year to above 90% of GDP this year, the highest level among Latin America's major economies by some distance. This will serve to dampen investor confidence for an extended period and will necessitate several years of austerity to reverse. However, around half of the public debt is intra-government debt held by the Banco Central de la República Argentina (BCRA, the central bank) and the social security agency. Excluding this debt, the public-sector debt ratio will be closer to 50% in 2018.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
After a hike in the policy rate to 60% at the height of the crisis in late August, monetary policy will be tight throughout the forecast period, although we assume that there will be a steady (but very slow) loosening of extraordinarily tight policy from 2019. Tight monetary policy is having an impact, as is evident in the deceleration of growth in the monetary aggregates (which the central bank has recently begun monitoring more closely as a complement to the policy rate), and we do expect the BCRA to begin to unwind its dramatic rate rise in the next few months. This process will be complicated, however, by weak confidence in the nascent inflation-targeting regime, which means that inflation expectations are not well anchored and pass-through from currency depreciation into consumer prices is high. In this environment, real rates will need to remain high throughout much of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
We have made substantial downward revisions to our forecasts for real GDP for this year and next, on the assumption that sharp currency weakening and fiscal tightening will deepen and lengthen this year's recession. On this basis, we now expect a deep contraction of GDP of 2.2% in 2018, and only very weak growth in 2019 of 0.3% (although in sequential terms, we expect growth to be gathering pace from early 2019).
The available activity data for the second quarter are dire; the monthly economic activity index shows a rapid shift from moderate growth (of 0.6% quarter on quarter) in the first quarter to a steep decline (of 3.9% quarter on quarter). The initial driver of this decline was the severest drought in several decades, but the contraction has become more broad-based amid a collapse of consumer and business confidence and a loss of consumer purchasing power. With public spending set to contract, and high interest rates contributing to much weaker credit demand and availability, our expectation is that GDP will contract in sequential terms for three consecutive quarters, with a recovery getting under way in early 2019.
Our forecast for recovery in 2019 rests on a number of key assumptions, including a return to normal harvest levels next year; an improvement in sentiment and in conditions for consumers, which will require a sustained decline in inflation; and a positive contribution of net exports to growth, reflecting a combination of import compression and a pick-up in export-related industry in response to much-improved competitiveness.
For both 2018 and 2019 there is an unusually high degree of uncertainty attached to our forecasts. There is, on the one hand, a not-insubstantial risk that policy tightening on top of drought could tip Argentina into a deeper, longer recession extending out to 2019. But, on the other hand, activity could rebound slightly more quickly than we currently have pencilled into our forecasts in 2019 if real currency adjustment proves a more rapid than expected spur to export manufacturing activity.
Our forecasts for the second part of the forecast period (2020-22) assume a return to moderate growth of over 3% per year. We recognise that such a prompt turnaround represents a benign forecast that is dependent on a successful economic adjustment that finally addresses the problem of the twin deficits and persistently high inflation. We do believe that this adjustment process is achievable; we also believe that the medium-term prospects for energy, mining, export-oriented industry and agriculture are good. But there are clear risks to these forecasts depending on developments in coming months.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Recent currency movements will feed through into consumer prices, and inflationary pressures will be compounded by the continued need to reduce the fiscal burden of energy subsidies (which implies an increase in utilities tariffs). Our forecasts assume a sharp spike in prices in late 2018 that pushes inflation over 40% by year-end, followed by a period of very gradual disinflation. The latter will, however, be complicated by continued increases in gas and electricity prices, and by unanchored inflation expectations, which will produce substantial exchange-rate pass-through. Even so, assuming that macro-economic policy remains tight under the auspices of the IMF deal, domestic demand remains subdued, and domestic supply strengthens on the back of an improved regulatory environment for agricultural and other producers, we continue to expect gradual disinflation in the medium term.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
The sharp currency slide of late August has left the peso undervalued in real terms. Based on our expectations of a temporary spike in inflation above 40%, and a further modest depreciation of the peso to around Ps42:US$1, the peso will be more than 15% weaker at end-2018 than its long-run (20-year) average in real, trade-weighted terms. This suggests that in the short term the peso does not have much further left to fall, although we expect some moderate, more steady nominal peso depreciation throughout the forecast period to more or less keep pace with inflation trends. Late in the forecast period, on our assumption of a shift to current-account surpluses, a modest recovery in portfolio flows and a rebuilding of reserves, there may be some renewed real appreciation pressures. At present, however, risks are geared towards periods of further weakness in response, for example, to political instability or to evidence that inflation is not subsiding as expected in 2019.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
The dramatic currency adjustment of August has reversed the accumulated peso overvaluation of recent years, and these sharp external competitiveness gains should produce a faster adjustment of the current-account deficit than we had previously been forecasting. We now project that the deficit will more than halve in 2019, to under 2% of GDP, on the back of a moderate expansion of goods and services exports and steep import compression amid recession. Assuming that investment in a more competitive industrial sector continues, and that Argentina becomes less dependent on oil imports in the medium term as energy sector investments start to come on stream, we now project that the current account will shift into surplus late in the forecast period.
Pressure on the foreign reserves will persist in the short term, but reserves coverage will be supported by fresh inflows of funds from the IMF under the SBA. As adjustment in the current account gathers pace, and assuming moderate inflows of FDI averaging 2.5% of GDP in 2018-22 and an eventual, albeit gradual, recovery of portfolio flows, a rebuilding of foreign reserves is likely.

Data sources and definitions
Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and European GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Commodity prices: IFS; non-oil
Oil prices: Brent average import price
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
US effective exchange-rate index: IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
Domestic data
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics Yearbook
US$ GDP: IFS; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at annual average market exchange rate
US$ GDP at PPP: IFS; Economist Intelligence Unit; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at estimated annual average of consumer products' PPP
Population and growth: Celade
Non-financial public-sector (NFPS) balance: excludes privatisation revenue
Prime lending rate: simple average rate charged on local-currency 30-day loans to creditworthy businesses
Deposit rate: average rate weighted by deposit amount on 30- to 59-day time deposits
Inflation: IFS; derived from consumer price index (CPI) for Buenos Aires metropolitan area, 1999=100
Labour costs: hourly wage in industrial sector
Real exchange rate: Economist Intelligence Unit; a real exchange rate of less than 100% indicates that the currency is undervalued vis-à-vis relative prices and vice versa
Balance of payments: IFS
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding with an original maturity in excess of one year, plus arrears and year-end IMF debt outstanding
Total external debt: sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and arrears
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
Celade: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía
IFS: International Financial Statistics
PPP: purchasing power parity; average ratio of prices in Argentina to prices in the US

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The government-comprising Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza, the party of the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras) and the small, right-wing Independent Greeks (AE)-has a two-seat majority in the 300-seat parliament. The government is vulnerable to further defections, and there is a significant risk of an early election (it is not due until October 2019). The centre-right New Democracy (ND) is likely to win the most seats and form a coalition government.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Greece to remain subject to strict policy conditionality over the medium term and until its debt to its international creditors is substantially reduced. Protests over labour market reforms, pension cuts, privatisation, and tax and social security increases are likely to continue as the government strives to meet the ambitious annual primary surplus budget target of 3.5% of GDP until 2022, as agreed with Greece's euro zone creditors.
Greece faces its biggest macroeconomic challenge now that it has exited the bail-out programme and no longer has access to official borrowing at preferential interest rates. How the economy performs during the post-programme transition will determine whether Greece will remain in the euro zone. We assess the risk of it leaving the zone by 2022 at more than 50%, given the difficulties that it will face in attaining rapid growth while meeting large primary surplus targets and restoring competitiveness without a currency devaluation. We expect that public debt will still exceed 170% of GDP in 2022.
Greece does not face short-term financing difficulties, as it will have sufficient funds to cover its debt repayments for almost two years after it exits the bail-out programme this month. However, the challenges posed by the high public debt burden and a poor growth outlook mean that Grexit will remain a significant risk in the medium and long term.
We forecast that annual average inflation will edge down from 1.1% in 2017 to 0.8% in 2018, before accelerating to an annual average of 1.5% in 2019-22, reflecting higher oil prices and a pick-up in domestic demand. These trends will result in widening, but still moderate, current-account deficits in 2018-22.

Greece's score recovers modestly in our 2018-22 forecast period, from a low base. The main areas of improvement are expected in the macroeconomic environment and as a result of efforts to improve policy towards foreign investment, private enterprise and competition, and the labour market.
Country forecast overview: Greece's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: The country's privatisation agency, under new management, gains momentum. Deals start to make progress.
2020-22: Efforts to valorise public property through concession management and long-leasehold development agreements.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: The Investment Incentives Law of 2016 offers more tax relief and fewer subsidies, and focuses predominantly on small firms. Plans to cut down on bureaucracy make little progress.
2020-22: "Fast-track" legislation could become more important if the economy normalises. It will cover "strategic" investments in energy, tourism, transport, communications and health.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Capital controls introduced in June 2015 are eased gradually. The risk of Greece leaving the euro area and reintroducing exchange controls and, possibly, restrictions on trade will remain high after exit from the European Stability Mechanism.
2020-22: There is more than a 50% risk of Greece leaving the euro zone if growth continues to disappoint.
Taxes
2018-19: Extensive efforts to widen the tax base. Government pledges to pursue aggressive tax collection, but implementation is difficult. Indirect taxes increase. Mandatory introduction of electronic point of sale terminals helps.
2020-22: Limited progress in cutting corporate income tax or value-added tax (VAT). Measures to tackle tax evasion stepped up. Independence of the tax authority remains in doubt.
Financing
2018-19: Liquidity tight. Uncertainty constrains lending capacity. Steps to reduce non-performing loans (NPLs) painfully slow, but foreign interest picks up. A moratorium on foreclosures is lifted for the majority of debtors.
2020-22: Lending hampered by need to make provisions for still high NPL portfolios. Greece's main banks sell more of their overseas subsidiaries. Some form of normalcy in sight towards the end of this period.
The labour market
2018-19: Labour market reforms now mostly passed, but implementation is problematic. Unemployment remains high.
2020-22: EU-funded job-creation schemes, particularly for youth, raise employment, but create few productive jobs.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Energy infrastructure comes to the fore as Trans-Adriatic Pipeline (TAP) nears completion. Privatisations pick up pace.
2020-22: Despite technical assistance from the EU, problems with absorption persist.
Technological readiness
2018-19: Greece rolls out high-speed internet, at a slow pace. The private sector adopts electronic payments by law.
2020-22: Significant financial and technical assistance from the EU, but Greece remains a laggard.

Background: After 400 years of Ottoman rule, Greece emerged as a sovereign state in 1830. A devastating civil war followed the retreat of German occupying forces in 1944. A military junta ruled the country from 1967 to 1974, but since then a democracy has been in place. In 1981 Greece joined the European Economic Community, now the EU. It became a member of the economic and monetary union (EMU) in 2001, but its public finances became unsustainable, resulting in a sovereign debt crisis in 2009-10. Greece's public debt has put its continued membership of EMU in question.
Political structure: Greece is a parliamentary republic, with deputies elected for four-year terms. The prime minister and the government hold executive powers. The president is elected by the 300-member parliament for a five-year term. The government requires the support of parliament to hold office. Since the 2010 crisis the traditional party system has broken down. Voters have blamed the parties that ruled Greece after the return of democracy in the mid-1970s-New Democracy (ND) and the Panhellenic Socialist Movement (Pasok)-for causing the crisis, which led to the imposition of painful austerity by the country's external creditors. The result has been political fragmentation and the rise of populist parties such as the left-wing Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), which came to power in 2015, and far-right parties such as the neo-fascist Golden Dawn (XA).
Policy issues: The ND-Pasok government of 2012-14, like its two predecessors, imposed draconian austerity packages. It also enacted fiscal and some structural economic reforms to meet the conditions of two EU-IMF bail-out packages totalling EUR240bn. Implementation proved difficult and ultimately brought down the government. After a seven-month confrontation with Greece's creditors, the Syriza-led government negotiated a new three-year European Stability Mechanism (ESM) programme. In 2012 public debt held by the private sector was restructured. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any further debt write-down. Now that Greece has exited the programme, it is subject to an "enhanced supervision" monitoring regime by its euro zone creditors.
Taxation: The tax rate on corporate profits is 29% and on distributed dividends is 10%. The top marginal personal income tax rate is 45% for income of more than EUR40,000. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at rates of 24%, 13% and 6%.
Foreign trade: In 2017 goods exports (fob) were worth EUR27.9bn (US$31.5bn) and imports (fob) amounted to EUR46.3bn. The current account registered a deficit of EUR1.4bn, equivalent to 0.8% of GDP.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
The coalition government-comprising Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza, the party of the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras) and the small, right-wing nationalist Independent Greeks (AE)-has survived since September 2015, despite having only a slim majority in the 300-seat parliament. Following the defection of two members of the AE, in protest at the agreement on the 27-year Macedonia name dispute, the government's majority has been reduced to just two seats. Mr Tsipras will aim to see through his parliamentary term, which ends in October 2019, but there is a significant risk of a pre-term election.
The government has been badly damaged by the authorities' handling of the emergency caused by wildfires in the Attica region in July, which resulted in the deaths of more than 90 people. The alternate minister for civil protection, Nikos Toskas, resigned soon afterwards, but the electorate will hold the entire government to account for the death toll from the disaster. Coming in the wake of more than 20 deaths caused by flash floods west of Athens, the capital, in November 2017, the wildfires have heightened public anger over the shortcomings of the government and the public administration.
In August 2015 the government tied its acceptance of bail-out reforms under a European Stability Mechanism (ESM, an inter-governmental assistance fund for countries in the euro zone) programme to the objective of receiving debt relief from its official creditors. Three years later, on August 20th, the government exited the programme with minimal debt relief, having lost much popular support along the way. Mr Tsipras aims to revive his party's political fortunes now that Greece has completed the programme, and will be hoping that economic growth will gain momentum over the coming year; however, The Economist Intelligence Unit is sceptical about his chances of doing so.
Tensions within the government coalition will persist, including over the continued implementation of austerity measures and the Macedonia name issue. The AE has said that it will oppose the name agreement when it is brought before parliament, and the senior ruling party, Syriza, may struggle to obtain the required majority.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
Syriza trails in opinion polls behind the centre-right New Democracy (ND), led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis; the gap has been more than 10 percentage points for some time. ND's lead may narrow during the election campaign, as Mr Tsipras is a formidable campaigner and there is little overt enthusiasm for Mr Mitsotakis or his party. However, given widespread popular disaffection with the government, the election-due by October 2019-is ND's to lose. If, as we expect, ND wins the largest share of the vote, it would benefit from the 50-seat bonus rule for the winning party. Even so, it would probably have to secure the support of at least one other party to muster a parliamentary majority.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
On June 12th Mr Tsipras and Zoran Zaev, the prime minister of Macedonia (the official name of which is the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia; the constitutional name is the Republic of Macedonia), announced their agreement to change that country's constitutional name to Severna Makedonija (North Macedonia). The two leaders attended a ceremony on June 17th in the Prespes district of northern Greece, at which their respective foreign ministers, Nikos Kotzias and Nikola Dimitrov, signed an agreement on the change. The breakthrough is only the first step towards a resolution of the name dispute, and-given public opposition in both countries-the agreement may fail to come into effect. Macedonia's parliament has approved the agreement, which will be put to a referendum on September 30th, before being presented in the Greek parliament next year.
Tensions between Greece and Turkey have risen recently. The risk of military confrontation is high, particularly in the Aegean Sea, but both sides will seek to avoid clashes. Points of contention-such as historical territorial disputes in the Aegean and the Greek courts' rejection of Turkey's extradition request for Turkish soldiers who fled to Greece on the night of the July 2016 failed coup in Turkey-have fuelled distrust. Turkey's release in mid-August of two Greek soldiers arrested for alleged espionage in March 2018 while on patrol in the border area of Evros has helped to ease tensions, which were threatening to boil over.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
On August 20th Greece emerged from an eight-year period (2010-18) during which it received a total of EUR274bn in official financial support from European creditors and the IMF (EUR32.1bn from the IMF) and was subject to three economic adjustment programmes. Repaying the country's outstanding public debt, which totalled EUR344bn (about 180% of GDP) at the end of March, means that future Greek governments will be subject to huge policy constraints. Fiscal austerity and policy conditionality will remain in place for the next five years and beyond.
At the June 21st meeting of the Eurogroup, Greece's official creditors agreed to close the final review of the third bail-out programme, paving the way for a disbursement of EUR15bn, which was released on August 6th. Of this, EUR3.3bn will be used to pay down the more expensive IMF debt, and the balance will form part of a buffer for Greece to use while it builds up market access. The total buffer, estimated at EUR24.1bn, should be sufficient to cover almost two years of the country's financing needs. This is more onerous than a precautionary credit line would have been, as Greece will be accruing interest on money that it does not currently need. However, intense political pressure not to invite further policy conditionality led the government to choose the more expensive option.
The Eurogroup meeting agreed to further debt relief for Greece, which was granted a ten-year grace period and a ten-year maturity extension on EUR96bn of its loans (provided by the European Financial Stability Facility). It will also get a reduction in the interest rates (for loans of EUR130.9bn) and a return of profits from the securities market programme and from the Agreement on Net Financial Assets relating to official sector holders of Greek debt-the European Central Bank (ECB) and national central banks of euro area countries-estimated at about EUR5bn.
Greece, in return, has committed to long-term fiscal prudence. It must achieve annual primary budget surpluses of 3.5% of GDP in the 2018-22 forecast period and 2.2% of GDP thereafter, until 2060. It will also be subject to an "enhanced surveillance" regime, which is a more exacting system of post-programme monitoring than those applied to other former bail-out countries. The debt-relief measures will be subject to quarterly reviews of the state of the economy and of the government's adherence to its commitments. As these reviews will be published, transgression by Greece would adversely affect market access.
After a three-year absence Greece has returned to the financial markets three times since July 2017. However, after August it will do so without the backstop of an official credit line. Recent emerging-market turbulence and investor risk aversion highlight the difficulties that Greece could face in the future on the international capital markets. Greece should have sufficient funds to meet its financing needs in the short term, through to early 2020. However, in the medium and long term the political and, arguably, the economic price of meeting high annual primary surplus targets may become unbearable. During the past two years Greece has exceeded its annual primary surplus targets, but at the expense of economic growth, which has been disappointing. Meeting such targets will remain a constraint on growth, alongside other negative factors, such as poor demographics and a weak business environment. Grexit is not a short-term risk, but, given that Greece is highly unlikely to improve competitiveness inside the euro zone or grow its way out of its huge debt burden, it will pose a significant risk in the medium and long term.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
In 2017 the budget surplus was equivalent to 0.8% of GDP and the primary surplus (budget balance minus interest payments) exceeded the bail-out programme target of 1.75% of GDP, coming in at 4% of GDP. We expect a minimal budget deficit in 2018 (0.2% of GDP), but we do not expect Greece to meet its annual primary surplus target of 3.5% of GDP this year, or in 2019-22. We forecast that the deficit will widen gradually during this period, reflecting constraints on revenue collection, a relaxation of spending restraint and only modest economic growth.
The restructuring of government debt to the private sector cut the debt/GDP ratio to 159.4% at end-2012, from 171.9% in 2011. However, large primary surpluses in 2016-17 were insufficient to arrest the growth of gross consolidated government debt, which rose to EUR317.4bn, or 179.1% of GDP, in 2017. Government debt is now almost entirely owed to official creditors. We expect that, without a debt write-down and assuming moderate nominal medium-term GDP growth rates, the public debt/GDP ratio will remain above 170% in 2018-22.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The ECB is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a quantitative easing (QE) programme that ran at EUR60bn per month until the end of 2017 and is running at EUR30bn per month in January-September 2018. The ECB's view of the outlook improved during 2017 and, although economic activity in the euro zone softened in early 2018, the bank is now more upbeat. We expect monthly asset purchases under the QE programme to conclude at the end of 2018. Rising commodity prices and evidence of growing domestic price pressure in some parts of the zone should mean that sufficient inflationary pressures will begin to emerge in 2019-20. We expect the ECB to take steps towards normalising its policy stance, with an increase of 25 basis points in the main refinancing rate, to 0.25% in early 2020, followed by five more rises that will lift the rate to 1.5% by end-2022. An increase in the deposit rate, which currently stands at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019, easing the pressure on banks' lending margins and supporting profitability.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Compared with 2007 levels, real GDP has shrunk by more than a quarter, government consumption by almost a quarter, household consumption by a fifth and gross fixed investment by almost two-thirds. The recovery, which began at the start of 2017, is fragile and vulnerable to domestic and external develop-ments, as shown by a marked slowdown in activity in quarterly terms in the second half of last year. We forecast that real GDP growth will pick up from 1.3% in 2017 to an average of 1.9% per year in 2018-22. The risks to our forecast are balanced. Upside risks include a continued strong tourism perform-ance. Downside risks include the frailty of the banking sector and political instability.
Seasonally and calendar-day-adjusted real GDP expanded by 0.8% quarter on quarter and by 2.3% year on year in January-March. Some high-frequency data-notably for tourism-are showing signs of strength, and sentiment has improved, especially in the services sector. We forecast real GDP growth of 2% in 2018. This remains a disappointing rate of expansion in the context of the slump of the past decade. Moreover, the recent wildfires may damage the tourism sector, and external developments (notably the threat of a global trade war) are a cause for concern. We expect a combination of more and higher taxes, higher social security payments, debt repayments and spending cuts to put pressure on household disposable income. Although we expect a modest acceleration in household spending in 2018-22, this will be from a low base and will be constrained by primary surplus targets of 3.5% of GDP per year, continued high unemployment and insipid lending growth.
A welcome development in 2017 was a sharp acceleration in fixed investment growth, albeit from a low base. We expect the momentum to continue in 2018 and beyond, with fixed investment growth averaging 5% per year in 2018-22. However, underinvestment during the crisis, and the depletion of Greece's capital stock, as well as uncertainty about the country's euro zone membership, are likely to restrict growth potential in the medium term.
Greece's external trade will be constrained by its relatively uncompetitive goods exports. Over the medium term we expect tourism to continue to support services export growth, contributing to annual average growth of exports of goods and services of 5.2% in 2018-22.
Greece will face its biggest macroeconomic challenge now that it no longer has access to official external financing at preferential rates. How the economy performs over the next five years and beyond will determine whether the country will remain in the euro zone. We assess the risk of Greece leaving the zone by 2022 as higher than 50%, given the difficulties that it will face in attaining rapid growth while meeting large primary surplus targets, and in restoring competitiveness without a currency devaluation. Grexit would lead to a sovereign default and a severe recession in the first few years, but the economy would then grow rapidly, assuming a responsible fiscal policy guided by the necessity to achieve a primary surplus. Growth rates under this scenario would be faster than those in our medium-term forecast. We have not incorporated Grexit into our forecast numbers.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
After stagnating in 2016, Greece's seasonally adjusted EU harmonised index of consumer prices rose by 1.1% year on year in 2017, driven by higher global energy prices, notably in the fourth quarter. Inflation dipped sharply at the start of 2018, rising by just 0.3% year on year in the first quarter, before accelerating since then. In the first seven months of the year inflation on the EU harmonised measure rose by an average of 0.5%. Economic growth is picking up, but significant slack remains in the labour market and domestic demand is subdued. Despite rising global commodity prices and increased tourism, we expect annual inflation to edge down this year, to an average of 0.8%. We forecast a pick-up to inflation of 1.5% per year on average in 2019-22 as the pace of growth quickens.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
The euro exchange rate peaked at almost US$1.25:EUR1 at the start of February but had weakened to US$1.16:EUR1 by late May in response to the formation of a populist, Eurosceptic government in Italy, and remained close to that level in June, July and early August. The euro could come under further pressure from political risk in Italy, and also from US monetary tightening. Nonetheless, we expect a broad stabilisation, with an average exchange rate of US$1.20:EUR1 in 2018-21, as the euro is supported by ongoing recovery in the region and receives structural support from a large regional current-account surplus, while the business-cycle downturn in the US will weigh on the dollar in 2020. Thereafter, we expect the euro to appreciate to US$1.24:EUR1 on average in 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
Greece's current-account deficit has narrowed since the start of the crisis. This mainly reflects the compression of imports owing to contracting domestic demand, but is also partly the result of improved competitiveness in the tourism sector. The current-account deficit narrowed to 0.8% of GDP in 2017, from 1.1% of GDP in 2016, according to the Bank of Greece (the central bank). We forecast widening deficits in 2018-22 as import prices rise and import volumes pick up in line with higher domestic demand, but these will be much smaller than the average annual deficit of 7.2% of GDP since Greece joined the euro zone in 2001.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit.
Global data
US and OECD growth: OECD
World trade growth: EIU aggregate
Oil prices: dated Brent
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
Domestic data
GDP growth and components: ELSTAT, National Accounts
Consumer prices: ELSTAT
Earnings index: ELSTAT
Foreign direct investment: IFS
Exchange rates: ECB, Eurostat

Balance of payments: IMF
External trade: ELSTAT
Population: UN population data
Industrial production: OECD, Main Economic Indicators
Abbreviations
ECB: European Central Bank
ELSTAT: Hellenic Statistical Authority
IFS: International Financial Statistics
